title: Seeing the Light
description: For those of you who have considered hoarding incandescent light bulbs before theyre phased out for good in 2014, you might want to hold off on renting that storage space. General Electrics Energy Smart LED bulb goes on sale on Wednesday on the companys Web site. The nine-watt bulb is not only energy-efficient  it produces the same amount of light as a 40-watt incandescent bulb (higher-wattage models are in the works) with 77 percent less power  but is also omnidirectional, unlike earlier generations of LED bulbs, which shed light in one direction only. Its 22,500-hour life span is twice that of a compact fluorescent bulb, and it contains no mercury. GE claims that one bulb will last 22.8 years, and GEs Energy Smart microsite, designed by the New York firm Doyle Partners, makes the point by following a girl from infancy to her wedding day, with the same light illuminating each scene. The bulbs $50 price tag may give sticker shock to all but early adopters. But considering its long life and its incandescent-quality white light  not to mention GEs assertion that if every American household bought just one, wed save almost $400 million in energy costs and prevent five billion pounds of greenhouse gas emissions in one year  the bulb could turn out to be a good investment in more ways than one.

description: Back in 2004, way before the mortgage bust and before Americans thought of banks as four-letter words, Jamie Dimon took charge of JPMorgan Chase & Company. Known as a tough, hands-on manager, Dimon was supposed to avert the sort of foolish risks that tempted so many of his peers. And sure enough, he was different.Instead of reviewing brief summaries of the banks operations, as his predecessor had, Dimon demanded to see the raw data  hundreds of pages detailing J. P. Morgans businesses every month. Instead of simply trusting his traders, Dimon put himself through a tutorial, so that he would understand the complex trades the bank was exposed to. And rather than run its mortgage machine at full throttle for as long as possible, Dimon reined in lending earlier than did others and warned his shareholders of looming trouble.

(Mom, I have a confession  I cut out of high school to see Raiders of the Lost Ark in this theater, he said from the front, and later confided to the Bagger that it wasnt a one-time thing.) Black Swan felt and played big to its hometown crowd, who could be heard shrieking and shuddering at the more macabre moments. The Red Shoes its not.

title: Year of the Couturire
description: With the Chinese buying cars by the tens of thousands every week  big cars, too  and throwing up new buildings, driving in Beijing is no lark. It was an hour before Guo Pei and her husband, Cao Bao Jie, reached the headquarters of Rose Studio, their fashion company, on the citys north side. The October sun was blazing pale when their Mercedes pulled up to a low-rise office complex, its white brick rendered shabby by newer developments. Cao, a stocky, good-looking Taiwanese man who goes by the name Jack, had been kneeling the whole time next to the driver; facing his wife, who sat in the back; and translating from Chinese into English. Now he sort of backed out of the car. Guo Pei, whose career as a fashion designer began when there was no fashion in her country, remained a study in Asian poise and etiquette. In addition to large eyes and delicate features, enhanced by careful makeup, she has a gentleness unmarred by circumstance. These circumstances include wealth and a list of clients in Beijings highest political, media and social circles. But as Jack said proudly, Guo Pei is a very traditional lady  a wonderful wife and daughter and mother who always cares more about her family than the attention she receives.

They then research the basic biology and epidemiology of H.I.V. and AIDS, and develop their own social media campaigns to educate people about the virus and to generate support for H.I.V. and AIDS advocacy.

title: Ginobili: The Spurs Man for All Paces
description: The San Antonio Spurs, in both success and failure, have long been a balancing act. On one end, we have an establishment. Tim Duncan is one of the best to ever lace up, and his style - deliberate, dominant, calculated - is perfectly in line with the philosophy of Coach Gregg Popovich. The two have functioned as the heart of the Spurs for more than a decade, and their track record speaks for itself.

title: Dressing Up | Keegan Singh and Graeme Armour
description: Its Friday night and the workweek might be over, but the night is still young. When it comes down to fashion, we need to all look different, says the stylist Keegan Singh, who shares a Chelsea apartment with the jeweler Eddie Borgo. Singh swaps an oversized Brooks Brothers blazer for a Graeme Armour cropped motorcycle jacket. There are few girls that know how to do that. Singh and the model Harley Viera-Newton playfully sift through the dark, directional and chic spring 2011 collection of Armour, the former Alexander McQueen intern and up-and-coming designer. He has that oomph I want to explore, gushes Singh. Paired with a simple sleeveless Calvin Klein undershirt or a preppy St. James top, my girl is someone with her own taste and thought on dressing, says Armour. Someone like Harley ticks all the boxes and makes it cool in her own way.

description: Oprah Winfreys cable venture denied a report on Wednesday that it was in talks to hire Terry Wood, a television guru who groomed Phil McGraw, Rachael Ray and other stars of syndication.

title: Rangel Asks Supporters to Make a Call on His Behalf
description: With the hour of his reckoning drawing near, Representative Charles B. Rangel on Wednesday morning asked thousands of his supporters to call the Capitol switchboard and ask their congressmen to vote against a measure that would censure him for an assortment of ethical violations.

title: Unsinkable Captain of Spoofs
description: SURELY you cant be serious. That line, said not by Leslie Nielsen but to him (by Robert Hays, the ostensible male lead of Airplane!, the movie in question), might be taken to sum up Mr. Nielsens career, or at least the part of it that people are most likely to remember. Of course Mr. Nielsen could be serious. Im serious! And dont call me Shirley. And thats what was so funny. He had also, up until Airplane!, been a sober and solid character actor, mostly on television, sometimes playing heavies, sometimes figures of bland authority. And if not for Airplane! and the spoofs that followed, he would be recalled now as one of those hey, its that guy guys of an earlier era, lingering in the memory banks of baby boomers and Gen-Xers who watched way too much TV when they were kids.

title: The UnMuseum
description: EVEN if it were just another glimmering new Lower East Side tower full of multimillion-dollar condos, the sleek, eight-story glass tower at 257 Bowery would qualify as a statement building, with its room-size red elevator visible through the buildings corrugated-glass facade and its sensuously undulating balustrade, perched high above the 29-foot-tall ground-floor exhibition space.

description: This time of year means parties. And, for parents of fall athletes, awards banquets. Sometimes those are bonding times for families, but in the context of an already stressful time (a senior who is in the throes of college applications, for instance) and a difficult age (a senior who has lost a parent recently, and seems to be processing her grief by lashing out at her surviving parent) what should be simple and joyful can become a minefield.

description: 4:57 p.m. | Updated The directors of the nations three nuclear laboratories said Wednesday that they were satisfied with the Obama administrations 10-year plan to modernize their facilities, a declaration Democrats hope will clear Republican obstacles to a new arms control treaty with Russia.

description: ON a balmy fall evening in the Mission District of San Francisco, hundreds of people spilled onto Valencia Street, where they chatted happily for a few minutes before pouring back into bookstores, cafes and theaters. It was a giddy, animated crowd, but most of all bookish  a collection of fans and believers, here to listen to the written word.

title: Theater Talkback: Speaking the Same Language
description: Watching the Atlantic Theater Companys exquisite productions of The Collection and A Kind of Alaska, two short plays by Harold Pinter, I almost forgot that the cast was speaking in a foreign language. Technically, of course, Pinter wrote in English. But as is true of most great dramatists, his syntax, locutions, rhythms and silences make up a sui generis grammar. To navigate the treacherous, autonomous nation that is Pinterland requires a thorough command of this exotic tongue.

title: Below Surface, U.S. Has Dim View of Putin and Russia
description: Early in 2009, as recession rippled around the world, the United States Embassy in Moscow sent to Washington a cable summarizing whispers within Russias political class. Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin, the rumors said, often did not show up at his office.

title: Cheshire Appeal Will Point to Twitter
description: NEW HAVEN  There were half a dozen of them typing away in the courtroom rows. Minute by minute, they sent out reports of gruesome testimony via Twitter. In the end, the defense says, there were more than 140,000 Twitter messages about the trial that dealt with rape and children tied to their beds in a house that was set ablaze.

title: Hamas Leader in Gaza Softens on Vote
description: GAZA  The leader of the Hamas government in Gaza, Ismail Haniya, said Wednesday for the first time that any resolution of the Palestinian dispute with Israel should be put to a referendum of all Palestinians around the world, and that if one were held, Hamas would accept the results no matter what they were.

title: Asked & Answered | Matthew Stone
description: The British artist Matthew Stone uses the rather Obama-esque slogan Optimism As Cultural Rebellion to describe his performance and photographic art. For Stone, the proto-manifesto suggests idealistic activism that he would like to inspire through his art. More practically, it has lead the former collaborator with outr designer Gareth Pugh to organize a series of large-scale performances that combine Greco-Roman bacchanalia, Joseph Bueys-inspired performance art and the more ecstatic moments of rave culture. We spoke with him following the November 26 performance of Anatomy of Immaterial Worlds, his first shamanic opera at Londons ICA.

title: No Criminal Charges Against Ensign
description: Justice Department prosecutors have cleared Senator John Ensign of criminal allegations arising from his affair with an ex-aide and his effort to secure lobbying work for the ex-aides husband, the senators lawyers announced Wednesday.

description: Ron Reinfeld and Idit Barak turned their dark and boxy apartment into a bright, loftlike space.

description: The Federal Reserves data dump of more than 21,000 loan documents from the financial crisis provides a vivid reminder of how ugly it can get when the credit markets freeze up. In order to get crucial overnight loans, hundreds of banks had nothing else to give the Fed as collateral except junk-rated loans and bonds  valued at $1.3 trillion.

Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company voted unanimously Wednesday to merge their organizations, forming a combination producing and presenting entity to be called New York Live Arts.

title: The Cheat: Dark Arts
description: This weeks recipe is a raggedy Christmas number out of Venezuela called asado negro. It requires a fat roast of beef that is simmered for a long time in dark caramel, its sweetness tempered by vinegar. The result is sticky and unctuous beneath a cloak of peppers, onions and leeks. It looks mysterious and bold on the plate and at the start of a New York winter can conjure some degree of Latin American humidity and joy.

title: Enforcement Takes On a Softer Side in China
description: CHENGDU, China  Like an urban drill sergeant, Tang Shenbin paced on a city square, sternly inspecting his nervous charges, issuing sotto voce commands with military authority. He wanted the female members of chengguan  Chinas burly enforcers of urban order, feared and despised for their capricious crackdowns and penchant for violence  to convey a certain impression to a clutch of onlookers.

title: Spain Reveals Plan to Reduce Its Giant Debt
description: MADRID  The Spanish prime minister, Jos Luis Rodrguez Zapatero, introduced measures Wednesday intended to distance Spain from Ireland and other ailing European countries.

title: In Ibsen, Discontent and Desires Unspoken
description: Its not surprising that Rosmersholm was one of Freuds favorite plays. Theres so much roiling under its surface  deep desire, silent guilt  that he even used it to illustrate psychoanalytic theory. As presented by the Pearl Theater Company, this Ibsen drama is compelling to watch as its characters grapple with those unvoiced emotions. Yet when their internal struggles turn into external battles, the production sometimes suffers.

title: Carpetbagger: The Gotham Awards
description: Bill Murray, Patricia Clarkson, Anne Hathaway and more turn out for the first movie awards of the season. Melena Ryzik reports (and tries to calm Jesse Eisenberg's nerves.)

title: 36 Hours in Damascus
description: DAMASCUS loves to flaunt its age. It claims to be the worlds oldest inhabited city  replete with biblical and Koranic lore, Roman ruins, ancient Islamic edifices and Ottoman-era palaces. But thats not to say the Syrian capital is stuck in time. Dozens of centuries-old mansions have been reborn as Mideast-chic hotels, and fashionable shops and restaurants have arisen in the ancient lanes of the Old City. Throw in a fledgling generation of bars and clubs, and the age-old metropolis has never looked so fresh.

title: Carpetbagger Video: The Gotham Awards
Some Time at the Races, With Luck and Change
description: When Jaimy Gordon won the National Book Award for fiction last month, she prompted a profligate outburst of metaphors about dark horses. After all, her winning book, Lord of Misrule, is set at a low-stakes, down-at-the-hoofs racetrack. And Lord of Misrule is the name of a shiny black beetle of a horse who arrives in this books last lap, just in time to serve as deus ex machina for a dramatic finale.

title: Searching for Clues in Historys Nooks
description: To call someone a conspiracy theorist is, in truth, to say something insultingly vague, because as we all know conspiracy theorists come in degrees. On the one hand are the elite squad of paranoids who keep 10 years worth of kidney beans in their basements, bite their nails and believe that the North Koreans are lacing our club soda with something dangerously nonnutritive. On the other hand are the languorous crackpots who wonder if codes are embedded in their Home Depot receipts, or if George Washingtons wooden leg hid an alternate Constitution. It is for this group that the series Brad Meltzers Decoded has been conceived.

title: First the Bonbon, Then the Main Course: Camp
description: Contemporary ballet is a murky category; like postmodern, it is much easier to use than identify. But heres one hint: If the dancers are wearing knee socks instead of point shoes, undulating their torsos and lashing their limbs hither and yon in unremarkably virtuosic phrases, chances are theres contemporary ballet afoot.

title: Just a Voice, a Piano and Mahler Lieder
description: Given Mahlers concentration on rich-hued, broad-boned symphonic works, the celebration of the 150th anniversary of his birth this year and the centenary of his death in 2011 are boons mainly to conductors and orchestras, and their audiences. But the Austrian baritone Wolfgang Holzmair was determined to join the party, and he has been touring with a program of Mahler songs that he and his pianist, Russell Ryan, plan to record in January. (Mr. Holzmair was to have made his Metropolitan Opera debut in the current run of Cos Fan Tutte, but withdrew because of illness.)

title: Conspicuously Sparse in Sundance Competition Lineup: Movie Stars
description: LOS ANGELES  The lineup of films competing in the 2011 Sundance Film Festival is heavy on off-the-wall stories, light on war documentaries and  for better or worse  nearly devoid of one of the festivals signature ingredients of late: stars.

description: The National Portrait Gallery in Washington has removed a video from an exhibition and apologized for its contents after the video was criticized by the Catholic League and members of the House of Representatives for being offensive to Christians.

description: If you guessed that Cathleen P. Black spent the day visiting two schools in Queens  Public School 111 in Astoria, and P.S. 78 in Long Island City  give yourself two points.

description: The story of Die Schne Mllerin, Schuberts song cycle about a miller lad suffering in unrequited love, has been interpreted many ways. The talented young tenor Paul Appleby sees the boy as an artist finding his voice.

description: As if in direct response to its overscaled, canon-cementing Abstract Expressionism display, the Museum of Modern Art is also giving us something quirky, speculative, physically light, a show called On Line: Drawing Through the Twentieth Century.

title: Store Review: TSC Signature, in Beirut
description: Food itineraries in far-flung locations tend to feature colorful public markets. But in the newly revived downtown area of Beirut, where slick corridors of high-end, marble-faced shops have replaced the souks that were destroyed in the civil war, there is a dazzling new food hall, TSC Signature, which opened in April.

title: Glimmers of Hope for Small Films During Glittery Oscar Promotions
description: Brooklyn, Brooklyn in the house! Darren Aronofsky shouted from the front of the Ziegfeld Theater on Tuesday night. Mr. Aronofsky, the director and Coney Island native, was living out a childhood fantasy when his film Black Swan had its New York premiere at that Midtown Manhattan movie palace, which he frequented while growing up. Mom, I have a confession: I cut out of high school to see Raiders of the Lost Ark in this theater, he said, later admitting it wasnt a one-time thing.

title: Outcome Uncertain in Ivory Coast Election
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast  Three days after a landmark election meant to bring peace here in West Africas former economic leader, an old fear hung over this tattered ex-boomtown: a president who refuses to give up power.

title: Tech Toys to Keep Your Gift Budget in Balance
description: While the leading candidate for this years most marvelous toy is the iPad, followed by, perhaps, a Microsoft Kinect video game system, both can put a significant dent in your gift budget. Consider that for the price of one iPad, you can buy five $99 BMX bicycles, and that one Kinect game costs the same as 10 classic beaded jump ropes, or about 48 cans of Play-Doh.

title: Kiteboarding in the Dominican Republic
description: FROM shore, David flashed a thumbs up: the signal for me to go ahead. I pulled down on the control bar attached to the harness on my waist, and the 20-foot-wide kite emblazoned with a dragon arced across the sky. Instantly, a jolt was transmitted through the lines that connected the kite to the harness, and I shot across the water.

title: A Single Deal Proves Crucial as a Title Is Defended
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  The Marsha May Sternberg Womens Board-a-Match Teams title was successfully defended on Monday evening here by Joyce Hampton of Blythewood, S.C.; Jenny Wolpert of Jupiter, Fla.; Daniela von Arnim from Germany; Sabine Auken from Denmark; and Bndicte Cronier and Sylvie Willard from France. They finished a quarter of a board ahead of Geeske Joel of Palo Alto, Calif.; Tobi Sokolow of Austin, Tex.; Jill Meyers of Santa Monica, Calif.; Jill Levin of Lake Ariel, Pa.; Debbie Rosenberg of New Rochelle, N.Y.; and Janice Seamon-Molson of Hollywood, Fla.

title: Top 10 Android Apps
description: A few weeks ago, I compiled a list of essential iPhone apps for people who are too busy to sift through the roughly 300,000 titles in the App Store.

title: Viewers Like Christmas
description: NBCs annual special Christmas in Rockefeller Center attracted its most viewers in seven years as 11.3 million tuned in to the tree-lighting ceremony at 8 p.m., according to Nielsens estimates. The show easily outperformed the combination of ABCs holiday specials How the Grinch Stole Christmas (6.9 million) and Shrek the Halls (7.4 million) in the time slot but lagged behind Foxs Glee (11.6 million) and CBSs Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer (12 million), which led at 8. NBC finished in second place for the night over all, averaging 8.3 million for The Biggest Loser from 9 to 11. CBS won the night, earning 15.1 million viewers at 8 for a rerun of NCIS and 9 million at 10 for its annual Victorias Secret Fashion Show. Fox was third with new episodes of its comedies Raising Hope (6.9 million) and Running Wilde (3.4 million) at 9 and 9:30. ABC ranked fourth.

title: In Asheville, N.C., the River Arts District Blooms
description: ON a recent autumn afternoon, a rusty cargo train lumbered past a rundown, three-story brick warehouse in Asheville, N.C., as a pack of dogs chased one another around a dusty dirt lot. Inside the dilapidated building, though, once-grimy rooms are now paint-flecked, clay-crusted artist studios. And on the lower level, a former storage space for slaughtered hogs is now home to the Wedge Brewing Company (125 B Roberts Street; 828-505-2792; wedgebrewing.com), a microbrewery that opened in 2008 with a variety of beers on tap and a sun-splashed patio.

description: BASICS

title: Letters: Looted Art
description: To the Editor: Regarding In Paris, on the Trail of Art Looted by Nazis (Nov. 21): As lawyers who have spent more than 10 years assisting the families of Holocaust victims in recovering Nazi-looted art, we welcome this article.

title: Letters: Cambridge Cemetery
description: To the Editor: In 36 Hours in Cambridge, England (Nov. 21), there was no mention of the Cambridge American Cemetery and Memorial, which is the only American cemetery from World War II in Britain. The graves (including that of my cousin) are of American airmen stationed in Britain who made raids on continental Europe and did not return. The memorial for those unknown include the names of Glenn Miller and Joseph Kennedy Jr. There is a lovely nonsectarian chapel on the grounds as well.

title: Trading Up: Mens Sweaters Borrow From Folk Patterns
description: At the hands of todays designers, the Fair Isle sweater has manned up and trimmed down, newly invigorated with the youthful spirit that brought it fame 85 years ago.

title: The Pedigree, Knitted In
description: ITS too bad that the previous Prince of Wales, the great-uncle of the current titleholder, is known to history for his dubious decisions: namely, spending barely a year as Edward VIII before abdicating the throne, and picking the wrong horse in World War II. Before he became the black sheep of the House of Windsor, the fair-haired Prince of Wales was known for woolens of a different color, his clothes slavishly imitated in the 20s and early 30s. In 1924, Mens Wear magazine put it bluntly: The average young man in America is more interested in the clothes of the Prince of Wales than in the clothes of any other individual on earth.

title: Fill-In | What an A Means
Best Media Apps for the iPad
description: The historical media verticals of radio, television, print and Web evaporate inside the frame of an iPadits all just content, backlighted and inviting, waiting for the swipe of a finger. Long-form narrative and news has found a reliable wing man in the iPad.

title: A Look Thats Worth a Million Hits
description: ON the afternoon of what has come to be known as Cyber Monday, Alissandre Martines, 23, a French Polynesian with high-arched eyebrows, was making a color-blocked scarf by Me & Kashmere look like a must-have.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: Best Camera Gifts
description: Finding just the right gift for the technology lover on your list might take a little research. Bettina Edelstein gets the low-down on this seasons popular camera trends from Rik Fairlie, a frequent contributor on the subject to the Gadgetwise blog and the Personal Tech pages of the New York Times.

title: Will the Big East and T.C.U. Live Happily Ever After?
description: On Monday, the Big East Conference and Texas Christian University entered into a shotgun wedding. Beginning with the 2012 season, T.C.U. will join the conference in all sports, including football, where their team has just completed an undefeated regular season.

title: Candidates for R.N.C. Chair Make Their Pitches
description: Four candidates seeking to lead the Republican National Committee delivered their pitches at an open forum on Wednesday, arguing that the party needs new direction and an aggressive focus on rebuilding a tattered fund-raising network if Republicans hope to mount a credible challenge to President Obama.

title: EBay Shows Where Mobile Shopping Is Hot
description: Using a cellphone to shop on eBay is big in San Francisco, along with most metropolitan areas. But mobile commerce has yet to catch on in the West Texas desert, most of South Dakota and rural Illinois.

title: Letting in the Light in Tel Aviv
description: Tel Aviv

title: Shopping Snapshots for Dec. 2
description: Chanel at Jeffrey New York; fingerless gloves; Mackage opens a store in SoHo; and more.

title: Designers Honor the Endangered Christmas Card
description: The digital age may someday mean the demise of the paper Christmas card. That is one reason Stefan Nilsson, the creative director of Designgalleriet, a gallery in Stockholm, chose to make holiday cards the focus of his year-end exhibition, which runs through Dec. 22.

title: The Air Stool
description: Hector Serrano wanted the Air stool he designed for Gandia Blasco, a Spanish manufacturer, to look good, but not so good that it competed with its surroundings: The idea was to create a stool that was understated and visually light enough to complement any setting, he said.

title: Small Shops, Big Wonders
description: RAYMAN BOOZER is a survivor, a member of that hardy (dare one say quixotic?) tribe known as independent retailers. Sixteen years ago, Mr. Boozer, an Indiana-born interior designer, opened Apartment 48 on West 17th Street. He had worked at Bloomingdales, Saks Fifth Avenue and Conrans and was eager to create his own retail magic.

title: Frazzled Moms Push Back Against Volunteering
description: IT was last spring, somewhere between overseeing Teacher Appreciation Week and planning the fifth-grade graduation party, when Jamie Lentzner, mother of two in Foster City, Calif., reached her breaking point.

title: Furniture, Lighting and Tableware on Sale
description: Frances Palmer is offering 20 percent off White Pearl ceramic tableware online, through Sunday (a scalloped cereal bowl, originally $35, is $28; a fluted vase, regularly $75, is $60); francespalmerpottery.com.

title: Asia Captures Lions Share of Big I.P.O.s
description: HONG KONG  A bank whose customer base is larger than the population of the United States, a French cosmetics maker, a microlender and a Chinese pharmaceutical company that makes an anticoagulant derived from pigs guts: Asian stock exchanges have seen it all this year.

title: House Ethics Committee Suspends Two Lawyers
description: The House ethics committee placed two of its attorneys on paid administrative leave last month for reported problems with their handling of the committees investigation of Representative Maxine Waters, a California Democrat accused of helping steer bailout money to a bank in which her husband owned shares.

title: Konstantin Grcic on Being Designer of the Year at Design Miami
description: Design Miami, the annual design-art fair being held in Miami Beach through Dec. 5, has named the German industrial designer Konstantin Grcic designer of the year. The selection of Mr. Grcic (pronounced GER-chich) was a surprise to many. While previously winners  including Zaha Hadid, Fernando and Humberto Campana, and Maarten Baas  have created sculptural objects that make provocative statements and veer closer to art, Mr. Grcic is known for his rigorous focus on logic, utility and simplicity.

title: More Accolades in the Year of the Saint
description: DREW BREES, the quarterback of the New Orleans Saints, was in New York on Tuesday to be honored as Sports Illustrateds Sportsman of the Year. There was a red-carpet party on his behalf, but he couldnt drink.

title: Cheney Hoping for R.N.C. Shakeup
description: Dick Cheney is sponsoring a shakeup attempt at the Republican National Committee.

title: Some Promising Ideas That Didnt Quite Work
description: Why do some toys become classics and others fade before their first set of batteries? Heres a closer look at some of the more highly marketed toys that didnt work, according to my testers, along with some alternatives that did. Barbie Video Girl Doll (Mattel, $45 at Toys R Us, ages 3 and up) seems like clever idea  put a video camera inside a doll  until you try to find the tiny Phillips screwdriver needed to fit the AAA batteries into Barbies legs. Your child soon will discover that Barbie has no speakers, so all the videos are silent until the doll is tethered to the computer.

title: Chvez Opens His Palace to Flood Victims

title: A Star-Filled Party for One Heavy Movie

Mr. Bardems character lives on the margins in a world that rarely has time for pleasure and seems encircled by death. He won a best actor prize at the Cannes Film Festival for his performance in the movie, which opens on Dec. 29.

title: At Art Basel Miami Beach, Less Heat

Gone too are the speculators who before the financial crisis used to race down the aisles as soon as the doors opened in order to snag a work that they thought they could flip at a profit a few months later. Indeed, on Wednesday during First Choice things seemed sedate compared to the years before 2008. Some described the giant convention hall as empty.

title: Attention-Grabber for Sudans Cause
description: I do human rights the way I played basketball, John Prendergast said. We were sitting in the outdoor restaurant of an unfinished hotel in Juba, a boomtown of mud and shanties beside the White Nile in southern Sudan. Its a restaurant where the Souths liberation leaders tend to gather, and these days they are in a buoyant mood. They have traded their fatigues for dress shirts and suits. A half-century of civil war seems to be culminating in independence. If a referendum on Jan. 9 goes as expected, the map of Africa will be redrawn  with a new nation around the size of Texas. But for the moment, Prendergast, who is Americas most influential activist in Africas most troubled regions and who huddled on a White House patio with President Barack Obama a few days earlier, talked about basketball guards.

title: In Malaysia, Tourists Are Lured by George Towns Colorful Past

For as long as anyone can remember, the eastern end of Stewart Lane, which runs behind the temple, has been marred by the blackened shells of seven historic terrace houses. Several years ago a suspicious fire left the houses roofless. But inside, allusions to a grand past remained: skeletons of timber staircases, bits of terra-cotta tile, indigo patches of lime wash on walls rising 25 feet.

God, for Mr. Bardem, is Al Pacino, who made a surprise visit to the celeb-stocked party, after his performance in The Merchant of Venice on Broadway. Mr. Pacino, his hair in a messy little ponytail, chatted with Mr. Bardem, who eagerly introduced him to Penlope Cruz, his very pregnant wife. Mr. Pacino promptly touched her belly. Played by Natalie Portman in a smashing, bruising, wholly committed performance, the young dancer, Nina, looks more like a child than a woman, her flesh as undernourished as her mind. When she goes to bed at night, a nearby jewelry box tinkling Swan Lake, a crowd of stuffed animals watches over her, longtime companions that  as Nina and this dementedly entertaining film grow more unhinged  begin to look more like jailers than friends.

title: In Good Company
description: Christopher Crawford and Jayzel Samonte started Company of We a little over a year ago from their downtown Manhattan apartment. Launched initially as an online-only boutique, the boys, 30 and 28 respectively, watched as their playful toggle coats and double-breasted captains jackets gained a virtual following, only to be later snatched up by the likes of Saks Fifth Avenue. This month, the designers opened up a pop-up shop in the West Village, where they are manning the registers, meeting their customers face to face for the first time. It breathes life into our digital roots, Crawford said of the earthy, masculine space. The shop also serves as a platform to introduce the Company of Wes womens capsule collection, featuring easy, ladylike confections like an elongated dinner jacket with metallic detailing and a pastel pleated skirt. The couples first foray into womens wear channels both the interior designer Kelly Wearstler (She was a Playboy Playmate, has impeccable taste and is now filthy rich, says Samonte) as well as friend and fashion journalist, Meenal Mistry, (Stylish, slightly mysterious, intelligent and aspirational, says Crawford). And as for sharing a life as well as a business? The New Yorker and Bravos Real Housewives can be the perfect high-low distraction, Samonte says with a laugh.

description: After an eight-year dispute the Court of Appeals in Paris has ordered the estate of Aim Maeght, the Paris dealer who represented the sculptor Alexander Calder during his lifetime, to return seven sculptures to the artists estate.

title: Keeping Score: Who Is the N.B.A.s Best Point Guard?
description: Justin Kubatko is the creator of Basketball-Reference.com, an online basketball encyclopedia. He is also a statistical consultant for the Trail Blazers.

title: Week 13 in Fantasy Football: Matchups and Q. & A.
description: The brothers Sablich are here to help with fantasy football analysis for Week 13. They also answered reader questions earlier in the week. Read their answers below and follow them on Twitter for more advice leading up to game time on Sunday.

title: Art Basel Miami Beach | Ruba Katrib
description: Ruba Katrib has been organizing some of the freshest and smartest museum shows anywhere  in Miami. As the associate curator at the Museum of Contemporary Art (MOCA) in North Miami, Katrib  a West Virginia native with a masters degree from Bard Colleges renowned Center for Curatorial Studies  has been responsible for recent surveys of Cory Arcangel and Claire Fontaine, and sprawling, international concept shows like last years The Reach of Realism. The Moment caught up with the creative force who helps to keep the city on the map all those other 51 weeks of the year.

title: Cables Offer Shifting Portrait of Karzai
description: WASHINGTON  Omans foreign minister says that he is losing confidence in him. A British diplomat says Britain feels deep frustration with him, while an Australian official complains that he ignores reality. A diplomat from the United Arab Emirates says Afghanistan would be better off without him. NATOs secretary general speculates that he has a split personality.

title: Cables Depict Afghan Graft, Starting at Top
description: This article is by Scott Shane, Mark Mazzetti and Dexter Filkins.

title: Co-op in the Platt-Designed Studio Building Is for Sale
description: IN 1904, when Charles A. Platt was commissioned to design an artists co-op studio building on 66th Street and Lexington Avenue, he was known as the countrys foremost architect of country houses, all heavily influenced by the style of the Italian Renaissance. The 11-story building was not only Mr. Platts first large-scale urban commission; it would also become his New York City home.

title: Contributors
Congress Approves Child Nutrition Bill
description: WASHINGTON  Congress gave final approval on Thursday to a child nutrition bill that expands the school lunch program and sets new standards to improve the quality of school meals, with more fruits and vegetables.

title: Night of Tributes and Performance, Too
description: Alvin Ailey died 21 years ago, on Dec. 1, the very date that his namesake company opened its annual season at City Center this year. He would surely have been astounded and delighted to see the by-now ritualized Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater opening night: the red carpet, the photographers, the stars, the speeches, the money.

title: Creating Primal Wilderness With Lunges and Antlers
description: Among the many marvelous aspects of the Chocolate Factory is the way in which this most specific of theaters is utterly transformed by each new occupant. Something about the rough little industrial space makes imaginations grow big. (I suspect that its an artist-run organization has something to do with it.)

title: Pictures of the Day: Israel and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Israel, Ivory Coast and Qatar.

title: GERBEN MULDER: Flowers
description: Newman Popiashvili

title: In Streaming, Options Grow
description: STREAMING movies on household TV offers vast amounts of appeal. Its why hardware manufacturers are devoting so much energy to the proposition.

title: LUC TUYMANS: Corporate
description: David Zwirner

title: Smart TVs Expand On-Demand World
description: TIVO started the modern home entertainment revolution with DVR technology, allowing consumers to watch the shows they wanted, when they wanted. Appointment television  shows worth building a schedule around  was obliterated.

title: Obama Seeking Aid for Jobless in Deal on Tax Cuts
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is holding out for an extension of unemployment assistance and of a variety of expiring tax breaks for low-wage and middle-income workers as part of a deal with Congressional Republicans to extend all the Bush-era tax cuts.

title: A Real Threat Now Faces the Nintendo Wii
description: THE question can now be asked: Does it make sense to buy a Nintendo Wii anymore?

title: Fun by the Barrel (Wine, Too)
description: BEADS of sweat covered Lorraine Nedells forehead as she bent over a cluster of merlot grapes one sunny fall morning at Sanninos Bella Vita Vineyard in Peconic, N.Y., on Long Island. Inching along the row of vines, she grabbed the purple berries, snipped them with a clipper and dropped them, over and over, into a plastic bin.

title: Survival Proves Popular
description: Survivor: Nicaragua topped the ratings on Wednesday night as 12.2 million viewers tuned in to that CBS reality show, according to Nielsens estimates. That put the program easily ahead of its 8 p.m. rivals, including NBCs Undercovers (4.8 million), Foxs Human Target (5.8 million) and the season finale of CWs Americas Next Top Model (3.4 million). CBS led the night over all despite a meager audience for its live 10 p.m. Grammy nominations concert special (5.1 million). NBC was second, earning solid results for Law & Order: SVU (9.2 million) and Law & Order: Los Angeles (9.1 million) at 9 and 10. Fox was third and ABC was fourth.

title: Honey, Lets Get a Little Divorced
description: MY husband and I recently celebrated a milestone. It was the day wed been married for 13 years, 2 months and about a week: the day our marriage outlasted my parents marriage.

title: T Exclusive Video | Julian Assange
description: Ts forthcoming Holiday issue includes a feature on Julian Assange, the controversial founder of WikiLeaks. In this exclusive behind-the-scenes video, filmed during the last week of September, our features and entertainment director Jacob Brown and the photographer Max Vadukul track the elusive Assange to London.

title: Taking Square Aim at Critics, E.P.A. Marks Its 40th
description: In the summer of 1970, President Richard M. Nixon consolidated the anti-pollution enforcement powers of 15 federal departments into a single new entity, the Environmental Protection Agency. Were going after the polluters, William D. Ruckelshaus, the agencys first director, said after his nomination to the post. All of them.

title: AMERICANANA
description: The Bertha and Karl Leubsdorf Art Gallery

title: Pictures of the Day: Israel and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Israel, Ivory Coast and Qatar.

title: Bachmann Had Last-Minute Spending Deluge
description: Its no secret that Michele Bachmann, the two-term Republican Congresswoman from Minnesota, is a prolific fund-raiser and a bullish mama grizzly to boot.

title: Dance Listings for Dec. 3-9
description: Dance

title: Celebrating New Music, Just Off the Beaten Path
description: Calling your new-music festival Darmstadt Essential Repertoire is a conscious provocation on multiple levels, as the New York composers Zach Layton and Nick Hallett surely realized when they chose the name. It alludes to the Darmstadt International Summer Courses for New Music, a venerable and formidable German laboratory for avant-garde innovation, known for dogmatic (and sometimes rancorous) adherence to modernist severity.

title: MARGRIT LEWCZUK: Art Work
description: 85 Metropolitan Avenue, near Wythe Avenue

title: CLAIRE PENTECOST: Interior Studies
description: Higher Pictures

title: Inhabiting a Six-Legged Nightmare: What Becomes a Monster Most?
description: Maybe its just a ripple effect of the Spider-Man obsession gripping Broadway, but Gisli Orn Gardarssons astonishingly athletic interpretation of the traveling salesman who awakes one morning transformed into a bug in Metamorphosis seems more arachnid than insect.

title: Youth and Perseverance Get Nods From Grammys
description: These days the Grammy Awards have a special fondness for two things: youth and a good comeback.

title: Q & A
description: An Accident in a Co-op Lobby

title: Retail Without a Safety Net
description: When Nina Garduno opened Free City Supershop in 2005, in a strip mall in Malibu, Calif., it was hard to describe the place. It wasnt a boutique, exactly, though she sold clothes and jewelry. It wasnt a concept store, though it offered a genuine sense of discovery rare in the world of retail. And you hesitated to lump it with the deadly term lifestyle, though she sold refurbished bicycles, custom turntables and teepees.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings for Dec. 3-9
description: Classical

title: Adding Green Space to MoMA With Tropical Terrariums
description: The Museum of Modern Art lobby  that awkward space designed by the Japanese architect Yoshio Taniguchi  spans a city block, making it as much a thoroughfare as a museum entrance. People flood the place throughout the day, ducking in from the cold, avoiding street traffic or simply using it as a meeting spot.

title: Social Network Nabs Seasons First Big Award
description: The Social Network was a big hit with the National Board of Review, which on Thursday awarded it several top prizes, including best feature, best director (David Fincher), best actor (Jesse Eisenberg) and best adapted screenplay (Aaron Sorkin). The groups president, Annie Schulhof, lauded the truthy drama for being a timeless story that will appeal to many generations, especially if or when Facebook takes over the world.

title: Gene Kaufman
description: Mr. Kaufman, 51, is the founder of Gene Kaufman Architect, a New York firm that specializes in hotels and multifamily housing.

title: A Tax Credit Set to Expire Soon
description: If youre in the market for certain energy-efficient home improvements, you may want to act quickly.

title: Back When Theater Was Simply Unrolled
description: Victorian theatergoers packed halls to watch canvases roll past. Entrepreneurs would ship paintings of exotic scenery hundreds of feet long to theaters nationwide, and stagehands, as if anticipating animated movies, would slowly reveal section after section of the moving panoramas. Pianists supplied uplifting music, and actors voice-overs explained the plot.

title: BlackBerry Aims for a Better Look
description: Research In Motion, which gave us the BlackBerry, was once considered the leader in mobile phone technology, creating mobile devices that changed the business world and rapidly propelled the adoption of instant communication.

title: Canal Street, Is That Really You?
description: IF ever a street seemed to embody the cacophony of New York City, Canal Street would be it. Tourists throng Canals sidewalks in search of bargains on copycat designer goods; commuters surge in and out of a maze of subway stops; and in the evening cars and trucks jostle to enter the Holland Tunnel amid a sea of brake lights and a jangle of horns.

title: Pop and Rock Listings for Dec. 3-9
description: Pop

title: Showcasing Romanian Film
description: A look at some of the selections from the Fifth Romanian Film Festival in NYC.

title: British Tell How Rescue by G.I.s Broke Down
description: LONDON  The British government revealed details on Thursday of a harrowing attempt by American Special Forces troops to mount a nighttime rescue of a British aid worker kidnapped by the Taliban in the highlands of eastern Afghanistan, and of the womans death when an American soldier threw a hand grenade into a gully where she was being held.

title: Jazz Listings for Dec. 3-9
description: Jazz

title: Maybe a Dinosaur, Just Not Purple
description: Barney Panofsky, a Montreal policemans son, meets his third wife at his second wedding, a gilded gala that he stumbles into halfway between his wayward bohemian youth and his distempered dotage. Barney, played with shambling energy and vulgar elegance by Paul Giamatti, catches a sudden, breathtaking glimpse of Miriam (Rosamund Pike) and pretty much forgets about the unnamed ninny he has just married (even though she is played by the lovely Minnie Driver).

title: Last Supper for the Laptop Generation
description: IF you had tied on a blindfold, suspended disbelief and allowed yourself to be carried last week to a particular location just off Park Avenue near 66th Street, your reopened eyes would have had trouble telling that they were not inside the Santa Maria delle Grazie monastery in Milan, looking at a sight everyone knows and few have actually seen: a magisterial painting of 13 enrobed men seated oddly on one side of a long dinner table.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Dec. 3-9
description: Art

title: Baucus to Vote Against Debt Plan
description: Senator Max Baucus said on Thursday that he will vote against the debt-reduction plan before President Obamas bipartisan commission when it votes on Friday, dealing a blow to the effort given his role as chairman of the Senate committee that would deal with the sort of tax changes and spending cuts the plan proposes.

title: A Spitfire Onstage, Singing of Young Love and Achy Hearts
description: A little over two years ago Lykke Li played a show at Le Poisson Rouge to celebrate the release of her debut album, Youth Novels. Wednesday night she was back on the circular stage there, introducing songs from her coming second album, Wounded Rhymes. Certain things hadnt changed.

title: Pellegrini Reflects on His Decision to Leave
description: Paolo Pellegrini, best known for helping the hedge fund manager John A. Paulson earn billions in a bet against subprime mortgages, has a lot of time to think about the market these days.

title: A Pianist Explores the Smoother Side of an Often-Aggressive Sound
description: It was not so long ago that when the Russian piano style was mentioned, what came to mind was a huge, steely, aggressive sound with a dynamic range that ran from fortissimo to quadruple fortissimo. Things are different now. Power remains a hallmark of Russian pianism, but young players like Olga Kern and Kirill Gerstein have made gracefulness, precision and subtlety parts of the equation too.

title: Cracking Open a Holiday Classic
description: STROLL down Fifth Avenue this month, or along an aisle at Target, or through any other shopping establishment for that matter, and you will inevitably hear Tchaikovskys Nutcracker. The music is so ingrained in the Christmas routine that it can be hard to hear it amid the holiday hubbub. But that is what Mark Morris wants audiences to do with his creation, The Hard Nut.

title: Weekend Miser
description: The 19th annual Double Dutch Holiday Classic is a competition that goes beyond anything you saw as a kid at your neighborhood playground. On Sunday students from around the world compete for spots on national and international double dutch teams, using, well, themselves and jump ropes, along with music, dance and gymnastics. The festivities begin at 1 p.m. at the Apollo Theater. Tickets can be bought online at Ticketmaster.com, by phone at (800) 745-3000, or at the Apollo box office. (253 West 125th Street, Harlem; 212-531-5305; apollotheater.org; $20-$22.)

title: A Deal on the Tax Dispute? Not So Fast
description: The White House may be compromising with Republicans on the Bush-era tax cuts, but it moved on Thursday to dispel reports that a deal (read: capitulation) is at hand.

title: Getting Small: A Mans World, in Miniature
description: If Charles LeDray does not have little, nimble-fingered elves working in platoons around the clock under his direction, then I dont know how he does it. His magical retrospective workworkworkworkwork  consisting mainly of thousands of miniature pieces of clothing, tiny ceramic vessels and dollhouse-scale furniture at the Whitney Museum of American Art  is dumbfounding. That one man could have singlehandedly created all these things defies credibility. (The exhibition was organized by Randi Hopkins, an associate curator at the Institute of Contemporary Art, Boston, where it first appeared this year.)

title: Discounts Abound for Popular Hybrid Cameras
description: FOR several years, camera makers have trained their engineering expertise on the sweet spot between compact point-and-shoot cameras and chunky (yet capable) D.S.L.R.s. An ideal combination would involve a small chassis, a big image sensor, the ability to swap out interchangeable lenses and snap-simple ease of use.

title: Movies Listings for Dec. 3-9
description: Movies

title: Ghost Town Where the Koreas Clashed
description: YEONPYEONG ISLAND, South Korea  Besides the military forces on the hill, Yeonpyeong Island has only about 1,400 residents in normal times. When North Korea shelled the village on Nov. 23, nearly every civilian was evacuated or fled to the mainland.

title: The Flesh and Blood Behind the AK-47
description: It is no accident that C. J. Chivers opens The Gun, his bold history of the AK-47, not with the loud crack that is the report of the rifle but with the monstrous bang of the first detonation of a Soviet nuclear bomb. As Mr. Chiverss detailed history then skirts as far back as the United States Civil War and brings us right up to the current conflict in Afghanistan, the message of his prologue is clear: For all that the escalating cold war shaped the last 60 years, no one was ever killed in conflict by a Russian nuke. By contrast untold millions have been wounded and killed by the AK-47 and related weapons, as they have proliferated and mutated from tools of engineering ingenuity, honestly wrought in defense of the socialist motherland, to the firearm of choice for both oppressor and oppressed.

title: Digital Devices Can Become Objects of Affection
description: I GAVE up my Palm Treo smartphone last year for an iPhone. It had been my companion for nearly five years, a long time for a cellphone. At the end people laughed at it, and by extension, at me. But I liked the feel of the thing. I liked what it, one of the first smartphones, could do.

title: Assorted Acts of Betrayal Among the Moneyed and Dysfunctional
description: There are various bad things in All Good Things, principally a dictatorial father, a submissive son and the tragic fates of the two unfortunate women who married them. These bad things are part of a strange case named David Marks, a fictional character based on Robert A. Durst, the true-life son of a New York real estate developer, Seymour Durst. Among the weirder bad things: in 1982 the younger Mr. Dursts wife, Kathie, disappeared. In 2000 his friend Susan Berman was murdered. (Both cases remain open.) A year later, while living as a mute woman in Texas, he killed (and chopped up) a neighbor in self-defense. Well, the jury called it self-defense before sending him to jail. The film takes a somewhat different view.

title: Gift Choices for Lovers of the Next Big Thing
description: TO be any kind of enthusiast, techies included, requires a modicum of snobbery. So if you are pondering a gift for your gadget lover, it had better be the Next Big Thing, otherwise you risk (at best) tepid thanks before your costly gizmo goes to the back of a drawer.

title: Country Dancing in the Big City
description: THE sound of fiddles and foot stomping may be the last thing you expect to hear at the Chinatown Y.M.C.A. Nevertheless, every weekend Country Dance New York turns the basketball courts into a country dance hall, filled with jigs, reels and plenty of swinging your partner.

title: Clinton Moves to Ease Tensions on Kyrgyz Base
description: BISHKEK, Kyrgyzstan  Hoping to defuse the latest round of tensions over a strategically important American air base, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton said Thursday that the United States would steer part of a lucrative Pentagon jet fuel contract to a newly created Kyrgyz state-owned corporation.

title: House Votes to Censure Rangel
description: The House of Representatives voted to censure Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of New York, for a host of ethics violations. Read City Rooms live blog of the proceedings.

title: A TV That Sounds Great Right Out of the Box
description: MOST solutions to mediocre television sound involve external devices like sound bars and surround-sound systems. Bose, maker of speakers, headphones and other audio equipment, took another approach: a TV that sounds good to begin with.

title: Kicking Back in a Temple to the Ring
description: Vinny Maddalone bombards the patrons at his Whitestone, Queens, bar with the classic tristate barrage of strung-together questions that await no reply: Hows-it-goin-hows-everything-everything-good? But dont look for him on Thursday. Hell be throwing different one-two punches at a heavyweight boxing match in the Prudential Center in Newark.

title: A Flash Flood in Paradise
description: Monday, Nov. 29

title: Gloves Suitable for Touch Screens
description: WITH technological innovation comes unexpected challenges. Consider, as freezing weather approaches, the touch-screen device.

title: Time Inc. Names No. 2 Editor, Signaling Possible Succession Plan
description: Time Inc. has revived its long-vacant No. 2 editorial position in a major management reorganization that centralizes a far-flung media empire stretching from Menlo Park, Calif., to Birmingham, Ala.

title: Rangel Censured Over Violations of Ethics Rules
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Charles B. Rangel, his gaze steady and his hands clasped before him, stood silently in the well of the House of Representatives on Thursday as Speaker Nancy Pelosi somberly read a resolution censuring him for bringing discredit to the House.

title: Shopping for a Smartphone, With a Focus on Features
description: WHEN shopping for a smartphone, it is common to be drawn to the coolest design. But a phone is basically a collection of features wrapped in a case. Too often that case is a distraction from what is more important: whether the phone has the right features for its prospective user and how well those features work.

title: Obama Promises to Work With Governors on Education, Economy
description: President Obama hosted a luncheon on Thursday for newly elected governors across the street from the White House at Blair House, where he promised to work closely with them to fix the economy and improve education over the next two years.

title: Spare Times for Dec. 3-9
description: Around Town

title: Boxes and Bars for Better TV Sound
description: THE sound bar, a single box that can replace a set of surround-sound speakers, can be a great gift idea for anyone who wants better sound out of a television but does not have the space or budget to set up a full-blown home theater.

title: Spare Times: For Children for Dec. 3-9
description: LULA BELL IN SEARCH

title: Design Miami | Q&A With Aranda\Lasch
description: Whether its designing the Design Miami exhibition tent (in 2008, 2009, and 2010), showing their work at the Johnson Trading Gallery booth, or conceiving the fairs floor plan (2010), Ben Aranda and Chris Lasch of the New York architecture firm Aranda\Lasch have been a consistent presence at the fair. This year, they added another arrow to their quiver: a Fendi-sponsored booth that showcases Modern Primitives, a collection of objects that are the product of the firms research into developing crystalline shapes into building systems. Despite the name, the concept behind their latest venture is anything but primitive, including references to the revolutionary 17th-century mathematician Johannes Kepler and a special app the duo devised to generate different formations. But the end results are beautiful sculptural pieces that fulfill both a function (in this case, mostly seating) and offer the possibility of being developed into a full-fledged architectural system. The Moment sat down with Ben and Chris to discuss the process behind the project, and how the storied Roman luxury house became part of the equation.

title: Where Alcoholism Drinks in the Laughs
description: Television has a drinking problem.

title: A Big Box for an Overlooked R&B Career
description: FOUR years ago Syl Johnson, a Chicago soul singer beloved by R&B purists but otherwise not well known today, was approached by the Numero Group, a small record label that wanted to reissue some of his music from the 1960s and 70s. Mr. Johnson said bluntly that he was not interested.

title: Lots of Wine, but None to Drink
description: San Francisco

title: House Tour: Saugerties, N.Y.
description: WHAT Two-bedroom house.

title: As Biodiversity Declines, Disease Flourishes
description: A study by a group of biologists, ecologists and medical researchers casts new light on a phenomenon farmers have known for years: the less the genetic variety in a crop or a herd, the greater the risk that disease will decimate it. The presence of many species in ecosystems, the scientists report in Thursdays issue of the journal Nature, damps a pathogens ability to spread among humans.

title: Guilt, Anxiety, Obstacles: Adultery Is Hard Work
description: Except during its three heated sex scenes, Come Undone, a sober exploration of the disruptive effects of adultery on family life, portrays infidelity, despite its thrills, as almost more trouble than its worth. At the same time those sex scenes (nude but not anatomically explicit) show the power of unleashed passion to make the rest of life feel like a laborious, frustrating slog. Directed by Silvio Soldini from a screenplay he wrote with Doriana Leondeff and Angelo Carbone, this movie is set in and around Milan, which is filmed without a smidgen of glamour.

title: Excerpt: 'The Sing-Off'
description: The NBC singing competition returns for another season.

title: Vengeful? Combative? Theres a Game for You
description: In 2010, makers served up a bounty of engrossing choices for adults who enjoy violent, intense video games.

title: 'Metamorphosis'
description: Photos from the show at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Napolitano Backs Immigration Bill
description: The secretary of homeland security, Janet Napolitano, called on Congress to pass a bill granting legal status to many thousands of illegal immigrant students, saying it would help immigration authorities focus their resources on deporting dangerous criminals.

title: Canada: Pigeon King Arrested in Alleged Squab Scam
description: THE AMERICAS

title: Amid the Ailing and Uninsured, Hospital Chaplain Finds New Faith
description: Standing in a hallway at Stroger Hospital on Wednesday morning, Dr. Stathis Poulakidas began a weekly status report on the mostly horrific cases in the burn unit he runs.

title: A Winning Smile Makes the Scamming a Breeze
description: Jim Carreys portrayal of Steven Russell, a notorious real-life con man now serving a 144-year sentence in a Texas prison, hot-wires I Love You Phillip Morris, a nervy comedy that bills itself as an improbable but true story.

title: Art Basel Miami Beach | Deal Or No Deal?
description: Yesterdays four consecutive openings of Art Basel Miami Beach  a ten-hour delight for jet-lagged, untanned dealers minding their booths  yielded an overall quiet turnout. On Thursday the fair opened to the public, and beyond the bottleneck at the gates things were  even quieter. Which is not to say dead, or even grim; the mood at Art Basel this year so far has merely been sober. The work is selling. The $20 Champagne is selling. You might say things have been laid back  is that OK? Why not. I even saw an errant Eames chair extrude beyond the limits of a booth, and it was not instantly destroyed by Swiss authorities.

title: Visual Culture Out of Africa
description: Africa is everywhere, so pervasive in our lives that we barely see it. Since it is in all likelihood the continent where human evolution began, it is literally in the bloodstream of everyone. DNA aside, huge portions of everyday life and cultural achievement are unthinkable without Africa.

title: Indian State Empowers Poor to Fight Corruption
description: NAGARKURNOOL, India  The village bureaucrat shifted from foot to foot, hands clasped behind his back, beads of sweat forming on his balding head. The eyes of hundreds of wiry village laborers, clad in dusty lungis, were fixed upon him.

title: Competition Wasnt Part of CTAs Apple Deal
description: The Chicago Transit Authority announced last month that it is looking for a consulting firm to help develop a revenue-generating corporate sponsorship program  a plan to sell private companies the naming rights to CTA train lines, train stations and bus routes.

title: An Interview With Stephen A. Schwarzman
description: Stephen A. Schwarzman, the chairman, chief executive and co-founder of the Blackstone Group, talks to Maria Bartiromo of CNBC about the future of private equity.

title: Africa and Its Legacy
description: Images from The Global Africa Project at the Museum of Arts & Design.

title: Commercial for Oprah Winfrey Network
description: A new commercial being shown in movie theaters features Oprah Winfrey discussing the launch of the Oprah Winfrey Network.

title: How Wine Became Modern
description: Images from a new exhibition at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art.

title: Some Blustery Gospel, Some Blaring Metal
description: The Rev. Johnny L. Jones

title: From Womens College to Football Powerhouse
description: Steve Murphy was surrounded by women while serving as vice president for student affairs at St. Xavier University in Chicago some 20 years ago. Not that he minded, but as a pragmatic, professional educator, he believed a better gender balance within the student body was essential to the universitys long-term health.

title: Stage Scenes: Lily Rabe
description: Photos of the actresss past performances in New York.

title: Living In | Cypress Hills, Brooklyn
description: Cypress Hills, a part of East New York just south of Queens, is a neighborhood on the upswing.

title: Radical Actions of the 60s, Reverberating in the Reflective 70s
description: Although Night Catches Us, written and directed by Tanya Hamilton, is haunted by the threat and the memory of violence, its tone is sober and calm, almost serene. Staking out volatile, myth-enshrouded historical territory  Black Panther militancy, police brutality, the ebbing of the revolutionary intensity of the 60s  Ms. Hamilton tells a modest, complex story with admirable clarity and nuance. That her film is so quiet, so evidently invested in contemplation rather than confrontation, gives it power as well as insight. The large dramatic gestures and sweeping implications are off-screen, between the lines, discernible as a kind of negative afterimage of what is actually seen.

title: Poles Seek to Overcome Gap in Math and Sciences
description: WARSAW  The newly opened science and technology center here was conceived not only as a place to excite young minds about science and discovery, but also as a chance for Poland to overcome at least one piece of its tragic past, to set aside one legacy of war and occupation  the decline of math and science education.

title: Chris Paul Sets Standard for N.B.A. Point Guards
description: One of the highlights of the first full month of the N.B.A. season was the outstanding play of the leagues top point guards. This seems to be a golden age for the position, with young stars like the Spurs Tony Parker, the Hornets Chris Paul, the Celtics Rajon Rondo, the Bulls Derrick Rose, the Thunders Russell Westbrook and the Jazzs Deron Williams mixed in with veterans like the Mavericks Jason Kidd and the Suns Steve Nash. This has sparked an age-old debate: Who is the best point guard in the N.B.A.?

title: After 30 Years, Preserving Nuns Legacy
description: There is no way that Flor Lazo could have memories of the unspeakable crime that rocked her homeland, El Salvador, on a distant Dec. 2. That monstrous deed  the torture, rape and murder of four American churchwomen by a military death squad  took place in 1980, a brutal time in El Salvador. Ms. Lazo was not born until five years later.

title: An Animated Space Odyssey
description: Beginning with accidentally sprayed Russian mucus and ending with deliberately deployed American urine, the plot of Mars owes at least as much to bodily fluids as it does to science fiction. Low key, low budget and low energy, this animated space odyssey from the writer and director Geoff Marslett accompanies three mismatched astronauts to the red planet and the search for new life forms.

title: Discovering a Sinister Santa in Finland
description: The Santa at the center of Rare Exports: A Christmas Tale is not the sort Mommy is likely to be kissing beneath the mistletoe (or anywhere else) this year. Rather, the focus of this bizarre Finnish fairy tale  as black as anything the Brothers Grimm could have dreamed up  is a sinister old codger who chews off ears and whose demon minion kidnaps innocent children. Ho ho no!

title: Managing Risk for JPMorgan, and Blindness
description: LONDON  As a trader at JPMorganChase in London, Ashish Goyal helps manage billions of dollars of the banks exposure to risks like foreign exchange fluctuations. In his spare time, he takes tango lessons, plays cricket and goes clubbing with friends. Mr. Goyal is also blind.

title: Where Prices Are Practical, and Cuisines Colorful
description: IN August, Debra Kayman bought her first home, a two-family on Ashford Street in Cypress Hills, in the East New York section of Brooklyn. She came to the United States from Trinidad and Tobago in 1985, living in East Flatbush with family until her move to Cypress Hills in 1988. There she rented a succession of apartments, including one on Arlington Avenue near the stately Arlington branch of the Brooklyn Public Library, built a century ago by the steel magnate Andrew Carnegie.

title: Remaking a School Lunch
description: How the nutrition bill would change a meal.

title: Inside the Life of a Leader

title: Speed-Freak Football
description: EARLY IN A GAME last month against Washington, a running back for the University of Oregons powerhouse football team darted through a small opening on the right side of the line, then cut smartly upfield for a seven-yard gain and a first down. A typical-enough play, and good for the home team. But seconds after it was over, the Oregon fans at Autzen Stadium in Eugene let out an enormous boo. I turned to the man next to me in the press box, who happened to be the associate director of Oregons bands, for an explanation. The officials arent moving the chains fast enough, he explained. Its slowing us down. Oregon made another first down, and the crowd booed more loudly. I wondered: What do these people want, sprinters imported from Jamaica to move the chains? Next, a Washington defensive player limped to the sideline with an apparent knee injury, and the boos came cascading down again inside Oregons concrete bowl of a stadium. They think hes faking it so the defense can get rest, my friend from the bands explained. Thats been happening to us a lot.

title: Kidney Punch
description: My father-in-law suffers from chronic kidney disease and expects to need a transplant in the not-too-distant future. He does not wish either of his adult children or me to donate a kidney, on the grounds that even in our late 30s, we are too young and might need our other kidney at some point down the road. Instead, he plans to add his name to the recipient list and wait his turn. May we ignore his wishes and anonymously donate a kidney when the time comes?  R.B., DENVER

title: Drinking, Driving and Paying
description: Heres what can happen: You attend a small dinner party at your brothers house with your 80-year-old mother, your visiting 74-year-old second cousin from Holland and assorted other family members. As per family custom, you enjoy hors doeuvres and several glasses of wine over a lovely meal full of conversation and laughter.

title: A Heart Loses Its Way
description: The 59-year-old woman struggled to her feet. Even with her husband at her side, it was tricky getting out of the car. At least it was now. She stood for a moment, unsure of her legs. Then all her strength seemed to evaporate; her legs felt like Jell-O, and despite her husbands arm around her, she sank to the ground. Can you stand if I help you? he asked. She shook her head  tears of frustration filled her eyes. Ill be right back, he assured her, then he sprinted the few steps to the doctors office, returning moments later with a wheelchair and a couple of nurses.

title: Wasted Data
description: As we consume, we leave stuff behind. We leave behind waste and garbage and refuse. And increasingly, we leave behind mountains of data. Thats true online, as presumably everybody knows, but also in the physical world: Kroger knows which coupons to print out for me when I check out with my Kroger shopping card, because in addition to saving me a few pennies, the card helps the chain keep precise track of my shopping history at its stores.

title: Scanners Gone Wild
description: Over the past three and a half years, the advancing army of Google Street View cars has pressed forward, its units opening fire on city after city from roof-mounted, omnidirectional cameras that seize, in an unyielding digital grip, panoramic images  of Rome! of Peoria! of Antarctica!  that Googles commanders stockpile and post online. Protests have followed dependably, and often literally, in their path. In spring of 2009, residents of Broughton, a hamlet in southeast England, took to the streets and surrounded a lone, unmarked Google car with its conspicuous periscope camera, the crowd swiftly herding the intruder out of their neighborhood. Later that year, in Bergen, Norway, two people dressed in full-body scuba suits  in goggles, snorkels and flippers  ran up a road after a Google car, each of the anonymous amphibians brandishing a pitchfork. And this past May, shortly after Google admitted that its cars werent just taking pictures  they had inadvertently gathered information, including e-mail passwords, from unprotected WiFi networks (We screwed up, Sergey Brin, one of Googles founders, said)  30 European countries banded together to combat Googles infringements on the privacy of citizens. The nations demanded improvements in Googles blurring techniques (designed to obscure faces, license plates, naked people) and sought a reduction, from 12 to 6, in the number of months Google could hold onto the millions of unblurred original images backed up on its servers. Individual European countries began investigations as well, securing exemptions to protect their citizens, with more than 240,000 Germans opting out of Street View in advance of it going live last month  an option that Google agreed to only in Germany (where, among other things, Stasi surveillance isnt yet a hazy memory). And last year Greece went so far as to ban Googles Street View vehicles from operating within their borders, pending further investigation.

title: Letters: The Rogue Room
description: I have noticed the magazines attempts to cover conservatives more frequently, and generally support them, but I felt that Robert Drapers article on Sarah Palin was yet more favorable propaganda for the former governor. He didnt reconcile the opinion of Palins inner circle with the general publics perception of her. For example, her biographer characterizes her as a brilliant writer with a nimble mind. How can you resolve this with the person who, for example, was unable in an interview to name a single newspaper or magazine she read, either because she doesnt read them or simply couldnt think of the right answer when the camera was on? Draper also suggests that the prevailing narrative of Palin is of a social-media visionary. Using Facebook and Twitter doesnt set her apart  what does is that the media follow her with rapt attention and present it as the other side of a never-ending argument between right and left, regardless of her importance to the political process.

Like Ms. Portman, Ms. Kunis trained rigorously for the movie, spending months working with Alexandra Blacker, a member of the Los Angeles Ballet. (Blacker! On the red carpet, Ms. Portman wore a black gown and Ms. Kunis a cream one, with a heavily-shouldered jacket and Christian Louboutin stilletos.
