title: Hanukkah, Autism and One Temples Run at a Miracle
description: On these days of Hanukkah, as Jews light the menorahs candles, they recite a blessing for miracles of the past, for enemies vanquished and for lamp oil sustained. What might constitute a Hanukkah miracle today depends, perhaps, on what one needs and what one asks. It could even happen on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.

title: Weekend Competition: Bill Stickers is Innocent
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to share graffiti that they have seen or  heaven forfend  written.

title: Volvo Recalling 7,400 Vehicles for Passenger Seat Problem
description: Volvo is recalling about 7,400 vehicles because of a problem with the front passenger seat, the automaker told the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

title: Alfred Eisenstaedt, Photographer of the Defining Moment, Is Dead at 96
description: Alfred Eisenstaedt, the German photographer whose pioneering images for Life magazine helped define American photojournalism, died on Wednesday while vacationing on Martha's Vineyard in Massachusetts. He was 96 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Treasury Nets Further $1.8 Billion From G.M. I.P.O.
description: From our colleagues at DealBook:

title: Gearshifts Prove a Moving Target
description: FOR the earliest automobiles crawling along horse-cart roads, a single fixed ratio of engine r.p.m. to vehicle speed was entirely adequate. But before long it became clear that building vehicles capable of both brisk acceleration and respectable top speeds would require some method of changing the speed relationships  the drive ratios  to match the conditions of the moment.

title: UBS Names Next Chief Financial Officer
description: LONDON  UBS, Switzerlands largest bank, appointed an executive at its American wealth management unit as the banks next chief financial officer, the company said Friday.

title: This Weekends Top European Matches
description: The outstanding matchups in European league soccer this weekend:

title: Nice Tries That Were Ahead of Their Time
description: WHILE the designs and layouts of transmission shifters have generally come and gone in industrywide trends, exceptions have appeared in every era. Some foreshadowed mechanisms that were years away; others were impractical and soon became the subject of historians trivia games.

title: Leaked Cables Stir Resentment and Shrugs
description: PARIS  In the world of diplomacy, known for its ambiguity and opacity, the WikiLeaks organization says its function is to keep government open. But with the release of some 250,000 American diplomatic cables, the outcome may be more ambiguous, closing doors to United States diplomats, turning candor to reticence and leaving many people leery of baring their souls and secrets to American officials.

title: South Korea and U.S. Reach Deal on Trade
description: WASHINGTON  American negotiators have completed a free-trade agreement with South Korea that will eliminate most tariffs on exports and solidify one of the nations most significant alliances in Asia, the Obama administration said on Friday.

title: Cleaning Up 'The Deuce'
description: After 30 years of redevelopment, Times Square has cleaner streets, new office buildings and renovated landmark theaters, but many landmarks remain.

title: The Producers Guild Unveils Documentary Finalists
description: Political downfall, military heroism, the educational system, the financial crisis, Rwandan genocide and the paparazzi are the subjects addressed by the films nominated for the years best documentary by the Producers Guild of America. Client 9: The Rise and Fall of Eliot Spitzer, from Alex Gibney; Inside Job, by Charles Ferguson; The Tillman Story, about Pat Tillman, the football player turned Afghanistan war casualty; Waiting for Superman, Davis Guggenheims attention-getting look at the countrys schools; Earth Made of Glass, which centers on the Rwandan president and a citizen dealing with the aftermath of the genocide there; and Smash His Camera, about the pioneering celebrity photographer Ron Galella, were all chosen.

title: Weekend Fare
description: Holiday-themed events  begin this weekend, including the menorah lighting at Grand Army Plaza in Brooklyn at 7 p.m. on Saturday and 6 p.m. on Sunday. Latkes will also be served, and children receive free gifts. If you havent had your fill of latkes, head over to City Winery, 155 Varick Street, on Sunday at 4 p.m. for an international latke festival. Tickets are $32.50, available online.

title: Pooper-Scooper Signs Vandalized on East 90th
description: Forget passive aggressive notes. On East 90th Street, softly worded signs exhorting dog owners to curb their best friends have led to some patently aggressive behavior.

title: The Success of Simpson-Bowles
description: Since the news today is that the deficit commission failed to reach the consensus required to send its proposals to Congress for a vote, its worth revisiting Josh Barros column from last week on why Simpson-Bowles has actually been a success story:

title: Senator Brown Supports Repeal of Dont Ask, Dont Tell
description: Senator Scott Brown, Republican of Massachusetts, said on Friday that he now supported the repeal of the militarys dont ask, dont tell policy regarding gay soldiers, after a Pentagon report this week concluded that allowing gay men and lesbians to serve openly would not pose risks to the battle readiness of troops.

title: Elaine Kaufman, Who Fed and Fussed Over the Famous, Dies at 81
description: Elaine Kaufman, who became something of a symbol of New York as the salty den mother of Elaines, one of the citys best-known restaurants and a second home for almost half a century to writers, actors, athletes and other celebrities, died Friday in Manhattan. She was 81.

title: The Rebirth of 42nd Street
description: A view of the Times Square streetscape in 1989 vs. 2010.

title: Holiday Books: Movies
description: No Marx Brothers movie exemplifies the divine anarchy of Julius, Leonard, Arthur and Herbert Marx as purely as the 1933 Paramount comedy Duck Soup. It was the last film in which all four brothers  stage-named Groucho, Chico, Harpo and Zeppo  appeared together on-screen. Unlike their earlier Paramount films (or those that would come after their move to MGM the following year), Duck Soup is devoid of romantic subplots or, for that matter, of any real plotline at all, save for the foundering of the bankrupt kingdom of Freedonia in a senseless, and quite conceivably endless, Groucho-led war. Yet Duck Soup is the film Harold Bloom, in an essay on the 20th-century American sublime, called one of the great works of art of the past century. Its one of the movies T. S. Eliot wanted to discuss when he met with Groucho in 1964 (Groucho had hoped to chat about Murder in the Cathedral), and the one that inspired Woody Allens character in Hannah and Her Sisters not to go home and shoot himself.

title: Holiday Books: Music
description: Fifty-six-year-old automobiles range from rotted-out clunkers tottering toward the scrap heap to cosseted antiques whose primary virtue is the evocation of nostalgia.

title: Holiday Books: Maps
description: At the time of his death in 1799, George Washington owned over 90 atlases and maps, probably one of the largest collections of its kind in 18th-century America. That Washington possessed so many is hardly surprising. From his youthful days as a surveyor through his long military career to his defense of Americas post-Revolutionary territorial claims, Washington relied on maps. They offered him not only a means of establishing plantation boundaries or planning military campaigns, but also a canvas upon which to project an image of the future glory of the nation he helped create.

title: Women of Mystery
description: What turns a human being into a legend? Is it a question of personal excellence: exceptional charisma, intellect, strength or beauty? Or is it an other-directed gift: an unusual capacity to engage the hearts and enlarge the dreams of admirers?

title: Visual Books
description: A graphic designer cant have too many books of typography. These specimen books nourish and replenish, inform and delight. I own more than 100 type catalogs and manuals dating to the late 19th century, and I know other designers (or design lovers) who have compiled even larger and rarer stashes. This holiday season, its a safe bet that type books will be welcome gifts for fontaholics everywhere.

title: Get Me to the Ballpark on Time
description: WHEN Jason Phillips was married to Molly Ray last June, a nephew of the bride bore the ring in a catchers mitt.

title: Holiday Books: Americana
description: One of the more disheartening news articles to appear this fall announced a blight on the field of childrens publishing. Apparently, the tyranny of standardized testing has stoked anxiety among some parents, who feel they must press chapter books on their offspring at increasingly younger ages, thus diminishing the market for picture books and causing publishers to prune their lists accordingly. Educators, parents, publishers: what are you thinking? Words are nice, but pictures are sublime. Picture books provide a portal not only to the love of literature, but to limber, limbic terrain  rich with sensory-emotional connections and lying, crucially, beyond the reach of language (not to mention beyond the reach of quantitative assessment). From such explorations we may emerge wiser, rounder.

title: Holiday Books: Curiosities
description: Bullfighting. Flamenco. Religious pilgrimage. On the face of it, little in Lena Herzogs earlier monographs prepares her audience for LOST SOULS (de.MO design, $54), photographs taken in cabinets of curiosities, collections of anatomical specimens dating back to the 17th century. But if the denial of death inspires the making of a photograph, fixing a moment so that it never ends and freeing its subject from the annihilation of time, preserving a fetus in a bottle answers a similar impulse.

title: Notable Crime Books of 2010
description: Choosing books for picky friends can be humbling. Theres always one smarty-pants who has read not only the gift book but everything else in the authors oeuvre. Another recipient refuses to consider any story about some stupid girl. And how about that ingrate who scorns the genre altogether, claiming to have developed more mature tastes? Im speaking, of course, about buying books for children. Picking crime novels for grown-ups is a breeze.

title: Very Good Years
description: Elvis Presley, Marilyn Monroe, Maria Callas, Judy Garland, Jack Kerouac: these and other giants of popular culture were long ago explored to death, yet biographers keep struggling to give the old stories a new spin. With most of the eyewitnesses gone, however, and the tattered clippings picked dry, writers are left to reinterpret the facts, leaning heavily on imagination. Many of their books enter a gray zone of shady credibility.

title: Holiday Books: Treasures
description: Do you have a treasure chest where you keep your secret delights? In ENCYCLOPEDIA OF THE EXQUISITE: An Anecdotal History of Elegant Delights (Doubleday, $27.95), Jessica Kerwin Jenkins explains that her first was a cunning grade-school jewelry box, designed to look like a small birdcage with a faux canary swinging behind brass bars. In its shallow drawer I kept a prism that made rainbows, . . . the face of my fathers old Timex and a sample vial of Patous Joy. Her grown-up version is a cabinet of curiosities  in book form  inspired in part by the encyclopedias of the Renaissance, which brimmed with exotic artifacts.

title: Holiday Books: Music
description: In his sweeping new book on singers in America since the dawn of the electrical microphone in 1925, Will Friedwald functions as cicerone on a grand cultural journey. Roaming across the decades in A BIOGRAPHICAL GUIDE TO THE GREAT JAZZ AND POP SINGERS (Pantheon, $45)  he started out with David Thomsons Biographical Dictionary of Film as his model  he spins off intelligent portraits that begin alphabetically with Ernestine Anderson (who is never less than subtle, whether belting the blues or tearing up a torch tune) and conclude on Page 539 as the curtain falls on Nancy Wilson. At that point, Friedwald shifts to a series of search-and-inform essays on assorted themes that crisscross generations, idioms, performing styles, record labels, the entertainment industrys evolution and a galaxy of careers, from Marlene Dietrich to Bob Dylan and Harry Connick Jr. Mahalia Jackson appears in a coda, as the author, wisely, genuflects to gospel music as a popular form.

title: The Joy of Lists
description: You've got to hand it to writers who have the hubris to stick a list in your face. There you are happily reading along in a poem or a novel and suddenly a Catalogue, an Inventory, a Phalanx of Facts appears on the page. Dont writers ever consider the possibility that lists stop the action, that they get in the way of the story? Of course not, writers dont care about our comfort level, they just like to show off how much they know and their ability to communicate it. If I were to draw up a list of all the poets and novelists who have resorted to lists, youd be astonished. Luckily, others have done the job for me, and if you take the time to peruse their books youll see that many writers, despite my misgivings, can make a list practically shimmy off the page.

title: Holiday Books: Humor
description: While much too large to fit in the nightstand of every hotel room, DRUNK STONED BRILLIANT DEAD: The Writers and Artists Who Made the National Lampoon Insanely Great (Abrams, $40) might be renamed the Giddy-On Bible of American Humor. Might be, if youre one-tenth as clever as the minds at National Lampoon.

title: Holiday Books: Graphic Novels
description: I need a time machine, the leader of a terrorist group mutters midway through DUNCAN THE WONDER DOG (AdHouse, paper, $24.95). Go back to Olduvai  flood it when theres still a chance. In this ambitious, beautiful, mystifying first graphic novel by Adam Hines, the unhinged villain has a better reason than most to wipe humanity from the earth: Shes not human. Shes a Barbary macaque who goes by the name Pompeii, and shes just set off a bomb at a California university. Duncan the Wonder Dog tweaks the old song into a provocative new question: What if we could walk with the animals, talk with the animals  and the animals fought back?

title: Notable Childrens Books of 2010
description: BUSING BREWSTER  By Richard Michelson.Illustrated by R. G. Roth.  Unpaged. Knopf. $16.99. (Ages 6 to 10)

title: Gardening Books
description: Instead of a roundup of gardening books, maybe we should just refer to this category of publication as Dirty Books. Anything to do with soil falls under our new rubric. That way, writers who farm wouldnt feel the need to elbow aside rosarians who write, who in turn wouldnt jostle rudely past backyard gardeners concerned with mundane raised beds of veggies, bruising thin-skinned egos along with the tomatoes. Anyone insane enough to dig holes, pour money into the ground, wait to see what happens and then sit down at a computer to tell us about it has earned the right to a little respect.

title: Holiday Books: Food
description: Seized by a strange and self-indulgent notion, Christopher Kimball resolved to spend two years recreating a 12-course high Victorian dinner party on an authentic period coal stove installed in his 1859 Boston town house, making everything from the calfs foot gelatin to the puff pastry to the food coloring. Served to a dozen celebrity guests  one course every 20 minutes, requiring more than 40 recipes  the feast would be filmed as a public television special. The result, chronicled in FANNIES LAST SUPPER: Re-Creating One Amazing Meal From Fannie Farmers 1896 Cookbook (Hyperion, $25.99), makes Julie Powells feat of cooking one recipe a day from Mastering the Art of French Cooking in Julie & Julia look like Childs play.

title: Brio and Bons Mots
description: He adds up to a vexing, enviable, beguiling figure: an artist for whom success came with surpassing ease, but who worked maniacally nonetheless. Nol Coward was born in 1899 in a London suburb. His father was a piano salesman, and family resources were often stretched. Coward died in Jamaica in 1973, perched in a vacation home (he owned another in the Swiss Alps) whose rolling vistas were a glittering reflection of his robust commercial triumphs.

title: Holiday Books: Movies
description: For a long time, literary criticism concentrated on teasing out the buried structural principles and philosophical concepts that gave shape and meaning to the stream of events that made up a fictional narrative  looking for the figure in the carpet, in Henry Jamess phrase, that turned chaos into order, randomness into meaning.

title: Holiday Books: New York
description: Even in the 1890s, photographers realized that, for the art of their craft, New York was a helluva town.

title: Killing the Gods
description: Never famous in her lifetime, Emily Dickinson had some astute things to say about fame as a phenomenon: Fame is a fickle food, for instance, and Fame is a bee. But perhaps most evocative is:

title: 25 More Cookbooks
description: ANJUMS NEW INDIAN. By Anjum Anand. (Wiley, paper, $24.95.) Modern, approachable Indian dishes from the British television personality whos been called the Indian Nigella Lawson. (In a good way.)

title: Comics
description: Forty years ago, the pioneering cartoonists of the underground comix movement turned the topics polite society didnt speak about  sex, drugs, neurosis  into the stuff of their confessional art. Now that theyre older, they have a few final taboos to address bluntly. One of those doing so is Joyce Farmer, who in the 70s contributed to the feminist anthology Wimmens Comix and helped create a notorious series about womens sexuality whose title cant be reproduced here. Shes kept a fairly low profile since then, but her new book, SPECIAL EXITS (Fantagraphics, $26.99), is forceful, unsparing and equally concerned, in its way, with saying the unsayable.

title: End Times
description: In their latest volumes, two of Americas best-known and longest-lived critics look to poems for clarity about the end of life  what Walt Whitman called the merge. In Last Looks, Last Books, Helen Vendler closely reads work from the final collections of five major 20th-century poets, all aware that death was coming soon. In Till I End My Song, Harold Bloom gathers 100 last poems, from Edmund Spensers Prothalamion (the source of the books title) to The Veiled Suite, by the Kashmiri-American Agha Shahid Ali, who died in 2001.

title: Holiday Books: Drawing
description: When a book insists, Take art lessons from a monkey! the only appropriate response, if you ask me, is O.K.!

title: Cookbooks by New York Times Contributors
description: Regular readers of The Timess Dining section will recognize some familiar names while browsing through this seasons new cookbooks.

title: Holiday Books: Paris
description: The sky of Paris, Edith Piaf once sang, is never cruel for long. With this lyric, the chanteuse has both bad and good news for anyone who has ever  over the course of a week, a day or even an afternoon  found himself alternately fogged in, frozen, drenched and dazzled by Pariss weather. On the one hand, the skies over the City of Light too often provide anything but. (Its not for nothing that Baudelaire, the self-described king of a rainy land, dwelled obsessively on his hometowns great gray sky, foggy seasons, drenched landscape and mists and rains.) On the other hand, the citys mists and rains can clear at the drop of a chapeau. At such moments, Piafs song concludes, the sky asks for forgiveness by offering us a rainbow.

title: Music Chronicle
description: LISTEN TO THIS  By Alex Ross.  Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $27.

title: Cory Delafield, Stark Townend
description: Cory Hoffman Delafield, a daughter of Deborah H. Delafield and William F. Delafield Jr. of Villanova, Pa., was married in Bryn Mawr, Pa., Saturday evening to Stark Wetherly Townend, the son of Susan E. Townend and Dr. Stephen C. Townend of Devon, Pa. The Rev. Peter T. Vanderveen, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Redeemer, where he is rector.

title: Holiday Books: Crafts
description: To call the work of Amy Sedaris quirky is too easy  its also a vast understatement. Known in some circles for her cheese balls and cupcakes just as much as for her offbeat film, television and stage appearances, Sedaris often defies definition. So does her book SIMPLE TIMES (Grand Central, $27.99), a hyperkinetic hodgepodge of Crafts for Poor People (written with Paul Dinello) celebrating traditional American handicrafts, as well as diversions like keeping pet rabbits and making mint juleps.

title: Holiday Books: San Francisco
description: Some years ago, I began spending time in the rural Southern town where my father had been raised, and I often found myself wishing for a decoder ring. Squirrels had longer tails, wisteria bloomed off schedule, and with all the diphthongs and dropped syllables, I had no idea what people were saying. The local language sprouted from the literal and cultural landscape that informed it  its racial history and disappearing farms, the coexistence of deer festivals and meth busts, the households where people wore Carhartts without irony and put Queer Eye on TiVo. How to understand all this? An atlas would have helped.

title: Travel Books
description: This seasons pack of travel writers are all over the map  both transcontinental ramblers and more sedentary souls who find their inspiration within the confines of a few square miles. There are urban adventurers in Italy and India, American road warriors and a nomad who pursues every form of transportation imaginable to follow Africas longest river from source to mouth.

title: Our Songs
description: Yip Harburg, the lyricist who wrote Brother, Can You Spare a Dime? and Over the Rainbow, described popular songwriting as the pulse of a nations heart, the fever chart of its health. In Showtime: A History of the Broadway Musical Theater, Larry Stempel aims to arrest the nations pulse with his thorough, sober analysis, or as he puts it, Might the time not now be ripe . . . for a scholarly reassessment of the history of the medium? Its a worthwhile endeavor, even if it doesnt leave much room for jokes.

title: Cookbooks
description: What confusing times these are. And Im talking just about new cookbook offerings. Falls usual glut of chef-y titles, primed for the giving, are notably absent. The food were being offered is much simpler, much faster and removed from the realm of fantasy  unless were talking about Modernist Cuisine: The Art and Science of Cooking, the Microsoft executive turned cooking whiz Nathan Myhrvolds $625 tome on 21st-century techniques (which you can preorder in advance of its March 2011 publication). The one big restaurant book is from a chef in Denmark who plucks his ingredients from rocks, beaches, logs, even cracks in the sidewalk. In short, were looking closer to home.

title: After 30 Years, Times Square Rebirth Is Complete
description: Next month, 11 Times Square, a new, glassy 40-story office tower at 42nd Street and Eighth Avenue, will formally open with its first tenant. Compared with the metamorphosis that has occurred around it, there is nothing extraordinary about the building except for this: Its completion officially marks the end of the long and tortuous redevelopment of Times Square, an effort that began 30 years ago.

title: New York City Cracks Down on Tickets Left Unpaid
description: Facing severe financial woes, New York is pursuing deadbeats who have long seemed to thumb their noses at the city with impunity, the hundreds of thousands of scofflaws who have accumulated a total of nearly $700 million in overdue parking fines.

title: Chef John DeLucie Unwinds With His Guitar
description: IF music be the food of love, John DeLucie is not about to quit his day job.

title: Clinton Says Leaks Dont Strain Gulf State Ties
description: MANAMA, Bahrain  The United States and Bahrain sought to project a unified front on Friday, five days after the king of Bahrain was quoted in leaked American diplomatic cables as urging Washington to stop Iran from getting nuclear weapons by whatever means necessary.

title: Sample Sale: Growing a Jazz Audience
description: ADAM SCHATZ, the 23-year-old concert promoter who runs the nonprofit outfit Search and Restore, has been trying to develop a new audience for jazz almost as if the old ones never existed. It helps people in his line of work to hold a base-line dogmatic assumption about culture, and his is that jazz culture has no laurels to rest on. Jazz has been so tainted by a pretty self-righteous attitude, he explained in an interview late last month, talking at a run. It kills any desire for people to go out and discover it.

title: Big East, Yankees and ESPN Believe in New Bowl
description: The Big East lusted for a bowl game in New York. The Yankees were intent on creating a college football tradition at their new stadium.

title: Kinnucan Gets Another Visit From the F.B.I.
description: John Kinnucan, the research analyst who refused a request by agents from the Federal Bureau of Investigation to wear a wire, has received a subpoena.

title: Analyzing Literature by Words and Numbers
description: Victorians were enamored of the new science of statistics, so it seems fitting that these pioneering data hounds are now the subject of an unusual experiment in statistical analysis. The titles of every British book published in English in and around the 19th century  1,681,161, to be exact  are being electronically scoured for key words and phrases that might offer fresh insight into the minds of the Victorians.

title: Survey Finds Pent-Up M.&A. Demand in Europe
description: Companies in Europe and Britain plan to make up for a dead year in mergers and acquisitions in 2011.

title: Vain Glorious | Aesops Newest Face Cream
description: What: Aesop Perfect Facial Hydrating Cream

title: When Puccini Rode Tall In the Saddle
description: MUSICAL centenaries are double-edged occasions. They can inspire illuminating perspectives on worthy topics, or they can be little more than knee-jerk pretexts for music publishers, presenters and record labels to fetishize round numbers in the name of sales, with musicologists gratefully riding their coattails. A centenary on Friday  that of the world premiere of Puccinis Fanciulla del West at the Metropolitan Opera, to be commemorated there with the second performance of a revival of Giancarlo del Monacos 1992 production starring Deborah Voigt and Marcello Giordani  is a milestone well worth contemplating, as it recalls not just the birth of a great opera but a sort of coming of age of opera in America.

title: On the Brink: Teaching About Tension in North and South Korea
description: Skirmishes between North Korea and South Korea have been far from rare in recent years, but the shots exchanged last week brought a new level of tension between the two nations  and to world diplomacy.

title: Teams Resort to Flop to Slow Oregon
description: EUGENE, Ore.  Early in the second quarter of Oregons victory at California on Nov. 13, Cal defensive lineman Aaron Tipoti looked toward a coach on the sideline, suddenly grabbed the back of his knee and tumbled awkwardly to the ground without being touched.

title: F.D.A.: Diet Pill Works, but Has Risks
description: A new diet pill from Orexigen Therapeutics narrowly meets the requirements for effectiveness but poses potential cardiovascular risks, reviewers from the Food and Drug Administration said Friday.

title: Elaine Kaufman is Dead at 81. Long Live Elaines
description: Elaine Kaufman, the irascible den mother who ran Elaines with an iron fist and surprisingly tender heart for the better part of five decades, died Friday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 81. Enid Nemy has her obituary here at The Times, and you ought to go read it. As Ms.Kaufman might have said, You might learn something.

title: Value Sinking Fastest on Homes Priced Low to Start
description: DURING the great housing bubble, it was the least expensive homes whose prices went up the most. And now it is those homes that are suffering the most.

title: New Role  for Virginia Thomas
description: Virginia Thomas is stepping aside as chief executive of the conservative organization she founded, but intends to keep ties to a new alliance between that group, Liberty Central, and the Patrick Henry Center for Individual Liberty.

title: Memories of Elaine: An Appreciation
description: One Saturday night this spring, a limber woman eating dinner at Elaines walked up to Table 4, bent very low, and reached out her hand to pay her respects to the imposing woman seated there.

title: Senate Democrats Voice Frustration Over Bush-Era Tax Cuts
description: Negotiating with Republicans over tax cuts for the rich is almost like the question of do you negotiate with terrorists?  Senator Robert Menendez, Democrat of New Jersey, posited during a news conference with other Senate Democrats on Friday.

title: Ice-Pick Bandit Sought in Jewelry Robberies
description: A burly, bespectacled robber armed with an ice pick is preying on women in separate corners of the city, in Stuyvesant Town in Manhattan and in Co-op City in the Bronx, the police said.

title: Judge Prods Airgas and Air Products
description: If CF Industries Holdings hostile offer for Terra Industries was the forever war, Air Products and Chemicals hostile offer for Airgas is the interminable war. It appears that Air Products still remains hesitant to fully engage, and yet it is still around, perhaps waiting for a helpful ruling from the Delaware Chancery Court or at least trying to make the markets think it will throw in its cards if it does not get some relief.

title: Patriots Thrive on Diet of Dink and Dunk
description: FOXBOROUGH, Mass.  Danny Woodhead is tucked into a back corner of the New England Patriots locker room, so diminutive that even the arms and shoulders of a small clutch of reporters are enough to obscure him. This, it seems, must be a little like the view opposing defenses have when Woodhead gets the ball in the Patriots offense.

title: Why Savings Account Rates Are So Pathetic
description: Savers just cant catch a break.

title: Habitats | Red Hook, Brooklyn
description: Ben Schneider did so much work on an old house in Red Hook, Brooklyn, that he might as well have started from scratch.

title: Rebuilt Almost From Scratch, and a Bit of a Mix
description: BEN SCHNEIDER was raised on the Upper West Side, the son of an anthropology professor (his mother, Jane) and a sociology professor (his father, Peter). To the surprise of his bookish parents, his favorite childhood possession was a workbench.

title: Getting More From Your Savings
description: In this weekends Your Money column, I tackle a question that many people have been asking of late: Why is it, exactly, that my bank cant pay me higher interest rates?

title: Block by Block | East Village
description: A stroll along a six-block stretch of East Seventh Street in the East Village finds an interesting mix of urban melting pot and college town.

title: BMWs Head of Exterior Design to Become Minis Design Chief
description: Mini and BMW have announced that Anders Warming, 38, the head of exterior design at BMW, will become head of design at Mini. He succeeds Gert Hildebrand, 57.

title: When a Backpack Falls From a Helicopter, Its Back to Square One
description: Thursday, Dec. 2

title: Musty Old, Clever Young East Seventh Street
description: IF you walk along East Seventh Street in the East Village, youre likely to hear Polish, Russian, Spanish, Ukrainian, German, maybe some Yiddish, and even English spoken in an array of regional accents. But the six-block stretch from Cooper Square to Avenue D is also like a college town, full of creatively dressed young people, many of them art students. Competing allegiances  urban renewal versus civic pride, bohemian protest versus entrepreneurial spirit  manage to live peacefully on a small campus.

title: The Celebrity Viral Video That Teaches You Norwegian
description: Because its Friday and why the heck not: the above viral video has been making the rounds, ostensibly to promote a Norwegian television series called Golden Times (Gylne Tider in the native tongue), whose hosts seek out and interview vintage celebrities of the 1970s, 80s and 90s. And what better way to bring to life the concept of such a show than by bringing together dozens of these celebrities to sing and/or lip-sync Let It Be?

title: Trichet Defends Euro and European Economic Vigor
description: PARIS  The president of the European Central Bank, Jean-Claude Trichet, tried on Friday to bolster confidence in the outlook for the euro zone and to remind investors that budgetary problems were not confined to Europe alone.

title: Obamas Remarks at Bagram Air Force Base
description: Following is the transcript of President Obama's remarks to troops at Bagram Air Force Base on Friday, as released by the White House:

title: Gun Drawn
description: Bar patrons outside Finnegans react to the police shooting in its immediate aftermath.

title: The Scene
description: Clusters of bystanders surrounded the scene amid a thick police presence.

title: John Harwood Interviews Austan Goolsbee
description: Austan Goolsbee, chairman of President Obama's Council of Economic Advisers, talked with John Harwood of the New York Times and CNBC recently about the state of the economy and more.

title: More Pandemonium
description: More pandemonium at the scene.

title: Administering C.P.R.
description: An unidentified woman performs CPR on Mr. Henry.

title: Pope Likes Electric Vehicles, but Wants More
description: Pope Benedict XVI is looking to the heavens for a power source  for a new car.

title: Perspective on the Scene
description: The shooting scene viewed from a distance.

title: 10 Questions for Austan Goolsbee

description: A lead actress in the new Broadway musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark suffered a concussion at the first preview performance on Sunday night when, standing offstage, she was struck in the head by a rope holding a piece of equipment, a spokesman for the actress said on Friday. The actress, Natalie Mendoza, who plays the villainess Arachne, did not perform on Thursday night and is not expected to return before Tuesday.

title: Just One Look | Michael Kors Pre-Fall Collection
description: Michael Kors may not like the term Pre-Fall but he embraces the concept. As he pointed out at his, er, Pre-Fall presentation on Thursday, the day after Labor Day is a little early to be busting out the triple ply cashmere, tweed and fur. These are the pieces you want to be wearing in September, he said of the graphic sweaters, narrow pants and day dresses in royal blue, red, white and black. When it comes to this voluminous coat in particular  and also the sharp, zip-back flats  we have to agree.

description: The awards campaigning for Lesley Manville seems to be working just fine so far. Ms. Manville, who plays Mary, a needy middle-aged women with a touch of a drinking problem in Mike Leighs Another Year, took home the best actress award from the National Board of Review on Thursday. (The British Independent Film Awards have also nominated her for best supporting actress.) And she is both amused and amazed at the machinery of awards season.

description: Representative Alan Grayson, Democrat of Florida, has just a few more days left in his term. But while he was defeated in the November election, Mr. Grayson has not given up his pit-bull approach to taking on Republicans in his speeches on the House floor, which at times include some incendiary declarations.

title: Agency Would Require Back-Up Cameras in All Passenger Vehicles
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration is proposing that all passenger vehicles be equipped with back-up cameras to reduce the chances of running over pedestrians, noting that small children are particularly vulnerable.

description: Of all the incredible two-way talents in the N.B.A. today, only one player is ranked in the top five in both offensive rating (the points per 100 possessions that the players team scores while he is on the floor) and defensive rating (you guessed it; the points per 100 possessions that a players team allows while hes on the floor). Care to take a guess?

title: With Elections Over, National Committees in the Red
description: Both the main Democratic and Republican campaign committees ended the 2010 political season with roughly $15 million in debt from their final attempts to sway voters in the days before the midterm elections, according to financial disclosure reports filed late Thursday night that track the period between Oct. 14 and Nov. 22.

description: Honda announced on Friday that its box-shaped Element would be discontinued after the 2011 model year.

description: Freelance classical musicians talk about their experiences and struggles.

title: Europe Jolted by Extremes of Weather
description: LONDON  Northern Europe remained in the grip of arctic weather on Friday after a week of blinding snow, biting winds and plummeting temperatures. Airports have closed, trains have halted in midtrip, cars have been abandoned on highways and several dozen people from Poland to Britain have died of exposure so far, the authorities say.

description: Samantha Storey is trying to make her packed lunches less boring, one box at a time.

title: Surveys: Christmas Spending May Not Be So Jolly
description: Although the Christmas shopping season is off to a strong start, some surveys of consumers are flashing red lights rather than green ones as to what the mood among retailers and marketers might be on Dec. 26.

title: Carbon Auction Yields $16.9 Million for New York
description: New York made $16.9 million in the latest auction of carbon dioxide credits, held this week under the cap-and-trade system known as Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative. But it remains to be seen whether the money will go to the energy efficiency programs it is intended for.

title: Song of a Future Dolphin and Other 9-Year-Olds
description: Kiya Horace stood in front of a microphone at Avatar Studios on West 53rd Street on Wednesday afternoon and waited for directions.

title: Familiar Eggnog Made New
description: I DIDNT grow up with eggnog, but when I met my first glass, I felt like we had been friends forever. It tasted like a spiked crme Anglaise, the kind of liquid custard meant to be drizzled over fruit or cake. I partook whenever it was served.

title: Art Basel Miami Beach | The Art of Parties, Day Three
description: With all the fairs opened and all the weather-delayed New Yorkers safely deposited in Miami, Thursday was primed to kick the party circuit into high gear. Despite a Swiss Institute/Bally party in Wynwood rumored to have cost half a million dollars (presumably spent on the laser show and on Peaches, who performed on the shoulders of a naked transvestite), the cab ride across the causeway was out of the question for most partygoers. This was more a matter of practicality than anything else, considering the door hell promised by the evenings most buzzed about event: the MOMA PS1/Interview magazine pool spectacular at the Delano. Ninety minutes before the performance, conceived by Mariah Robertson, was scheduled to begin, the receiving area behind the hotels shrubbery resembled a military state. For a moment even MOMAs Klaus Biesenbach was stranded on the other side.

title: F.D.A. Panel Backs Expansion of Obesity Surgery
description: A federal advisory panel on Friday endorsed an expansion of the use of Allergans Lap-Band stomach restricting device to patients who are less than severely obese.

title: Combative Fire in Swirls, Wails and Striking Steps
description: A Noche Flamenca performance is created on the premise of a steady build: there are carefully placed sparks along the way, but just about every show leads to fireworks in the form of Soledad Barrio. No matter how many times youve seen Ms. Barrio dance, the experience is strangely intimate; theres something voyeuristic and cathartic about watching a woman pry open her soul, scatter it on the floor and put it back together again.

title: A Low Bar in Cancn? Not for U.S., Envoy Declares
description: Todd Stern, the chief American climate change negotiator, arrived on Friday in the Mexican resort town of Cancn, where the annual two-week United Nations climate extravaganza has been under way since Monday.

title: Up Front: Choosing the 100 Notables
description: With this issue, we again present our 100 Notable Books of the Year. The task of choosing them  or rather of excluding other superb books  grows harder each time. Consider it in terms of arithmetic: If we limited ourselves to a single work of fiction and nonfiction chosen from each of the issues published since Dec. 6, 2009, when the previous Notables list appeared, we would exceed our self-imposed limit.

title: A New Van Leeuwen Truck Brings Coffee to Central Park
description: A few weeks ago, Van Leeuwen Artisanal Ice Cream added a new truck to its expanding buttercup-yellow fleet. Called Turtle (all six trucks are named for animals: Kangaroo, Panda, Rattlesnake, Bobcat, Eagle), its as focused on coffee as it is on ice cream.

title: An Anxious Fed Took Citi Subprime Debt as Collateral
description: When the Federal Reserve lent $70 billion through a program designed to kick start the credit markets, Pimco, BlackRock and other big investors ponied up a hodgepodge of collateral, including some securities backed by Citigroups subprime credit card debt.

title: Standoff Set Up With 2 Ivory Coast Presidents
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast  Defying international observers and the countrys own electoral commission, officials tied to President Laurent Gbagbo on Friday declared him the winner of a landmark election in this troubled West African nation, potentially setting the stage for the kind of violence and division that the long-awaited voting was supposed to prevent.

title: Lessons Learned in Auditioning for Job
description: MANY years ago, my husband learned a harsh lesson about offering too much to get a job. He was in college, trying to sell advertisements for a local newspaper. Talking to a business owner located in a hard-to-find part of town, Mark suggested putting a map in his ad and even drew a sample one to show how it would look.

title: A Test for Humanity in a Postapocalyptic World
description: Ridley Scotts 1982 Blade Runner is a stylish action movie starring Harrison Ford as Deckard, a bounty hunter in pursuit of coolly attractive androids. Philip K. Dicks Do Androids Dream of Electric Sheep?, the 1968 book its based on, is a very different novel of ideas, at its essence about an unhappily married man.

title: Coen Brothers Saddle Up a Revenge Story (or Two)
description: LOS ANGELES  With a sly hipness that is the trademark of Joel and Ethan Coen, a billboard just outside the Melrose Avenue gate at Paramount Pictures promotes their next film, True Grit, with a promise: Retribution. This Christmas.

title: Music for Seaside Village, But Hold the Salt Cod
description: A dozen or so performances of Handels Messiah aside, December is typically a slow month for classical music in New York, and Carnegie Hall evidently sees the lull as an opportunity. In full import mode, Carnegie is presenting not only the fall portion of its citywide festival JapanNYC, which opened on Friday with showings of films scored by Toru Takemitsu at Film Forum, but also a four-concert sampling from the Risor Chamber Music Festival in Norway.

title: From Mahler, Love, Despair, Fairy Tales And Animals

title: Google and the Victorians: The History Goes Way Back
description: Most computer database searches  where you use key words to retrieve documents  are based on something called Boolean logic. What you may not know is that the term refers to a 19th century mathematician named George Boole, who developed his now indispensable theory in the 1854 book The Laws of Thought.

title: Number Crunching, Carpetbagger-Style
description: Well, after 20 blog posts, a dozen interviews, five movies, three red carpets, two video tapings and one instance of slipping into a party to which we werent technically invited, weve made it through the first week of award season more or less intact. Hurrah! Only 12 more weeks to go!

title: And Baby Makes Comedy When a Princess Is Taken West
description: There are a lot of different movies jostling for our attention inside The Warriors Way. In terms of formula, it resembles the chop suey western Shanghai Noon: an Asian princess and her protector are transported to the Wild West, where theyre pursued by Americans with guns and Asians with swords. Jackie Chan has been replaced by the Korean star Jang Dong Gun, and Lucy Liu by a remarkably composed toddler named Analin Rudd.

description: LOS ANGELES  Unlike many of the thousands of people who smuggle wildlife into Los Angeles every year, the authorities say, Sven Koppler chose not to conceal his exotic tarantulas under his clothing. They say he bundled them in multicolored straws or plastic containers and sent them in boxes through the United States Postal Service.

description: Google's proposed $6 billion bid for the social discount site Groupon would complement other local business-focused services, analysts say. DealBook's Evelyn M. Rusli examines the expected deal.

title: Poster Master With a Cool Hand
description: IF youve gone to the movies within the past seven decades, chances are Bill Gold had something to do with getting you there. A designer who created the posters for some of the best-known films in history, Mr. Gold struck that tricky balance between art and commerce, creating works that won design-world plaudits and enticed audiences to buy tickets.

title: Googles Play for Local Businesses
description: 8:39 p.m. | Updated Googles proposed $6 billion deal for the social discount-offer site Groupon would complement other services focused on local business, analysts say. Evelyn M. Rusli of DealBook examines the possible deal, which stumbled late Friday evening when Groupon brushed it off  at least for now.

title: A Bit of Bastianich and Batali
description: Just in time for the holidays, Joe Bastianich and Mario Batali have given Westchester County a giant glittering gift: Tarry Market, in Port Chester. Self-styled purveyors of fine foods, these blockbuster restaurateurs, who also recently opened Eataly, the Italian food emporium in Manhattan, have quietly opened this second spot  a sort of Little Eataly.

title: An Expansive Feast to Make Ganesh Proud
description: SINCE its opening 17 years ago, Jaipore has experienced a number of changes in its size, dcor and culinary style. Bit by bit it has sloughed off its British Raj looks (dcor left by Victorian Manor, one of the previous tenants) for just a few touches of India, like the requisite statue of Ganesh, the remover of obstacles and bringer of good fortune.

title: The World This Week
description: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

title: Kielbasa Kingdom
description: At Pulaski Meat Products in Linden, theres a strong aroma of smoked meat from the countless kielbasi and hams that hang from the ceiling and fill the display cases. Shelves at this Polish specialty store are lined with an array of imported goods, like dried mushrooms, smoked fish and all sorts of sauerkraut and pickled preserves. The deli serves prepared dishes, including pirogi (50 cents apiece), stuffed cabbage ($2.99 each) and goulash ($5.99 a pound), among other takeout meals and sandwiches.

title: Indian Fare, Emphasizing Comfort
description: FRIENDLY service, low prices and meals that make rich use of vegetables are the hallmarks of Paratha Junction, a simply decorated restaurant tucked away in a strip mall in Franklin Park. Here, a bowl of thick tomato soup flavored with ginger, garlic and coriander is $3; a bowl of kozhi rasam  clear broth studded with tender chicken and sparked with black pepper, coriander and cumin  is $4.

title: Given Space, East Directs West to a Path To Pursue
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  The longest event at the fall North American Championships took six days to complete. On Wednesday evening the Senior Knockout Teams was won by Roger Bates of Mesa, Ariz.; Drew Casen and Marc Jacobus of Las Vegas; Jim Krekorian of Pensacola, Fla.; and Eddie Wold of Houston. Lou Ann ORourke was their nonplaying captain.

title: If You Like It Hot, a Host of Options
description: MY first meal at Shangri-La restaurant in Guilford was a scorcher: a plate of Sichuan cumin-seasoned lamb chops nearly buried under a fantastic number of dried red chilies. Sichuan cooking has mild foods, too  the blazingly hot peppers so identified with the cuisine were introduced only after Europe discovered the Americas  but if you like it hot, theres plenty to choose from at Shangri-La.

Altman, a prominent Wall Street investment banker and former Treasury deputy secretary, is a leading candidate to become the next director of President Obamas National Economic Council reignited on Friday when he was seen at the White House for a second time in recent weeks.

description: A Brooklyn cafe with free Internet access is a haven for those who crave silence.

title: Charity Fixer to the Stars
description: LAST month, the actress Demi Moore and her husband, Ashton Kutcher, appeared at the United Nations on a panel announcing a United Nations-sponsored fund for victims of human trafficking. In January, they had founded the DNA Foundation, a charity to stop the brokering of young girls for sex. The truth is, slavery, globally, is a dirty little secret, Mr. Kutcher told an audience of 500, his voice wavering as he pointed out the average age of a sex slave is 13. It is happening everywhere right in front of our eyes and we ignore it.

title: Steamed Dumplings: Homemade Is the Way
description: STEAMED Chinese-style dumplings  often called shu mai, although there are many other types  are a real treat. Sadly, though, when served in restaurants they are often disappointing, with too-dense filling, not much flavor and a wrapper thats chewy rather than tender.

title: Making Chinese Dumplings
description: To make great Chinese dumplings at home without fancy folds or pleats, check out this weeks Minimalist column.

title: On the Street | Fabulous, Mr. Fox
description: A touch of fur, real or synthetic, gave some New Yorkers a cozy look last week. The sidewalks displayed everything from the popular fur vest to the fuzzy collars or trimmings on hooded parkas.

title: Destination: LAPTOPISTAN
description: JUST after 4 oclock on a Wednesday afternoon, as a dozen people clicked away on their laptops at the Atlas Caf in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, half of a tree broke off without warning less than a block away. It crashed into the middle of Havemeyer Street, crushing a parked car, setting off alarms and blocking the street. A deafening chorus of horns rose outside Atlass window as traffic halted. An 18-wheeler executed a sketchy 10-point turn in the middle of a crowded intersection before a pair of fire trucks made their way through the traffic jam in a blaze of red. Chain saws roared, sawdust flew and the horns built to a peak. It was New York urban pandemonium at its finest.

title: Sometimes a Mans Got to Hoop
description: BING CROSBY was a gorgeous singer and so was Karen Carpenter and also Nat King Cole  as is his daughter, too  and lets not forget Chrissie Hynde or, for that matter, Alvin and the Chipmunks. Yet regardless of how much one admires fine vocal styling, this time of year tests the patience of the most devoted pop fan. I refer, of course, to the curse of holiday music.

description: The Timess Ariel Kaminer on New York department store holiday window displays.

title: Ts the Season
description: Having a gang of style-centric girlfriends to shop for means gifts have to be three things: penny-wise, clever and no-fuss cool. Chlo Sevigny for Opening Ceremonys capsule T-shirt collection (openingceremony.us), screen printed with Robert Mapplethorpe photographs and available next month (preorder and give an I.O.U.), manages to be both street savvy and seasonal  no easy feat. There are so many to choose from, Sevigny says.I think they all hold a bit of his magic. For your other eclectic pals, here are some other suggestions:

title: Lotus Hires Former BMW and Ferrari Executives
description: Lotus Cars announced two new high-level executive hirings. The news confirms a widespread impression that the sports car company is making an aggressive effort to expand sales  an effort signaled by the hiring of a new design chief, Donato Coco, roughly a year ago and the unveiling of multiple new models  Elise, Elan, Esprit, Elite, and Eterne  at the Paris auto show in September.

title: Buffett Helps Create Nuclear Fuel Bank
description: Spurred by a pledge of $50 million from Warren E. Buffett, the billionaire investor and philanthropist, the board of the International Atomic Energy Agency voted Friday to set up a global nuclear fuel bank that aspiring nations can turn to for reactor fuel instead of making it themselves.

title: Holiday Windows Can Be a Harsh Mirror
description: Silver-clad galaxy hoppers gaze idly through telescopes or space visors amid a Jules Verne fantasy world in which nothing is as it seems: The gears on a wheel are the teeth of a sawfish, hanging crystals of ice are glittering jewels and the spines of an alligator are polished white shells, which in turn resemble the skyline of a futuristic city. Bergdorf Goodman credits the fashion to Marc Jacobs, Isaac Mizrahi and CD Greene. The drugs used to achieve the psychedelic effect however go unnamed  sadly, as that is one product that no store would have trouble moving.

title: Blue Skies and Blue-Chip Sales at Art Basel Miami
description: MIAMI BEACH  Wind, rain and even snow left some collectors making the pilgrimage to Art Basel Miami Beach stranded for hours at airports in New York and Europe. But here, except for a few showers on Wednesday afternoon, the sun shone brightly, as if to demonstrate how much the little strip of South Beach, which each December becomes the setting for an art-world bacchanalia of buying, selling and socializing, is a place apart from the rest of the country, where unemployment and financial anxiety linger.

title: Lisa Neumann, Ian Weston
description: Lisa Anne Neumann, the daughter of Susan Neumann and Edward H. Neumann of North Potomac, Md., was married Saturday evening to Ian Philip Weston, the son of Joyce S. Weston and Burton S. Weston of Great Neck, N.Y. Rabbi Marim D. Charry officiated at the Marriott Wardman Park hotel in Washington. Cantor Henrique Ozur Bass took part in the ceremony.

title: Marie Wilson, Jorge Espinel
description: Marie Helen Wilson and Jorge Espinel were married Friday at the Municipal Marriage Bureau in New York. Blanca Martinez, an employee of the City Clerks office, officiated.

title: Kathleen Morris, Robert Kraus
description: Kathleen M. Morris and Robert D. Kraus were married Saturday at the Williams College Faculty Club in Williamstown, Mass. Rabbi Jeffrey W. Goldwasser officiated.

title: Jana Singer and Larry Sidman
description: Jana Beth Singer and Larry Richard Sidman were married Saturday evening at the Ritz-Carlton hotel in Washington. Rabbi William D. Rudolph officiated, with the assistance of Cantor Abraham Lubin.

title: Ellen Tobin and Todd Kaminsky
description: Ellen Betsy Tobin and Todd David Kaminsky were married Saturday evening at the Fresh Meadow Country Club in Lake Success, N.Y. Rabbi Moshe Schwartz performed the ceremony, with Cantor Bette Cohen taking part.

title: Gina Miller, James Neale
description: Gina Miller and James Wyatt Neale were married Monday in Flippen Park in Highland Park, Tex. Judge John Peyton, of the Probate Court of Dallas County, officiated. On Saturday, the Rev. S. M. Wright II, a Baptist minister, performed a ceremony that included Jewish traditions at Casa de Mita, a hotel in Punta Mita, Mexico.

title: Hannah Gaw, Andrew Richardson
description: Hannah Elizabeth Gaw and Andrew Garmory Richardson were married Saturday evening at St. Mary of the Assumption Roman Catholic Church in Brookline, Mass. The Rev. Brian M. Clary, the churchs pastor, performed the ceremony.

title: Catherine OConnor and Michael Devine
description: Catherine Ryan OConnor and Michael Gerald Devine were married Saturday at St. Joan of Arc Church in Orleans, Mass. The Rev. Robert J. Powell, a Roman Catholic priest and the churchs pastor, performed the ceremony, with Msgr. Richard Malone, the great-uncle of the bridegroom, taking part.

title: Judging The Bodies In Ballet
description: Go to any gallery and you see how painters and sculptors for centuries have made fat an issue. The nudes of Titian, Rubens, Rembrandt and Renoir show women with curves that are no longer part of any fashionable idea of beauty. Venus or Diana had a belly like that? I love most of them myself, but I have friends who object. Either way, all of us acknowledge that weight plays a part in our response.

title: (Non)Rumors Over Non-Papers at Climate Talks
description: Dec. 4, 7:34 p.m. | Updated CANCN, Mexico  At almost every negotiation in recent years aimed at building a new international climate agreement, a batch of delegates and United Nations officials huddle at the end of the first week to start framing some kind of text. The diplomatic term of art for such documents is non-paper. The idea is to have something readyfor high-level officials to firm up before the meeting ends a week later.

title: Budget-Cutting Colleges Bid Some Languages Adieu
description: Albany

title: Scott Brown Was an Outlier After All
description: A new poll from Public Policy Polling in Massachusetts suggests that Republican Senator Scott Brown  who represents one of the Democrats few opportunities to play offense in a cycle in which they hold more than two-thirds of the Senate seats that will be contested in 2012  is in relatively good shape for re-election. Against a series of potential Democratic opponents, he holds leads by margins ranging between 7 and 19 points, according to the survey.

title: The Hunt for Julian Assange
description: One big lesson from the WikiLeaks dump  of state department documents:  Weddings in Dagestan are insanely awesome.

title: Chronicle of a Changing City
description: THE PARK AVENUE CHRISTMAS LIGHTS are a tradition that goes back to 1945, when a group of neighborhood families arranged to put up majestic fir trees on the avenues central malls to honor soldiers who died in World War II. The group turns on the lights on the first Sunday of December, after a festive ceremony outside the Brick Presbyterian Church at 91st Street. Early on, the cost was paid by the founding families. Nowadays, the $10,000 tab is picked up by the Fund for Park Avenue, which also maintains the mall plantings, and whose lighting committee includes Muffie Potter, David Rockefeller and Joanne Woodward, said the funds president, Barbara McLaughlin.

title: A Puppeteer and His Stick Friend
description: Basil Twist, 41, is a third-generation puppeteer who spends roughly half the year on the road and the other half in Greenwich Village, where he lives and works. He runs the Dream Music Puppetry Program at the Here Arts Center downtown, which presents his work and that of others. On Broadway, some of his most recent creations include puppets for The Pee-wee Herman Show and for the musical   For Mr. Twist, Sunday is often a work day, or a day to unpack. ISOLDE RAFTERY

title: China: 2 Intellectuals Barred From Leaving the Country
description: In two separate incidents on Thursday, Ai Weiwei, a prominent Chinese artist and frequent critic of the Chinese Communist Party, and Mao Yushi, an 80-year-old economist, were prevented from flying out of Beijing to cities in Asia, presumably because Chinese authorities are trying to keep Chinese intellectuals from attending the Nobel Peace Prize ceremony in Norway next Friday. The prize was awarded to a Chinese dissident, Liu Xiaobo, in early October. China is also preventing Mr. Lius wife, Liu Xia, from leaving the country to collect the prize. On Thursday, Mr. Ai was catching a flight to Seoul, South Korea, and Mr. Mao was going to Singapore. Both were stopped in the Beijing airport and told by the authorities that they could not travel because they might endanger state security. Mr. Ai said in a Twitter message that he had not intended to go to the Nobel ceremony but that he was instead traveling on a matter related to his art.

title: Jets Leonhard Breaks Leg in Collision at Practice
description: Jets safety Jim Leonhard broke his right leg in practice Friday, and it looks almost certain that he will miss the remainder of the season.

title: European Union Members Reach Deal to Enforce Driving Laws
description: The days of Europes motoring law free-for-all appear to be numbered. Under a deal reached on Thursday, the 27 nations of the European Union plan to step up cooperation in enforcing penalties levied for speeding or offenses like drunken driving and failing to wear seat belts. The agreement has been in the making for many years and is subject to approval by the European Parliament before becoming law. The new system  expected to come into force by 2013  would apply all over the bloc, except for Denmark, which has the ability to opt out on justice cooperation. Britain and Ireland, which also have special  though different  provisions, will decide whether to take part.

title: U.S. Aided Mexican Drug War, With Frustration
description: MEXICO CITY  More than a year ago  before drug cartels killed a gubernatorial candidate and began murdering mayors, before shootings and kidnappings in Mexicos industrial capital, Monterrey, surged to the point that the State Department ordered children of American diplomats there to leave the country  a Mexican official admitted that the government feared it could lose control of parts of the nation.

title: When Love Is in Transit
description: Buses  whether local or inter-city  seem to rank somewhere between the dentists office and the laundromat as likely backdrops for powerful emotion. Who falls in love, erupts in rage, experiences an epiphany on a bus? More people than you might think, at least according to the following poems found last week in the Missed Connections section of newyork.craigslist.org. They are printed verbatim, with only line and stanza breaks added. The titles are the subject headings. ALAN FEUER

title: Weekly Pick Em: Championship Saturday
description: In the current college football era, where strength of schedule is just one of the factors determining where a team stands in the Bowl Championship Series rankings, those at the top can often find themselves rooting for already defeated opponents, hoping a win here or there will convince the computers metrics that their schedule is indeed stout. Well, on Saturday, none of that will matter. The equation will be much simpler for most teams: win a game and win a title. Oregon is an exception. If the Ducks beat Oregon State in the rivalry known as the Civil War, then they will merely secure a chance to win a title. Of course, it will be the B.C.S. championship. Auburn is hoping to join Oregon in that game, but first the Tigers will have to beat South Carolina and win the Southeastern Conference. Florida State and Virginia Tech, two teams that have improved as the season has gone on, will fight it out for the A.C.C. title, while the old foes Oklahoma and Nebraska will meet for one last time as members of the same conference, a fitting end to the Cornhuskers time in the Big 12. Connecticut will be looking to wrap up the most improbable B.C.S. berth in the country. If the Huskies beat South Florida, they will be Big East champions. Even without mathematical formulas, there is plenty at stake on Saturday.

title: A Happy Ending to a Raw, but Common, Tale
description: Lilla Roberts is a 73-year-old retired physical therapist, a pleasant, engaging woman who moved to this country from Jamaica 46 years ago. In 1988, she bought a small house in Jamaica, Queens, putting down $25,000, and taking out a mortgage for around $120,000. For many years, she religiously made her mortgage payments.

title: Video Eye Aimed at Teachers in 7 School Systems
description: As part of the project to develop new ways to evaluate teachers, researchers have recruited 3,000 teachers in seven school systems  Dallas; Denver; Charlotte, N.C.; Hillsborough County, Fla.; Memphis; New York; and Pittsburgh  who allowed themselves to be videotaped in their classrooms. (As part of the agreement, only researchers can view the tapes, not school administrators).

title: Teacher Ratings Get New Look, Pushed by a Rich Watcher
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  In most American schools, teachers are evaluated by principals or other administrators who drop in for occasional classroom visits and fill out forms to rate their performance.

title: Under Fire Since Explosion, Mining C.E.O. Quits
description: Don L. Blankenship, the embattled chief executive of Massey Energy, resigned Friday in a move that might enable the company to improve relations with federal regulators but might also hasten a takeover.

title: Panel Votes to Expand Surgery for Less Obese
description: A federal advisory panel Friday endorsed an expansion of the use of Allergans Lap-Band stomach-restricting device to patients who are less than severely obese.

title: Groupon Said to Reject Googles Offer
description: 11:37 p.m. | Updated  Groupon has walked away from Googles $6 billion takeover offer, according to a person close to Groupon. The rejection at least temporarily thwarts Googles efforts to buy the social buying site, which would have been its largest acquisition to date.

title: Football Coaches Say Dont Overlook Small-Town Players
description: ST. PAUL  In his three years on the University of St. Thomas football team, quarterback Dakota Tracy has heard all kinds of remarks about his tiny hometown, Geneva, Minn., which has a population of 449. Because he shares a house with three teammates, all from Twin Cities suburbs, the ribbing can be relentless.

title: Two Communiqus, and a Commanders Dilemma
description: Charleston Harbor, S.C., Dec. 4, 1860

title: Once in Glare of the Media, Club Owner Is Now a Critic
description: BOSTON  The former owner of a nightclub in Rhode Island who drew news media scrutiny when 100 people died at the club in a 2003 fire has quietly re-emerged as a media critic.

title: The Transformation of 42nd Street
description: A 30 year plan to make over 42nd St. is completed

title: New Subject of Debate on Mideast: Hummus
description: Forget Hezbollah and Hamas. The latest chapter in the Israeli-Arab conflict is all about hummus, the chickpea dip that is a staple of American college cafeterias.

title: 8 Urns in Unknown Grave at Arlington Spur Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON  The Army has opened a criminal investigation after the discovery of eight urns of cremated remains of soldiers in a grave marked unknown in Arlington National Cemetery, an Army official said this week.

title: Pfizer Plans $75 Million Fund to Address Shareholder Suits
description: Pfizer has agreed to set up a $75 million fund and to create a new compliance committee to settle shareholders lawsuits accusing the board and top officials of failing to stop illegal marketing of its drugs, according to a settlement agreement filed in United States District Court on Friday.

title: One Borough, Five Generations
description: Melanie Lefkowitzs family has had an enduring presence in Brooklyn since the early 20th century. She chronicles their lives in words and pictures.

title: Jokes and Secret Hopes for Lieutenant Governors
description: OMAHA  They have been disparaged as spare-tire politicians, kept in the dark and used only in emergencies. They have been dismissed as ribbon-cutting versions of the appendix, prominently situated but without any discernible function. And the office itself has been likened to a form of political purgatory, with occupants passing time hoping for some outside force to elevate them.

title: BP Is Planning to Challenge Estimates of Oil Spill
description: BP intends to challenge official government estimates of how much oil leaked from its runaway well in the Gulf of Mexico, a move that could reduce its legal liability by billions of dollars, according to documents the company filed with the presidential commission investigating the spill.

title: Herms Falls as Holders Discuss Takeover Defense
description: Shares of Herms International fell 9.3 percent in Paris on Friday as members of the companys controlling family met to discuss their strategy for fending off the unwelcome interest of Bernard Arnault, the chief of LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton. Hermss limited-partnership structure and the combined 73 percent stake held by the Puech, Guerrand and Dumas families make it impossible for an outsider to gain control against their wishes. But the families are considering ways to ensure that they can sell shares as needed without allowing Mr. Arnault to increase his stake. Mr. Arnault has made a career of acquiring family-owned businesses on his way to creating the worlds biggest luxury group. He surprised the company in late October with the disclosure that he had acquired 17.1 percent of its shares. A spokeswoman for Herms declined to comment on the meeting Friday.

title: Surviving a Job Loss, and a Familys Devastation
description: Sitting in her living room in Ocean Hill, Brooklyn, Aldine Francois, 27, peeled layers of silk cloth away from a white book with golden pages. It was a photo album holding the most recent pictures she had of her mother, from a wedding in July 2009.

title: How Iran Derailed a Health Crisis
description: So how did Iran do it? How did a conservative theocracy decide to deal with its drug addicts as if it were Canada? In Tuesdays column, I wrote that Iran is treating its massive epidemic of injecting drug use mainly as a health problem. With this strategy, it has effectively managed to lower H.I.V. rates among drug users and keep the disease from spreading. It has taken an approach to drugs known as harm reduction, which includes the provision of methadone maintenance therapy and clean needles to drug users.

title: Walter Energy Will Buy Rival
description: Walter Energy, a coal producer, said on Friday that it had agreed to buy Western Coal of Canada in a deal that values the company at 3.3 billion Canadian dollars ($3.26 billion).

title: On Eve of Butler-Duke II, Passions Still Run Deep
description: There are few do-overs in sports, and Saturdays basketball game between Duke and Butler is not one, no matter how many times it is referred to as a rematch of Aprils national championship contest.

title: Tax-Cut Debate Turns to Millionaires
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Democrats on Friday denounced Republicans for insisting on continued tax breaks for millionaires and billionaires, even as they braced for the White House to make concessions that would allow an extension of the Bush-era tax cuts at all income levels.

title: A View of the Bronx, of the Past and of a Dream Reconsidered
description: A former colleague of my brothers recently called him to ask if he was, by any chance, related to someone by my name. My brother informed him (nervously, I am sure) that that person was his sister. Well, tell her I have some of her mail, came the reply.

title: From a Ski Resort, Djokovic Emerges as a Serbian Tennis Groundbreaker
description: KOPAONIK, Serbia  To begin to understand how a small, struggling nation like Serbia managed to reach its first Davis Cup final this weekend, you could interview Slobodan Zivojinovic, a big-serving Serbian trailblazer at Wimbledon and elsewhere before he became a portly tennis administrator and car salesman.

description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.
