title: Millions Bracing for Cutoff of Unemployment Checks
description: More than two million jobless Americans are entering the holiday season seized with varying levels of foreboding, worry or even panic over what lies ahead as they cope with the expected cutoff of their unemployment benefits.

title: If Its So Easy, Why Dont You Try It
description: POSTHUMOUS fame and high auction prices notwithstanding, the painter Jackson Pollock was not an uncontested genius during his lifetime. The critic Robert Coates once derided a number of Pollocks works as mere unorganized explosions of random energy, and therefore meaningless.

title: In a First for Obama, Nine Pardons Are Granted
description: WASHINGTON  For the first time since taking office nearly two years ago, President Obama exercised his clemency powers on Friday by granting pardons to nine people.

title: The Show Must Go On
description: IN September, officials at the 61-year-old Surflight Theater in Beach Haven announced that they needed $500,000 by Oct. 31 to keep it from closing. Fund-raising efforts came up short  some $300,000 has been raised to date  but the theaters annual Holiday Spectacular is going on anyway.

title: Singing His Way Toward the Big Break
description: Before the advent of reality TV, YouTube and American Idol  the distant early 1980s  practically the only route for a show-business hopeful to stardom in New York was by pounding the pavement with a handful of 8 x 10 head shots and a heart full of dreams. And thats the time, place and essential story of ...And Then I Wrote a Song About It.

title: A Silicon Bubble Shows Signs of Reinflating
description: In a memorable scene in the The Social Network, the actor Justin Timberlake, who portrays the Silicon Valley investor Sean Parker in the movie, leans over the table and tells the founders of Facebook in a conspiratorial tone: A million dollars isnt cool. You know whats cool? A billion dollars.

title: Back to the Barricades: Les Miz Reworked at 25
description: Susan Boyle has ruined it for all future Fantines. When Betsy Morgan, for instance, a mere wisp of a young woman, opens her mouth to sing the character Fantines solo, I Dreamed a Dream, in Les Misrables, at the Paper Mill Playhouse, at least half the audience has to be thinking about Ms. Boyles stunning 2009 performance of that song on Britains Got Talent (78 million YouTube views so far). And wondering why this actress is so vocally demure in comparison.

title: Washington: Court-Martial for Soldier
description: A second of five soldiers accused in the killings of three Afghan civilians has been referred to an Army court-martial. The soldier, Specialist Adam C. Winfield, is accused of shooting an unarmed man after his unit leader, who is also accused in the killings, reportedly detonated a grenade to fake a combat situation. The other three cases are pending. The killing happened months after Specialist Winfields parents have said they tried to warn military officials that their son was concerned about unjustified killings by his unit.

title: Trying Not to Let the Color Show
description: Normally its a touching Hallmark-card kind of scene. A glamorous mother at her dressing table, doing her hair and makeup for a dinner party, while her daughter looks on.

title: A Diner That Was the Special of Every Day
description: Its purpose on this planet is bluntly advertised on the outdoor sign: Breakfast-Lunch-Dinner.

title: New Jersey Closer to Sales of Medical Marijuana
description: A standoff between Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey and advocates for medical marijuana has ended in a compromise that could put marijuana on the market for seriously ill patients by next summer.

title: Parent Sues to Block Schools Chief
description: The father of two Brooklyn public school children filed a lawsuit against state education officials on Friday to stop Cathleen P. Black, a publishing executive, from becoming the next New York City schools chancellor.

title: Lottery Numbers
Former Yeshiva Principal Sought on Abuse Charges
description: A former Brooklyn yeshiva principal and three of his sons sexually abused four of the principals other children, molesting one of the victims over 15 years, the authorities said Friday.

title: Hanging Out at Elaines
description: Elaine Kaufmans Upper East Side restaurant was a joint that all but shouted New York to the rest of the country, if not the world.

title: Saturday: Red Flags Purpose
description: If such a thing were possible, it would be nice to have red flags warning us of the difficulties lurking in a puzzle. Today, I ran into trouble in the lower right, then upper right, middle, lower left and finally in the red-flag-worthiest upper left.

title: Messiah, Modest or Mighty
description: SINCE its premiere in 1742, Handels Messiah has been interpreted, reinterpreted and, some say, misinterpreted so many times that its identity has become muddled. But that is not stopping two of Connecticuts major orchestras, joined by leading choirs, from weighing in with their own versions of the piece  versions that contrast markedly in scale and style.

title: Detective Faces Charges of False Drug Arrests
description: An undercover New York City police detective assigned to an embattled narcotics unit in Queens has been charged with falsely accusing five men of selling drugs to him, according to a 48-count indictment unsealed last month in Queens.

title: Maps for Navigating to a New Perspective
description: What are maps for? Of course, you think you know, and so did I  until I found my way to Mapping: Memory and Motion in Contemporary Art, at the Katonah Museum of Art. The works in this terrific exhibition offer so many takes on the subject that you feel your personal definition of cartography exploding as you walk  with no map to guide you  through the galleries.

title: A Tale That Rings With a Familiar Sound
description: The Sound of Music made the news in October, when the core cast members of the movie version visited The Oprah Winfrey Show for a 45th-anniversary reunion, during which Christopher Plummer, who played the role of Capt. Georg von Trapp, admitted that, yes, he had called the musical the name long attributed to him, The Sound of Mucus.

title: The Junkie and the Atheist
description: As an Irish-American, I dont usually trumpet the work of a nation that kept my ancestors under its boot heel for nearly 300 years. But having just finished the memoirs of two great exports of Britain, I rise to praise a pair of Brits in the season of book-buying.

title: Shop, Shop, Shop, Then Eat, or Even Dine
description: AT Fratelli Trattoria, an 18-month-old Italian restaurant in the Tanger Outlets at the Arches in Deer Park, diners are presented with a choice. As they enter the spacious foyer, they can turn right to order pizza by the slice at the counter, with catch-as-catch-can seating at five tables in front. Or they can turn left, to be seated by a hostess in a full-service restaurant with a menu featuring entrees like chicken mezzaluna with asparagus in white wine sauce.

title: The First Lady of First Editions
description: Greg Lawrences Jackie as Editor (St. Martins/Thomas Dunne Books, $26) is the first biography of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis dedicated to her 19-year publishing career, which began in 1975 with a $200-a-week editorial job at Viking. (A head honcho at Random House had politely turned her down.) Lawrence credits Kennedy with publishing 97 books, including many on dance  memoirs by Martha Graham and Gelsey Kirkland, and a collection of Pushkin fairy tales prefaced by Rudolf Nureyev. If you produce one book, she said, you will have done something wonderful in your life.

title: Its a Small Town After All
description: RARELY has a town been conceived and constructed in the glare of publicity and aura of hope that greeted Disneys master-planned, picture-perfect village of Celebration in central Florida. Expectations were so high that, in November 1995, 4,000 people entered into a lottery for the chance to win the right to pay 25 percent over the market price to move into one of the first 500 or so homes.

description: Allison Moultry needed many things in November 2009: surgery to treat a pulmonary artery aneurysm; a doctor to diagnose the lump in her breast; and help paying bills after her heart condition meant she could not do her job as a day care provider. She did not need bedbugs.

title: Mick Without Moss
description: On the top floor of a photography studio somewhere in Chelsea, Mick Jagger is capering about to a sleepy reggae cover of Eleanor Rigby. The photographer has requested mischief, and Jagger is gamely attempting to provide some  pouting, smirking, stomping his feet and shrugging his shoulders in a style that is part hipster frug, part Rumpelstiltskin tantrum. He is wearing clumpy black Nikes, electric green and black socks and drainpipe jeans in a Prince of Wales plaid. (Earlier, when he arrived at the studio, he had on a shiny, aubergine-colored John Pearse jacket with camouflage lining, but this, sadly, has now been replaced by a rather more subdued Alexander McQueen drape coat.)

title: Sam Wyche Recalls a Frantic No-Huddle Moment
description: With college teams faking injuries to stop Oregons no-huddle spread offense, the former Cincinnati Bengals coach Sam Wyche can understand how the Ducks must feel. In the N.F.L. playoffs after the 1988 season, Wyche recalled how Seattle Seahawks nose tackle Joe Nash repeatedly fell to the ground on second down to slow Cincinnatis no-huddle spread.

title: Photo Replay: Dec. 3
description: A view of the day in sports, including highlights from the Davis Cup.

title: Orender Will Resign W.N.B.A. Post
description: Donna Orender announced she was stepping down as president of the W.N.B.A. after six seasons. She will continue to work for the league as a consultant as she begins a marketing and strategy company. Orender presided over six years of modest growth for the W.N.B.A., with increases in attendance and sponsorship.

title: In Good Paste
description: It was too early in the day for a drink, which was a shame, because the image of Lauren Santo Domingo tending a Lalanne hippo bar would have been amazing. Instead, Santo Domingo and I got drunk on her mountain of scrapbooks -- visual cocktails spilling over with inspiration, literally. "I'm working on a rooftop garden in Paris, so I sent this topiary picture to Madison" -- that would be Madison Cox -- "who's designing it," Santo Domingo narrated, flipping through the sketchbooks she jams with magazine clippings. Crudely cropped and pasted down, the tear sheets are arranged with an art director's eye for winking juxtapositions, making Santo Domingo a kind of Alexey Brodovitch, if Alexey Brodovitch had been an "It" girl.

title: Full House
description: Down by the Hudson in an old Manhattan pickle factory lives a widow surrounded by a tyrants ransom in broken violins. Armand Fernandez, known as Arman since the day a printer left the D off his name in a catalog, was a founding member of the midcentury French New Realists and one of the giants of 20th-century art. His medium was objects and his process a focused attack that he called the pinnacle of a catharsis. His friend, the painter Yves Klein, told him when they were young, Ill take whats organic, you take whats manufactured. Klein invented his iconic International Klein Blue and died young; Arman squared off in violent yet precise acts against violins and guitars, shower hoses, sofas, paint tubes, bicycles, motorcycles, cars and statues, which he smashed, flattened, burned, sawed in half, cast in bronze and sliced, or sank into Perspex or concrete. His 1961 manifesto was titled The Realism of Accumulations, and when he wasnt destroying to create, he made harmonic sequences, set on wooden panels, of musical instruments (whole or chopped), watch faces, trumpets, ladles, gas masks, typewriters, saws and paintbrushes. An Arman retrospective, at the Pompidou Center in Paris through Jan. 10, gives some idea of his range, output and influence on artists as diverse as Jeff Koons and Damien Hirst, but it cannot, for practical reasons, include his 106-foot-high Hope for Peace, a concrete tower in Beirut, Lebanon, in which he buried 78 tanks, jeeps and various pieces of artillery.

title: The Gift of Reconciliation
description: As the ocean liner steamed in from the open sea and approached the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, the boy worried that the ships superstructure would not clear. It was a cold, sunny winter day, Wednesday, the 22nd of December, 1965, he said. There are certain dates etched in your memory. His journey to America had begun in Egypt, where his father was a leading religious figure. The image of the Statue of Liberty came into view slowly ... such majesty and beauty. It was a life-changing moment in my life. I was 17 years old. That Feisal Abdul Raufs American story began off the southern tip of Manhattan can seem foreordained, in light of the controversy that consumed him 45 years later. At his first glimpse of his new world, he told me, I had an intuition that my work would involve introducing Islam to America. Yet at that point, young Rauf was himself in the throes of typical adolescent questioning. In such a free society  it was the 60s!  religion had become a matter of choice. Not so in Kuwait, where he was born, and where religion was inherited. In America, religion was pass. I was bewildered by all that. I was asking, Does God exist? What is the meaning of life? And I found the answers to my religious questions as a matter of choice. I could choose to embrace my Muslim faith  and I did. That simply, Feisal Abdul Rauf glimpsed the meaning of the nations defining freedom. America made it possible for me to freely and deliberately choose to be religious and Muslim. Rauf would become an American citizen in 1979.

The staid, sculptured bumps of hair looked painfully anachronistic, and just like that, a trend that seemed fresh on Pradas fall runway came tumbling down. For all the talk of the beehive this fall, no ones really wearing it, says Orlando Pita, who created the edgy style on the previous page. The big editorial up-do doesnt translate into real life. Accordingly, at the spring shows, hair started to come undone. There were long, partial plaits at Givenchy, sex-kitten tousles at Isabel Marant and half-up-half-down dos at Miu Miu and Christopher Kane, while the rocker chicks at Balmain looked like they had just rolled out of bed. For Pita, the new down-do is all about texture. Weve seen perfectly blown out, silicone-sleek hair for so long, he says. The new texture doesnt look so worked on. Its all in the brushing and the products you use. Pita sprays Elevate, a texturizer from his own line, into wet hair and dries it using his fingers to encourage the natural wave. (Everyone has one.) Next, he sprays dry shampoo (his version is called Refresh) onto the roots (avoiding the top of the head) in one-inch sections. Finally, he gently brushes it out with a Mason Pearson brush, fluffing the hair so it feels soft, not tacky with product. I call it the anti-blow dry.

title: Editors Letter
description: Last July, I rode my bicycle down to the Bowery to be photographed sitting on a paper moon. The photographer was Alice OMalley, whose pictures of downtown personalities hung recently at MoMA P.S. 1, and her price for a Polaroid was $20. I felt as though I had been given the perfect gift  a sentimental miniature by a great artist for a song  and one that I will pass on to my sons. I thought about Alice and her moon when we began planning this holiday issue; I wanted to convey that magical sense of being in the presence of someone who is truly gifted, and being allowed to walk away from the experience with something very special. She was one of the first people I called; the result is a breathtaking portfolio of intriguing and talented beauties in wistful resort frocks, which Alice produced with the fashion editor Susan Winget.

title: Gifted | Lindsey Wixson, Mathieu Lehanneur and Gaspar No
description: LINDSEY WIXSONHaving walked in all the big shows, including Prada, Chanel and Marc Jacobs, and done campaigns for Miu Miu, Versace and John Galliano, Wixson is the breakout model of the year.

title: Sunday: On a Roll
description: Note: This puzzle may be solved in Across Lite or the Java applet as a normal crossword. However, since it contains bonus elements that cannot be rendered electronically, we encourage solvers to print out the PDF that is also being offered.

title: Haunted by Attack, Few Return to Island
description: YEONPYEONG ISLAND, South Korea  Sitting in front of his home, Chang Woon-il looked almost out of place, a lonely human figure on a street where stray dogs wandered among the abandoned and broken houses. Nor was he intending to stay very long. Wielding a stubby knife, Mr. Chang, a 64-year-old fisherman, quickly shucked oysters as he hurried to gather as much food as he could before catching the next ferry out.

title: Why Iran Loves WikiLeaks
description: THE editor of WikiLeaks, Julian Assange, has much in common with the anarchists of the early 20th century: he aims to disrupt the established order by impairing its alliances and violating its proprieties. With the release of a quarter-million documents written by American diplomats at home and abroad, many of them shockingly candid, he has gone some distance toward accomplishing this. Take the Middle East, for example.

title: All or Nothing = Nothing
description: Washington

title: Killing Reveals Truths of Life at Limelights Edge
description: LOS ANGELES  Ronni Chasen could be loud. And she pushed.

title: For Pentagon Lawyer Who Co-Wrote Report on Gays, Military Bias Hits Home
description: WASHINGTON  Few officials have had to handle more legal mayhem and institutional queasiness at the Pentagon this year than Jeh C. Johnson, the Defense Departments general counsel and a co-author of an intensely debated new report on the effects of allowing openly gay men and women to serve in the United States military.

title: What if the Secrets Stayed Secret?
description: I READ the Monday New York Times with what can only be described as a sinking feeling.

title: Protecting Online Privacy
description: The Federal Trade Commission has come up with timely recommendations to protect privacy online.

title: Senator at the Luau
description: The emblematic dish of Hawaii is kalua pig, baked whole in a pit with ti leaves and lava rocks. It is perfect both as party food and political metaphor, for a state that has been living for 50 years on heaping helpings of federal largess. The people of Hawaii are the No. 1 per-capita recipients of Congressional earmarks, thanks largely to their beloved senior senator, Daniel Inouye.

title: Mothers Call Led to Rescue of 10 Children From Smugglers in Phoenix, Officials Say
description: PHOENIX  It could have been mistaken for a day care center, with so many children of all ages inside. But the authorities said that the crowded house in a working-class neighborhood here was really a drop point for a human-smuggling operation and that the 10 children, ages 2 to 17, were illegal immigrants being held for ransom.

title: Buying Rice  With Your Cell Phone
description: My Sunday column is about the use of cell phones to fight poverty by bringing banking services to the unbanked. Ive long been fascinated the the power of microsavings and financial services for the poor, but the problem has always been what platform to use. Most microfinance institutions arent even allowed to accept savings deposits, because for that they would need a banking license.

title: Critics Accuse Group of a Serious Texas Sin: Forgetting the Alamo
description: SAN ANTONIO  For 105 years, a private organization of women descended from Texas pioneers has been taking care of the Alamo with very little oversight by the state.

title: James P. Simpson Dies at 87; Cleaned Up Galveston
description: Something of a relic of the speakeasy era, Galveston County, Tex., was dotted with gambling dens, prostitution parlors and illegal nightclubs well into the 1950s  a time when it was still against state law to sell liquor by the drink. (You could buy a bottle, brown-bag it into a club and order ice.)

title: Richard N. Goldman, Civic Leader and Patron, Dies at 90
description: Richard N. Goldman, a San Francisco civic leader and philanthropist best known for co-founding the Goldman Environmental Prize, which is given to six grass-roots environmental activists every year, died Monday at his home in San Francisco. He was 90.

title: Sweat | Cold Weather, Hot Handball
description: Handball is New York Citys quintessential street game, and for nearly a century, the city has produced many of the best players in the world.

title: State Cuts Put Officers on Front Lines of Mental Care
description: PORTLAND, Me.  As community mental health systems fray under the strain of state budget cuts and a weak economy, law enforcement officers across the nation are increasingly having to step in to provide the emergency services that clinics have typically offered the mentally ill.

title: Neediest | Bridging a Community
description: With help from The Neediest Cases Fund, a Yiddish language group for fixed income seniors at The Edith and Carl Marks Jewish Community House in Brooklyn was able to continue weekly meetings.

title: Truth and Plea Bargains
description: The value of DNA testing to clear the unjustly convicted is well known. That did not stop the Bush administration from bullying defendants who pleaded guilty to waive their right to seek such testing. Attorney General Eric Holder made the right choice last week, ordering the Justice Department to drop this policy.

description: Caprera, Italy, Dec. 5, 1860

description: To the Editor:

title: With Lead in California, Woods Pursues No. 1 Ranking
description: THOUSAND OAKS, Calif.  On Saturday at the Chevron World Challenge, nobody caught Tiger Woods, who is in hot pursuit of top-ranked Lee Westwood a half a world away.

title: Auburn Coasts to a Date With Oregon
description: ATLANTA  All season, Cam Newton has been college footballs most prominent drama major. But whether it was N.C.A.A. investigators or opposing defenses, Newton has shown an uncanny ability to elude obstacles in his path.

title: Falling Into the Partisan Trap
description: To the Editor:

title: Putting a Living Face on the Nameless Dead
description: It was a midmorning in early September when two strawberry pickers at a Watsonville farm were struck by an odor wafting from an overgrown ditch.

title: Seed of a Future Defeat Lies in Victories by 4 West Texas Lawmakers
description: Ross Ramsey, managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column

title: Whistle-Blower Shows Courage at Center of White Sox Kickback Scheme
description: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative

title: As Venture Capital Business Changes, Elite Firms Move to Keep Their Edge
description: Jonathan Weber writes a regular column for The Bay Citizen

title: State Charges for Records Hurt Media
description: The goal of the legislation was lofty: to help people who have been exonerated clear their criminal records, quickly and completely. The unexpected result? News organizations must pay hundreds of dollars in monthly fees to access the states criminal records database.

title: Sorting Out Whos Who for Council
description: Labor and business leaders are busy sifting through questionnaire responses from the record crop of would-be aldermen to determine which of the challengers might be friendly to their agendas and could mount viable campaigns.

title: Nonprofit Groups Saw Flags Before School Payment Scandal
description: San Francisco school officials, including Superintendent Carlos A. Garcia, received warnings that a group of administrators in charge of after-school programs used questionable accounting practices while handling millions of dollars in district money, according to senior executives with community organizations.

title: In East Texas, Piles of Wood Look Like an Electric Opportunity
description: Driving his mud-spattered Suburban through a wood storage yard, Danny Vines gestured out the window at piles of lopped-off logs and bushy materials.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: The Texas Shuffle
description: Weve all walked into a record store looking for one thing and left with another. As quaint as that may seem in the digital age, record store clerks are the original purveyors of If you like ... They get to know your tastes and revel in suggesting albums they think you will enjoy. At the few surviving mom-and-pops, where the owners and employees are typically the best authorities on their local music scene, those referrals are often for albums made by musicians down the block or around the corner  although you may never have heard of them.

title: Crabbers
description: Crab season is here and Spud Point Crab Company, based in Bodega Bay, is enjoying its best run in more than seven years. Fishing offshore for up to 36 hours at a time, its five boats set traps and collect up to 8,000 pounds of Dungeness crabs before returning to their dock.

title: For the Ultimate, Intimate Concert, Host It Yourself
description: As the time comes to gather with friends and family around a warm hearth, consider this: home holds the heart, but it may also hold your next concert.

title: Trying to Ignite Spark of Revival in a Grim Gary
description: Anthony Broadnax clambered up the stairs of a vacant brick building in Gary, Ind., on Thursday, stepping through rubble left by thieves who had ransacked the structure for copper. The thick burgundy carpet was littered with trophies, microwave popcorn and plastic flowers.

title: As Bullies Go Digital, Parents Play Catch-Up
description: Ninth grade was supposed to be a fresh start for Maries son: new school, new children. Yet by last October, he had become withdrawn. Marie prodded. And prodded again. Finally, he told her.

title: Mounting Debts by States Stoke Fears of Crisis
description: The State of Illinois is still paying off billions in bills that it got from schools and social service providers last year. Arizona recently stopped paying for certain organ transplants for people in its Medicaid program. States are releasing prisoners early, more to cut expenses than to reward good behavior. And in Newark, the city laid off 13 percent of its police officers last week.

title: Pushing a Right to Bear Arms, the Sharp Kind
description: PHOENIX  Arizona used to be a knife carriers nightmare, with a patchwork of local laws that forced those inclined to strap Buck knives or other sharp objects to their belts to tread carefully as they moved from Phoenix (no knives except pocketknives) to Tempe (no knives at all) to Tucson (no knives on library grounds).

title: A Range of Options for a Victims Parents
description: When a child becomes entangled in an online conflict, parents understandably feel stricken. But they do not need to panic, experts say. Increasingly, parents have options, ranging from giving their child emotional support to contacting schools and the police, as well as Web sites and service providers, most of whom are tightening their processes to handle complaints.

title: For 2nd Year, Younger Women Beat Older Men at Czech Event
description: In chess, men almost always outperform women, and younger players often beat older ones. But which group  women or older players  has the advantage when they face each other?

title: Helen Boatwright, Celebrated Soprano, Dies at 94
description: Helen Boatwright, an American soprano renowned for her interpretations of Charles Ives, died on Wednesday in Jamesville, N.Y., outside Syracuse. She was 94 and had lived nearby in Fayetteville, N.Y.

title: College Football Replay, Dec. 4
description: A look at the days action in regular-season finales, conference championship games and the Football Championship Subdivision playoffs.

title: In a Hometown Parade, Posey Trumps Even Santa
description: LEESBURG, Ga.  The last float in Leesburgs 22nd Spirit of Christmas Parade, as always, was occupied Saturday by Santa Claus. It is the law, the mayor said jokingly.

title: Vows: Rachel and Ryan
description: It was a setup. A mutual  friend conspired for Rachel and Ryan to meet at a bridal shower. Despite rumors, he was not shy. They danced and talked until 3 a.m. and a fun romance was to follow.

title: Jeter Deal Done; Now Comes Hard Part
description: Derek Jeters signing with the Yankees is a reminder of what the pilot sometimes says over the intercom after he has landed the plane: the safest part of your day is now over.

title: A Shared Vision on Climate, With a Glitch
description: [Dec. 5, 10:35 a.m. | Updated Rajendra K. Pachauri, the chariman of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change has confirmed the small error in the draft described below. On Sunday morning, he told me he was contacting relevant officials about the need for correcting the wording that the statement uses.]

title: Gates Arrives in Oman
description: MUSCAT, Oman  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates arrived in Oman on Sunday as a jumping off point for a trip to the U.S.S. Abraham Lincoln, an aircraft carrier in the Arabian Sea used to launch air missions into Afghanistan.

title: Rhapsody in Green
description: Sharon Wauchob just presented her first collection as creative director for Edun, the socially conscious line founded by Bono and Ali Hewson and now partially owned by LVMH. The Madagascar-made organic poplin cotton dresses and Kenyan beadwork found in a number of her clothes made us think: who better to advise on greening up holiday packaging supplies? Wauchob suggests recycled tissues from Calligrane ($14 per sheet, 6 Rue du Pont Louis Philippe) and, for ribbons, old ripped T-shirts strung with locally produced African beads (beadsofparadisenyc.com). Recycling should be impulsive, she says, an intimate way to give a little bit more.

title: Fancy Free
description: This holiday season, designers are trading vertiginous heels for vamp-heavy embossed leather and flouncy Lurex flats. Prepare to be comfortably seduced.

title: The Democrats Tax Cut Dilemma
description: Saturday afternoon, the Senate failed to achieve cloture on a proposal to extend the Bush-era tax cuts for family incomes below $250,000 but end them for incomes above this threshold.

title: Historic Hong Kong Building Hosts Photo Festival
description: The imposing 19th-century Central Police Station is one of the few historic buildings of note left near SoHo, a Hong Kong quarter stuffed with bars, restaurants, galleries and boutiques. For years, it has been mostly left unused, despite various plans to turn it into a cultural center.

title: Wax Works
description: Isabel Toledo, long New Yorks most singular designer, makes magic with a Mizensir candle. I really wanted to tap the secret garden of my memories, says Toledo, recalling days spent in the Caribbean, where lemon trees and rosebushes are often in bloom together. The pairing never fails to lift my spirit.

title: Cash Flow to Terrorists Evades U.S. Efforts
description: WASHINGTON  Nine years after the United States vowed to shut down the money pipeline that finances terrorism, senior Obama administration officials say they believe that many millions of dollars are flowing largely unimpeded to extremist groups worldwide, and they have grown frustrated by frequent resistance from allies in the Middle East, according to secret diplomatic dispatches.

title: Europe Wary of U.S. Bank Monitors
description: WASHINGTON  When the European Parliament ordered a halt in February to an American government program to monitor international banking transactions for terrorist activity, the Obama administration was blindsided by the rebuke.

title: Meddling Neighbors Undercut Iraq Stability
description: WASHINGTON  Saddam Husseins Iraq was a regional menace that sent shudders through its neighbors. Todays Iraqi leaders are struggling to restrain the ambitions of the countries that share Iraqs porous borders, eye the countrys rich resources and vie for influence.

title: Straphangers
description: Whether your wheels are on a bike, car or train, you need the right bag for how you roll.

title: Watch Out for Online Scams This Holiday Season
description: The Internet security firm McAfee recently released a list of the online scams that consumers should be aware of this holiday season.

title: Ink: The New Accessory
description: Diamonds are forever  but so is pigment etched into skin. Once the province of sailors and bikers, the tattoo has recently been elevated to the runway (Louis Vuitton and Yves Saint Laurent) and to the days supermodels, like Catherine McNeil. Here, four artists suggest a few indelible additions to your jewelry box.

title: Shaping the Way
description: Suddenly everyone is talking about Thomas Tait, 23, the London-based Central Saint Martins graduate who in October, with barely two collections to his name, won the first-ever Dorchester Collection Fashion Prize. The Montreal-born Tait has yet to sell a single dress outside of private orders (some accessories are available through a project with Asos.com), but he says the prize money will enable him to begin proper production and retail sales. However, its his new friends, famous for their taste, who are likely to move his business along the most. Giles Deacon, Daphne Guinness, Stephen Jones and others selected him for the award; another judge, Manolo Blahnik, has been widely quoted gushing over Taits incredible couture mind.

title: From Boos to Boss as Giants Face Redskins
description: A pause in our coverage of the Northeast mini-Super Bowl  Jets-Patriots  to bring you a few recommended links on the Giants:

title: Capitalist Crusaders
description: Eleven years ago, Donna and Philip Berber had a Texas-size life  a booming tech company in Austin (Cybercorp), three sons and, you know, flowers in my garden, says Donna, who started A Glimmer of Hope, a foundation to help the rural poor in Ethiopia. Then, after seeing a video of his wife handing out bread to the hungry in Addis Ababa, Philip made a trip there himself and decided to turn my back on my commercial career. With $60 million from the recent sale of Cybercorp to Charles Schwab (for $488 million), he joined the foundation full time, and the couple (hes Irish, shes English) became pioneers of philanthro-capitalism. The Berbers endowment covers all of Glimmers operating costs, which has allowed the foundation to spend $40 million and counting to help alleviate poverty in Ethiopia. One hundred percent of the money, not 50 or 80 percent, needed to get to the people, says Philip, comparing Glimmers business model with that of other charities. We had to start with a clean piece of paper.

title: Laura & Adam
description: Adam Singh and Laura Darby Brown fell in love over a game of Dungeons and Dragons.  They continued their adventures in the Democratic Republic of Congo, studying chimpanzees.

title: What Does $60 Billion Buy?
description: In todays Week in Review section, I look at how else Congress could spend $60 billion a year  the annual cost of extending the Bush tax cuts on income above $250,000 a year. This post provides details on the calculations.

title: Gaylord Opryland Reopens
description: The Gaylord Opryland hotel in Nashville celebrated its reopening recently with three days of events that included country music concerts, a Christmas tree lighting and indoor fireworks at its Delta Atrium.

title: With Great Satire Comes Great Publicity: S.N.L. Sends Up the Spider-Man Musical
description: 11:38 a.m. | Updated

title: T Holiday Issue
description: The latest holiday issue of T makes its debut this weekend with Mick Jagger on the cover. At 67, Jagger, the iconic rocker/style-setter/knight of the cultural realm, shows no interest in raking over the past  a fitting idea for a newly redesigned T. Along with several retooled features, youll see plenty of fresh faces, among them Nicki Minaj, Reeve Carney, Sasha Pivovarova, Todd Selby and a full cast of up-and-comers in music, fashion, film and art. Theyre all gifted in some way, and theyre our holiday gifts, along with other offerings both ruminative  the Icelandic volcanos surprise gift of time, Wikilieaks not-always-welcome gift of information  and retail: Theres an eye-popping preview of the spring collections boldest moments; a portfolio of languid, ladylike dresses worn by fierce modern beauties like Maggie Gyllenhaal and Mila Kunis; and a guide to gifts so good you cant give just one.

title: An Endangered Butcher Gets His Groove Back
description: Updated, Tuesday, Dec. 7 | Six months or so ago, Jeffrey Ruhalter was a butcher in a deep funk, grappling with a sinking family business that dated back to his German great-great-grandfather in 1870. Jeffreys Meat Market is, he says, the last original tenant at the Essex Street Market on the Lower East Side, opened by his grandfather in 1940. The dynamics of change, along with the global economic downturn, had blindsided him.

title: Bookshelf
description: Jessica Kerwin Jenkinss Encyclopedia of the Exquisite (Doubleday, $28) collects historys most reverie-inducing marginalia  on subjects like milk baths, italic typefaces and blancmange, a silky almond pudding name-dropped by Chaucer. The same sun-baked optimism that sent The Girl From Ipanemainto the stratosphere also spawned some of the best album art ever, now compiled in Bossa Nova and the Rise of Brazilian Music in the 1960s (Soul Jazz Books, $40). Punta Arenas, Abomey, Alice Springs: the postmarks in Under the Sun: The Letters of Bruce Chatwin (Viking, $35) betray an epic case of wanderlust. When good triumphs over evil, the comic-book heroes of Marc Guggenheim and Tara Butterss Halcyon (Image Comics, $3.50) face an uncommon enemy: ennui. A monograph on the man who made Marilyns skirt billow: Sam Shaw (Hatje Cantz, $75). The Victorian hoop skirt, the Gibson Girl coif, the plume hat slouching over one winking eye  these and every other part of Gypsy Rose Lee are examined afresh by Karen Abbott in American Rose: A Nation Laid Bare (Random House, $26). And in We Have Met the Enemy: Self-Control in an Age of Excess (The Penguin Press, $27), Daniel Akst explains why theres a glut of everything these days  except willpower.

title: Disinflation Confirmed
description: One of the things you often hear is the claim that statistics showing falling inflation are just about housing. Via Mark Thoma, the San Francisco Fed has done the homework: the same downward trend is there if you purge housing from the core index:

title: King of the Jungle
description: A dark and stormy night: the clich has come to life, zombielike, and is clutching the party island of Bali in an intense and unseasonable monsoon. Ive had to bribe my cabby to get him to take me to a spooky gate on a lonely country road. You cant miss it, Bickerton, a reclusive artist, had assured me. I dont. Set into twin niches chiseled into the stelae that serve as gateposts are two severed heads. Gene Simmons-caliber tongues writhe from mouths agape in midscream, and only their neon complexions give them away as sculptures.

title: Not Crass, Class
description: Karl Smith sort of takes issue with my point about how Social Security is a favorite target of the Beltway crowd, because its not important to anyone they know. I doubt anyone thinks about it in such crass terms, he writes.

title: Final: Giants 31, Redskins 7
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The Giants 31-7 win over the Washington Redskins on Sunday was a showcase of dominating defense and a thundering rushing offense. But the victory was important because of what it signified for the Giants.

title: Undercut by Microsoft, Russia Drops Piracy Case
description: MOSCOW  The authorities have dismissed software piracy charges against one of Russias most well-known environmental groups after Microsoft indicated that it would no longer support the case.

title: G.O.P. Leader Sees Outline of Tax Deal
description: After thwarting efforts to raise taxes on Americas top earners, Sen. Mitch McConnell, the Republican leader, predicted Sunday that Congress would retain the expiring Bush-era tax cuts for a limited number of years and might also extend unemployment benefits as part of a compromise with the White House.

title: Another Look at the 2010 World Cup
description: The awarding of the 2018 and 2022 World Cups to Russia and Qatar is certain to change the way the world views the sport of soccer. These days, that metamorphosis is not limited to play on the field. In todays graphical world, computers and the human imagination have added a new dimension to objects as prosaic as the plain-vanilla tournament draw sheet.

title: Web Site for Teenagers With Literary Leanings
description: When Jacob Lewis helped create the beta version of the Web site Figment with Dana Goodyear, a staff writer at The New Yorker, Mr. Lewis envisioned it as a sort of literary Facebook for the teenage set.

title: Israel Credits Outside Help as Deadly Fire Is Contained
description: JERUSALEM  A deadly forest fire that had raged for four days in the parched north of Israel has been brought more or less under control, an Israeli police official said Sunday evening, crediting assistance from an international fleet of more than 30 firefighting aircraft and the so-called Supertanker, the worlds largest fire-extinguishing plane.

title: Ailey Continues to Build on Its Proud Tradition
description: Why does almost everyone who choreographs for Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater create work that looks as if its made for Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater: The Brand?

title: Pressure Rises to Bolster European Bailout Fund
description: European finance ministers are under mounting pressure to significantly increase the 750 billion-euro rescue fund for the currency union when they meet Monday.

title: Downsizing: When a Heavenly Body Got the Boot
description: The Caltech astronomy professor Mike Brown is not the first person to write about the rise of the planet Pluto (discovered in 1930 by Clyde Tombaugh) or its recent demotion (in 2006) to second-class citizenry in a newly reduced, eight-planet solar system. He may not even be the best, coming on the heels of Neil deGrasse Tysons breezy Pluto Files, the novel Percivals Planet and at least one other nonfiction book on the cosmic Pluto flap.

title: For One Team, a Pairs Title; For Another, an Early Exit
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  The Nick Nickell team did not threepeat in the Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams here on Sunday because it failed to qualify on Saturday. Leading the 10 teams that advanced to Sundays two sessions were Kevin Bathurst of New York; Daniel Zagorin of Skokie, Ill.; Bart Bramley of Dallas; Nikolay Demirev of Arlington Heights, Ill.; and Peter Bertheau and Fredrik Nystrom from Sweden.

title: On the Express Train to Hell and Other Sonic Journeys
description: The American Composers Orchestra has had to scale back its operations in recent seasons. This essential freelance ensemble, which has championed American music for 34 years, used to present up to five concerts a season at Carnegie Hall. Like many arts institutions facing economic hard times, it has adjusted. These days it offers a playfully billed series called Orchestra Underground at Zankel Hall, downstairs from Carnegies main hall.

title: A Trove of Ancient Silver Said to Be Stolen Returns to Its Home in Sicily
description: AIDONE, Italy  They came in throngs. On Friday afternoon hundreds of residents from this tiny hilltop town in eastern Sicily excitedly trekked up the steep slope to the towns archaeology museum to celebrate the return to Aidone of a treasure trove that was buried nearby some 2,200 years ago and illegally whisked away in more recent times.

title: The Click Fix
description: It was a dark December, decades ago, a beastly night of sleet and hail, a night to ruin your favorite boots. Needing gifts and needing them in a hurry, I dashed from drugstore to thrift shop to the fresh hell that is Macys at holiday time, in search of something that might slake the peculiar appetites of my peculiar circle. How pleasant to remember those desperate hours as I sit under an afghan, laptop on my knees! A few clicks are all it takes to find that for $150 bottegaveneta.com offers a woven-leather money clip, usa.hermes.com a ladybug key ring. Whats that  you hate obvious labels? Perhaps an exception can be made for a Lanvin Cabas tote that resembles a laundry bag, if that item were made of marine blue nylon and cost $840 at barneys.com? Or even a graffiti-bespeckled motorcycle helmet by Martin Margiela at aloharag.com? If you insist that your gangs predilections swerve away from capitalist exccess, send Walter Benjamins Arcades Project, 1,088 pages for $31 at www.hup.harvard.edu. But Americans defy categorization, and that same person enjoying Benjamin may be a defender of the Second Amendment, pouring port from a crystal decanter decorated with a shotgun-toting hunter from the old Park Avenue emporium scullyandscully.com. Or, if your posse prefers The Simpsons to Schopenhauer, try a pair of Bcassine plastic servant-girl earrings, invariably available on ebay.com. Dont think you know anyone who wants a pair of ear bobs based on a circa-1905 French comic-book scullery maid? Guess you havent peeked inside my jewelry box lately.

title: Soloists Take or Share the Spotlight as Needed
description: After two nights in the relatively intimate Zankel Hall, the musicians of the Risor Chamber Music Festival from Norway moved to the considerably larger Stern Auditorium on Friday night for the third of four concerts in its Carnegie Hall residency. The first half of the concert featured two world-class soloists in superb form; the second half, remarkably, was better still.

title: Its a Jungle Out There: Big Cats, Big Body Counts
description: Attention all water buffalo, impalas, zebras, ostriches, elephants and lizards: Run for your lives. Its Big Cat Week.

title: Fake Writer, Real Books? Thats Castle
description: On a recent episode of Castle, the cutesy ABC police procedural that is more gumdrop than gumshoe, a male stripper turns up dead after a night of carousing with some bachelorettes who are still drunk and memory-impaired from cheap tequila. Before long it is revealed that the stripper  who liked to dress up as a cop, carry a toy gun and call himself Officer McNaughty  was also involved in a real estate con. And this is where, from a critical perspective, things get problematic.

title: Navigating Past Nihilism
description: Nihilism stands at the door, wrote Nietzsche. Whence comes this uncanniest of all guests? The year was 1885 or 1886, and Nietzsche was writing in a notebook whose contents were not intended for publication. The discussion of nihilism  the sense that it is no longer obvious what our most fundamental commitments are, or what matters in a life of distinction and worth, the sense that the world is an abyss of meaning rather than its God-given preserve  finds no sustained treatment in the works that Nietzsche prepared for publication during his lifetime. But a few years earlier, in 1882, the German philosopher had already published a possible answer to the question of nihilisms ultimate source. God is dead, Nietzsche wrote in a famous passage from The Gay Science. God remains dead. And we have killed him.

title: Aquatic and Narcotic, Propelled by the Drummer
description: Its easy to be a great drummer by being loud, but Stella Mozgawa finds all the other ways. Shes dense, leaving little air in her patterns. Shes not overly forceful, sometimes sounding as if she were nudging the rhythm out. And shes reliably in the pocket, the steady force that sets the mood and pace for the rest of the band.

title: A Slow Weekend at the Box Office
description: The weekend after Thanksgiving is typically one of the slowest of the year at the North American box office, and the last three days proved no exception. The only sizable new release, The Warriors Way, a Relativity Media western designed as a vehicle for the South Korean superstar Jang Dong-gun, flopped badly with just $3 million in ticket sales. Most notable for the weekend was a film that opened in only 18 theaters: Darren Aronofskys Black Swan, a dark portrait of a ballet dancer (Natalie Portman), grossed $1.4 million for a per-theater average of $77,459  one of the best art-house results for the year and a record for the studio behind the film, Fox Searchlight. Over all Tangled (Walt Disney Studios), above, was No. 1 in its second weekend in theaters, selling $21.5 million for a new total of $96.5 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office statistics. Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1 (Warner Brothers) was second with $16.7 million for a three-week total of more than $244 million. The runaway-train thriller Unstoppable (20th Century Fox) lived up to its title, tying for third in its fourth week with about $6.1 million for a new total of $69 million. The musical Burlesque (Sony Pictures Entertainment) shared third-place ranking with $6.1 million of its own for a two-week total of $29 million. Love and Other Drugs (Fox) rounded out the top five with $5.7 million for a two-week total of $22.6 million.

title: Gala for Billy Crystal Will Benefit a Childhood Haunt
description: The Tisch School of the Arts will hold a benefit gala on Monday honoring Billy Crystal, the actor, writer and, apparently, amateur tap dancer. Proceeds from the performance will go toward renovating the schools original building at 111 Second Avenue, near Seventh Street in the East Village, also known as Central Plaza. It was there that Mr. Crystals father, Jack, produced The Sessions jazz concerts on Friday and Saturday nights from the late 1940s through the early 60s. In a telephone interview on Sunday, Mr. Crystal, right, emphasized the legacy of jazz, particularly Dixieland, that his father helped preserve there at a time when rock n roll was beginning to permeate the music scene. He also talked about his own ties to the building, referring to a world of these amazing musicians, their spirit, their sense of humor that, he said, first inspired him as a child to take the stage to tap-dance. But it was watching his father as the master of ceremonies that had the most profound effect on him. He was up onstage with a microphone, and I guess I wanted to do what he did, he said.  Whoopi Goldberg and Robin Williams will be among those paying tribute to Mr. Crystal at the gala, at Jazz at Lincoln Centers Frederick P. Rose Hall. They will be joined by several Tisch alumni, including James Franco, Marcia Gay Harden and Jesse L. Martin.

title: Stolen Russian Documents Are Recovered by the U.S.
description: Historic documents stolen from the national archives in Moscow and St. Petersburg between 1994 and 2002 were returned to Russia at a ceremony on Friday in Washington, the United States Immigration and Customs Enforcement Agency said in a statement on its Web site, www.ice.gov. The documents include a decree made by Catherine the Great in 1792 and a report, marked Top Secret, that was written by Gen. Vasily Blyukher in 1932 outlining the reconstruction of airfields. The documents were found for sale or loan for $300 to $15,000 each on five American Web sites. An investigation continues into several other stolen documents believed to have been smuggled into the United States.

title: Waste Land Finds Some Gold
description: Some lingering awards news to start your week. Late on Friday the International Documentary Association gave Waste Land its top honors of the year. The film, Lucy Walkers documentary about how a group of trash pickers in Brazil are transformed by working with the Brazilian artist Vik Muniz, won the best feature award as well as the Pare Lorentz Award. The International Documentary Association, a Los Angeles-based group, last year picked Anvil! The Story of Anvil, which was snubbed by the Academy, for its highest prize. title: Marco Brambillas Evolution (Megaplex)
description: Anyone whos ever taken the elevator at the Standard Hotel in New York will be familiar with the work of the artist Marco Brambilla. His kaleidoscopic video piece Civilization  a film collage loosely depicting the journey from purgatory to celestial heights  has been wowing hotel guests since 2009. Following a recent collaboration with Kanye West for his video Power, Brambilla has now taken his manic motion picture collageing to a new level and has produced arguably the first 3D video art piece ever. Evolution (Megaplex) is a three-minute-long three-dimensional firework of images, scenes, and clips culled from an archive of over a thousand movies, ranging from Hollywood blockbusters (E.T., Mad Max, Star Wars) to cult classics (Idiocracy, Zardoz, Salo)  all set to a score of a bombastic rendition of Prokofievs Romeo and Juliet. During the poolside screening at the Standard Spa Hotel in Miami last Friday, guests including Jeffrey Deitch, Bob Colacello, Jefferson Hack, Michael Stipe and Cecilia Dean sported especially designed Armani Exchange 3-D glasses and turned the event into a quiz of sorts, trying to identify different bits and pieces. (Was that Klaus Kinski in a loincloth, or a nubile Sting? And what movie was the woman riding a giant phallus taken from?)

title: Sad Day for Terriers, but Dexter Lives On to Kill Again
description: Its either a terrible day or a great day to be the creator of a cult cable-television series. FX announced on Monday that it would not be ordering a second season of Terriers, its series about a former detective (played by Donal Logue) and an ex-burglar (Michael Raymond-James) trying to make it as private investigators in San Diego. The show, created by Ted Griffin, the Oceans Eleven screenwriter, and whose producers included Shawn Ryan, the creator of The Shield, was well reviewed at its debut in September. Ginia Bellafante in The New York Times  called it a welcome love child, one we are eager to embrace rather than put up for adoption. But it never seemed to reach a critical mass of viewers, and while we dont want to say its title was to blame, we will point out that Mr. Ryan recently renamed another new cop drama he is preparing, changing its title from Ride-Along to The Chicago Code.

title: In Their 30s, in the Throes of a Big Chill
description: Stop me if youve heard this one: a group of college friends in New York, now in their 30s but still best buddies and confidants. ... Whats that you say? Stop?

title: Gates Skeptical of Dont Ask , Dont Tell Repeal This Year
description: MUSCAT, Oman  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates cast doubt Monday that the Senate would vote before the end of the year to allow gay men and women to serve openly in the armed forces.

title: Remembering the Night John Lennon Was Shot
description: We filed out of the Spectrum in Philadelphia that warm December night, my high school buddies Jim, John, Glenn and I, exhausted and exhilarated, echoes of Santa Claus is Coming to Town ringing in our heads. Bruce Springsteen had rocked us righteously, and all was right with the world.

title: WikiLeaks Founder Warns About More Dispatches
description: WASHINGTON  Julian Assange, the beleaguered founder of the anti-secrecy group WikiLeaks, has threatened to release many more confidential diplomatic cables if legal action is taken against him or his organization. Mr. Assanges threat poses a problem for the Obama administration as it explores ways to prosecute Mr. Assange or the group.

title: In the N.F.C. West, the Race Is as Ugly as It Is Close
description: The N.F.L. showcased the best side of parity this weekend. Ravens-Steelers? Jets-Patriots? Those are probably the best four teams in football now. But in the last two weeks of the season, the N.F.L. will avert its eyes from the flip side: consecutive division games for the Rams, including the season finale with the Seahawks, to be played, just like those others this weekend, with the division title hanging in the balance.

title: Leaked Cable Lists Sensitive Sites
description: WASHINGTON  A State Department cable released by WikiLeaks provides a compendium of sites around the world  from hydroelectric dams in Canada to vaccine producers in Denmark  that, if lost, might critically impact public health or the national security of the United States.

title: Afghanistan Softens Ban on Private Security Firms
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Afghan government appeared Monday to edge away from plans to ban all private security companies, announcing modifications that would allow most licensed firms to continue their work, but leaving important details in doubt, company representatives and Western officials said.

title: Market Watch | Bidding on Luxury
description: Heritage Auctions, better known for selling collectible coins and vintage comic books, is exploring new and perhaps more feminine ground. This month the company introduces its latest category: luxury accessories.

title: Boardwalk Empire Builds on Strong Performances
description: If you missed the season finale of Boardwalk Empire on Sunday night, chances are you missed the whole season, in which case you are hereby advised to sequester yourself for part of the holiday season and catch up via HBO on Demand. The visual splendors of Boardwalk Empire have been exhaustively noted  the cinematography; the grand and meticulously constructed sets; the detailed Prohibition-era suits made by Martin Greenfield Clothiers, the renowned Brooklyn tailoring outfit; and so on  but the series has also easily delivered the best television performances of the year. Steve Buscemi (as the Republican Party boss Nucky Thompson), Kelly Macdonald (as a young Irish widow, Margaret Schroeder, whose moral relativism is leaning in a Carmela Soprano direction) and Michael Pitt (as the Oedipally afflicted young gangster Jimmy Darmody) all merit recognition beyond what the devalued Emmys have to offer.

title: What Were Reading: The Working Rich
Winfrey Chooses Two Dickens Novels for Book Club
description: For her latest book club selection Oprah Winfrey decided to go old school, she said on Monday. Ms. Winfrey has selected two Charles Dickens novels, A Tale of Two Cities and Great Expectations, both announced on her show on Monday, both books that she had never read before. They could be two of the last selected for the Oprah Book Club before her show goes off the air next year.

title: D.N.R. by Another Name
description: Lets imagine an end-of-life scenario. Your ailing and elderly parent has been admitted to the hospital yet again with a condition shes not going to recover from. The medical team asks what they should do if her heart stops. Shes always said she didnt want to die hooked up to a bunch of machines, but youve never really explored the details. Besides, though she has a terminal illness, no one has yet mentioned the d-word.

title: Miller Says Hall Is Trying to Rewrite History
description: Marvin Miller fell one vote short of election to the National Baseball Hall of Fame on Sunday  the closest of five losing votes that began in 2003  and he still believes he will never be enshrined.

title: Germany Reluctant to Expand European Bailout Fund
description: BRUSSELS  Despite rising pressure for new measures to draw a line under the debt crisis, Germany moved Monday to close off debate on an increase to a 750-billion-euro bailout fund, or the more radical step of issuing common euro zone bonds.

title: Two Broadway Shows On the Move
description: In a confluence of financial interests and theater availability on Broadway, two commercially popular rock n roll musicals  the metal/hair band love story Rock of Ages and the Beatles tribute show Rain  will change theaters in early 2011 to continue their runs, the producers of both shows said on Monday. The moves, which are relatively rare for Broadway, will allow Rain to stay open, while Rock of Ages will be able to lower its weekly running costs (and potentially increase its profit margin) by running in a smaller Broadway house.

title: Animation Domination Contest Narrows
description: The Oscars for the world of animation, the Annies, announced the nominees for this years top prize on Monday, and there were no surprises to be had. Toy Story 3, How to Train Your Dragon, Tangled, The Illusionist, and Despicable Me received nods for best animated feature. The list of finalists, from the International Animated Film Society, is sure to have some overlap with the little gold man race, especially this year, when the Academy can nominate only three films (out of 15 submitted for eligibility). Toy Story 3 is a lock, of course, but may also wind up in the best picture category, as Up did last year. Tangled performed well at the box office against stiff competition, which could help its chances. How to Train Your Dragon might be a good bet for the final spot, but dont double-down yet. Last year, Annie voters gave a nomination to the little-seen Irish film The Secret of Kells, and it went on to secure an Oscar slot. Can the same happen for the Despicable Me or The Illusionist this year? The Bagger will pay close attention to the cartoon winnings to find out.

description: Steve Jobs started with one Apple Store in California, which became a chain that grew to hundreds of shops worldwide. Tom DeVesto says he has no such intention.

As Reed Hastings, the chief executive of Netflix, said in a press release, We are now primarily a streaming video company delivering a wide selection of TV shows and films over the Internet.

title: Big, Bold Snapshots of New York
description: Just when you thought youd seen enough purportedly iconic photos of New York City, our pals at Lens took a stroll this morning through the pages of a new coffee-table book whose editor said he aimed to unveil hidden gems that would excite even the most jaded New Yorkers and then print them big and bold. The editor, Reuel Golden, succeeded, David Dunlap writes on Lens in the introduction to an interview with Mr. Golden. The book, New York, Portrait of a City, Mr. Dunlap found, seems to burst with fresh imagery and little-known masterpieces. Check it out on Lens.

title: Red Sox Finally Get the First Baseman on Their List
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Two years ago, when San Diego Padres General Manager Jed Hoyer was an assistant to Theo Epstein, the general manager of the Red Sox, he experienced visceral disappointment when Mark Teixeira, then a free agent, spurned Bostons offer at the last moment and instead signed with the Yankees, a defining moment in the recent histories of both teams.

title: Uncertainty Rules in the N.B.A. Player Market
description: Next week, players who signed contracts this summer will turn trade eligible, bringing in a number of new candidates for teams to chat about and yes, more names and numbers to be used by any team trying to pry Carmelo Anthony away from the Denver Nuggets.

title: We Made It Ourselves | Volunteer Park Cafe Sundries
description: When her friend Joshs bacon jam started appearing on grocery shelves in Seattle, Ericka Burke thought, Thats not fair. What can I make? And then it came to her: Mac-n-cheese. Ive never seen a nice, glass-bottled sauce. The resulting sauce puts anything in a box to shame  most homemade varieties, too. But that isnt the only good to come out of the kitchen at the citys Volunteer Park Cafe. If youre going to place an order, a care package is the move here.

description: Jacques Steinberg, education correspondent for the Times, appears on the Today show to discuss what works in a college essay.

title: Bondurant Driving School Opens Track to Paralyzed Drivers

title: The Life and Opinions of Maf the Dog and of His Friend Marilyn Monroe
description: My story really begins at Charleston, a perfect haunt of light and invention that stands in the English countryside. It was warm that summer and the mornings went far into the afternoon, when the best of the garden would come into the house, the flowers arranged in pots and given new life by Vanessa in her fertile hours. She was always there with her oils and her eyes, the light falling through the glass ceiling to inflame the possibility of something new. She had good days and bad days. On good days she set out her brushes and knew the time was right for work when all her memories became like an aspect of sleep.

title: Marilyn, Dostoyevsky and Me, Her Pup
description: Brian the dog here. You know, the talking dog from Family Guy: best-selling author, actor, television writer, movie director, song-and-dance ace, civil rights crusader and, yes, animal companion. Because of my sterling literary credentials, Ive been asked to review this British poochs new memoir: The Life and Opinions of Maf the Dog and of His Friend Marilyn Monroe, ghosted by this novelist guy Andrew OHagan.

description: Twice a year, Movement Research  an organization integral to the development of experimental dance in New York City and beyond  hosts a festival programmed by guest artists. For the fall installment, masterminded by John Jesurun, a playwright, director and designer, and Jon Kinzel, a choreographer, performer and visual artist, the idea is to explore an increasingly multidisciplinary landscape. Their name for such a place is Truly Madly Deeply, though not for the Anthony Minghella film; instead, as they explain in a statement, they are drawn to a deep group of truly mad artists.

In Nigeria, extremists, possibly including a well-trained operative just arrived from Chad, were believed to be planning a massive terrorist attack. In his teens and 20s in California he played keyboards in rock bands and piano in jazz clubs. But he had thorough conservatory training and won prizes in major international competitions. He has explored world music, arranging and composing some 40 genre-blending works for the Kronos Quartet. His song cycle Piano Lessons was given its American premiere this season by Dawn Upshaw and Emanuel Ax at Carnegie Hall.

title: Just Looking | Aware: Art Fashion Identity
description: When is a dress not just a dress? Certainly when its part of Aware: Art Fashion Identity, currently on view at Londons Royal Academy. The third in a series of rapidly organized exhibitions on contemporary culture, Aware takes as its subject the mutable nature of sartorial identity. Its really about how we use clothing to say who we are, what tribe we belong to and what we believe in, says Kathleen Soriano, the museums director of exhibitions, who was considering the proposal for the show, put forward by the artist Lucy Orta and the independent curator Gabi Scardi, when news reached her of the death of Alexander McQueen. When he died, it brought into focus the enormous contribution that hed made, not just to fashion but also to art, and how close the two can be, Soriano explained.

Why, the experts wail, are so many people wasting their lives solving meaningless puzzles in virtual worlds?

title: Adventurously Bashing Borgias Amid the Clamor of Old Rome
description: Perched like a ballet dancer atop the giant, majestic flagpole rising from the pinnacle of Castel Sant Angelo, I survey the seven hills of the ancient city rolling to the horizon before me. In the distance below, beyond streets teeming with merchants and thieves, beggars and courtesans, I spy the Colosseum and the Pantheon. Directly beneath me, in the dungeons of the debased Rodrigo Borgia (also known as Pope Alexander VI), the Countess of Forli, Caterina Sforza, languishes as I plot her rescue.

title: 21 Bodies Found in Colombia Mudslide
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Colombian rescue teams on Monday recovered 21 bodies of victims killed by a mudslide that ripped through a poor hillside area above Medelln, but they feared that more than a hundred other people, including dozens of children, might have died in the disaster.

The red rope does not open for me or any of the others. I am not on the List because, like many business travelers, I have let my elite status lapse on various airlines since it is no longer worth the effort.

description: In Baby Universe: A Puppet Odyssey, Earth is a beat-up old floozy who wistfully recalls her more verdant, hydrated days: So much life. I was pretty then. Mostly, however, shes just tired and jaded: I dont care about my people. Ive been trying to kill them for years.

title: Flower Power | Liya Kebede as Waris Dirie
description: In Desert Flower, the catwalk fixture and Gifted subject Liya Kebede stands in for the Somali-born model Waris Dirie. A victim of female genital mutilation, the 13-year-old Dirie escaped an arranged marriage in Somalia and made it to London in the 1980s, where she worked at McDonalds before being discovered by Terence Donovan. Kebede, 32, grew up in Ethiopia and was discovered by a filmmaker at the French lyce in Addis Ababa. In a recent interview, she was quick to draw a distinction between her own life story and Diries. On the surface we have parallels, she said, before explaining how different life seemed in Djibouti, a neighboring country to Somalia, where parts of the film were shot. This is where she came from. Theres nothing there, theres no water, theres nothing. And being in that environment was a new thing for me, and then trying to understand how you go from that to become this incredible woman  [Dirie] was never really a victim of her circumstances.

title: Maker of Shoah Stresses Its Lasting Value
description: Even at 85, Claude Lanzmann is not one to rest on his laurels or shirk a controversy. A quarter of a century after his documentary Shoah transformed the way the world regarded the Holocaust, the film is about to be re-released in the United States  an event he welcomes as long overdue.

title: Scottish Artist Wins Turner Prize for a Recording
description: Susan Philipsz, a 45-year-old Scottish artist, has won this years Turner Prize, The Guardian reported. She is the first artist to win for a sound work: she recorded herself singing a 16th-century Scottish lament under three bridges in Glasgow. The prize, established in 1984 by the Tate in London, goes to a British artist under age 50 and comes with about $39,000. Ms. Philipsz beat out Dexter Dalwood, known for his contemporary take on traditional history paintings; Angela de la Cruz, a painter and sculptor nominated for her installation After, at the Camden Arts Center in London; and the Otolith Group, consisting of the London artists Anjalika Sagar and Kodwo Eshun, who make documentary films for a series of exhibitions called A Long Time Between Suns. (Finalists each receive about $7,800.) Ms. Philipsz is only the fourth woman to win the award, after Rachel Whiteread, Gillian Wearing and Tomma Abts. In a statement the judges said they admired the way in which her work provokes both intellectual and instinctive responses and reflects a series of decisions about the relationship between sound and sight and that she draws on the immersive properties of sound and uses her own voice to create powerful sculptural experiences.

title: New Director for State Theater in New Brunswick

title: Holiday Wish List | Bruce Pask
description: Ts mens fashion director, Bruce Pask, is craving the finer things in life this holiday season. Never mind dapper suits and polished loafers  its all about cozying around a Roy Hardin-designed fire pit with a cheeky bottle of Charles Smith wine and the new volume of Christopher Isherwoods diaries, The Sixties. If were dreaming here, I would really love to hopscotch from one Aman resort to another in the Far East, Pask says. title: City Opera to Perform Rufus Wainwright Work

Instead New York City Opera said on Monday that the company would produce it sometime next season. The Met and Lincoln Center Theater originally commissioned the work, Prima Donna. But the Met declined to present it because Mr. Wainwright insisted on keeping the libretto in French. The opera is about a retired soprano dealing with her past. It had its first performance in July 2009 at the Manchester International Festival in England and was also put on at Sadlers Wells in London and the Luminato Festival in Toronto. Janis Kelly, above, will sing the main role, and Tim Albery will direct, a publicist for Mr. Wainwright said.

title: China: Resized Beijing Museum Breaks Ground
description: Construction began last Thursday on a museum that has been the centerpiece of a contentious plan to raze and rebuild a large section of ancient alleyways in the heart of Beijing, according to a report on Monday in China Daily, an English-language newspaper. But the scale of the original plan has been changed, and alleyways and courtyard homes will no longer be destroyed in the project, the report said. The museum, called the Beijing Time Museum, is being built on a site southeast of the Drum Tower, a 13th-century landmark. The original plan encompassed an area 20 times larger than the current project and ignited criticism from people concerned about the relentless destruction of historic areas in Beijing, China Daily reported. That plan was put on hiatus in September after the wave of criticism and a bureaucratic reshuffling of neighborhood governments.

description: Liliane Bettencourt, the heiress of LOral, has reconciled with her daughter after a three-year legal battle that divided the family and sparked scandals that ensnared top French politicians. The agreement, announced Monday by a lawyer for the daughter, Franoise Bettencourt-Meyers, ended a fierce legal clash between Mrs. Bettencourt-Meyers and the celebrity photographer Franois-Marie Banier, whom she had accused of exploiting her 88-year-old mother to reap more than $1 billion in cash and presents. Mrs. Bettencourt-Meyerss husband, Jean-Pierre Meyers, is expected to take charge of the familys holding company, Tthys, at the end of the month.

title: Malaysia: Rights Group Says Caning Is Torture
description: Amnesty International is calling on Malaysia to halt the practice of judicial caning, a punishment the organization said amounts to torture and violates international law. In a report released on Monday, Amnesty International said that the number of offenses subject to caning under Malaysian criminal law had increased to more than 60 in recent years and that as many as 10,000 people were caned annually. Based on interviews with 57 people, the report found that some inmates had been left with permanent scars and physical disabilities after being hit with the 3-foot-long cane used in Malaysian prisons. A statement issued by the prime ministers office said that the government could not comment on the accuracy of the report because it had not had adequate time to review its findings.

title: Poland: Medvedev Promises to Forge Better Relations

The pledge came after talks in Warsaw between President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia and his Polish counterpart, Bronislaw Komorowski. It was the first official visit to Poland in nine years by a Russian president. With Poland now having increasing influence in NATO, which it joined in 1999, and the European Union, which it joined in 2004, Mr. Medvedev said that if Moscow wanted better ties with both organizations, it needed to forge better relations with Poland.

title: T Exclusive Video | Dorothea
description: Barnaby Roper, the innovative New York filmmaker and photographer, has created a short film exclusively for The Moment starring the model Dorothea Barth Jorgensen. In this captivating short, Roper combines powerful lighting and exquisitely timed edits  along with more than a little wax  to transform Dorothea into a three-dimensional otherworldly beauty. When not appearing in T films or posing for the pages of Italian Vogue or Love, the Swedish-born Jorgensen can often be found at Surf Caf in Brooklyn, reading her beloved Anas Nin, or, you know, analyzing dreams. She also has a wicked blog called Displaced Bones, where you can see Jorgensens beautiful friends captured through her own lens and read her poetry and various musings.

title: The Tax Cut Deal
description: As policy, the bargain Barack Obama just struck with Congressional Republicans is a classic it makes sense, but only if  situation. Given the parlous state of the economy, it makes sense to maintain the low Bush-era tax rates, it makes sense to extend unemployment benefits, and it makes sense to temporarily drop the payroll tax rate  if, that is, our leaders use the time between today and 2012, when this bargain comes up for renegotiation, to make real progress on a strategy for long-term deficit reduction, joined to a base-broadening, rate-lowering tax reform package that renders the debates over the Bush tax cuts obsolete.

Toscanini was in the pit; Enrico Caruso, Emmy Destinn and Pasquale Amato sang the leads; and Puccini, alone in his box, surveyed the scene. That is, until the end of Act I, when the composer and cast appeared on stage for 14 curtain calls. Similar pandemonium broke out at the end of the other two acts.

title: Feuding in Cartoon Land
description: Think cartoons are all sweetness and fluff? Thats not all, folks. In the wake of the Annie nominations on Monday, animators and Oscar watchers are talking about some studio drama behind the scenes. This past summer, the Walt Disney Company and Pixar Animation announced they were withdrawing from the Annies, the cartoon worlds equivalent of the Oscars, presented by the Hollywood branch of the International Animated Film Society, because of a dispute with the way the group chooses its winners. Among Disneys complaints: that the guild allows anyone to buy a membership (in contrast to most awards-bestowing organizations) and that rival DreamWorks Animation has too much power because it gives all of its employees complimentary membership to the guild, Brooks Barnes wrote in August.

title: Deconstructing Chicken Soup
description: I really had a great weekend of cooking; winter takes the pressure off of shopping for the best possible ingredients and just lets you hunker down and play with whats around. I baked bread, twice; I made fruit compote; I produced a decent vegetable soup (disregarding, Im sorry to report, my own advice about putting turnips in soup, thus allowing me to reiterate: do not put turnips in soup); and I ate leftovers.

title: Cast Set for Opera Based on 9/11 Hero
description: The San Francisco Opera on Tuesday disclosed details of a new opera by Christopher Theofanidis based on a book about Rick Rescorla, the head of security for Morgan Stanley who died shepherding people to safety during the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. The opera, Heart of a Soldier, will star the baritone Thomas Hampson, the tenor William Burden and the soprano Melody Moore. Francesca Zambello will direct and Patrick Summers will conduct. It will have its first performance on Sept. 10, the eve of the 10th anniversary of the attack.
