description: Since captivating the downtown performance scene of the 1990s as Kiki, the singing, boozing, yarn-spinning half of the drag cabaret duo Kiki and Herb, the Maryland native Justin Bond has become a witty, kitten-heeled fixture of the New York avant-garde. Bond, who is in his 40s and identifies as transgender, was the mistress of ceremonies in John Cameron Mitchells 2006 indie film Shortbus, and in October he performed at the Kitchen with his House of Whimsy Players in Re:Galli Blond (A Sissy Fix), a self-penned musical spectacle of transgender oppression and uplift. From the phone in his East Village loft, he chatted about his latest project, Justin Bond: Christmas Spells, opening Dec. 9 at Abrons Arts Center.

title: A Navel-Gazing Oscar Countdown
description: We know youve marked your calendar: there are now 83 days until the 83rd Academy Awards (Feb. 27, 2011). To celebrate this red-letter date, the Academy itself is starting a countdown, revisiting each and every Oscar event by year. The first one, held in 1929, gave the top prize to Wings, the only silent film ever to win an Academy Award; it was also the only time individual prizes were given for dramatic and comedic direction. (They went to 7th Heaven and the laff-riot Two Arabian Knights, respectively.) There wasnt much room for industry speculation or public betting, though, because the ceremony, in the Blossom Room of the Hollywood Roosevelt Hotel, was held three months after the winners were announced. Two hundred and seventy people attended, and the Academy president, Douglas Fairbanks, was the host. Plus-ones were welcome, as long as they paid $5 for their seat. Before conducting Die Wlkure in La Scalas season-opening gala performance, Mr. Barenboim spoke from the pit and urged Italys president, Giorgio Napolitano, who was present, to protect the arts, The Associated Press reported. We are deeply worried for the future of culture in the country and in Europe, the conductor was quoted as saying. title: Class and the Culture War
description: My column yesterday plucked out one thread from the National Marriage Projects depressing new report, The Retreat from Marriage in Middle America, and looked at the ways in which its findings complicate some of our stereotypes about the American culture war  in particular, the widespread understanding (one that Ive perpetuated in my own writings) that less-educated Americans tend to be more religious and socially conservative than well-educated Americans. The Retreat from Marriage report suggests that this frame held up more strongly in the 1970s than it does today. On some questions (the morality of premarital sex, whether a divorce should become harder to obtain) well-educated and less-educated Americans seem to have converged over the last few decades, or else the less-educated have become more permissive than college graduates. At the same time, rates of churchgoing have fallen much faster among less-educated Americans than they have among college graduates, to the point where theres now a strongly positive correlation between education and church attendance one that didnt exist in the 70s. (The recent trend toward secularization, it turns out, may have been driven more by community college dropouts than by Richard Dawkins-reading Ph.Ds.)

Thompson is an extraordinary scientist focused for decades (along with his equally remarkable wife,Ellen Mosley-Thompson) on direct observations of climate as well as evidence derived from ice cores extracted from glaciers around the world. He appears to have spent more time on ice fields above 18,000 feet than any human being in history. (The connection between glaciology and behavior will become clear below.)

title: Now Sparkling | Alexis Bittar Heads West

Last week, the Brooklyn-based jeweler opened a shop on Abbot Kinney in Venice, Calif., another on West Third Street in Los Angeles, and next week hell open on Filmore Street in Pacific Heights in San Francisco. Expanding at a time when many other designers are just staying above water may be a bold move. But Bittar believes its a great time to come into new cities with a force. He chose Los Angeles, in particular, because he feels the city, along with New York, shapes the country in terms of trends. San Francisco, on the other hand, is a revenue leader for the company; the new shop will cater to a woman Bittar describes as being more artistic, with a personality more like New York City women. The boutiques dcor incorporates 1930s wallpaper thats been sprayed with graffiti, along with a smattering of the taxidermy groupings that have become a Bittar design statement. Were creating animal hybrids with these, like putting swan wings on a gazelle, he says. On a theatric level, having a store is great. And I think it makes shopping fun.

title: Shoe In | Pierre Hardys New Digs
description: The artist Dan Graham has not gone into retail design as far as we know, but you could easily mistake Pierre Hardys first United States boutique, in the West Village, for one of Grahams installations. His glass and mirror pavilions, which are often plunked down into incongruous environments (say, a forest or the roof of the former DIA building in Chelsea), play tricks on the eye, integrating the spectator into the structures reflected surfaces. Hes my dream artist, Hardy said earlier this week, acknowledging the homage. His shop, at 30 Jane Street, which was designed by David Mann of MR. Architecture + Decor is a little jewel box  all smokey brown glass and mirrors; its situation, ensconced within the rough and crudely patched walls of a historic carriage house, feels both serene and strangely precarious. Its exactly the opposite of Paris, Hardy explained. There you have historical places you cant touch and you have to work with it. Here we had to destroy and rebuild everything because what was here was unusable. We tried to do something more precious in the middle of something more raw. A particularly Grahamesque touch comes in the form of two large plates of interlocking glass that section off the 1,400-square-foot space into semi-private cubbies so you can catch furtive glimpses of the woman trying on Hardys special New York Skyline shoes next to you (Um, excuse me, do those come in my size?), and still maintain the illusion that you have the place all to yourself.

title: Blue Valentine Sheds NC-17 Rating
description: Ending weeks of artistic protests and online hand wringing, the Motion Picture Association of America has reversed its decision to award Blue Valentine, the marital drama starring Ryan Gosling and Michelle Williams, an NC-17 rating. After a final appeal by Harvey Weinstein and Co. today, the film, which has earned attention as much for its finely tuned performances as for any explicit content, will now be rated R, which should help its awards chances. (Ms. Williams and Mr. Gosling are both indie darlings and previous Oscar nominees.) The vote by the board was apparently unanimous.

title: Hitting Home: How Is Your Community Dealing With Budget Woes?
description: Police officers are being laid off. Firehouses are going dark. Several states have released prisoners early, more to save money than for good behavior. And Arizona will no longer pay for certain organ transplants for people in its Medicaid program. The Great Recession has taken a big toll on the finances of state and local governments, and with federal stimulus money running out many governments will continue to have to scramble to make ends meet. Join Times correspondents Thursday in a conversation about how state and local governments are dealing with budget woes. Ask a question or share your story about what is happening in your town or state. Use the comments area below or respond via Twitter using the hashtag #nytchat. Be as specific as possible.

title: Bettman Says Head Shot Rules to Remain; LaFontaine Urges Zero Tolerance
description: N.H.L. Commissioner Gary Bettman said the leagues legislation against hits to the head would remain in place for the foreseeable future.

title: Bold Crossings of the Gender Line
description: ITS certainly a statement on our times that, in the same month, James Franco graces the covers of GQ and Candy. In GQ, he appears in a moody head shot. In Candy, a style magazine dedicated to what it calls the transversal  that is, transsexuality, transvestism, cross-dressing, androgyny and any combination thereof  Mr. Franco, shot by Terry Richardson, vamps in trowel-applied makeup, heavy jewelry and a womans dominatrix-style power suit.

title: China Resisted U.S. Pressure on Rights of Nobel Winner
description: BEIJING  It was just before Christmas 2009, and Ding Xiaowen was not happy.

title: Officials Pressed Germans on Kidnapping by C.I.A.
description: BERLIN  American officials exerted sustained pressure on Germany not to enforce arrest warrants against Central Intelligence Agency officers involved in the 2003 kidnapping of a German citizen mistakenly believed to be a terrorist, diplomatic cables made public by WikiLeaks show.

title: Donations Ban on iPhone Apps Irritates Nonprofits
description: The nonprofit world is stewing over the ban Apple has put on making donations on the iPhone via charity apps.

title: In Germany, From Derelict to Pristine
description: A once abandoned water tower is now a six-story home to a British couple.

title: Strike May Be Watershed Event in Spain
description: MADRID  When Spanish air traffic controllers conducted a wildcat strike over the weekend that shut down airports across the country, they were hoping to force the government to back down from its plans to cut their pay, increase their regular working hours and put Spains two largest airports under private management.

title: Legal Advice at a Moderate Price?
description: Now may be a good time to lawyer up  at least from a price perspective.

title: In Germany, a Water Tower to Call Home
description: JOACHIMSTHAL, GERMANY  On a bike ride almost a decade ago, Richard Hurding, a product designer, spied what would later become an unlikely home  a derelict water tower, perched on a hill surrounded by trees.

title: A Store Is Born | Amarees
description: In our latest Holiday issue, we feature Amarees, a new high-end clothing and homewares store in Newport Beach, Calif. owned by sisters Dawn Klohs and Denise Schaefer. See our behind-the scenes look at the stores gestation as shot by Felix Thomas Juranek.

title: On a Milestone Day, Business Lessons From the Beatles
description: Fans of the Beatles gathered at global vigils on Wednesday to commemorate the 30th anniversary of the death of John Lennon.

title: Florida Officials Expected to Grant Jim Morrison a Pardon
description: Alex Sink, the chief financial officer for the State of Florida and a member of the states clemency board, said on Wednesday that she would probably support a push by Gov. Charlie Crist to hand out a posthumous pardon for Jim Morrison, the lead singer for the Doors. The pardon would come 40 years after Morrison was convicted of indecent exposure after a rowdy profanity-laced concert at the Dinner Key Auditorium in Miami.

description: An 18th-century house in Maine, a two-bedroom condo in Atlanta and a four-bedroom house in Kansas.

title: The Selling of a Long Shot
description: The campaign to get an Oscar nomination for Paprika Steen, who stars in Applause as an actress fresh out rehab desperate to regain custody of her sons, came to Midtown Manhattan and the Aquavit restaurant on Tuesday. Over Elk bourguignon and pepper-smoked Spanish mackerel, the gregarious Ms. Steen beguiled a room full of journalists and industry players with her stories and banter, which of course was the whole idea, even if a few of the attendees were a little fuzzy about exactly which northern European country she actually came from.

description: Images from the location shoot of "The Tourist."

title: Smelling an Opportunity
description: MASON, Ohio  For more than a decade, some of the nations shrewdest marketers have tried to muscle in on the neighborhood dry cleaner, only to give up after years of labor and millions of dollars in investments.

description: A view from the space capsule that was carried into orbit by Space Exploration Technologies Corporation's Falcon 9 rocket.

description: It is not the blockbuster deal the technology sector was hoping for this month, but Herokus investors should be pleased.

description: In a closely watched case, a federal jury on Wednesday awarded a Minnesota resident $1.82 million after finding that Johnson & Johnson had failed to adequately warn patients that its antibiotic Levaquin may cause tendon damage.

description: The Pre-Fall Collections, being shown in New York over the next several weeks, arrive in stores in May to fill the gap between bikinis and furs.

Buffett are planning to announce 15 more signatories to the Giving Pledge they started last summer, bringing the total number of billionaires and multimillionaires committed to giving away at least half their wealth to 65.

title: The S.E.C. Goes Global With Insider Trading, Again
description: The international flair of the Securities and Exchange Commission continued on Wednesday when it filed suit against unnamed investors who bought Wimm-Bill-Dann Foods shares in the days before the PepsiCo agreed to buy the Russian beverage company.

title: George H.W. Bush Endorses Arms Treaty
description: 5:51 p.m. | Updated Former President George H.W. Bush, who signed and won Senate approval of the original Start arms control treaty with the Soviet Union in 1991, endorsed the proposed follow-up treaty with Russia on Wednesday, lending another well-known Republican voice to the White House campaign for approval.

title: Inside the Decorated Diplomatic Reception Rooms
description: David Stark, the event planner, brought holiday chic to rooms at the State Department.

title: Afghan War Officer-Training Program Lags, but Makes Progress
description: WASHINGTON  A high-priority Pentagon program to train a cadre of officers with special skills for the Afghan war has recovered from a number of start-up stumbles, but is still less than halfway to its numerical goal at the one-year mark, according to senior Pentagon officials.

title: Former Environmental Commissioner to Run Prospect Park
description: Prospect Park has a new leader with a long history of helping keep the city green. Emily Lloyd, a former commissioner of the city Department of Environmental Protection and the Department of Sanitation, has been chosen to replace the parks longtime administrator, Tupper Thomas.

title: 8 Charged in Sewage Dumping in Brooklyn Creek
description: Four people and four businesses at a Brooklyn shopping center face criminal charges over the dumping of raw sewage and restaurant grease into Shell Bank Creek in Sheepshead Bay, home to bluefish, crab, striped bass and other fish, in addition to a marina.

title: Radiation Rules Differ for Humans and Pets
description: WASHINGTON  One group receiving treatment for a thyroid disorder is given a radioactive drug that makes the patients a potential hazard to children or pregnant women for several days. Still, doctors usually send them home immediately after treatment.

title: Behind Camera, Checking the Ego
description: David O. Russell does not have the reputation of an evenhanded filmmaker. Depending on whom you talk to, Mr. Russell, whose work includes the Persian Gulf war satire Three Kings and the existential corporate comedy I Heart Huckabees, is quixotic, combative and occasionally brilliant.

description: To the Editor:

title: Onstage in Milan, Shadowy Giants Visible in New York
description: Say this for Robert Lepages unfolding production of Wagners Ring cycle at the Metropolitan Opera: the concept is likely to have a certain unity and consistency. There is, after all, only so much you can do to distract from the workings of the giant mechanism that dominates the stage.

title: An Eye for Detail, and Plenty of Pop
description: STYLE is, like, the wrapping paper of my life.

title: Backers Rev Up Oil Sands Campaign
description: Havent heard of the Keystone XL pipeline project yet? Thats about to change.

title: Misbehaving, but Plenty of Regrets
description: The first song T. I. performs on VH1 Storytellers: T. I., which will have its premiere on Friday night, is Still Aint Forgave Myself, a catalog of his misdeeds going back to childhood: Started interacting with fiends at the age of 13/Now my mama finding rocks in my socks/Glocks in my toy box.

title: Folky Strokes, With Dabs of News, Video and Static
description: For a composer generally described as contemporary classical, Minimalist or avant-garde, Mikel Rouse has recently been getting almost folky.

title: Does Music Trump Story? More Answers to Your Broadway Questions
description: Yesterday, Larry Stempel, the author of the new book Showtime: A History of the Broadway Musical Theater, answered readers questions about lyric writing, guilty pleasures and other topics. Today Mr. Stempel takes a look at the music vs. lyrics debate, short runs and more. His final set of answers will be posted tomorrow.

title: Gift Ideas for Photo Hobbyists? Its a Snap
description: IF self-respecting photography lovers havent received a digital single-lens reflex camera as a gift by now, they have probably broken down and bought one for themselves. You might think that leaves the camera buffs loved ones plaintively wailing, Now what do we get him? He already has a camera.

title: Filling First Base in Chicago
description: Within hours of each other on Wednesday, the Cubs and White Sox came to terms with free-agent power-hitting first basemen.

title: Exploring Variations in a Christmastime Favorite
description: The predictable charms of the annual performances of Handels Messiah at St. Thomas Church on Fifth Avenue, invariably among the best in New York, have mainly to do with the St. Thomas Choir of Men and Boys, directed by John Scott, and Concert Royal, the period-instrument orchestra directed by James Richman. They do not necessarily involve the guest vocal soloists, who, though sometimes excellent, can be uneven.

title: 8 Charged With Polluting Brooklyn Creek
description: Four people and four businesses in a Brooklyn shopping center  including a T.G.I. Fridays and a movie theater  face criminal charges that they dumped raw sewage and restaurant grease into Shell Bank Creek, the short body of water that separates the oceanside neighborhoods of Sheepshead Bay and Gerritsen Beach. The creek is home to bluefish, crab, striped bass and other fish, in addition to a marina. Read about the charges on the Green blog.

title: CBS Wins Again
description: Crime shows lifted CBS to No. 1 on Tuesday as a rerun of NCIS led the night with 11.8 million viewers at 8 p.m. and NCIS: Los Angeles drew 10.4 million at 9. A Christmas-theme episode of Foxs Glee led in the important demographic of viewers 18 to 49 as the episode (11 million) easily outperformed its other 8 p.m. competitors: ABCs special A Charlie Brown Christmas (8 million) and NBCs game show Minute to Win It (7 million). Fox ranked second for the night in total viewers, NBC was third and ABC fourth.

title: An Abandoned Mens Club Is Now a Home
description: SELMA, Ala.

title: A Renovation That Preserves the Decay
description: An industrial designer from Atlanta took an abandoned 20,000-square-foot building on the waterfront in Selma, Ala., and made into a home.

title: Shopping With Harry Heissmann
description: An interior designer shopped for Christmas tree trimmings that look handmade or vintage.

title: The Beekeeper Next Door
description: MIKE BARRETT does not have much of a yard at his two-story row house in Astoria, Queens. But that fact has not kept him from his new hobby of beekeeping  he put the hive on his roof. When it was harvest time this fall, he just tied ropes around each of the two honey-filled boxes in the hive, and lowered them to the ground.

title: Orfeo Quagliatas Sculptural Glass Cups
description: Orfeo Quagliata, a Mexico City glass artist, started working in the medium as a child, grinding and polishing as an apprentice to his father, Narcissus Quagliata. In the years since, he has produced glass jewelry and sculpture, as well as functional objects for the home.

title: Forced From Home Yet Never Free of It
description: WITH each year, my childhood house grows bigger in my mind, each nook and corridor casting a longer shadow. The stone steps, about a hundred in total, appear elongated, as if they might reach the sky rather than the front gate. The pomegranate trees and forsythia that had once filled the garden have overgrown into a tropic wilderness, a meteorological miracle for South Korea. The pond, where I looked for the koi with their multiple colors, has turned into a reservoir as deep as the one in Central Park. Rising beyond it all are the peacocks from my fathers menagerie, and I wait, as I have always, for the magical fanning of their tails.

title: Christmas Tree Trimmings
description: HARRY Heissmann, an interior designer who worked for Juan Pablo Molyneux and Albert Hadley before opening his own office last year, is passionate about Christmas. True, he sold his collection of antique cast-iron Christmas tree stands to help finance his move from Germany in 1995, but that only speaks to how much he wanted to live in New York.

title: Sales From Judy Ross Textiles, Klein Reid and Others
description: Judy Ross Textiles will offer deep discounts on hand-embroidered stockings, pillows, hand-knotted rugs and runners at its holiday sample sale, through Saturday (an 18-inch chain-stitch pillow, below, originally $195 to $225, is $80; 3-by-6 runners, originally $1,620 to $2,070, are $750 to $800); 41 Union Square West (17th Street), Room 526, (212) 842-1705, judyrosstextiles.com.

title: Brooklyns Seaport Flowers Expands Into Home Dcor
description: For years, discerning flower buyers throughout New York City have turned to Amy Gardella at Seaport Flowers in Brooklyn Heights for her sophisticated, modern arrangements. Now that she has moved into a larger space off Atlantic Avenue, Ms. Gardella has expanded her offerings to include an array of home dcor, including porcelain vases, lamps, botanic prints and vintage furniture.

title: Care for a Bronze Cherry?
description: Malia Jensen, a 44-year-old artist in Brooklyn, considers her life-size painted bronze cherries and stainless steel bird feet to be small sculptures. But whether they are art, functional objects (paperweights?) or simply decorative, they are certainly tactile.

title: A Restaurant Where the Ambience Is Jewel-Like
description: Beauty & Essex, a restaurant opening on Saturday on the Lower East Side, was designed by the Manhattan firm AvroKO to resemble a jewelry store that would sell pieces kind of reminiscent of what my sophisticated grandmother had, said Peter Kane, who owns this restaurant, and Stanton Social, with Richard Wolf and Chris Santos. But with a Lower East Side sensibility.

title: David Stark on Washington Chic
description: Tucked away inside the sprawling Foggy Bottom complex in Washington that is the State Department are the Diplomatic Reception Rooms  42 rooms, used daily by everyone from Secretary of State Hillary Clinton and President Obama to cabinet officials. This year, to celebrate the rooms 50th anniversary, the State Department teamed up with Time Inc. and InStyle. Ariel Foxman, the editor of InStyle, brought in David Stark, a New York event producer, to decorate a few of the rooms on the eighth floor of the department  those most frequently used for receptions and diplomacy, and the only ones open to the public  for the holidays.

title: Voodoo, Vivid Colors and Strange Visions
description: Watching Celebrating Revelations at 50, the film tribute by Judy Kinberg that precedes the piece during the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theaters current season, its notable how rough hewn  and powerful  the dancing looks in the historical footage of Ailey and others performing in that work. Today the Ailey dancers are sleek, athletic masters of the universe, and the pieces routinely draw midmovement applause and cheers for moments of virtuosity.

title: Azzedine Alaas Mark on Fashion
description: In a way, Mr. Alaas place in the fashion world has remained constant.

title: Azzedine Alaa: The Master of the Female Form
description: ON the second floor of a former warehouse in the Marais quarter of Paris, the little man in the faded Chinese pajamas picked up the phone on the second ring. It was after 1 a.m., but few people who dialed his number at that hour expected to get a machine or a sleepy voice. They expected to get Azzedine Alaa, the designer, and like an Arab grocery, he was open late.

title: Theres a Nap for That
description: All due credit to Benjamin Stein for that headline, which accompanies his sons handmade iPhone blanket.

title: Behind the Camera, Checking the Ego
description: David O. Russell does not have the reputation of an evenhanded filmmaker. Depending on whom you talk to, Mr. Russell, whose work includes the Persian Gulf war satire Three Kings and the existential corporate comedy I  Huckabees, is quixotic, combative and occasionally brilliant. For his latest film, The Fighter, a passion project brought to him by his frequent star Mark Wahlberg, Mr. Russell takes on the true story of Micky Ward and Dicky Eklund, brothers and struggling boxers from Lowell, Mass., near where Mr. Wahlberg grew up. He plays Micky, the quieter but more successful of the two, and Christian Bale , in an outsize, twitchy performance that is generating Oscar talk, plays Dicky, a recovering drug addict and a wiry charmer.

title: Dumplings With the Kitchen God
description: In the historical novel Under Fishbone Clouds one character pauses to contemplate the failure of Chairman Maos Cultural Revolution and its grandiose plans to change the world. This character, a woman named Yuying, has grown old enough to smile wryly at those objectives.

title: Iran Security Officials Arrest Four at Newspaper
description: TEHRAN  Security officials have raided one of Irans few remaining independent newspapers, arresting three journalists and a managing director, web sites associated with the political opposition reported Wednesday.

title: A Melting Pot of Nutcrackers
description: A look at the holiday classic from the Lower East Side of Manhattan to Houston.

title: Nutcracker Nation: Yes We Can!
description: Snow lay in piles on the sidewalks in Salt Lake City, where I saw The Nutcracker danced in a theater that was two years old when Diaghilevs Ballets Russes appeared there in 1917 and that was once a vaudeville house. In Houston the next day the temperature was around 65, and The Nutcracker was being staged in a grand 1980s opera house next to a bayou.

title: Revisiting a Mellowed Pierre Boulez
description: Pierre Boulez celebrated his 85th birthday in March, and in keeping with the classical music worlds customarily expansive treatment of composers birthdays, the festivities have run through the year. The latest installment was a sold-out Composer Portraits concert at the Miller Theater on Monday evening. The virtuosic Talea Ensemble performed, and Mr. Boulez was on hand for a lively onstage interview with Ara Guzelimian, dean of the Juilliard School.

title: Browsing: Shopping Snapshots for Dec. 9
description: New Gucci collection for children; Pierre Hardy opens his first U.S. store; sales, openings and events of the week.

title: After West Starts With an Ace, Declarer Ponders the Meaning
description: At the Fall North American Championships in Orlando, Fla., on Sunday, the Reisinger Board-a-Match Teams was won by James Cayne of New York; Michael Seamon of Dania Beach, Fla.; and Giorgio Duboin, Antonio Sementa, Lorenzo Lauria and Alfredo Versace from Italy. They finished 0.38 points in front of Christal Welland-Henner and Roy Welland of New York, Steve Garner of Chicago, Howard Weinstein of San Diego, and Josef Piekarek and Alexander Smirnov from Germany.

title: Scared Straight Comes to Wall Street
description: The White Collar Watch columnist, Peter J. Henning, speaks to Amy Walsh, a former prosecutor, about the recent insider trading inquiry into hedge funds. Is the governments extraordinary use of manpower and technology an effort to keep financial professionals looking over their shoulders?

title: Providing Security in Jurez, Mexico
description: Miguel Macias runs the fastest-growing security firm in Jurez, where drug violence has spiked.

title: Nightlife in New York, Dec. 9 to 14
description: A PREVIEW of the must-attend parties, talked-about openings and fashionable night spots for the week ahead.

title: Facebook Welcome Groups for Freshmen Now Appear Less Official
description: More than 150 Facebook groups that appeared to be official welcome sites for the prospective freshman classes at colleges and universities were altered Wednesday, to make clear that they exist partly as a marketing tool for a commercial, roommate-matching service known as Roomsurf.

title: Lucy Sykes Rellies Birthday Dinner
description: AS guests filtered in for her 41st birthday party, Lucy Sykes Rellie, the British-born socialite and fashion designer, was instructing the owners of the Park Avenue Tavern to turn the lights down and the music up.

title: 'Scared Straight' Comes to Wall Street
description: White Collar Watch columnist Peter J. Henning speaks to Amy Walsh, a former prosecutor, about the recent insider-trading inquiry into hedge funds. Is the governments extraordinary use of manpower and technology an effort to keep financial professionals looking over their shoulders?

title: For First-Timer, an Icy Challenge
description: Jeff Vervoort, left, an associate professor in radiogenic isotope geochemistry at Washington State University, and John Goodge, a professor of geological sciences at the University of Minnesota-Duluth, will be writing occasional posts from their research expedition in Antarctica.

title: Champions League: See You in February
description: The group stage of the UEFA Champions League concluded on Wednesday with Arsenal, Shakhtar Donetsk and Roma claiming the final three berths in the 16-team first knockout stage, which begins in February.

title: Summerall Reflects on the Mesmerizing Lombardi and the Analytical Landry
description: Pat Summerall is best known as the former lead voice of N.F.L. games for CBS and Fox, not as a kicker and occasional tight end and defensive end for the Chicago Cardinals and the Giants. His new book, Giants: What I Learned About Life From Vince Lombardi and Tom Landry, recalls the influence exerted by Lombardi, who coached the Giants offense, and Landry, who coached their defense, on him and the team. Once Summerall became a Giant in 1958, he sat in on the offensive and defensive meetings. It was the season when the Giants lost to the Baltimore Colts, 23-17, in overtime, in the N.F.L. championship game.

title: A Poison Pill Cure at Fortune Brands
description: Fortune Brands has found an antidote for its poison pill. The odd combination of liquor, golf clubs and faucets never made sense. The conglomerate structure also dissuaded specialist rivals from making takeover bids. Carving up the company should solve the problem.

title: An Insider Case of Life Borrowing From Art
description: A bit of unsolicited advice for any DealBook readers thinking about evading the law: when engaging in insider trading from your online brokerage account, dont borrow code names from the most famous, albeit fictional, insider trade of all time.

title: From Retired Brands, Dollars and Memories
description: THERE are auctions of old paintings, old books and even old bottles of wine. Now, old brand names can be added to the list.

title: Sex Offender Is Indicted in Killing Two Years Ago
description: Two years after a 25-year-old woman vanished after leaving a nightclub in Manhattan, the man who has long been considered by investigators to be the main suspect in the case has been indicted on murder charges, the authorities announced on Wednesday.

title: Hackers Give Web Companies a Test of Free Speech
description: A hacking free-for-all has exploded on the Web, and Facebook and Twitter are stuck in the middle.

title: Yahoo Revamps Local Pages
description: Yahoo is giving its local listings  a strictly functional service akin to the Yellow Pages  a makeover.

title: N.F.L. Invites Helmet Safety Ideas
description: With the federal government, state legislatures and football helmets regulatory body already focusing on concussions and head protection, perhaps the most influential group of all  the N.F.L.  convened its own summit of experts Wednesday to discuss possible reforms.

title: Washington Rule Makers Out of the Shadows
description: WASHINGTON  Federal rule makers, long the neglected stepchildren of Washington bureaucrats, suddenly find themselves at the center of power as they scramble to work out details of hundreds of sweeping financial and health care regulations that will ultimately affect most Americans.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: Tracking and Privacy
description: Concerns about commercial tracking of Web users  and how consumer data is used  have led the Federal Trade Commission to call for action, including a way to opt out. On this weeks Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein speaks with Tanzina Vega, a New York Times media reporter who has been covering online privacy. Ms. Vega says that some in the advertising industry are raising alarms about the F.T.C.s proposal for a simple tool to opt out of tracking.

title: A New Phono Preamp From Parasound. Wait  What?
description: Of all the news releases inundating my in-box in the weeks before the annual Consumer Electronics Show  new cameras, new computer chips, a ton of gadgets for the iPhone and iPad  the one least likely to catch the attention of any au courant reviewer was about a new phonograph preamplifier.

title: Pirates Catch Exposed Route of Arms in Sudan
description: KHARTOUM, Sudan  It was September 2008 and a band of Somali pirates made a startling discovery.

title: F.C.C. Ponders Ways to Avoid Cable Blackouts
description: WASHINGTON  Seeking to end the brinksmanship that left many cable television customers in the Northeast without access to the first two games of the World Series this year, the Federal Communications Commission will consider changes to the rules governing negotiations between cable providers and broadcast networks, an agency official said Wednesday.

title: As Windows Slide Shut, a Trade Moves On
description: Jesus Leonardos usual place of business felt more like a funeral parlor than a betting parlor on Wednesday.

title: Twins that Look Alike, and Work Alike
description: Arlene Sloan is not sure which of her twin sons, Brett or Michael, helped sell some sports-themed wallpaper to a startled customer at her interior design shop. It was nearly four decades ago, when the boys were just 8 or 9 years old, and they were  and still are  so much alike that either could have been the precocious salesman.

title: Yankees Offer Cliff Lee $140 Million
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Armed with a lucrative contract proposal from the Yankees, Cliff Lees agent left the winter meetings Wednesday afternoon to fly back to Arkansas to consult with his most coveted client. In related news, Brian Cashman, the teams general manager, said he felt like Hannibal Lecter in a straitjacket while he waited for a decision.

title: ODonnells Magic Turns Loss Into Gain
description: Christine ODonnells failed bid for a Delaware Senate seat could turn out to be her big win.

title: Cold Leaves Detroit Unfazed
description: DETROIT  This is what a 20-something-degree day means around here: Most of the smokers huddling outside businesses wear gloves. Taking indoor tunnels between buildings is acceptable. It is time to start searching closets for the ankle-length parkas and enormous boots, giving up any semblance of fashion.

title: Miamians Bundle Up; Tourists Insist Its Fine
description: MIAMI  Cold weather does many things to this paradise of palm trees and pink. It empties Biscayne Bay of boats, it leads parents to dig winter hats from storage. But above all else, it sharpens the divide between residents and visitors.

title: Uncommon Cold Strikes in Georgia
description: ATLANTA  What people in the South dont know about cold is a lot.

title: Bridge and Tunnel Types
description: Take a date to the Brooklyn Bridge for spectacular views and a romantic stroll. Take a drive in the Lincoln Tunnel and prepare for a cramped, crawling trip to New Jersey.

title: Power Shift: Red Sox Sign Crawford
description: ORLANDO, Fla.

title: U.S. Union Backing Boosts Korea Trade Pact
description: An unusual split in the labor movement has developed over President Obamas proposed free-trade pact with South Korea, with two powerful unions backing the deal  a development that experts say will make Congressional ratification far more likely.

title: In Tax Deal, Many Public Employees Will Pay More
description: More bad news for government workers.

title: Bond Yields Continue Their Climb
description: Investors sold Treasuries for a second consecutive day on Wednesday, sending interest rates higher in response to the tentative deal to extend Bush-era tax cuts even as the Federal Reserve was trying aggressively to keep borrowing costs low.

title: More Antarctic Cruise Ship Peril
description: .Dec. 9, 9:12 a.m. | Updated My friend Jon Bowermaster, a peripatetic kayaking filmmaker and travel writer, alerted me overnight to a post he wrote on an unfolding maritime emergency as the cruise ship Clelia II struggled* with limited power in extraordinarily violent seashalfway between the Antarctic Peninsula and Cape Horn.

title: On Beltran, Mets Are All Ears
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Whenever one team inquires about a player on another team who does not figure into that clubs plans, it is an intriguing conversation. Such was the case, if only for a brief moment, when the Boston Red Sox asked the Mets about Carlos Beltran on Tuesday night.

title: Another Politician Falls, and Earth Barely Shakes
description: CARMEL, N.Y.

title: Love the Name, if Not the E.R.A.
description: The Mets once had a Buzz (as in Capra). So why not a Boof?

title: Surviving Hitler and Stalin to Fight Poverty and Cancer
description: For Larisa Shchetinina, now 72, the decision to leave Ukraine  though not the act itself  came suddenly. In 1992, she went to Kiev to say goodbye to her brother, who was moving to Israel. In the center of the countrys capital she saw graffiti on a wall that read, in large letters: Lets drown Russians in Jewish blood.

title: New York Betting Parlors Close Doors
description: After more threats of extinction than anyone could remember, the New York City Off-Track Betting Corporation unexpectedly made good on a threat of its own and closed the doors to its parlors on Tuesday night.

title: Lottery Numbers

title: Class and the Culture War (II)
description: One final point on the National Marriage Project report. Ive been emphasizing the bad news, but I do think its genuinely good news that well-educated opinion as opposed to just well-educated behavior has been moving in a more conservative direction on divorce. (48 percent of college-educated Americans now agree that divorce should be more difficult to obtain, up from just 36 percent in the 1970s.) When social conservatives try to envision public policy responses to the crisis of the American family, theyre almost inevitably stymied by the fact that our upper class (which is, by extension, our policymaking class), while increasingly conservative in the way its members arrange their own private lives, remains intensely allergic to the kind of legal and cultural paternalism that certain earlier elites practiced as a matter of course. Ive suggested before that America would benefit if its upper class showed a willingness to translate some of the more conservative habits theyve embraced (or partially embraced) in their personal lives into law and public policy, but Ive never seen much reason for optimism that our elite might actually move in this direction. So the fact that theres been an uptick in college-educated support for reforming divorce laws is better news than I expected  and a sign, perhaps, that the educated classs present mix of private conservatism and public permissiveness isnt set in stone.

At Art Barter, opening tonight at NP Contemporary Art Center on Chrystie Street, your money is no good anyway. Instead you can offer up your personal goods or services in exchange for a work by, say, Tom Sachs or Terence Koh. The idea for Art Barter, which made its debut last year in London, came from Lauren Jones and Alix Janta, who were inspired by the free-thinking ways of Burning Man, the RCA Postcard Auction and Freecycle. If youre stuck for ideas, here are some things that have changed hands in the past: a Tracey Emin piece for 30 hours of French tutoring; a Jason Dodge work for a week in a Scottish castle. description: About a year and a half ago, I gave an unreserved rave to the Skyfire browser. I did the same about a year ago when the browser was made available forAndroid, with speedy downloads and the ability to show Adobe Flash animation on phones that didnt support it.

title: Row Houses Gone Wild
description: THEY say free-range chicken is better  how about free-range blocks? Seventy-First Street from West End to Broadway rises steeply midblock and then, like a roller coaster  wheeee!  hurtles downhill. The architecture has a certain giddy touch, joyously untempered by the good taste of contextualism so often claimed as an urban ideal.

title: Visiting an Ordinarily Unique Artist
description: Here is a description of some of the most innovative and important American theater of the last quarter of the 20th century. A man sits at a table and starts talking. If he has props, they are minimal  a spiral notebook, a record player, a box of pictures  and his costume is correspondingly modest, consisting usually of a flannel shirt, blue jeans or chinos, and sneakers. He speaks mostly about himself, digressing from anecdotes about his childhood and professional life into more serious confessional territory, though always with reserve and good humor.

title: Bystanders to Chinas Transition
description: The Beijing-born, New York-based filmmaker Miao Wang follows three cabbies around her old hometown in the picturesque documentary Beijing Taxi, filmed over several years leading up to the 2008 Beijing Olympics. The cabbies have interesting and poignant things to say about being left behind in Chinas rush to modernize, and Ms. Wang; her directors of photography, Ian Vollmer and Sean Price Williams; and her editor, Sikay Tang, have produced an attractive and seamless set of images of working-class Chinese life. (The chronology gets a little herky-jerky, with major changes in the drivers lives happening entirely off screen.)

title: In Rare Bow to Public, Russian Tower to be Moved
description: MOSCOW  The city authorities in St. Petersburg intend to relocate a planned 1,299-foot glass-and-steel tower for the state energy company Gazprom, saying it has caused too much dissension among architects and residents for it to be built at the chosen site in the citys historic center.

title: Friends Who Didnt Mince Words
description: The story of Julia Childs life  how a gawky and outgoing diplomats wife from Pasadena, Calif., came to write the classic Mastering the Art of French Cooking (1961)  has been told so many times and in so many ways (biographies, memoirs, histories of American eating, movies, PBS documentaries, blogs) that its not clear theres more worth knowing. This potato has been peeled.

title: F.B.I. Asks Panel to Delay Report on Anthrax Inquiry

title: In Zurich, A District Cleans Up
description: Gentrification is cleaning up the vibrant Aussersihl district of Zurich, where restaurants and galleries are edging out the questionable characters.

title: An Eras Injustices Fuel an Artists Activist Works
description: PURCHASE, N.Y.  The American artist Faith Ringgold, who turned 80 this year, is best known for the vivacious story quilts about African-American life that shes made over the past three decades. But if all that survived from her career were her paintings and prints from the 1960s and early 70s, shed still be in the history books. An inspired and incisive exhibition at the Neuberger Museum of Art here shows why.

description: Customers looking for custom bra fittings, on-site alteration and hard-to-find sizes have relied on the shop for more than three decades.

title: Metropolitan to Host Czannes Card Players
description: In the 1890s, when Czanne was depicting nude figures in his series of Bathers and experimenting with landscapes in his canvases of Mont Sainte-Victoire, he was also painting several of the workers on his family farm near Aix-en-Provence. What he captured in paintings and drawings were the figures of stocky, pipe-smoking men, their expressions dour, their dress drab. Some he painted by themselves, others in twos or threes sitting around a table absorbed in a game of cards. This later group  Card Players, as the series is known  was a 19th-century take on the so-called genre painting made famous by 17th-century Dutch masters.

title: Make Em Laugh With Tales of Tears
description: If my life wasnt funny, it would just be true, and that is completely unacceptable is how Carrie Fisher rationalizes rehashing the more sordid details in books, screenplays, blogs, a Broadway show called Wishful Drinking and now an HBO film version of that stage performance.

title: Pfizer to Pay Its Ex-Chief $4.5 Million in Severance

title: Perils of the Corporate Ladder: It Hurts When You Fall
description: The Company Men puts us down on the ground after having been up in the air. The movie powerfully revisits a theme touched on last year in the bitter comic drama Up in the Air: the devastating impact of sudden downsizing on corporate executives who have lived by the treacherous adage You are what you do. Instead of regarding these unfortunate men from the lofty perspective of a charming, cynical hatchet man logging frequent-flier miles  George Clooneys character in Up in the Air  The Company Men looks them straight in the eye from inside the trenches.

title: How Much Instability Is Too Much?
description: Will Oldham, performing as Bonnie Prince Billy at Town Hall on Wednesday night, spent a lot of time standing on one foot: hopping, swinging his left leg, tucking it up under him like a stork. Perhaps, as he does in his songs, he was testing just how much instability he could get away with. He never toppled.

title: His Path From Shutter to Paintbrush
description: If you think you know all you need to know about Norman Rockwell, think again. Norman Rockwell: Behind the Camera at the Brooklyn Museum is a revelation. It is no secret that Rockwell relied on photographs to achieve the seeming naturalism of his paintings. But the extent and sophistication of his use of photography from the late 1930s on will come as a surprise to many of his fans and detractors.

title: Chic Peek | Dior Store Reopens
description: To celebrate the reopening tomorrow of Christian Diors sprawling 57th Street flagship, the houses creative director of accessories, Camille Miceli, designed a clutch of one-of-a-kind jewels, including this $3,500 metal and crackled ceramic necklace. The two-level boutique, which has been given a glamorous face-lift by Peter Marino, also features several chic art commissions, including mirrored glass installations by Rob Wynne, a Oyoram video piece and a stunning ceiling relief by David Wiseman. 21 East 57th Street; (212) 931-2950.

title: When Youthful Desire Grows Into Regret
description: When Lee Hoibys opera Summer and Smoke, adapted from the Tennessee Williams play, had its premiere in 1971, it was criticized by some for its conservative music, awash in the harmonic language of Menotti (Mr. Hoibys mentor), Barber and Mahler, and its unabashedly lyrical vocal writing. But the work, with an effective and delicately poetic libretto by the playwright Lanford Wilson, also won deserved praise for doing what an opera is supposed to do: telling the story with sure dramatic pacing and understated expressivity, in music admirable for its directness and melodic grace.

Its the tale of the passage from the East to the West, and of the transformation of a young Chinese boy into, well, a ballerina. More precisely (say it slowly), into Nina Enimenimynimova. Now say it faster: EE-nee-MEE-nee-MIN-i-MOH-va.

But for all the shows seasonal trimmings, the religious aspect of Christmas is conspicuously absent. Santa Claus, mistletoe, snowy wonderlands and hopes for peace on earth proliferate, but the Nativity remains backstage.

description: If Scrooge and Tiny Tim are making nice and the Rockettes are wearing out their tap shoes, it must mean that the holiday theater season is here. Whether Christmas makes you want to twirl in the snow or hurl on Santas lap, there are plenty of shows  from the cheery to the blasphemous  to keep the winter blahs at bay. Reviewers for The New York Times have weighed in on Looking at Christmas and Elf, but here are a few more ideas, with suggestions for who might most appreciate a seat. (Tickets can be purchased at theatermania.com unless otherwise indicated.)

title: Playwright Clears His Stage and Bookcases
description: TWO years ago Ed Schmidt, a New York playwright, got word that his father was near death in upstate New York. He bundled his family into the car and drove north, explaining to his young children on the way the sad fact that Grandpa might not recognize them when they got there. As it happened, they arrived minutes too late; Willie Schmidt, a former history teacher and camp director, had died, probably as they were parking the car.

description: NOT long ago, the friend of a friend spent the night in a hotel room, which is sometimes what you do when you find out your spouse has been having a yearlong affair. His flight was sadly predictable  its all many of us are capable of after discovering such a betrayal  though I am sure he now realizes that mere movement is not a fix for that kind of agony.

description: Episode 2 of NBCs a cappella series The Sing-Off helped lift the network into second place in the ratings on Wednesday. According to Nielsens estimates, 7.6 million viewers tuned in to the series from 8 to 10 p.m., down slightly from the 8.6 million who tuned in to the Sing-Off premiere on Monday but still just enough to give NBC an edge over ABC for the night. CBS easily led the night over all, earning 12.2 million at 8 for Survivor: Nicaragua and 14.2 million at 9 for Criminal Minds. ABC garnered its best ratings with Modern Family at 9 (11 million) and The Middle at 8 (8.8 million). Fox was fourth.

title: In the South of France, a 1927 Mnage  Trois Takes an Incendiary Turn
description: The life and work of Ernest Hemingway have been notoriously difficult to translate comfortably onto the screen. For one thing, his signature spare sentences, when spoken by actors, often sound as affected as the most rococo effusions of Oscar Wilde. Beyond that, Hemingways chest-beating, rifle-bearing Papa Bear explorer persona seems overbearingly pompous if not creepily antediluvian in these postfeminist times.

title: Eat Free? I Do!
description: My fianc and I are researching venues for our wedding rehearsal dinner. We found an Italian restaurant that seemed perfect. We sat with the manager and came up with menu ideas, and told him we would come back that night to try the food. We returned with a couple of friends and spoke with the night manager, who knew about us and promised to take care of us. The meal was multicoursed and delicious, but we were shocked by a $300 tab. Were we wrong to take the manager at his word and assume the meal would be free?

title: I Just Popped Out to Play Beethoven
description: If you question whether the Museum of Modern Art should be collecting works of performance art, your doubts may be assuaged by the sight and sound of Stop, Repair, Prepare: Variations on Ode to Joy for a Prepared Piano, a trenchant, newly acquired work by Allora & Calzadilla, the artist team that will represent the United States at the next Venice Biennale. Created in 2008 and first exhibited at the Haus der Kunst in Munich that year, this performance-sculpture-recital-dance piece was an instant hit when it was at the Gladstone Gallery in Chelsea in January 2009.

title: Let a Hail of Bullets Be Your Umbrella
description: As far as movie meet-cutes go its hard to beat the one in Vengeance, when the mystery man played by the French chanteur Johnny Hallyday runs into three Hong Kong assassins in a Macau hotel. The three have just finished a job and slipped into the hall when theyre surprised by Costello (Mr. Hallyday), whos headed toward his room. He gives them and their weapons the once over and strolls away, just another visiting Frenchman taking in the existential view. One beat later and theyre the best of friends.

title: Chanels Byzantine Express
description: I always love Chanels Mtiers dArts collection, created in 2002 to showcase the work of the small Paris ateliers, like Lesage, that the company bought. The clothes are quietly evocative of a place and usually a little more down-to-earth than couture. And, as we know, Karl Lagerfeld never minds extra work. Ive seen two of the shows (in Paris and Tokyo); the latest one I had to catch online. It was held in the house, on the Rue Cambon. Called Paris-Byzance, the collection didnt quite soar off to Byzantium  too somber in color and shape, I suppose  but I liked the use of square shapes (jeweled buttons especially), the straight-line long dresses, many of the murky carpet-colored tweeds, the flat sandals and Frejas slouchy pants.

title: Educator Is Said to Have Rejected Chancellor Job
description: In defending his selection for schools chancellor, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has called Cathleen P. Black, a publishing executive with no education experience, exactly the right person for the job and suggested that her skills as a manager were unrivaled.

title: Exploring the Art of Louisiana Furniture
description: Louisiana cabinetmakers under Napoleonic rule earned job titles as elite as bniste and doreur, building and gilding furniture for plantation owners. The artisans ranks included slaves, free men of color and immigrants from Germany and the Caribbean. But they developed a signature Louisiana style.

title: J.&J. Unit Issues Recall of Rolaids
description: A unit of Johnson & Johnson announced a nationwide recall on Thursday of all lots  more than 13 million packages  of the soft chewable versions of Rolaids, its popular antacid drug, after reports of consumers finding metal and wood particles in the products.

title: Misfits Life of Exaggeration
description: The introspective ramblings of a young, underemployed actress get a thorough airing in You Wont Miss Me, an experimental portrait of a New York misfit for whom sex and the city are no longer enough.

title: Warsaw Makes a Bid to Be Central Europes Financial Hub
description: WARSAW  It may come as a surprise to some people that the upstart Warsaw Stock Exchange has surpassed the venerable Vienna exchange in trading volume, but to Ludwik Sobolewski, president of the Polish bourse, this is old news indeed.

title: Modern Treasure Hunts for the Whole Family
description: NOT long after Morgan Lawless, now 13, took up geocaching last year, he asked his mother, Lisa, if she could drive him to a cache near their home in Mamaroneck, N.Y., and let him seek hidden treasure by following Google maps on his iPad Touch.

title: Movies in a Tunnel; Words and Photos in Harlem
description: This weekend Rooftop Films goes underground for two afternoons to show movies in the Atlantic Avenue tunnel in Brooklyn. On Saturday the event is Trapped in the Tunnel, a program of short films about people who venture into unknown territory, like an insurgents cave in the Iraqi desert, an abandoned coal mine in Pennsylvania and, in Covered Tracks, a film by Nathan Kensinger and Meghan OHara, a train tunnel under Manhattan that is 50 blocks long and has served as a makeshift town for the homeless. On Sunday a second series of shorts, Tunnel of Love, about ill-fated romance, will be shown. On both days the door, or rather the manhole on Atlantic Avenue and Court Street through which the audience will enter (down a 10-foot ladder), opens at 1 p.m. A tour of the tunnel begins at 1:45, with the screening at 2:15. A party at Last Exit bar (136 Atlantic Avenue, near Clinton Street) starts at around 4:15; drinks are compliments of Sailor Jerry rum. (Cobble Hill, Brooklyn; 718-417-7362, rooftopfilms.com; $20.)

title: Step Hits Its Stride Again
description: FOR many, the very mention of step aerobics evokes images of exercisers in leg warmers and leotards, even though other classes have come to dominate group schedules at gyms today. In New York City, however, this seemingly faded fad from the 1990s is far from dead.

title: Laura Halzack and Eric Naison-Phillips
description: LAURA HALZACK began studying ballet before she started school, and after graduating from the University of New Hampshire, dedicated herself to a career in dance. She left her hometown, Suffield, Conn., for Astoria, Queens, and filled hard years working odd jobs at night so she could take dance classes during the day. She joined the Paul Taylor Dance Company in 2006 and, as her star ascended, she learned to live a nomadic life on the road, touring for weeks on end.

title: Unlicensed Drivers and Fatal Crashes
description: States have enacted measures to prevent illegal immigrants from having drivers licenses and increased enforcement of laws against unlicensed driving. About 80 percent of illegal immigrants are Hispanic. According to federal crash data, Hispanic drivers killed in crashes are disproportionately unlicensed, particularly in Southern states where illegal immigration surged in the last decade.

title: House Tour: Bridgeport, Conn.
Grey New York to Be Led by Its Chief Creative Officer
description: GREY, long dismissed as being as creative as its name, is giving a creative executive the job of leading its New York office, the agencys largest, which produces campaigns for marketers like Canon, DirecTV, E*Trade, GlaxoSmithKline, Pfizer and Procter & Gamble.

description: YEONPYEONG ISLAND, South Korea  Choi Cheol-yeong vividly recalls the shock and fear that he felt during North Koreas lethal bombardment of this small island, and says his nerves remain on edge because he thinks another attack will come, possibly during South Korean artillery drills this week.

title: Royals Hear Shouts of Off With Their Heads in London
description: Updated | Friday | 9:08 a.m. As my colleague John Burns reports, the enduring image of Thursdays protests in London may well be the stunned looks on the faces of Prince Charles and his wife Camilla, as they were subjected to a barrage of abuse while driving past protesters on Londons Regent Street.

title: John E. du Pont, Heir Who Killed an Olympian, Dies at 72
description: John E. du Pont, an heir to the du Pont chemical fortune whose benevolent support of Olympic athletes deteriorated into delusion and ended in the shooting death of a champion wrestler, died Thursday in a western Pennsylvania prison. He was 72.

title: After Aetna, Pondering Health Care
description: When tensions between the Obama administration and the nations health insurers were at their highest earlier this year, Ronald A. Williams, the chief executive of Aetna, stood out as one of the few industry voices that still resonated within the White House.

title: A Bankrupt Bargain on Taxes
description: While Wall Streets moguls and whiz kids might not want to admit it, the best way to figure out whats really happening in the economy is to read the daily newspapers. Youll learn all you need to know there. And the zeitgeist is fairly bubbling these days with an array of stories that seem to be pointing to serious economic trouble ahead. We can no longer ignore the message that is being broadcast loud and clear: We must get our fiscal house in order and take meaningful  exceedingly painful, yes  steps to close the $1.3 trillion federal budget deficit. You can be the most zealous Keynesian economist on the planet and still know that at some point we cannot continue to have both guns and butter without serious repercussions. And we have clearly reached that point.

title: New York City Sues State Over the Cost of Housing Juveniles in Prisons
description: Taking a contentious step intended to shake up the states troubled juvenile prison system, New York City is suing the state, claiming it overcharged tens of millions of dollars a year for housing many of the citys young offenders in upstate jails.

title: Putting Rumors to Rest, Howard Stern Renews His Sirius XM Contract
description: Howard Stern is staying on satellite radio for another five years.

title: A Love Tormented but Triumphant
description: If youre going to read more than 700 pages of someones diary covering just a decade, you want him to be a good writer, to know interesting people, to be intensely self-aware and above all to be a fascinating companion. Christopher Isherwood ranks high on every count. He was 56 years old when he began these diaries in 1960, an Englishman whod lived in the States since 1939, mostly in Los Angeles. In his youth he was best known for his Berlin novels, Mr. Norris Changes Trains and Goodbye to Berlin, on which much later the musical Cabaret was based.

title: A Volleyball Contender Built on Family
description: The University of Northern Iowas McLeod Center in Cedar Falls has a sort of bandbox quality. Three thousand fans can sound like 10,000.

title: Visualizing Slavery
description: The 1860 Census was the last time the federal government took a count of the Souths vast slave population. Several months later, the United States Coast Surveyarguably the most important scientific agency in the nation at the timeissued two maps of slavery that drew on the Census data, the first of Virginia and the second of Southern states as a whole. Though many Americans knew that dependence on slave labor varied throughout the South, these maps uniquely captured the complexity of the institution and struck a chord with a public hungry for information about the rebellion.

title: Interim Coach Leads Vikings Out of Storm

title: How Real Does It Feel?
description: Is it a documentary? Is it like a documentary? I find myself hearing (and asking) these questions so often that I have started to wonder what they mean. Its not just that the definition of documentary itself is mutable: unlike other journalistic and quasi-journalistic forms, no code of ethics has ever been agreed upon by practitioners of the art, and what rules of thumb there are tend to be temporary, controversial and broken as soon as they are made. To take examples only from this calendar year, a single generic rubric covers a muckraking, talking-head essay on Wall Street like Charles Fergusons Inside Job, a ruminative memoir on parenthood like The Kids Grow Up, by Doug Block, and an exercise in intensive fly-on-the-wall objectivity like Frederick Wisemans aptly titled Boxing Gym. And those are just the easy cases  the nonfiction films that the academy might agree to consider for its award in the always-crowded and controversial feature-documentary category.

title: Thunder and Lightning
description: A century after Jim Thorpe first found athletic fame at the Carlisle Indian Industrial School in Pennsylvania, his sporting career is preserved primarily by witnesses words rather than by objective measurement. When he was at his peak, in the early 1900s, his best sport, football, was in its infancy, a rough game undergoing basic rule changes and largely devoid of statistics. What made him exceptional in any case was the unquantifiable combination of power and speed, only hinted at in yardage totals or points. Florid descriptions by the sportswriters of the day and recollections by those who played with him and against him make up a majority of the record. One reporter described his broken-field running as demonstrating amazing intelligence, as he evaded tacklers by an easy lope that carries him over the ground at remarkable speed without betraying any undue haste. His famed coach at Carlisle, Pop Warner, taught his player the technique of unexpected contact, which Thorpe mastered, where you sometimes fake the defensive player to make him stop moving, then, wham, you hit him with the hip or stiff arm, in the words of a teammate.

It was the first movie from her production company, Blossom Films, and, as a producer, Ms. Kidman made an unorthodox choice for director in John Cameron Mitchell (Hedwig and the Angry Inch), who had never before directed a movie he didnt write. Rabbit Hole was made for about $4 million, and eventually bought for distribution by Lionsgate. It opens Dec. 17 in limited release. In a wide-ranging interview in a SoHo hotel room recently, Ms. Kidman and Mr. Mitchell spoke about the constraints of indie filmmaking, their childhood and adult inspirations. This is an edited version of their conversation.

title: Cmon, Touch Me Babe

We know of only one  this liquid blue Science of Sequin frock from the spring collection of Boudicca, the London-based label designed by Zowie Broach and Brian Kirkby. Run a hand over the sequins and they flip over, revealing a paler underside; if the path of the caress is retraced, they return to their original position. The idea of making a garment that recorded touch was, says Broach, seductive as soon we came across the fabric. It immediately inspired your sense of imagination and play. Only six dresses were made, and they arrive in stores this week, just in time for the holiday cocktail circuit. What would be amazing, Kirkby says, would be to know where they finally end up. But something as unique as this is possibly best a secret that takes its own time to tell.

The auction house said the winning bid, which includes the houses commission, was made by Adam Sender, whom it identified as an American collector; he is also a hedge fund trader whose office is home to works by Ed Ruscha, Kara Walker and John Currin, according to a recent report by Bloomberg News. Mr. Sender took part in the auction by phone and outbid three other contenders to claim his trophy, which Sothebys expected to fetch $200,000 to $300,000. With this lot Mr. Sender does not receive the verse that begins, Come writers and critics who prophesize with your pen, which Mr. Dylan apparently added later, nor does he own the 1960s, which belong to everyone, man.

title: American Girl
description: Many readers of Little Women have fantasized about being Jo; a few about being Meg, Beth or Amy. After reading Susan Cheevers biography of Louisa May Alcott, even fewer would want to change places with the novels author. Like her heroine, Alcott was a bookish tomboy with three sisters, a writer who churned out pseudonymous melodramas before finding fame as a domestic novelist. Unlike Jo, Alcott never married, concluding that liberty is a better husband than love. Where Jo romps with her own children as well as a houseful of her husbands students, Alcott declared that she never liked girls and stayed clear of children until adopting a niece at 48. A third difference is that Little Women portrays a matriarchal household made up of a mother, her daughters and their cook. Adding a servant spared her characters some of the domestic work that ate up Alcotts own time. An even greater wish-fulfillment, however, lay in subtracting the man of the house. The March girls spend much of the novel waiting for their father to return from the Civil War, but in real life Alcott was the one who left Concord, Mass., in 1861 to nurse wounded soldiers.

title: The Shores of Tripoli

As a result, we Americans have tended to view this history through the lens of our own past. Adrian Tinniswoods dramatic narrative, Pirates of Barbary, reminds us that the corsairs had preyed on Europeans long before the United States arrived on the scene. Her father, the owner of three of the best restaurants in the city, has chosen a young man named Jinyi because he has agreed to take their family name, to live in their house and to let Yuying continue her studies. What Yuying doesnt know is that her future husband is illiterate and of peasant stock. Although only a few years older than she, he has led a life of extraordinary hardship. He is, however, a good and loyal person and a fine cook. And the one thing he has never had  and really wants  is a family.

title: Paperback Row
description: BLOOD-DARK TRACK: A Family History,  by Joseph ONeill (Vintage, $15.95.) First published in 2001, ONeills reconstruction of the lives of his grandfathers  one Turkish, one Irish, both imprisoned on suspicion of subversion during World War II  is a double narrative involving an unsolved 65-year-old murder, a rusted pistol, clandestine train travel and assignations in the dark. ONeill tirelessly turns the soil of his grandfathers lives, discovering proofs of guilt or innocence in the offhand utterances of relatives, in obscure documents . . . and in shards of local history, politics, language and custom, Colin Harrison wrote in the Book Review.

title: Tragedy in Black and White
description: In the austral summer of 2005-6, the veteran magazine journalist Fen Montaigne traveled to Palmer Station in Antarctica to work with the highly regarded polar ecologist Bill Fraser. For nearly five months, Montaigne gamely weighed and banded Adlie penguins and their predators, attached radio tags to feathers, dodged shooting streams of gack (giant-petrel vomit), sifted through guano in search of silverfish otoliths and reveled in the sensory delights of the most alien and beautiful place on the planet.

title: Learned Lolita
description: Characters should want something in every scene, Kurt Vonnegut once advised fiction writers, even if its only a glass of water. The idea is that yearning makes us human, and our idiosyncratic desires often get us into interesting forms of trouble. At the start of his new novel, Sunset Park, Paul Auster merrily disregards Vonneguts rule, introducing Miles Heller as a man with no longings or hopes who has trained himself to want as little as humanly possible. On the surface, Sunset Park is fairly straightforward, without Austers trademark postmodern flourishes. Yet he tests the rules throughout, as if the experiment were to write a conventionally satisfying novel while bucking many of the conventions of how to write fiction.

title: Hallucinatory Effects
description: Jim Carroll died at the age of 60 a year ago. Rumor has it that his death had something to do with liver damage due to substance abuse. If that is incorrect, repeating it here is no more or less unfair than the way he himself massaged the facts of his life for public consumption. Carroll was a product of his imagination, like many of the best poets (Col. Tom Parker, Guillaume Apollinaire, Josef von Sternberg), and he was one of the best poets. Theres a parallel time and world inhabited by those who understand that all information is legend, that experience is show business. Thats why Hollywood is the dream factory and Carrolls first commercial poetry collection was Living at the Movies (and perhaps why his Selected Poems is called Fear of Dreaming). He lived in his head. Doesnt everyone? The difference is that he knew it.

title: All the Kings Men

title: European Exotic
description: Hedy Lamarr, born Hedwig Kiesler in 1914 in Vienna, enjoyed an early if not particularly auspicious start in Max Reinhardts theater, and a few bit parts in movies before the Czech director Gustav Machaty cast her as the centerpiece of Ecstasy. The idyll of a young bride, married to a frigid older man, who finds liberation in the arms of a virile engineer was genuinely audacious in its concentration on a womans thwarted desire. But what made it the scandal of its time  1933  and onward were bucolic nude scenes of the star swimming and chasing a runaway horse, and rapturous close-ups of her sexual awakening. Seeing it now, one imagines generations of adolescents approaching it expecting soft-core titillation and being disappointed by the wholesomeness of a girl who is less sex goddess than pudgy teenager with small breasts (about which more to come). In an all-but-silent movie that has more in common with Leni Riefenstahls mountain-girl films (not to mention Soviet paeans to the Noble Worker), Hedwig is radiantly and un-self-consciously au naturel, lovely but as yet unformed, undefined.

title: Waterworld

He made his name with The Professor and the Madman, a gripping account about murder, insanity and the making of the Oxford English Dictionary. His subsequent output revealed a taste for big Earthy subjects. The Map That Changed the World spun the history of geology into a popular beach book. Later books turned the same trick with volcanoes (Krakatoa) and earthquakes (A Crack in the Edge of the World).

description: Carlo Rotellas article, about the film professor and Focus Features C.E.O. James Schamus, is a paean to what a liberal-arts education should be about  the appreciation and contemplation of truth and beauty. This ought not be limited to classes like Schamuss; it should be an essential part of every education. The next generation will be the first in our nations history to be less educated while spending more time in school because of the obsessive focus on education as only a means to a future paycheck. I hope Schamuss students wander far and wide and continue the essential pollination of all our professional endeavors with his particular brand of weird.

title: Letter: A Big, Fat Miracle
description: As the author of a book on the use of enteral nutrition to treat Crohns disease, I am all too familiar with the skepticism Fred Vogelstein faces because of his sons use of the ketogenic diet for epilepsy (Nov. 21). Like the keto diet, enteral nutrition  an all-liquid diet  has been recognized for decades as an effective treatment for Crohns. But in spite of randomized, controlled trials confirming its efficacy, few doctors prescribe it, and patients who try it face the same curiosity bordering on alarm that Vogelstein describes. Unfortunately, the proliferation of quack dietary treatments has made gaining acceptance of nutritional therapies that actually have solid science behind them an uphill battle.

title: Letter: Killing a Dead Horse
description: Sadhbh Walshes anecdote distilled a sentiment I have struggled to articulate since the economic downturn: despite our collective temptation to indulge in defeatist lamentations over our imagined powerlessness  given the job market, mortgage crisis, health care and so on  our work may lie in the situation that is right before us, whether that be the opportunity to extend love to a friend, a neighbor or an animal in need. These seemingly small gestures may be our right work at the moment. Thank you for reminding us how immeasurably powerful we human beings are in the best and worst of times.EMMA LYNN WORTHNew York

description: LIKE a presidential election or the arrival of a rare astronomical body, the release of a new James L. Brooks movie is always an event. Its been six years since his last directorial effort, Spanglish, and 13 since the release of As Good as It Gets, which won Academy Awards for Jack Nicholson and Helen Hunt. At 70 Mr. Brooks could easily rest on his laurels: a roster of credits that includes The Mary Tyler Moore Show and Taxi, Broadcast News and Terms of Endearment, not to mention his current day job as an executive producer of The Simpsons; he was also a writer and producer on The Simpsons Movie in 2007. Instead hes getting back into the game with How Do You Know, a romantic comedy (which Columbia Pictures will release on Friday) about the intertwined lives of a professional softball player (Reese Witherspoon), her self-assured boyfriend (Owen Wilson), an executive (Paul Rudd) in legal trouble, and his father (Mr. Nicholson).

title: From Vail to Gstaad, Lures Beyond the Slopes
description: THE latest crop of new and improved ski lodges work hard for your money. Its no longer enough to offer ski-in/ski-out access, a downy duvet and hot chocolate by the lobby fire. In an effort to extend their appeal to the occasional skiers or nonskiers in the family, resorts have expanded their off-mountain attractions, adding diversions like increasingly lavish spa treatments, hot-air balloon rides and bowling. Children get special attention at these elevations, with nonski activities tailored to them, including hotel scavenger hunts and mountaineering classes. Guests still check in for the slopes, but now theres much more to do after the lifts close. These newcomers best represent the ski-free entertaining trend.
