title: Avalanche Survival: Know Your Snow
description: IT was a skiers fantasy: four feet of powdery, fresh snow draped across the backcountry of Red Mountain Pass in Colorado. But the dream quickly turned nightmarish when, just a few feet from my skis, the slope tore open and a gash ripped across the mountain like a zipper. I fell into a shallow crevice and watched as a slab of snow broke into chunks that tumbled down like giant cinderblocks.

title: Is Disentis Skiings Next Big Secret?
description: IN the early 1990s, Powder magazine, the proudly die-hard ski rag that has weaned countless future ski bums, published an article in which the author spoke of a mystical ski area of unprecedented off-piste challenge. So paranoid was the writer that this mountains pristine slopes and elevator-shaft chutes would soon be overrun by, well, the rest of us, that he wouldnt even name the place. He would only call it  tantalizingly  Valley X.

title: In Zurich, a District Cleans Up
description: Though questionable characters still populate parts of Aussersihl, bohemian boutiques and avant-garde galleries have moved in over the past few years in other parts of the neighborhood.

title: Switzerlands Valley Z
description: In Disentis, Switzerland, powdery valleys are served by a resorts ski lifts, but they are ungroomed and uncrowded, for now.

title: Bill Clinton Holds Court in Impromptu White House News Conference
description: Former President Bill Clinton held a remarkable, spur-of-the-moment news conference at a White House podium on Friday to announce his backing for the tax compromise President Obama reached with Republicans this week.

title: Rendering Elgars Mercurial Impressions
description: At his best Colin Davis brings a magisterial British reserve touched with wildness to his conducting. This blend of seeming opposites is rarely 50-50. It depends on the piece. And certain composers are best suited to Mr. Daviss passions, among them Berlioz, Sibelius and Stravinsky.

title: Where Is Reggie Bushs Heisman?
description: The Heisman Trophy is, presumably, somewhere in New York City.

title: Sanders Rails Against Tax Bill  For Hours and Hours
description: 7:04 p.m. | Updated Senator Bernard Sanders, independent of Vermont, took to the floor of the Senate at 10:24 this morning to denounce the tax cut deal struck between the White House and congressional Republicans  and kept going for more than eight hours.

title: The Week in Pictures for Dec. 10
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the new 42nd Street, the Chelsea Hotel and a memorial for a Beatle.

title: Chic In Review | When Giorgio Met Gaga
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Illness Forces Navratilova to Leave Charity Climb
description: Had the climb gone according to plan, it would have been shared every step of the way, every dollar raised, Martina from Mount Kilimanjaro calling out to the world for a good cause.

title: At Michaels With Kirsten Dunst and All Good Things
description: The last time the Bagger was at Michaels, we were having lunch with a midget (his term) wrestler named Puppet.

title: Laughing and Crying at Ghosts, Fictive and Real
description: Perhaps the best way to describe Jack Fervers new Rumble Ghost, which reinterprets the 1982 horror film Poltergeist and later morphs into a psychodrama-therapy session, is that its a piece of theater with some dancing and a lot of choreography. In any case, its darkly funny.

title: Private Negotiations Within a Public Setting
description: At the start of Risa Jaroslows new piece, The Partner Project/Scene in Public, a woman (Elise Knudson) walks briskly around the edge of the audience and then onto the stage, wearing a light coat. This may be a nod to New Yorks frigid weather. But the fact that it takes a moment to register Ms. Knudson as a dancer, stepping from public realm to stage, seems emblematic of Ms. Jaroslows work, which has frequently blurred the lines between art and life in its use of nondancers and its preoccupation with community.

title: Boyfriend Is Charged in Designers Death
description: Read the full version of this article appearing in Saturdays newspaper.

title: Formula One Confirms 4-Cylinder Engines for 2011
description: From our colleagues at the Formula One blog:

title: Echoes From a Distant Contemporary Past
description: This is a collectors show. Nothing wrong with that. After all, collectors are people, too  very important people. They are the ones who keep the lights on and the curators running. Without patrons like the Medici, Pope Pius IV and the kings of France, we would not have Michelangelo, Leonardo or Versailles.

title: The Airport Playhouse Is Grounded for Good
description: THE Airport Playhouse in Bohemia was in financial peril when Ed Brennan and his wife, Terry, started running it six years ago, Mr. Brennan said.

title: Peter C. Marzio, Director of Museum of Fine Arts, Houston, Dies
description: Peter C. Marzio, the director of the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston, for the last 28 years, died this morning of cancer, the museum announced. He was 67. During his tenure, the museums attendance increased from 380,000 people annually to over 2 million, and its endowment grew from $25 million to over $700 million. A full obituary will follow.

title: Finding Some Keys to Free Bachs Music
description: THE harpsichordist Bradley Brookshire is on a mission. Mr. Brookshire, an assistant conductor at the Metropolitan Opera and the director of graduate studies at the Purchase College Conservatory of Music, means to infuse Bachs oeuvre with the lifeblood he thinks revisionists have drained out of it. And his performing colleagues are on board.

title: Raunchy Provocateur Exhibits a Different Passion
description: A perceptive listener might have recognized chords from Jesus Christ Superstar being pounded on a piano in a cramped rehearsal space on West 30th Street in Manhattan on Thursday night, but not the potentially sacrilegious way this musical was being performed.

title: Noir-Infused Intrigue at a Lonely Bus Depot
description: I havent yet seen Spider Man: Turn Off the Dark on Broadway, but I did get a mild case of arachnophobia while watching The Tangled Skirt, Steve Braunsteins overlong but deftly mannered play now onstage at New Jersey Repertory Company in Long Branch.

title: Rookies Dunks Earn Online Views and On-Court Smiles
description: LOS ANGELES  Blake Griffin first dunked a basketball when he was 13, in the gym of his junior high school in Oklahoma. Nobody remembers it, probably, except for him.

title: Apples With Candied Bacon  la Mode
description: Mark Bittman pairs sweet and savory in a simple dessert.

title: The Game Is Big, but the Crowd Should Be Enormous
description: Almost 110,000 people are expected to watch when Michigan plays Michigan State in Ann Arbor on Saturday, a crowd that will shatter the hockey attendance record by more than 30,000. The notion of a crowd that size, roaring in temperatures expected to be at the freezing mark, a seething well of fans reaching up and up into the overcast wintry sky, gives pause to Rick Comley, the Michigan State coach.

title: Apples With Candied Bacon  la Mode
description: Time: About 30 minutes

title: Finally, a Dessert With Some Meat in It
description: BACONS near-ubiquity has only occasionally extended to the dessert tray, but maybe its not a bad idea. Ive been offered candied bacon a couple of times in the past year, and it got me thinking of a trail of ingredients. Bacon is, after all, a close cousin to lard, and lard makes a significant contribution to the best pie crusts. (You may not know it, but if you find most pie crusts disappointing, its a lack of lard, or butter, or both.)

title: Amazon Extends Holiday Free Shipping Deadline
description: For people who are still in the making a list, checking it twice phase of Christmas shopping, Amazon.com has extended the deadline for free shipping in time for the holiday.

title: Choosing Recipients of Charity
description: December is the season of solicitations, and besides the catalogs peddling obscure gadgets and enormous hunks of meat from the Great Plains, youve also probably received an impressive pile of pleas from various nonprofit institutions.

title: Expanding Bacons Horizons
description: Bacon, apples, ice cream: Not exactly a classic combination, but a good one. Read more in this weeks Minimalist column.

title: Rebuilt Theater Opening Amid Debate
description: It has a storied past that includes names like Eugene ONeill and Edward Albee, and on Saturday the newly renovated Provincetown Playhouse will be opened to the public by New York University, which says it spent $4.5 million restoring a building that has played an important role in Greenwich Village and theatrical history.

title: How to Divide Up Your Charity Budget
description: This weekends Your Money column was born of personal frustration. The charitable solicitations that pile up around this time of year are a nagging reminder to me that my family doesnt do as good of a job as it should of thinking strategically about philanthropy.

title: In a Crumbling Castle, a Coming-of-Age Story
description: I Capture the Castle, a gentle British heirloom currently being presented by the Shakespeare Theater of New Jersey through Jan. 2, falls neatly within the genre of coming-of-age plays. Unfortunately, it can be difficult to tell this type of tale when the actress playing the character who is supposed to be maturing is already a grown woman.

title: Expecting Declarer May Ruff in the Dummy? Lead a Trump
description: The Bobby Nail Life Master Open Pairs at the Fall North American Championships in Orlando, Fla., last month was won by two young Japanese bridge professionals, Kazuo Furuta and Hiroaki Miura. They finished a board ahead of Fred Gitelman of Las Vegas and Brad Moss of San Anselmo, Calif., with Steve Garner of Chicago and Roy Welland of New York third.

title: Early Mass, With Its Exoticism Intact
description: The Ensemble Organum, the French early-music choir directed by Marcel Prs, has explored a rich repertory that runs from old Roman chant to Josquin, with occasional detours to examine Sufi and other Middle Eastern traditions. Mr. Prss research and his view of history as a fluid continuum in which diverse influences mingle have led him to unusual and sometimes provocative ideas about how early church music might have sounded in its time.

title: Its What She Knows: The Luxe Life
description: AT 39 and with four features to her name, Sofia Coppola finds herself caught in something of a double bind  the predicament of the auteur whose constancy risks being seen as predictability, or worse. Her admirers detect in her work a good eye, impeccable taste, an exactitude with indistinct moods and feelings. Her detractors claim that her frame of reference is narrow, that she makes the same film over and over again.

title: Braised Leg of Lamb With Olives and Celery Root Pure
description: Time: About 5 hours

title: Seven-Hour Lamb, in About Five
description: SEVERAL years ago, I made a dish known as seven-hour leg of lamb. A much-esteemed, classic preparation, it called for braising the meat in wine and aromatics for the better part of a day, at which point, said the recipe, Id serve forth a silky, tender cut of meat so soft you could cut it with a spoon.

title: Strands Tied Into a French Knot
description: Among the many gifts that can be ascribed to the brilliant French pianist Pierre-Laurent Aimard, a knack for illuminating connections among the works he plays is certainly high on the list. In recent seasons Mr. Aimard has linked canonical pieces by Bach with modern fare by Xenakis, Ligeti and Elliott Carter; found common ground for Mozart and Stockhausen; and even convincingly played Mr. Carters music alongside a bit of Rachmaninoff.

title: Leadership on the Field Made Him a Legend
description: In the annals of life lessons, coach wisdom has become canonical and perhaps none more so than Vince Lombardis, a fact that is news only to those whose exclusive contact with football has come from Friday Night Lights. Lombardi took over the Green Bay Packers in 1959, when the team was largely an object of derision, and led the franchise to five National Football League championships and two Super Bowl victories before the 60s had come to a conclusion.

title: Now Baking | Blue Bottle Brooklyn Goes Beyond Coffee
description: When Blue Bottle Coffee decided to plant slow-drip roots in New York City asphalt earlier this year, I was excited, sure, but such scoops are better left to the barista trackers. It wasnt until a few weeks later, when James Freeman (thats Mr. Blue Bottle to you) told me about the second phase of his Williamsburg invasion that the mania hit. Hed be bringing the pastry program to Brooklyn in the fall, he said.

description: Chapter 1

description: More Photographs

For Would-Be Authors, a Chance at a Happy Ending

title: Horns Pointed Toward the Future
description: WHEN the tubist Charles Daellenbach and four compatriots formed the Canadian Brass 40 years ago, successful brass quintets were few and questions about the way forward were many.

title: Once-Burned, Highland Is Bullish on Debt
description: After getting burned in the credit crisis, Highland Capital Management is optimistic again about high-yield debt.

title: Walters and Winfrey Together Tie for Second
description: ABCs hourlong Barbara Walters interview special with Oprah Winfrey on Thursday night attracted 13.1 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates, enough to tie CBSs CSI as the second-most-watched show in prime time. Both shows lagged just slightly behind The Mentalist on CBS at 10 p.m., which garnered 13.3 million viewers. CBS led the night ahead of ABC, winning the 8 p.m. hour with its comedies The Big Bang Theory(12.1 million) and $#*! My Dad Says (9.5 million). ABC broadcast the holiday specials Shrek the Halls at 8 (6.9 million) and Prep and Landing and 8:30 (7.5 million). Fox ranked third and NBC fourth.

title: Why C.E.O.s Should Stop at City Hall
description: This past Wednesday, Jim Gray, a wealthy construction executive from Lexington, Ky., flew to New York City for a whirlwind round of meetings. Mr. Gray, 57, is the chief executive of Gray Construction, a family-owned business that builds large industrial facilities for the likes of Toyota, Siemens, Caterpillar and other giant manufacturers. It has around $500 million in annual revenue.

title: Canvas? Paint? No, Just Sound
description: LONDON  The Turner Prize, awarded annually to a British artist 50 or younger, tends to be won by someone who pushes the definition of art in novel and provocative (or derivative and irritating, take your pick) ways.

title: Sexuality in Modernism: The (Partial) History
description: WASHINGTON  With the exhibition Hide/Seek: Difference and Desire in American Portraiture, one of our federally funded museums, the National Portrait Gallery, here in the city of dont ask, dont tell, has gone where our big private museums apparently dare not tread, deep into the history of art by and about gay artists.

title: Spices of the 60s in Lone Star Recipes
description: In the imaginary geography of pop, Texas is where thinkers get rowdy, restless, heartbroken and drunk. A Texas double bill, the Old 97s and Hayes Carll, lived up to the reputation on Thursday night at the Bowery Ballroom.

title: Nascar Driver Sues ExtenZe
description: Robby Gordon, the Nascar car owner and driver, has filed a $690,000 lawsuit against ExtenZe, formerly a sponsor of Gordons Sprint Cup team, claiming that the maker of male enhancement pills did not adhere to the terms of their sponsorship agreement.

title: With Filibuster, C-SPAN Has a Hit on Its Hands
description: Mr. Sanders has gone to C-SPAN.

title: 2010 on Pace to Be Warmest on Record, NASA Says
description: An analysis of average global temperatures through November by NASAs Goddard Institute for Space Studies shows 2010 on pace to become the warmest year since the collection of temperature data began 130 years ago. NASA previously ranked 2005 as its warmest year ever.

title: Body Fell From Plane, Authorities Say
description: BOSTON  A North Carolina teenager whose body was found in a Boston suburb last month had most likely stowed away inside a planes wheel well and fallen as it lowered its landing gear, the authorities said Friday.

title: Naismiths Papers Fetch Record $4.3 Million
description: David Booth grew up in Lawrence, Kan., the college town where James Naismith began coaching basketball at the University of Kansas a few years after inventing the sport in Springfield, Mass., in 1891.

title: Look of the Moment | Phoebe Philo
description: The Look: Tux Redux  here reinvented as a jumpsuit. Smoking!

title: How Does a State Get a House Seat?
description: With the release of new population figures coming soon, some states are preparing to gain House seats and others bracing to lose them.

title: Sunday Preview
description: This weeks Travel section, the Ski Guide 2011, includes a compendium of information to help any skier through the coming season. Christopher Solomon reveals the next great unexplored ski haven: the off-piste runs of a resort in Disentis, Switzerland. There, he found a 2,000-foot ski run blanketed with nearly untouched powder even though the latest storm had swept through nine days earlier, he writes. And we were alone. Not bad at all.

title: Court Rejects Industry Challenge to Limits on Smokestack CO2
description: Efforts to restrict greenhouse gas emissions through an international agreement still appear mired in an array of disputes on display in Cancn climate talks.

title: Agencys Shtick Is Jewish Humor for a Good Cause
description: In these darkening days between Hanukkah and Christmas, here is a story to keep your spirits high  a story of cooperation between Jews and Christians, between people named Seinfeld and Samberg and people named Morgan and Lohan. A story of celebrities putting ethnic differences aside to raise money for charity.

title: The Dan and Dave Show
description: TWO wolves were eating at the Lion. Dan Abrams, NBCs chief legal analyst and founder of the Mediaite Web site, was sharing a table at the boisterous Greenwich Village restaurant with Dave Zinczenko, editor of Mens Health and author of the best-sellers The Abs Diet and Eat This, Not That. The men are active investors in the Lion, their first joint venture in a decade of friendship that tends to be characterized in the gossip pages as bachelors in a bromance, as Mr. Zinczenko, 40, put it, laughing.

description: The unannounced visit by President Obama and former President Bill Clinton to the White House briefing room was a surprise to absolutely everyone  including Mr. Obamas top advisers.

title: Special Cakes, on and Off TV
description: When Corina Elgart, 33, of Huntington, N.Y., was a criminal investigator in Washington, she never dreamed shed be competing in Next Great Baker, the TLC reality-show spinoff of Buddy Valastros juggernaut, Cake Boss. But she is in fact whipping up cakes for special occasions with the other contestants on the show, which had its season premiere on Dec. 6.

description: New Yorkers in their stylish winter dress to prove once again, that there is abundant holiday cheer.

title: Recipes for Party Dips and Appetizers
description: Festive snacks for your Oscar party.

title: A Pulsating Scene, For Dinner or Dancing
description: THE red carpet and the doorman distinguish Sugar Dining Den and Social Club from its outlet-store neighbors on Voice Road in Carle Place. This combination restaurant and nightclub, which was opened in May by Brian Rosenberg, a former hotel executive, and Randy Narod, an entrepreneur, makes a big first impression.

title: The Chocolatiers Tale
description: Lisas Chocolates and Gifts occupies a small, freestanding building that abuts a picturesque pond, with llamas grazing in the meadow nearby. In its bucolic setting, this plank-sided country store in Canterbury looks to be from the Norman Rockwell era, though it opened in 1997.

title: A Void in Ethnic Dining Filled on Restaurant Row
description: ALTHOUGH ethnic restaurants have been proliferating throughout Connecticut, especially in Fairfield County, there remains one big void: North African and Middle Eastern cuisine. The arrival of the Fez in Stamford in May has helped fill that void.

title: When Wrinkle-Free Clothing Also Means Formaldehyde Fumes
description: The iron, that relic of households past, is no longer required to look neat and freshly pressed. Why bother when retailers like Nordstrom offer crisp wrinkle-free finish dress shirts and L. L. Bean sells chinos that are great right out of the dryer.

title: Mexicans Suggest That They Killed a Drug Leader
description: MEXICO CITY  He walked the streets with a book of his own spiritual quotes. They called him the craziest one, for his odd, cultic hybrid of Christianity and grisly violence, which included rolling severed heads into a nightclub four years ago.

title: Baking Magic
description: Its 9 a.m. and David Meltzer and Simone Williams have been working for about 10 hours already. Grinding grain with their grist mill, mixing in other organic and antibiotic- and hormone-free ingredients, and then forming and kneading dough by hand, the two are committed to creating extraordinary breads for their company, All You Knead Artisan Bakers.

title: A Contemporary Spot for Classic Greek
description: SOON after you sit down at Elia Taverna, a nine-month-old Greek restaurant in Bronxville, a server will bring you a basket of warm pita and a small bowl of delicious assorted olives in oil, garlic and lemon. If youre an adult, you will be offered a complimentary glass of red or white wine (there is no liquor license yet). And if there are any questions about the menu, the waiter will fill you in as if he had all the time in the world, even though the restaurant is likely to be crowded.

title: Clinton at White House Sets Twitter on Fire
description: Political Washington watched, slack-jawed, as President Obama on Friday offered former President Bill Clinton the White House briefing room and Mr. Clinton took it  for a full half-hour.

title: For Future Iron Chefs, More Places to Learn
description: THE students questions were as pointed as the knives they were carefully sharpening on steel rods.

title: Full Wallets, but Using Health Program for Poor
description: AFTER immigrating to New York City from China in the 1970s, Z. Y. Tung and his wife worked hard  he as a bank manager, she as a public school secretary  lived frugally and saved every penny they could for the next generation.

title: Use of Cholera Vaccine in Haiti Is Now Viewed as Viable
description: The World Health Organization is shifting its position in favor of vaccinating against cholera, acknowledging a growing clamor for ways to slow Haitis outbreak.

title: Breakfast(s) at My Place(s)
description: If an award existed for ensuring that New Yorkers ate well on Sunday (and every other day), Eli Zabar, whose gastronomic empire includes E.A.T. on Madison Avenue, the Vinegar Factory, Elis Manhattan and Elis Bread, would be a serious contender. He has been growing vegetables on the Vinegar Factory rooftop for 15 years, and he took over the farmers market in Amagansett, N.Y., in 2008. Mr. Zabar, 67, lives on the Upper East Side with his wife, Devon Fredericks, 60, who works for the company, and their 19-year-old twin boys, Sasha and Oliver. DONNA PAUL

title: Notes from a Young American in Congo: Treating Rape Victims
description: She was running from the soldiers in the field when she tripped and fell.

title: Verdict Is Guilty in Abduction of Elizabeth Smart
description: A federal jury in Utah on Friday convicted an itinerant street preacher, Brian D. Mitchell, in the 2002 abduction of Elizabeth Smart, disregarding defense claims that he was insane.

title: What Works in the Classroom? Ask the Students
description: How useful are the views of public school students about their teachers?

title: Sinatra Is Long Gone, but the Room Is Still Packed
description: At this Midtown temple of southern Italian cooking, Sal Scognamillo, the third-generation executive chef and co-owner, greets newcomers and regulars alike, readily admitting the place never would have lasted if Frank Sinatra had not taken up frequent residence in a curtained-off alcove upstairs. Famous visitors  like Jennifer Lopez, Sean Combs, Florence Henderson and Carroll OConnor  are immortalized in photos near the entrance, on 56th Street between Broadway and Eighth Avenue. All visitors can take a bit of the place with them  Patsys cookbooks, pasta and red sauce are displayed in a case along with a ceramic vessel labeled Ashes of Problem Customers. The offerings have not changed much since the beginning, in 1944, and still pack the house. On Wednesday night, the crowd included a family on its annual holiday visit. DIANE CARDWELL

title: Gates Regrets Rejection of Dont Ask Repeal
description: ABOARD A UNITED STATES MILITARY AIRCRAFT  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said on Friday that he was disappointed but not surprised by the Senate vote late Thursday that dimmed chances for repeal this year of the dont ask, dont tell law.

Spencer, a Roman Catholic priest and a cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony at the St. James Chapel of the Archbishop Quigley Pastoral Center in Chicago.

Judge Dragan Garic ruled Friday that the statute for some of the charges had expired in 2008 and 2009, although the trial started before those dates. description: 1: The ranking of students in Shanghai on standardized tests for reading, math and science administered in about 65 countries. Students from the United States finished far behind: 17th in reading, 23rd in science and 31st in math, which was significantly below the average.

title: Laugh Lines
description: JAY LENO

title: Whispering Fire on a Crowded Planet
description: Marc Roberts, my favorite climate cartoonist (and perhaps the only one), has a biting riff out on the conclusion of the climate negotiations in Cancn, Mexico, which reached agreement early this morning on an outline for further actions, but with heaps of conditionality and scant signs of hard commitments.

title: A Friends Mistake, an Understudys Chance
description: Hempstead, N.Y.

title: Fighting Words
description: As G.M. prepares to roll out its plug-in, Chevy Volt, the companys chief executive, Daniel F. Akerson, took a shot at Toyotas popular hybrid, the Prius.

title: Gizmos Come to Play at Winter Meetings
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Like a rapidly spreading fire, word began to circulate Wednesday through the crowded lobby of the Dolphin Hotel at baseballs winter meetings. General managers, scouting directors and at least one owner had heard the news and were eager to see if it was true.

title: A Giants Project Is Paying Off
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  His coach took notice when Jason Pierre-Paul, in his first practice a week before the first game of his only season of major college football, sent a 315-pound offensive lineman tumbling sideways onto his ear during a pass rush drill.

title: The Loud, and Memorable, Voice of Lombardi
description: In 1967, Vince Lombardi was being interviewed on camera by NFL Films for a CBS documentary about him. But Lombardi, normally hyperexpressive on the sideline, at practices and in the locker room as the Green Bay Packers coach, was not delivering.

title: Planned Fire Dept. Fees for Motorists Criticized
description: A plan by the New York Fire Department to allay severe budget cuts by charging motorists up to $490 to respond to accidents and car fires has touched off blistering criticism and calls for the City Council to outlaw the policy.

title: Obama to Meet With Executives
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama will host a roundtable with about 20 corporate chiefs on Wednesday, according to the White House, part of an attempt to ease strained relations with business.

title: One Billionaire Bows Out of the Next Americas Cup
description: Ten months after Larry Ellison and his BMW Oracle Racing team, lawyers included, celebrated victory over Alinghi in the Americas Cup, it remains uncertain where BMW Oracle will defend its very expensive prize.

title: Straight Outta Hoboken
description: TO the best of my knowledge, Frank Sinatra acknowledged the existence of rap music only once in his life: at the lavish 1995 tribute in honor of his 80th birthday, after the hip-hop trio Salt-n-Pepa performed a special-lyrics version of their hit Whatta Man, he turned to his wife, Barbara, and said, Marvelous.

title: Canadiens Price, Once Fans Target, Is Now a Favorite
description: No player entered the N.H.L. season facing more pressure than Canadiens goaltender Carey Price.

title: The Care and (Healthy) Feeding of the Jaguars
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla.  The Jaguars high-traffic cafeteria used to be a snack trap, characterized by unmarked sugars, hidden calories and hard-to-see preservatives. With its cookie buffet and pizza day, the players ate it up, never stopping to think the low-grade fuel they were pumping into their bodies could be making the team sputter.

title: What Progressives Dont Understand About Obama
description: Oakland, Calif.

title: New Backing for Gas Line Through Asia
description: MOSCOW  A plan to build a regional natural gas pipeline across war-ravaged southern Afghanistan, long thought to be impractical given the dismal security there, moved a step closer to becoming a reality on Saturday.

title: Mensches and Mentors in the Press Box
description: What a mournful year it has been for those of us who grew up in or around New York without ESPN or WFAN, and whose primary sports enlightenment came rolled up in the back pockets of our fathers as they returned home from work.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Dec. 12
description: As lawmakers head into what is expected to be the final week of the 111th Congress, the Sunday morning talk shows focus on the fate of the administrations controversial tax cut deal.

title: Edwards Eulogized as Defender of Her Family
description: RALEIGH, N.C.  In the moments before the funeral for Elizabeth Edwards began here Saturday afternoon, women from the Edenton Street United Methodist Church removed a spray of white lilies and yellow roses from her coffin. Men wiped the rain from the lid, preparing it to be wheeled into the sanctuary, where 1,100 people waited.

title: Poland, Bastion of Religion, Sees Rise in Secularism
description: SWIEBODZIN, Poland  A statue of Jesus, one of the tallest in the world, stands on the flat frozen fields of this small western Poland town, its arms outstretched and gaze fixed straight ahead at a community trying to push back a rising tide of secularism.

title: Giants-Vikings Game Is Moved to Monday
description: A big winter storm in the Twin Cities has left the Giants stranded in Kansas City. Pat Hanlon, the Giants vice president for communications, said the team would stay the night there.

title: Now Grandma Can Win a Trip Too
description: Each time I announce my annual win-a-trip contest, to take a university student with me on a reporting trip to the developing world, I get indignant letters.

title: Win-a-Trip With Nicholas D. Kristof
description: The columnist invites students and those over the age of 60 to enter a contest for a reporting trip to Africa in 2011.

title: Announcing Win-a-Trip 2011  With a Twist!
description: As my Sunday column notes, Im now accepting entries for Win-a-Trip 2011  and this time, Ill be taking not only a student but also someone 60 or over. Im hoping for lots of applications from both ends of the demographic spectrum.

title: Jobless Aides Comb the Democratic Market
description: WASHINGTON  Seemingly desperate times call for desperate measures, which explains why Jonathan Lipman found himself sitting in a hospital room in early November, his day-old son resting on his shoulder, thumbing his BlackBerry searching for a new job on Capitol Hill.

title: Scandal and a Schism Rattle Atlantas Schools
description: ATLANTA  Did any school district in the country have a tougher week than the one in Atlanta?

title: House Is a Star of a Movie, and of a Real-Life Dispute
description: GOLDEN, Colo.  With its distinctive clamshell design, columns of glass windows and mountain perch, the Sculptured House is best known for its prominent role in the 1973 Woody Allen sci-fi comedy Sleeper.

title: The Ponzi Scheme That Changed My Life
description: IT was a Remember where you were when ... ? moment: on Dec. 11, 2008, I was standing under a palm tree in Santa Monica when my cellphone rang.

title: Samuel P. King, Judge and Critic of Hawaiian Charity, Dies at 94
description: Samuel P. King, a federal judge who mobilized the power of the pen to topple overseers of one of the nations wealthiest charities, a 19th-century trust set up by Hawaiian royalty to educate the kingdoms natives, died Tuesday in Honolulu. He was 94.

title: Along a Course of Purling Rivers, a Raw Divide
description: MISSOULA, Mont.  In this region famous for both its angling and its authors, Annick Smith has a long history with the Blackfoot River.

title: Led by Crosby, Penguins Are on a Hot Streak
description: The Penguins are still without Jordan Staal, and they are also missing Evgeni Malkin, but going into Saturday nights game at Buffalo, they had won 11 straight, the second-longest winning streak in their history.

title: Sunday: The Wish
description: I am Eloise. I am six. I am a city child. I live at the Plaza.

title: A Race to Capture a Bounty From Shipping
description: SAVANNAH, Ga.  Port officials here are racing to dig six feet of mud from the bottom of the Savannah River by 2014. In the world of major waterway expansions, that is an impossibly tight timeline.

title: He Found Bag of Cash, But Did the Unexpected
description: TEMPE, Ariz.  For a homeless man like Dave Tally, the $3,300 in cash that he found in an abandoned backpack a few weeks ago would have gone a long way. Food. Shelter. Repairs to his bicycle. Spending it would not have been a problem.

title: Gay Bashing at the Smithsonian
description: EACH Aug. 4, my wife Alex and I visit a church to light candles for two people we loved who both died tragically on that day two years apart  my mother, killed at 64 in a car crash, and Alexs closest friend from graduate school, killed by AIDS at half that age. My mother was Jewish but loved the meditative serenity of vast cathedrals. Alexs friend, John, was a Roman Catholic conflicted by a religion that demonized his sexuality. Our favorite pilgrimage is to an Episcopal church, Grace Cathedral in San Francisco, not as some sectarian compromise but because of its AIDS chapel, a haunting reminder of the plague that ravaged that citys population, especially its gay men, some time ago.

title: Staffs Worry About Shifts in County Health System
description: As Tia Speat strode through the quiet halls of Oak Forest Hospital last week passing out fliers about the nurses unions contract negotiations with Cook County officials, angry nurses accosted her with questions and complaints about proposed cuts in service and staff.

title: Reality Check
description: The failed attempt by the U.S. to bribe Israel with a $3 billion security assistance package, diplomatic cover and advanced F-35 fighter aircraft  if Prime Minister Bibi Netanyahu would simply agree to a 90-day settlements freeze to resume talks with the Palestinians  has been enormously clarifying. It demonstrates just how disconnected from reality both the Israeli and the Palestinian leaderships have become.

title: Buried in Perus Desert, Fossils Draw Smugglers
description: OCUCAJE, Peru  Nestled between the Andes and the Pacific, the sparse desert surrounding this outpost in southern Peru looks like one of the worlds most desolate areas. Barren mountains rise from windswept valleys. Dust devils dance from one dune to the next.

title: Protecting Peru's Fossils
description: Simon Romero reports on Peru's efforts to halt the illegal trade of fossils that are found in the Peruvian desert.

title: Health Care and the Deficit
description: Here is a basic truth about the deficit: In the long run, it cannot be fixed, without reining in spending on Medicare and Medicaid.

title: Lessons for a Modern City Found in Success Stories From Abroad
description: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: A CD Label That Plays to Sounds of Chicago
description: When the pianist Bradley Parker released his first LP in 1979, he went to the Chicago Tattooing and Piercing Company parlor on Belmont Avenue and had the album title, Latin Black, inked across his left forearm. This was novel among artists in the 80s, when tattoos belonged primarily to sailors and biker gangs.

title: Justice Stevens and the Death Penalty
description: In the current "New York Review of Books," the retired Justice John Paul Stevens makes a compelling argument for abolishing the death penalty. He explains how it fails to meet the Supreme Courts own standards for execution and persists only because of misguided political and cultural reasons.

title: In the Peruvian Desert, a Troubled Trove
description: Perus Ocucaje Desert holds one of the most coveted troves of marine fossils known to paleontology, a set of treasures that faces plundering by thieves.

title: Chinas Army of Graduates Struggles for Jobs
description: BEIJING  Liu Yang, a coal miners daughter, arrived in the capital this past summer with a freshly printed diploma from Datong University, $140 in her wallet and an air of invincibility.

title: China's 'Ant Tribe'
description: The reporter Andrew Jacobs follows a young man from his provincial hometown to Beijing to look for work.

title: Our Envoys, Ourselves
description: Washington

title: Lets Race! If Only in Our Minds
description: I was rolling up the bike lane on Eighth Avenue on my way to work recently when a man on a Trek roared past with legs pumping like Greg LeMond.

title: Lost and Found
description: Out in one of the pastures lies a pocket knife with a serrated blade. I lost it at least 10 years ago, but I think about it every time I walk the fence-line. Somewhere, too, theres a pair of lined work gloves. And where are my gaiters? Or, for that matter, the wonderful pair of flip-flops that vanished?

title: Agencies Challenged by Demand for Diapers
description: Damikka Griffin, a social worker, would like it if her low-income clients did not have to choose between necessities like paying their phone bill and rent, or diapering their infants. When she can take diapers with her on a trip to a clients home, it makes her job easier.

title: Snowstorm Shifts Giants Game to Monday
description: The Giants flight to Minneapolis was diverted to Kansas City on Saturday because of a snowstorm. Late Saturday, their game against the Minnesota Vikings was also diverted  to Monday night.

title: New York Governor Vetoes Fracking Bill
description: Gov. David A. Paterson of New York on Saturday vetoed legislation intended to curtail natural gas development using the technique called hydraulic fracturing until a closer review of its effects can be undertaken.

title: A Beating on My Beat
description: Moscow

title: A Vermont Senator Becomes a Twitter Sensation
description: BOSTON  Im not here to set any great records, or to make a spectacle, Senator Bernard Sanders, independent of Vermont, said Friday, about a minute into his speech on the Senate floor. By the time he stopped talking, nearly nine hours later, Mr. Sanders was an ascendant, if unlikely, Internet star.

title: Obama Calls Turkish and Mexican Leaders on Diplomatic Leaks
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama for the first time joined in his administrations diplomatic repair work in the wake of the disclosure of numerous American cables by WikiLeaks, calling the leaders of Turkey and Mexico on Saturday in an effort to smooth things over.

title: In Africa, the Laureates Curse
description: Lagos, Nigeria

title: Readers With Plenty to Say
description: LATE at night, at home in the Eastern time zone, Karen Garcia awaits the electronic publication of The Timess daily dose of two Op-Ed columnists. Her goal: read fast, formulate a hurried response and fire back with her comment.

description: UNIONDALE, N.Y  Islanders General Manager Garth Snow, speaking at Nassau Coliseum on a night when more than a thousand Quebec Nordiques fans came to the arena to show the National Hockey League that their city deserves a team, said that the Islanders arent going to play one day longer than we have to in this arena.

description: To the Editor:

description: More details emerged on Saturday about the final moments and death of a 33-year-old fashion designer who the authorities say was strangled by her boyfriend, who has been charged with trying to kill her at the exclusive Soho House in Manhattan.

description: The best new restaurant

title: Distance and Politics Affect Lawmakers Spending on Travel
description: The retiring State Representative Joe Crabb led all members of the Texas House in government-financed travel expenses in the last fiscal year, according to a Texas Tribune review of expense reports.

title: Stockholm Hit by Blasts After E-Mail Warning
description: STOCKHOLM  One man was killed and two other people were injured when two explosions hit the heart of Stockholms city-center shopping district on Saturday evening, the police in the Swedish capital said. The countrys foreign minister called the blasts a terrorist attack, and an e-mail to news organizations minutes before the blasts seemed to link them to anger over anti-Islamic cartoons and the war in Afghanistan.

title: Profit Outweighs Risk in Jurez Factories
description: In 2009, more than $42 billion in trade value moved through the ports that Ciudad Jurez shares with El Paso, representing 15 percent of the total trade between the United States and Mexico. That number is estimated to be even higher in 2010.

description: Carmelo Anthony had finished his workout, and now it was time for reporters to begin theirs.

description: Jonathan Weber writes a regular column for The Bay Citizen.

title: Punch to Armys Gut as Navy Hits Ball Loose
description: PHILADELPHIA  His gold helmet tilted back on his head and the black under his eyes smeared, Army quarterback Trent Steelman, looking spent in every way, hobbled to the locker room after the Black Knights lost to Navy for the ninth straight time.

title: City Finds Millions, but Reaps Little in Case
description: A former engineer at the San Francisco Department of Building Inspection who stands accused of a lengthy list of building-related crimes was also creative, the authorities said, when it came to another dubious deed: hiding assets.

title: Swedenborgian Church
description: Built in 1895, the Swedenborgian Church at the corner of Washington and Lyon Streets in Pacific Heights is a National Historic Landmark. Warm and wooded, it was designed and constructed by prominent artists and architects of the Arts and Crafts movement and is regarded as one of Californias earliest buildings in that style. HANK PELLISSIER

title: Lives With Polished Veneer Are Snared in S.E.C. Inquiry
description: In the fall of 2006, Arnold and Annabel McClellan settled into a new school and social year. The couple sent their younger child to an exclusive Episcopal nursery school. Their elder took his place at one of the most traditional private schools in San Francisco.

description: As the Heisman Trophy ceremony began in New York on Saturday night, the college football world suddenly got whiplash from looking down to Gainesville, Fla.

title: Holder Calls Terrorism Sting Operations Essential
description: MILLBRAE, Calif.  Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. has defended the use of sting operations orchestrated by government informers, telling advocates for the civil rights of American Muslims on Friday night that the tactic is an essential law enforcement tool in uncovering and preventing terror attacks.

title: Photo Replay: Cam Newton
description: A look back at the career that led to a Heisman Trophy for Auburn quarterback Cam Newton.

title: Poll Suggests Risks for Obama if Liberals Feel Taken for Granted
description: A new poll from Marist University is suggestive of a potential worst-case scenario for President Obama. As he endures criticism from his left over his handling of the tax policy debate with Republicans, his approval rating has declined among liberals, according to the poll: 69 percent of them now approve of his job performance as compared with 78 percent in November. Likewise, his approval rating has declined among Democrats: to 74 percent from 83 percent. However, there has been no comparable improvement in Mr. Obamas standing among independents.

title: Beth Straus, Who Revamped New York Botanical Garden, Dies at 94
description: Beth Straus, who was a transformative figure at the New York Botanical Gardenfor nearly a half century, helping to revamp its image from that of a public park to that of a museum and fostering one of its crown jewels, the Peggy Rockefeller Rose Garden, died on Monday at her home in Somesville, Me., on Mount Desert Island. She was 94.

title: Peter C. Marzio, Houston Museum Director, Dies at 67
description: Peter C. Marzio, who as the director of the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston for nearly 30 years elevated it to major-museum status through an ambitious program of physical expansion and a commitment to Latin American, Hispanic and Asian art, died on Thursday in Houston. He was 67.

title: Isles Boisterous Crowd Is Filled With Nordiques Fans
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  An estimated 1,100 fans of the old Nordiques traveled to Nassau Coliseum from Quebec for Saturday nights game between the Islanders and the Atlanta Thrashers, an effort to show the N.H.L. that their city deserves a team.

title: Onetime Prodigy Shows Renewed Signs of Promise
description: Tennis players fantasize about drubbing the top-ranked Rafael Nadal. Luke McShane, an English grandmaster, got to live out the chess version of such a dream last week at the London Chess Classic, where he soundly defeated Magnus Carlsen, the worlds No.1 player, in the first round.

title: Heisman Triumph Tinged With Hurt
description: The presentation of the 2010 Heisman Trophy had about as much suspense as a Harlem Globetrotters game. For 13 star-kissed games, Auburn quarterback Cam Newton seemed to toy with opponents  from overmatched nonleague teams to the meat of the Southeastern Conference  as if they were the Washington Generals.

title: Luck Could Revisit a New York Moment
description: At a lunch table overlooking the bustle of Times Square on Saturday afternoon, Stanford quarterback Andrew Luck smiled after he misspoke.

title: Prisoners Strike in Georgia
description: In a protest apparently assembled largely through a network of banned cellphones, inmates across at least six prisons in Georgia have been on strike since Thursday, calling for better conditions and compensation, several inmates and an outside advocate said.

title: Andrew Lucks New York Moment May Not Be His Last
description: At a lunch table overlooking the bustle of Times Square on Saturday afternoon, Stanford quarterback Andrew Luck smiled after he misspoke.

title: Fans Target Becomes Their Favorite
description: No player entered the N.H.L. season facing more pressure than Canadiens goaltender Carey Price.

title: In Amsterdam, a Rich Survey of Islamic Art
description: A globally renowned collection of Islamic art is on view at De Nieuwe Kerk (Dam, International Exhibition Centre, Gravenstraat 17; 31-20-626-8168; www.nieuwekerk.nl) through April 17. Assembled by Prof. Nasser D. Khalili, a well-known scholar and benefactor, it includes over 500 objects, among them illuminated Korans and manuscripts, paintings, gold, jewels, textiles, ceramics, glassware, lacquerware, metalwork and wood carvings.

title: Orwellian Centrism
description: I dont usually bother looking at the Washington Post. But Im inside the Beltway right now, so I spared a peek  and for my sins ended up reading Dana Milbank, who praises Obama for punching the hippies.

title: Are Giants Better Off Facing Favre?
description: The snowstorm that postponed the Vikings-Giants game to Monday night will give Brett Favre an extra 31 hours to heal, possibly allowing him to extend his streak of consecutive games started. You could interpret that as bad news for the Giants, who would otherwise face Tarvaris Jackson.

title: Park Slope Plane Crash | A Collision in the Clouds
description: This is the first in a week-long series of stories and multimedia marking the 50th anniversary of the December, 1960, air disaster in New York City.

title: Park Slope Plane Crash | Were You There?
description: The principal came into my room, looking very distracted and asked if he could sit with me for a minute, said Vera McLoughlin, a second-grade teacher at Public School 77 on Second Street in Park Slope. Then he told me what had happened and said he was not going to let the students out at lunchtime.

title: After Attack Hits Sweden, Focus Turns to Suspect
description: STOCKHOLM  A day after two explosions struck central Stockholm, killing the man suspected of being a suicide bomber and wounding two other people, investigators began to focus on the possibility that the person responsible was a disaffected Iraqi-born Swede who had attended college in Britain.

title: Roof Falls In, Sending the Giants Game to Detroit
description: MINNEAPOLIS  The roof of the Metrodome deflated early Sunday morning under the weight of the heaviest snowfall in almost two decades, forcing the N.F.L. to move the game scheduled to be played there between the Minnesota Vikings and the Giants to another domed stadium in Detroit on Monday night.

title: Comment Etiquette, Public Editor-style
description: NYTimes.com is a fertile field for readers to offer comments on news stories, opinion pieces and blogs, as I pointed out in my Sunday, Dec. 12 column. But you might ask: how does the Public Editor himself moderate comments? So I thought I would offer here a bit of information on the comment moderation approach that I take.

title: The Doom of Broder
description: Uh-oh. David Broder says the tax deal marks the beginning of Obamas recovery. The president is doomed.

title: Suicide Attacks Leave at Least 15 People Dead in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  Suicide attacks on Sunday struck a government compound in the Sunni heartland of western Iraq and a Shiite procession northeast of Baghdad. A third suicide bombing appeared to have been averted north of Baghdad when security forces in Balad shot and wounded the driver of a pickup truck packed with explosives.

title: 6 Americans Killed by Bomb at a New U.S.-Afghan Outpost
description: ZHARE, Afghanistan  Six American soldiers were killed and more than a dozen American and Afghan troops were wounded on Sunday morning when a van packed with explosives was detonated at a new jointly operated outpost in southern Afghanistan.

title: Holden Scores Winner for Bolton
description: The American international Stuart Holden, who missed two games with a thigh injury, returned to the lineup for Bolton Wanderers on Sunday and scored the game winning goal two minutes before the end of the match. Holdens goal gave Wanderers a 2-1 win over visiting Blackburn Rovers in the English Premier League.

title: Japan Plans Military Shift to Focus More on China
description: TOKYO  In what would be a sweeping overhaul of its cold war-era defense strategy, Japan is about to release new military guidelines that would reduce its heavy armored and artillery forces pointed north toward Russia in favor of creating more mobile units that could respond to Chinas growing presence near its southernmost islands, Japanese newspapers reported Sunday.

title: Blast in Kandahar Kills Six
description: A van exploded beside a joint outpost in southern Afghanistan on Sunday, killing six Americans.

title: Out of Our Brains
description: Where is my mind?

title: The Students of Act Out
description: Photos of students in an acting class where gay issues take center stage.

title: Germany Signals Support for Euro-Zone Members
description: FRANKFURT  In a shift of tone that may signal more commitment to keep the euro zone in one piece, Germanys finance minister ruled out the possibility that any country would ever be ejected from the European monetary union, and said calls to restore the Deutsche mark were unrealistic nostalgia.

title: Onstage, Young Star Reins in Her Hair
description: Just 10 years old, and Willow Smith has already learned one of the tenets of effective management: delegate, delegate, delegate.

title: A Gem From the Nationals Features an Odd Trump Trick
description: The best-played contract at the Fall Nationals in Orlando, Fla., last month was also the worst-defended. Such is bridge sometimes.

title: Steele to Announce Decision on R.N.C. Run
description: The battle for control of the Republican National Committee will take a new turn on Monday when Michael Steele announces whether he plans to step down as party chairman or will disregard the onslaught of criticism about his oversight of the committee and seek a second term.

title: 'Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?'
description: Tracy Letts, Amy Morton, Madison Dirks and Carrie Coon in a scene from the production at the Steppenwolf Theater in Chicago. (Video courtesy of the production)

title: Video of Metrodome Roof Collapsing
description: Maybe the Giants miscalculated by not traveling to Minneapolis earlier in the week, but the collapse of the Metrodome roof certainly makes the issue moot.

title: Straying From the Canon With Unfamiliar Fare
description: By no means has the vital English cellist Steven Isserlis excluded the standard repertory for his instrument from his purview, on record or onstage. But bringing to light unfamiliar and worthy works by second-tier Romantics as well as contemporary composers seems to give Mr. Isserlis special delight. That his interests can draw sizable numbers of palpably engaged listeners is a credit to his estimable skills, enlightened advocacy and communicative powers.

title: Celebrating Steve Reich, a Bit Early
description: If he thinks about such things, Steve Reich is probably just getting used to being 74, having attained that age on Oct. 3. But composers 74th birthdays are really just the starting bell for celebrations of their 75th, and Axiom, one of the Juilliard Schools resident new-music ensembles, offered an all-Reich program as an early tribute on Thursday evening at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Helping Gay Actors Find Themselves Onstage
description: One by one the students in Brad Calcaterras acting class stood at the front of the room and tearfully, joyfully, brazenly talked about being gay. A young lesbian laughed about her first kiss. A gay man described living with H.I.V. since the 1980s. A transgender woman performed high kicks. Before one man said anything his body shook, and he began to sob.

title: Bloomberg Rules Out Presidential Run
description: Despite renewed speculation about his presidential aspirations, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Sunday categorically ruled out running for the White House in 2012 in an appearance on Meet the Press on NBC.

title: A Playfully Roasted Old Chestnut
description: Theres no Sugar Plum Fairy in The Hard Nut, Mark Morriss version of The Nutcracker, and no prima-ballerina dances to the music Tchaikovsky wrote as a grand pas de deux. Instead the adagio of that grand pas de deux (with its tremendous series of slow downward scales) becomes a grand ensemble. It contains moments, however, when it suddenly becomes a true  but anti-grand  pas de deux, in which both hero and heroine dance (rather than a woman dancing with the help of a male cavalier).

title: Offering Sturm Galore, Fire and Drang as Well
description: Go for the fireballs, stay for the self-mythologizing and angst: That could be the pitch for Rammstein, the German rock band that played its first American show since 2001 on Saturday night at a sold-out Madison Square Garden. During the concert flames shot up from the stage, down from the rafters and sideways from flamethrowers mounted in microphones and on a set of angel wings; fireworks added explosions and showers of sparks. At one point a man ran around the stage in a flaming suit, with an E.M.T. on hand to snuff him out.

title: Up Close, Yes. Personal? In Varying Degrees.
description: During Justin Biebers five-song performance on Friday night at Madison Square Garden the videographers for the overhead screens all seemed to be leaning back. The audience could not look into his soul.

title: Sincerest Form of Flattery: Some Joke!
description: Days before Thanksgiving the CBS late-night host Craig Ferguson was informed by a fan on Twitter that he had a particularly ardent French admirer. Some might say a copycat. Others might say a plagiarist.

title: Start, Then Start Again on a Newly Made Stage
description: Nicole Wolcott is a queen of the quick cut. For her, movement works best when its snappy, with an emphasis placed on crisp, rhythmic precision. Its as if the body truly is an instrument: virtuosity is found in a rapid sideway glance, pivoting feet, a hip that sinks and shakes like a piece of machinery, or a brisk plunge to the floor. Theres no denying that skill is involved, but for the viewer it doesnt take long for fatigue set in.

title: In My Fathers House, That Airless, Bitter Place
description: Merging astronomy, Buddhist philosophy, and political and social unrest, Mundane History may carry a modest title, but its ambitions are exactly the opposite. A simple, almost spare family drama told through strong, purposeful images, this first feature from the Thai director Anocha Suwichakornpong parallels the emotional dynamic of a single home with the tumult of an entire country.

title: Monday: Now  and Then
Egon Schiele Seen From Many Angles
description: Egon Schiele is dancing with himself again. The Viennese Expressionist artist  who died in 1918 but has been regularly reincarnated by the American performance artist John Kelly  can once more be found performing an angular pas de trois with two mirror images at the Ellen Stewart Theater at La MaMa. And if you havent ever seen Egon and his Alter Egons (thats what theyre called), you have missed one of the sweetest testaments to artistic self-involvement ever staged.

title: Opposites Attract, and React, in a Dark Neighborhood

At a more modest family home, Old Mill Cottage in High Wycombe, outside London, the Mitfords had to take walks on footpaths that were open to the public.

title: Slow Start for Narnia and The Tourist
description: Smooth sailing it was not at the weekend box office, where The Chronicles of Narnia: Voyage of the Dawn Treader experienced weak ticket sales in North America, and The Tourist flopped. Dawn Treader, a $140 million 3-D fantasy from 20th Century Fox and Walden Media, sold about $24.5 million in its first weekend, enough for No. 1 but on the low end of expectations. Dawn Treader sold a solid $67 million overseas, but unless it performs very well domestically  something Fox says is possible given strong exit polls  the Narnia franchise, based on the books of C. S. Lewis, could end here. The weekend was much worse for two stars considered among Hollywoods most bankable: Johnny Depp and Angelina Jolie saw their new film, The Tourist, fizzle in second place with about $17 million. That result may not sound terrible, but The Tourist cost GK Films about $100 million to make and Sony Pictures Entertainment tens of millions to market. Sony acknowledged that sales were soft but said the studio expected the overseas reception to be substantially stronger. Tangled (Walt Disney Studios) was third with about $14.6 million for a three-week total of $115.6 million. Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1 (Warner Brothers) was fourth with $8.5 million in its fourth weekend for a total of $257.7 million, while Unstoppable (Fox) was fifth with $3.8 million for a five-week total of $74.3 million.

Most dancers from the Broadway run, which closed in September, have been retained, including the Tony Award nominees Karine Plantadit, Keith Roberts and John Selya. The show opened Saturday, the day before what would have been Sinatras 95th birthday.

In Robot Chicken: Star Wars Episode III, which makes its debut Friday on Cartoon Networks Adult Swim channel, an all-star cast lends its voice to a third installment of knowing, willfully nerdy send-ups of the Star Wars saga, including Zac Efron (playing Anakin Skywalker); the Star Wars veterans Anthony Daniels, Billy Dee Williams and Ahmed Best; Donald Glover of Community; Seth MacFarlane, Mr. Greens boss at Family Guy; and of course Mr. Green himself.

title: Los Angeles Museum of Contemporary Art Paints Over Mural
description: Street art  graffiti, uncommissioned public art, call it what you will  has found greater acceptance in the gallery and museum world over the last several years but the fit hasnt always been comfortable. Anyone looking for evidence of the tensions now has a marquee example. The Los Angeles Museum of Contemporary Art, run by the former New York gallery owner Jeffrey Deitch  a longtime champion of street art  late last week ordered a wall mural it had commissioned by Blu, an Italian graffiti artist, to be whitewashed because it found the artwork inappropriate. The mural, on a wall of the museums Geffen Contemporary wing, was planned as a kind of advertisement for an ambitious exhibition focusing on street art that the museum will open in April. But as Blu neared completion of the mural  which conveyed a strident antiwar message, showing rows of caskets draped with one-dollar bills instead of flags  the museum changed its mind and began painting it over on Thursday.

In Baghdad, a roadside bomb exploded near a procession, wounding four, and three others were hurt in a blast near a Shiite mosque. For several years, largely Sunni insurgent groups have attacked Shiites during the holiday, which commemorates the centuries-old death of a revered imam.

The fine created a furor in France, which has approved a ban on similar veils that goes into effect next spring; the driver, Sandrine Mouleres, 31, is a Muslim convert who has written a controversial autobiography. Also on Monday, a court upheld the firing for insubordination of an employee of a day care center, Baby Loup, in Chanteloup-les-Vignes, for refusing to remove her veil.

His death today is a tremendous loss for all of us who knew him, and for the country as well. Richard never achieved his dream of becoming secretary of state, but he leaves a legacy around the world  from Bosnia to East Timor, from AIDS clinics in South Africa to his legions of followers in the United States  that exceeds that of many Secretaries of State. title: The Uncanny Ouch-Man: Hugh Jackman Hurt Taping Oprah Stunt
description: Though hes better known for his portrayal of the comic-book hero Wolverine, Hugh Jackman might as well have been rehearsing for a role in the Spider-Man musical when a stunt he was taping for The Oprah Winfrey Show went wrong on Tuesday. Mr. Jackman, who is one of several Australian celebrities being filmed at the Sydney Opera House for a series of special episodes called Oprahs Ultimate Australian Adventure, was zipping onto the set while suspended in a wire harness device called a flying fox, but at the end of his speedy trip collided with a lighting rig suspended above the stage. The Press Association said Mr. Jackman was bleeding from his right eye as he was removed from the rigging, and taping was halted for about 10 minutes while he received medical treatment (and a glass of red wine), but the actor returned to the set with a black eye and bandages to finish his interview. That was so much fun until the end, Mr. Jackman said.

This was evident in upholstery-inspired fabrics, bits of fringe and Roman-shade like draping of the some of the more artfully engineered pieces that Posen turned out for Pre-Fall. (A laser cut leather dress with boucl inserts cuts a bombshell figure.) But another muse made a cameo appearance in the collection: Tina Turner, the designers 7 year-old poodle. That is her face, in silhouette, on the sweater that anchors one of our favorite looks.

Jewelry is the perfect accessory to dress up or down any look or add a girly element to a more utilitarian, rugged look. Building on the success of previous guest collections by designers like Fenton Fallon and Miriam Haskell, J. Crew sought out Lisa Salzer of Lulu Frost for the next collaboration on its list. (Im a huge Lulu Frost fan and even have pieces stashed in my purse for a fashion emergency, Webb confesses.) Known for her estate piece aesthetic, Salzer and her team put a vintage twist on modern designs  10k gold necklaces, bracelets and earrings with handmade chains and antique glass crystals. title: How to Unlike Pages on Facebook

title: On Our Radar: Chernobyl to Open to Tourists
description: Ukraine will open the sealed zone around the doomed Chernobyl nuclear reactor to visitors beginning next year, the countrys Emergency Situations Ministry declared. The nuclear reactor exploded nearly 25 years ago, killing dozens and spreading radioactivity across Europe. A spokeswoman for the Ukrainian agency says the tour will be medically safe and will be positive in conveying very important messages. [Associated Press]

title: A Control Freak Finds a Way to Expand
description: Almost a year ago, we published a small-business case study that weighed the potential pros and cons of geographic expansion for Thinking Caps Tutoring, a company that offers study skills coaching, subject tutoring and test preparation to middle- and high-school students in the New York area. Alexandra Mayzler, who founded Thinking Caps and who described herself as a control freak, feared the quality of her highly personalized services would suffer if she expanded hastily. But she also said she wanted to build an enduring stand-alone brand, not an Alexandra brand.

title: The Taliban Remembers an American Envoy
description: The Taliban statement on the death of Richard C. Holbrooke, the chief American envoy to the region, carried a dignified, almost somber tone. It seems they took him seriously, as they do all enemies and as Mr. Holbrooke took them.

description: Tyler Cowens essay in the latest American Interest is nominally about income inequality, but really its about the pernicious role that big finance plays in modern political economy. Cowen isnt worried about inequality per se, but he is worried about the forces that give rise to it, and specifically the boom-bust cycle of Wall Street investment  and more specifically still, the way the bust part of the cycle tends to make taxpayers suffer more than the Wall Street investors themselves, thus incentivizing further recklessness and still worse crack-ups down the road:

title: To Think, Perchance to  Debating the Dream Act
description: December 15, 2010, 10:10 a.m. | Updated Overview | What difficulties do undocumented immigrant children face when it comes time for them to go to college? What are the pros and cons of the legislation that has been proposed to address these difficulties? In this lesson, students engage in a roundtable debate on the Dream Act and will then write a letter to their United States senators either supporting or opposing the legislation.

Fans like Devendra Banhart, Erin Wasson and Alexandra Richards are, well, mad for the bohemian pieces with a rock n roll edge. Seeing our pieces on people is still a pretty big deal, Purvis admits. description: Katie Holmes is considering starring in a Broadway production of William Mastrosimones psychological drama Extremities, about a woman who turns the table on her would-be rapist and then struggles along with her two roommates about what to do with him. A spokeswoman for Ms. Holmes, a television and film actress and the wife of Tom Cruise, confirmed that she had been approached about the role; the spokeswoman had no further information. Ms. Holmes made her Broadway debut in 2008 in a revival of All My Sons.

title: Emanuel Testifies in Chicago Residency Challenge
description: CHICAGO  It was a campaign appearance no candidate would wish for, least of all one who knows the ins and outs of political imagery and messaging as well as Rahm Emanuel. Yet there was Mr. Emanuel on Tuesday, seated at the front of a crowded basement meeting room, under oath, answering fierce, pointed questions from people who believe that he should not become mayor of Chicago.

title: Honolulu Symphony Shuts Down
description: The Honolulu Symphony has officially gone out of business. A United States Bankruptcy Court judge on Monday approved the orchestras liquidation, The Associated Press reported. The orchestra was running out of money and mired in a labor dispute. It stopped performing in October 2009 and filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code but asked the court to convert the filing to Chapter 7, liquidation. The symphony said it was founded in 1900 and calls itself the oldest American orchestra west of the Rockies.

The Raging Bull himself hosted a party for The Fighter at his Tribeca Film Center on Monday night, the director David O. Russell told us. He said the best thing, Mr. Russell said from his hotel in New York. You know, my best compliment is that it was honest. That to me is a lot, coming from a man of few words.

The purpose was to emphasize to Lee; his wife, Kristen; and his agent, Darek Braunecker, that the Rangers were serious about keeping him.

title: Westerly, R.I., Waits for Its Development Angel

Royce has spent millions buying and redeveloping properties in this waterfront town on the Connecticut border  his way, associates say, of strengthening a community where he has summered for many years. His biggest venture by far is Ocean House, a $140 million hotel, resort and condominium that opened last summer in the moneyed enclave of Watch Hill.

title: Howard Sherman, Executive Director of American Theater Wing, to Step Down
description: Howard Sherman, the executive director of the American Theater Wing, which co-presents the Tony Awards, announced on Tuesday that he would step down when his current contract ends on June 30, after eight years in the position. In a statement, Mr. Sherman said that he did not have a new job lined up but that he believed in making his intentions known rather than quietly seeking his next opportunity; the business side of New York theater is an insular world, and gossip tends to spread quickly when a top executive is coming or going. Theodore S. Chapin, chairman of the board of the Wing, credited Mr. Sherman with raising the profile of the organization through its Working in the Theater television program, video and Web-based programs, podcasts, and Twitter. Mr. Sherman developed new internship and education programs for aspiring artists, and he also conceived and supervised a 2009 collection of essays, The Play That Changed My Life, contributed by leading playwrights and edited by Ben Hodges. He also serves as the point man on the Tonys for the Wing, which created the awards in 1947 and now co-presents them with the Broadway League, a trade group of theater owners and producers.

Each takes a refreshing, almost sideways approach to the subject of ethnic tension.

title: Richard Holbrooke, Man of Letters

In his role as a diplomat, he seemed to maintain ironic distance on himself, watching as he conducted negotiations at the highest level and reflecting on his own activities and decisions. One of them put an arm around my neck and pulled me to the ground, Mr. Little told the Manhattan news site DNAInfo. The other guy took the money from my pocket. They took $380, Mr. Little said. title: Coney Islands Shore Theater Is Named a Landmark

The Landmarks Preservation Commission approved the designation for the Shore and three other buildings on Tuesday afternoon. The Shore, originally known as the Coney Island Theater, was built between 1924 and 1925. Beginning in the mid-1960s, the theater began housing musical revues and burlesque. A few years later, following a brief experimentation with adult film, it catered to a (presumably) different demographic: bingo players. Today, at seven stories high, the vacant building is one of the tallest in the area.

The Gabrielsson book, not yet titled, will also shed light on the mysterious fourth novel in the series, her publisher, Seven Stories Press, said. Ms. Gabrielsson has said she has a partial manuscript of the fourth novel saved on a laptop computer but she hoped it would never be published. Her book is scheduled for publication in the United States in June, her publisher said on Tuesday. The years that followed have been marked by repair, reform and reversals; recompense, recrimination and reinterpretation. title: Phys Ed: The Benefits of Exercising Before Breakfast
description: From the archives.The holiday season brings many joys and, unfortunately, many countervailing dietary pitfalls. Even the fittest and most disciplined of us can succumb, indulging in more fat and calories than at any other time of the year. The health consequences, if the behavior is unchecked, can be swift and worrying. A recent study by scientists in Australia found that after only three days, an extremely high-fat, high-calorie diet can lead to increased blood sugar and insulin resistance, potentially increasing the risk for Type 2 diabetes. Waistlines also can expand at this time of year, prompting self-recrimination and unrealistic New Years resolutions.

title: Faulty Weld Is Suspect in Rupture of Pipeline
description: WASHINGTON  The natural gas pipeline that ruptured in September, killing eight people and burning dozens of houses in a suburb south of San Francisco, may have had a badly welded seam in a stretch of pipe that was supposed to be seamless, federal investigators said Tuesday.
