title: Three-Team Deal Could Affect Carmelo Anthony
description: The Nets, the Los Angeles Lakers and the Houston Rockets agreed in principle to a three-team deal Tuesday that involved three players. The trades most significant effect, however, could rest with a player who was not involved: Carmelo Anthony.

title: Sweden: F.B.I. Aids Bombing Inquiry
description: Swedish investigators looking into the botched explosions that killed a 28-year-old suicide bomber in a crowded shopping district in Stockholm are being assisted by a team of F.B.I. experts who specialize in analyzing bomb fragments, a spokeswoman for the Swedish security police said Tuesday. Diplomats said the seven-member F.B.I. team, whose assistance was requested by the government of Prime Minister Fredrik Reinfeldt, arrived in Stockholm less than 24 hours after the weekend attack that lightly wounded two passers-by. Swedish officials have said that the Iraqi-born Swede who has been identified by investigators as the bomber, Taimour Abdulwahab al-Abdaly, probably had accomplices and that high priority was being given to identifying them.

title: F.B.I. Breaks Up Child Pornography Ring
description: LOS ANGELES  An investigation into an online child pornography ring has led to the arrests of 16 men in the United States, as well as arrests in South America, Europe and New Zealand, Federal Bureau of Investigation officials announced on Tuesday.

title: Senate Democrats Introduce Spending Bill
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Democrats on Tuesday unveiled a $1.1 trillion spending bill to finance the federal government through the end of the fiscal year on Sept. 30. Republicans said they would oppose it and insist on a temporary spending measure through the early part of next year when they hold the majority in the House and six additional seats in the Senate.

title: Georgia: Lawsuit Over Muslim Womans Head Scarf
description: The American Civil Liberties Union has filed a lawsuit on behalf of a Muslim woman in Georgia who was arrested in 2008 when she refused to remove her head scarf while entering the Douglasville Municipal Court to accompany her nephew to a traffic hearing. The woman, Lisa Valentine, verbally protested the order and was briefly jailed for contempt of court. Ms. Valentine is suing the City of Douglasville and court officers for damages, arguing that her religious freedoms were violated. Georgia has since recommended that religious head coverings be permissible in the states courthouses, but Ms. Valentine is asking for the recommendation to be made a binding policy.

title: Louisiana: Justice Department May Sue BP
description: The Department of Justice could sue BP over the Gulf of Mexico oil spill as soon as Wednesday, joining the sprawling federal litigation that already involves some 23,000 plaintiffs, The Wall Street Journal reported on Tuesday. Judge Carl J. Barbier, who is running the centralized litigation from New Orleans, issued an order in October that all master complaints should be filed by Dec. 15. Stephen J. Herman, a leader of the group of plaintiffs lawyers in the case, said that he had not heard that the government was preparing to join the litigation, but added, It was inevitable that they were going to file suit.

title: San Francisco Approves Cup Plan
description: After several days of modifications, the San Francisco Board of Supervisors unanimously approved a plan to host the 34th Americas Cup along its northern waterfront. Mayor Gavin Newsom was to sign the bid late Tuesday and present it to the organizers of the race, who want a deal in place by Friday. The organizers, though, are pushing for additional assurances the plan will give them the ability to recoup the nearly $500 million they expect to spend on the event. Some of those details were expected to be worked out by the end of the week. If not, the organizers have said they will seek another site.

title: U.S.O.C. Board to Vote on Expanding
description: The United States Olympic Committees board of directors is expected to vote Thursday on whether to add five members to the board. Four of the new directors will fill positions created by the board after an independent advisory panel headed by Paul Tagliabue recommended that the body be expanded to 15 members from 11. The fifth would fill a vacant position created by the departure of the board member Stephanie Streeter, who served in 2009 as acting chief executive before stepping down later that year.

title: Sudan: President Cancels Zambian Trip
description: Sudans president, Omar Hassan al-Bashir, who is wanted on genocide charges, abruptly canceled his planned trip to Zambia to attend an environmental conference starting Wednesday, according to Zambias state radio. Zambia had invited Mr. Bashir even though it was legally bound to arrest him because it is a member of the International Criminal Court, but nearly 30 African human rights and other groups have since flooded the Zambian government with letters and faxes of protest. Mr. Bashir has been forced to skip two other high-profile international events in the past two weeks.

title: Kosovo: Report on Organ Trafficking
description: A report on the illegal harvesting of and trafficking in human organs in Kosovo will be presented Thursday to the Council of Europe, a 47-nation group that deals with issues of human rights. According to Agence France-Presse, the report says that ethnic Albanian guerrillas of the Kosovo Liberation Army trafficked in organs of Serb prisoners after the 1999 Kosovo conflict. Prime Minister Hashim Thaci  one of the leaders of K.L.A. units during the conflict with Serb security forces  fiercely denied the accusations, the news agency said. Past investigations by the United Nations war crimes tribunal dealing with the Balkan wars did not produce credible evidence on organ trafficking, according to a former tribunal official. But the former chief prosecutor Carla Del Ponte raised the issue as hearsay in her 2008 memoirs.

title: Pakistan: Party Leaves Governing Bloc
description: An Islamic party withdrew from the governing coalition after Prime Minister Yusuf Raza Gilani ousted its minister on Tuesday. Muhammad Azam Khan Swati, who held the portfolio for science and technology, had been involved in a public fight with a colleague, Hamid Saeed Kazmi, minister for religious affairs. Mr. Swati had accused Mr. Kazmi of corruption; Mr. Kazmi denied the allegations. The decision is unlikely to bring down the governing coalition, led by the Pakistan Peoples Party of President Asif Ali Zardari, but is likely to weaken an already fragile government, analysts said.

description: MOSCOW  Moscow was jittery on Wednesday after rumors spread that migrants from the Caucasus planned a street protest in response to the weekends ethnic attacks.

title: YouTube Said to Seek a Producer of Web Video
description: SAN FRANCISCO  YouTube, the video site owned by Google, is in talks to buy Next New Networks, a Web video production company, according to two people briefed on the discussions. The acquisition would be YouTubes first major foray into producing original content, and demonstrates how intently it is focused on offering professional videos rather than just short clips by amateurs.

title: A Business Owner Reflects on a Failure to Pay His Taxes
description: On his way from Philadelphia to the Jersey Shore for some senior-week revelry in the early 80s, 17-year-old Gary Barbera had business on his mind. He had seen a newspaper advertisement for a 1971 Chevy Nova and decided to buy it  not for cruising with his buddies but as an investment. Later that week, after giving the Nova a good wash and some detailing, he sold his very first car, at a profit of $360.

title: Homes for $700,000
description: A two-bedroom house in Los Angeles, an ancient property in Rhode Island and a standalone condo in Washington state.

description: Weve just published a conversation with Gary Barbera, a Philadelphia auto dealer who pleaded guilty to filing false tax returns and was recently sentenced to three years probation. He says he neglected to tell his accountant about certain bonus checks hed been awarded by Chrysler. Now under house arrest, Mr. Barbera must wear an ankle bracelet, but he is allowed to go to work every day to run his dealership.

description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The International Committee of the Red Cross, which usually seeks to avoid the public eye, held a rare news conference here on Wednesday to express deep concern that Afghanistan security had deteriorated to its worst point since the overthrow of the Taliban nine years ago and was preventing aid groups from reaching victims of conflict.

description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  On Wednesday, the events surrounding the Jets, their sideline, their suspended strength coach and their great wall of inactive players felt like an N.F.L. version of a A Few Good Men.

description: Carving a path down a mountain on skis or a snowboard takes training. But several ski resorts are now offering downhill thrills that dont require any Alpine skills by installing mountain coasters.

title: Beauty Spots
description: THICKENING AGENTS Sometimes the frizzy-haired girls get all the attention (at least when it comes to products). But there is help for the limp-locked: Living Proof, which makes the popular product No Frizz, recently introduced a new daily hair-care system called Full. The collection includes a sulfate-free shampoo and conditioner, a root-lifting spray and a thickening cream that the company says creates a micro-pattern of thickening points on each strand. Available at Sephora or LivingProof.com ($24 per item).

title: Wildly Abrasive
description: NOT long ago, Jessica Chavkin, a childrens clothing designer who lives in Gramercy, returned from a two-week trip to smog-saturated Beijing and Shanghai, and booked a Deep Sea Detox massage and body wrap treatment, costing $165, at a Bliss spa. My skin just felt puffy, she said. She also spent $35 more for a process called dry brushing, which entailed natural bristles being run over her skin in short, quick strokes.

title: Arthur Fiedler, 84, Conductor Of Boston Pops 50 Years, Dies
description: Arthur Fiedler, conductor of the Boston Pops Orchestra for 50 years and one of the world's best- known musical figures, died yesterday morning at his home in Brookline Mass. He was 84 years old.

Mr. Moses, whose long list of public offices only begins to hint at his impact on both the city and state of New York, was 92 years old.

description: PEKING, Dec. 19 -- Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher today signed the agreement formally committing Britain to surrender Hong Kong to China in 1997 in return for terms guaranteeing a 50-year extension of its capitalist economic system.

All three actors will remain with the production, which was scheduled to run through Jan. 29, 2011.

Its in the garden level of Marcel Breuers brutalist masterpiece, a walnut-paneled coffee cart thats acting as a place-holder until a new museum cafe will be opened by Union Square Hospitality Group in the spring. In the meantime, you can visit the coffee bar (without paying admission) and get a cappuccino made on a Strada, the next-generation pressure profiling espresso machine from La Marzocco.

A study by an auto industry research group said on Wednesday that requiring automakers to meet fuel economy standards of 60 miles per gallon by 2025 would decrease sales because cars and trucks would become more expensive, and could eliminate up to 1.3 million jobs nationwide.

title: AMC Gets on Board Post-Civil War Drama Hell on Wheels
description: For its next original series AMC is going back to the 60s  the 1860s, that is. On Wednesday AMC, the cable-television home of the period drama Mad Men (as well as Breaking Bad and The Walking Dead), said it had committed to a full season of Hell on Wheels, a series set in post-Civil War America. In a news release AMC said Hell on Wheels, which is created and written by the sibling screenwriters Joe and Tony Gayton (Faster), would star Anson Mount as Cullen Bohannan, a former soldier in the Confederate Army who, in searching for the Union soldiers who killed his wife, finds his way to a lawless town called Hell on Wheels, and to the construction of the first transcontinental railroad. The release said the series would explore the railroads institutionalized greed and corruption, the immigrant experience and the plight of the newly emancipated African-Americans during Reconstruction. Additional cast members include the rapper Common (whose acting credits include Just Wright and Date Night) and Colm Meaney (of the Star Trek spinoffs The Next Generation and Deep Space Nine); no premiere date has been announced.

title: New Car Smell Blamed in Hit-and-Run
description: Many drivers enjoy the so-called new car smell, a mix of volatile organic compounds that rise from the plastic, leather, cloth, wood and other interior components of cars fresh off the assembly line. The aroma is so popular that some companies even sell new car smell air fresheners.

description: Abraham Piper, clearly a fan of brevity, runs a Web site called TwentytwoWords. His daily goal is to curate the Web into short snippets and to condense life into questions of less than two dozen words.

description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  The receivers of Giants past made haunting appearances Wednesday at the teams practice facility. Victor Cruz chatted up reporters in the locker room. Ramses Barden hobbled into the cafeteria with a walking boot.

description: BERLIN  Europes smoldering financial crisis flared up on Wednesday, with riots over austerity spending in Greece, new signs of troubles in Spain and little indication that European leaders were moving any closer to agreement on a systemic approach to long-term stability.

title: BMW and Subaru Have Best Resale Value, Says Kelley Blue Book
description: BMW and Subaru are the 2011 model-year winners of the Kelley Blue Book Best Resale Value Awards, which is based on the publications projection of how well new models are expected to retain their original list price after five years of ownership.

description: 6:35 p.m. | Updated to reflect that the Bing feature that allows users to continuously scroll through image results is not new.

title: Messiah Season, in All of Its Hues
description: You might think that the fixation musical organizations have on Handels Messiah at this time of year would get old quickly, given that this big works domination of so many concert halls and churches reduces the variety of New Yorks musical life. Yet the annual parade of Messiah performances offers a fascinating variety all its own. Instrument design and performing sensibilities have changed radically since the works 1742 premiere, and competing performing traditions have arisen, the latest based on the conceit that contemporary musicians can approximate Handels sound world.

title: Speaking of Henry Ford
description: Over at Jalopnik, Justin Hyde takes note of an article by Henry Ford that ran in The New York Times in 1931. description: WHEN Toi Washington, 34, began her search for knee-high boots, her requirements were simple. They had to be cute and comfortable. Ms. Washington usually wears labels like BCBG Generation, but she is not particularly loyal to any one brand. To her surprise, two pairs of Naturalizers caught her eye, and she didnt hesitate to buy both. It was her first comfort footwear purchase.

description: John Goodge, left, a professor of geological sciences at the University of Minnesota-Duluth, and Jeff Vervoort, an isotope geochemist from Washington State University, will be writing occasional posts from their research expedition in Antarctica.

title: Using Winter Squash al Dente
description: When cooking Italianate dishes with winter squash or pumpkin, I almost always cook the squash until it is very soft. For ravioli fillings I generally roast it, yielding a puree that is relatively low in moisture and that benefits from caramelization in the oven; for risottos I typically cook the squash with onions or shallots before the rice even goes in, then add more once I begin moistening the rice with liquid  or use roasted squash. And very good it all is, in that dense, pumpkin-pie way were used to with these fruits.

title: Noel in the Museum, Medieval Edition
description: Despite a hiatus of sorts in recent years, on the eve of its 25th-anniversary season, Anonymous 4 seems as strong as ever, continuing to demonstrate the qualities that have made it a perennially popular a cappella ensemble. In the Metropolitan Museums acoustically vibrant Medieval Sculpture Hall on Tuesday evening, the four women sang with their trademark vocal blend, sparing use of vibrato and purity of tone in a program called Noel: Four Centuries of Christmas.

title: MoMA Sending Abstract Expressionists to Canada
description: For the last three months they have been taking a star turn at their home, the Museum of Modern Art, in the sprawling Abstract Expressionist New York show. But in an unexpected move, a host of paintings by Jackson Pollock, Mark Rothko, Robert Motherwell, Lee Krasner and other titans of the New York School will soon be heading north on tour. The museum announced Wednesday that the exhibition  or at least a large chunk of it  would travel to the Art Gallery of Ontario, where it will be on display from May 28 through Sept. 4. The show will feature about 100 well-known works from the Moderns collection. And as of now, the Art Gallery of Ontario  once run by Glenn D. Lowry, the Moderns director  will be the only other site to host the exhibition.

title: Twitter Financing Raises Its Value to $3.7 Billion
description: Twitter, the micro-blogging phenomenon, raised $200 million in a new round of venture capital financing led by Kleiner Perkins Caulfield & Byers, Claire Cain Miller of The New York Times reports. Spark Capital, Benchmark Capital and Union Square Ventures also participated.

title: Juilliard Players Join the Fierce Give and Take of a Prokofiev Concerto
description: The Juilliard Orchestra, the schools flagship student ensemble, can, as you might expect, handle just about any music you put in front of it, and it seems likely that its public concerts would pack Alice Tully Hall even if they were not free. As it is, the tickets disappear quickly, and listeners hoping for seats released at the last minute form a line down West 65th Street.

title: Michigan Republican to Head House Intel Panel
description: Representative Mike Rogers, a Michigan Republican, has been tapped to chair the House Intelligence Committee in the next Congress.

title: 2 in Race to Lead Johnson & Johnson
description: After a year marked by embarrassing consumer product calls, Johnson and Johnson on Wednesday set in motion a horse race between two longtime executives to succeed William C. Weldon, 62, the chief executive and chairman.

title: Suffering of a Noble, Romantic Soul Man
description: Tank opened his Tuesday night show at S.O.B.s with a harangue, lamenting the decline of the sort of classic soul he prefers, and proffers, in favor of music thats younger and dumber. He suggested he should maybe give up singing for rapping, or maybe make an illicit sex tape to get noticed, an unkind allusion to R. Kellys legal troubles. He wouldnt have to consider these options, though, if only R&B was how it used to be.

title: Home Labs on the Rise for the Fun of Science
description: One day Kathy Ceceri noticed a tick on her arm and started to worry that it was the kind that carried Lyme disease. So she went to her home lab, put the tiny arachnid under her microscope, which is connected to her computer through a U.S.B. cable, and studied the image.

title: Theater Talkback: When Familiar Words Are Heard Anew
description: Wahuhrah, wahuhrah , exasperated pause, words. That, more or less, is how Rory Kinnear pronounces the immortal redundancy words, words, words in Nicholas Hytners new production of Hamlet for the National Theater in London. Those words (words, words) have of course been uttered more times than any calculator could compute.

title: Looking at Income Class and Votes for Obama
description: In light of the Census Bureaus release on Tuesday of data from the American Community Survey, a blogger from The Big Picture who writes under the pseudonym Invictus suggested we investigate how income may have affected the 2008 presidential election.

title: Large Gulf Remains in Stuyvesant Town Rent Case
description: Landlords and tenants appear to be far apart on what the legal rents should be for thousands of apartments in the beleaguered Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village complexes on the East Side of Manhattan.

title: Downtown Stalwarts Flock to a Gay Wedding
description: One of the often overlooked accomplishments of the experimental theater scene in New York is the longevity of its major figures. Richard Foreman and the Wooster Group have been producing consistently for decades. Following them, artists like Richard Maxwell and the Elevator Repair Service have built long, fertile careers without the usual detours to Hollywood made by more mainstream artists. There is a real pleasure not only in following these artists as they evolve over years, but also in their kind of often elusive work, which provides valuable and revealing context.

title: New Feud Over Oversight Panel Job
description: The night before Democratic leaders were expected to tap Representative Edolphus Towns as the partys senior member on the House oversight committee in the next Congress, Mr. Towns abruptly announced he wasnt up for the job.

title: House Easily Passes Dont Ask, Dont Tell Repeal
description: The House of Representatives Wednesday handily approved a repeal of a ban on gay men and lesbians serving openly in the military, ratcheting up the pressure on Senate Republicans who have resisted holding a vote to overturn the ban on procedural grounds.

title: MDC, Often Acquisitive, Makes Another Deal
description: MDC Partners, the advertising holding company that owns agencies like Crispin Porter & Bogusky and Kirshenbaum Bond Senecal & Partners, is making another acquisition.

title: Watching The Fish Fade to Black
description: MAX FISH, a bar on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, celebrated its 21st anniversary last Sunday. Balloons adorned the pastel walls, tin trays freighted with lasagna and chickpeas were unwrapped, and rock bands thundered through sets in the back lounge. But the mood was less exuberant than reflective. Days earlier, patrons learned that the storied dive bar would be shuttered at the end of January, another victim of high rent.

title: A Winning Loser
description: NBCs two-hour season finale of The Biggest Loser on Tuesday night attracted 11 million viewers, the shows largest audience in almost a year, according to Nielsens estimates. Although that reality series drew higher ratings for its fall finale in 2009 (13.5 million), NBC still easily ranked second for the night over all, earning 7.7 million at 8 for its game show Minute to Win It. CBS dominated the night at No. 1, leading during every time slot and producing the nights largest audience with NCIS at 8 (19.8 million). Following it, CBSs NCIS: Los Angeles drew 16.8 million at 9, while The Good Wife attracted 11.7 million at 10. In third and fourth places, Fox and ABC broadcast mostly repeats.

description: 49ers (5-8) at Chargers (7-6)Thursday, 8:20 p.m.Line: Chargers by 9

title: Heeding Audience Cues and Ping-Pong Balls
description: A contest involving swigs of whiskey forms one section of Witness Relocations Im Going to Make a Small Incision Behind Your Ear to Check and See if Youre Actually Human. This is called Worst Whiskey Contest; a brief journalistic investigation on opening night last week at the Bushwick Starr unearthed that the title comes from the quality of the alcohol (Philadelphia, $9.99 a liter, for those connoisseurs of economy out there).

title: The Financial Impact of Divorce on College Students
description: Heres some more evidence of how divorce is utterly devastating to ones financial life  and the financial lives of ones family.

title: U.S. Rethinks Strategy for the Unthinkable
description: Suppose the unthinkable happened, and terrorists struck New York or another big city with an atom bomb. What should people there do? The government has a surprising new message: Do not flee. Get inside any stable building and dont come out till officials say its safe.

title: Angry Birds Takes Over the iPhone
description: For $25, lovers of Angry Birds can now display their affection for the game by buying cases for the iPhone and iPod Touch that display the various characters in the game. You can choose between red or yellow kamikaze heroes, or one of the smirking green pigs.

title: Agreement Seems Near on Long-Stalled Lower East Side Project
description: The Lower East Side may be in the grips of a full-on gentrification, with a rotating cast of boutiques, hotels and cafes continuously flocking there, but several forlorn patches of land have remained frozen in time.

title: For Kevin Spacey, a Reviled Lobbyist Is No Mere Villain
description: In its current state Facebook has many virtues. Moviemaking is not among them.

title: New Chancellor Getting Up to Speed, in a Hurry
description: Cathleen P. Black rounded the corner Wednesday on two weeks of whirlwind school visits to prepare for her new job as city schools chancellor, stopping in for 45 minutes at the high-performing Medgar Evers College Preparatory School in Crown Heights, Brooklyn.

title: Wid Chapmans Vivid Dormitory Commons in Brooklyn
description: Many colleges have residences for their students. Those that dont often rely on companies like Educational Housing Services, in Manhattan, which builds and operates dorms and student lounges that colleges can rent  like the one in Brooklyn Heights, designed by Wid Chapman.

title: The New I:Wing Fan
description: The i:wing, which mimics the movements of a bird in flight, is more than just a new kind of fan. Its like a robotic, breeze-making pet.

title: Painting Without Pain: The Basics
description: WHEN I first painted houses during summer breaks from college, I was lucky no one was watching. My abstract period, as I like to remember it, was an oil-over-latex, enamel-on-glass, dripping binge of experimentalism that paved the way for latter-day masterpieces.

title: Sales at Ligne Roset, Intrieurs and Others
description: During the Dransfield & Ross sample sale, today and Friday, pillows, linens and decorative accessories will be marked way down (fake crocodile frames, originally $59, are $15; 16-inch round fake shagreen placemats, regularly $34, are $12; occasional tables, originally $405, are $140); 54 West 21st Street (Fifth Avenue), Suite 1201, (212) 741-7278 or dransfieldandross.biz.

title: Lillian August Opens in Manhattan
description: Lillian August doesnt do anything small scale. The 23-year-old companys flagship store in Connecticut is 75,000 square feet; its first New York City store, which opened last week, is a mere 17,000.

title: Doormats
description: AS winter approaches, and shoes and boots begin to accumulate muck, a good doormat comes in handy. For an interior designer like Philip Gorrivan, though, finding attractive doormats is a year-round quest.

title: Charlie Baker on Creating Windows for Herms
description: Its the time of year when the windows of most Madison Avenue retailers are dressed up for the holidays with Christmas trees and other seasonal decorations. The ones at Herms, however, stand stylistically apart from the rest. There are plenty of trees  but not of the evergreen variety.

title: Up Close: A Party Planner of Choice
description: Bronson Van Wyck was recently named the readers-choice event designer of the year by BizBash. Here are some examples of his party designs.

title: Antiques Cherished for Their Imperfections
description: Make-dos  scarred, centuries-old domestic objects that were mended in unusual ways  have a devoted following and a deconstructed aesthetic that would look at home in a high-end design store.

title: Leaving the Tinsel to Professional Hands
description: Three designers and the homes that theyve fluffed for clients during the holiday season.

title: Somewhere There Is a Free Lunch
description: I cant believe it, you came late and you got something that is that exciting, Nora Ephron said to the Bagger at a lunch for Somewhere on Wednesday afternoon, peering jealously at our plate: sweet potato ravioli with brown butter, winter squash and a few bright cranberries. Have some, we said, and a forkful was gone.

title: Tree-Trimming Advice From the Experts
description: PHOEBE HOWARD, a Florida decorator, got her start in the design business by providing Christmas decorating services. At one point, she was fluffing four houses a day. She suggests putting out citrus, pomegranates and cranberries mixed together in bowls with fresh greens, as she once did. It smells good and looks good, Ms. Howard said.

title: Even the Tree Has a Stylist
description: CAMPION PLATT, an architect known for designing swanky spaces like Manhattans MercBar, renovated the Upper West Side town house owned by his publicist, R. Couri Hay, this year. And as a special favor, later this week he plans to decorate Mr. Hays Christmas tree for him. There will be lavender tinsel, one garland of signed Warhol dollar bills and another made from celebrity photographs Mr. Hay snipped from magazines during the year  images of his favorite scandals and beauties, Mr. Platt said, including Tiger Woods, Lindsay Lohan and Carla Bruni. A video installation showing moody black-and-white Manhattan holiday images, which is also Mr. Platts firms Christmas greeting, will be playing continuously on Mr. Hays flat-screen television. To be sure, Mr. Platt is doing a bit of cross-pollinating by planting his name on Mr. Hays festivities, but he is also making sure that the decorations for Mr. Hays annual Christmas party are on a par with the interior architecture.

title: In Make-Do Objects, Collectors Find Beauty Beyond Repair
description: REUSE is all the rage these days: Witness the rise of fixers, tinkerers and hackers  that scrappy set of do-it-yourselfers who gather in collectives from Brooklyn to Berlin to breathe new life into broken objects that would have been consigned to the junk heap a few years earlier.

title: A-List Parties: More Taste, Less Flash
description: AMONG the heirloom antiques that Bronson Van Wyck, the Manhattan party planner, keeps in his cavernous Flatiron district apartment is a giant map of England from the 1930s, on which each social engagement of King George VI was meticulously plotted.

title: Old Meets Efficient in an English Terrace House
description: The Christophers family lives in an 1840s house in Birmingham, England, retrofitted to be carbon neutral.

title: An English House That Generates as Much as It Consumes
description: BIRMINGHAM, England

title: Tannenbaum Talks About Alosi and Building of Jets Wall
description: The transcript of General Manager Mike Tannenbaums conference call with reporters on Wednesday, as provided by the Jets. Tannenbaum said that the strength coach Sal Alosi had told inactive players to stand side by side on the sideline to obstruct Dolphins players on punts. A previous post discussed the ethics of that and whether other Jets might have known.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: Loving Your Phone
description: Just how attached are you to that smartphone? Would you say youre in love? J.D. Biersdorfer chats with Damon Darlin, the technology editor for The New York Times, about gadgets becoming objects of affection  at least until theyre replaced. Mr. Darlin says that electronic devices have become increasingly personal, often functioning as extensions of our brains, and it is the software we really love.

title: Front Row: Unbridled Fashion Returns to the Red Carpet
description: Cases of individuality have emerged at recent red carpet events, a change from the safe choices celebrities have made for fear of style pundits judgments.

title: Writer Races to Victory From Way Off the Pace
description: KALAMAZOO, Mich.  Jaimy Gordons novel Lord of Misrule, which won the National Book Award for fiction last month, was such a long shot that even Ms. Gordon and her publisher, Bruce McPherson, didnt think it had much of a chance. Ms. Gordon wore an old dress to the award ceremony and didnt bother to prepare any remarks. On learning that the book had been selected as a finalist, Mr. McPherson, the owner and sole full-time employee of McPherson & Company, a tiny press in Kingston, N.Y., only reluctantly upped the print run to 8,000 copies, from 2,000.

title: On Our Radar: Cold in Florida, Chinese Premier in India
description: Near-record cold descends on Florida, but fruit growers say they have so far emerged relatively unscathed. We certainly did not have anything catastrophic last night, an orange grower says after night temperatures drop below freezing. [Reuters]

title: Red Carpet Dress-Up Is Stylish Again
description: IS it safe for unbridled fashion to return to the red carpet?

title: TV Cables: Making the Right Connection
description: Sam Grobart discusses the different kinds of television cables, and advises against buying needlessly expensive ones.

title: An Enforcer for Consumer Finance Rules
description: Richard Cordray, Ohios attorney general, is about to take his battle against foreclosure fraud, abusive payday lenders and misbehaving global financial houses to Washington.

title: A Sherlock Holmes Tale Thats Hardly Elementary
description: Perhaps the greatest of the Sherlock Holmes mysteries is this: that when we talk of him we invariably fall into the fancy of his existence, T .S. Eliot wrote in a 1929 review of The Complete Sherlock Holmes Short Stories.

title: Newly Released Books
description: With Armageddon, Disaster and Cruelty in their titles, some of this months new books dont seem to have the holiday spirit. But in the hands of a gifted novelist or a clever illustrator, prison, grief, infidelity  even the end of the world  have their pleasures.

title: Bank of America Starts Talks on Soured Mortgages
description: In a bid to turn down the temperature in what promises to be an extended legal battle, Bank of America has opened a dialogue with investors who want the bank to buy back tens of billions in soured mortgages.

title: Is Google Too Big to Shop?
description: This week, Steve Pearlstein, a columnist for The Washington Post, locked horns with Google over the thorny subject of the search giants dominance and its quest to spread into new corners of the Web by buying other companies.

title: Browsing: Shopping Snapshots for Dec. 16
description: After 10 years with Lutz & Patmos, Marcia Patmos has introduced her own collection; boot selections for the season and more.

title: California: Sheriffs Deputies Brawl
description: Seven Los Angeles County sheriffs deputies have been suspended from duty after a brawl at a holiday party for employees of Mens Central Jail. About 100 people had gathered last Friday at the Quiet Cannon banquet hall in Montebello when an argument involving several deputies turned violent around 11:30 p.m. No shots were fired, but at least two people were injured, according to a sheriffs spokesman, Steve Whitmore. All the deputies involved have been suspended with pay, but the department released little other information.

title: The Americans Are in Our House. What Will the Taliban Think?
description: KUNDUZ, AfghanistanLife in troubled Kunduz Province can be summed up in a word: precarious. [see Alissa J. Rubins Times story Taliban Extend Reach to North, Where Armed Groups Reign]

title: Showing Their True College Colors
description: Passion for college football can be found just about everywhere  including the floor of the House of Representatives.

title: Los Angeles Schools to Seek Sponsors
description: LOS ANGELES  The football field at a public school here, in the second largest school district in the country, soon may be brought to students by Nike.

title: MacKenzie Miller, Trained Champion Horses, Dies at 89
description: MacKenzie Miller, who trained champion thoroughbred horses for nearly half a century and at the age of 71 saddled the 1993 Kentucky Derby winner, Sea Hero, died on Dec. 10 in Lexington, Ky. He was 89.

title: Chinas Push Into Wind Worries U.S. Industry
description: PIPESTONE, Minn.  Finishing the 20-story climb up a ladder inside a wind-turbine tower, Scott Rowland opened the top hatch to reveal a panorama of flat farmland dotted with dozens of other turbines.

title: Counting the Victims in a Honeymoon Killing
description: GUGULETU, South Africa  The Honeymoon Murder, as the crime is often called, has proved to be more than a riveting whodunit. South Africas honor seems on the line, as is the dignity of Guguletu, this crime-bedeviled township near Cape Town where the abduction happened.

title: At the Garden, the Buzz Is Back, and So Are the Knicks
description: Sent an e-mail to somebody Wednesday afternoon that ended, Im at the Knicks game.

title: Louisiana: Ex-Official Guilty
description: Anthony Jones on Wednesday became the second chief technology officer under former Mayor C. Ray Nagin of New Orleans to plead guilty to federal charges related to a kickback scheme involving a vendor. Mr. Jones is charged with conspiracy to commit bribery for accepting $20,000 in payoffs in 2006 and 2007 in exchange for approving and expediting payments to companies owned or controlled by Mark St. Pierre, a technology vendor. Last month, Greg Meffert, pleaded guilty to federal charges and admitted receiving nearly $900,000 in kickbacks in exchange for steering millions of dollars of work to Mr. St. Pierre. Mr. St. Pierre is facing trial in February. Mr. Jones was demoted from chief technology officer in 2008 for claiming that he had a college degree, which was untrue, and forced to resign in 2009 for a variety of reasons, including filing false invoices.

title: Q&A: FIFAs Chuck Blazer
description: Chuck Blazer is the general secretary of Concacaf, the regional confederation that includes the United States. He is also the only American on FIFAs powerful 24-man executive committee (a member since 1996), which recently awarded the 2018 and 2022 World Cups to Russia and Qatar. He said he cast his vote for Russia (2018) and the United States (2022), which lost out to Qatar in the fourth round of voting. Blazer spoke by telephone on Monday with Jack Bell of The Times from Abu Dhabi, where he is serving of the chairman of the committee that oversees the Club World Cup.

title: Ruling Is Upheld Against Executives Tied to OxyContin
description: A federal district judge in Washington has upheld the disbarment of three former top executives of the company that made the prescription painkiller OxyContin, ruling that they should still be prohibited from involvement in any government-financed health care program.

title: At Carlyle, an Effort to Close the Gender Gap
description: As a young investment banker, Karen H. Bechtel could remember standing out at high-level corporate board meetings for one reason: She was the only woman present.

title: Kilpatrick Indicted in Criminal Ring
description: DETROIT  The citys imprisoned former mayor, Kwame M. Kilpatrick, and two top aides rigged contracts, collected millions of dollars in bribes and defrauded taxpayers, the federal government said on Wednesday in a 38-count indictment that characterizes Mr. Kilpatricks inner circle as a long-running criminal organization.

title: Lineman Steps Out of the Trenches to Save a Strangers Life
description: Last week, Warren Sallach, a road maintenance worker from Brenham, Tex., called Matt Hoffman, a senior defensive end at Rowan University in Glassboro, N.J. They had never met, and Sallach froze when Hoffman answered.

title: The Best of 2010: 'The Aliens'
description: Charles Isherwood narrates a look at Annie Baker's play.

title: Canada Faulted for Lax Oil Sands Oversight
description: OTTAWA  An extensive review of Canadas oil sands released on Wednesday rejected several claims from both the energy industry and environmentalists while accusing Canadian governments of inadequate oversight of the projects.

title: East Slope vs. West Slope: Two Options for the Coatless
description: There are plenty of alternatives to the classic camel coat. Pick your look: East Coast ski patrol or Sun Valley winter hippie.

title: Six Victories, but Five First-Round Draft Picks
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

title: Ski Bunnies on City Slopes
description: EARLIER this month, when the temperatures in New York at last dropped to a seasonally appropriate level, Hilary Gallagher, a clerk at Intermix in SoHo, was watching as shoppers filtered into the store and, with their winter jackets discarded on the dressing room floor, tried on what Ms. Gallagher described as the urban ski get-up: Fair Isle sweaters (long and belted from D & G on sale for $859; loosely draped from Juliette Jake at $285) layered with fur vests (honey-colored raccoon by Theory, $1,200; cropped fox by Yves Salomon, $495; hooded mink by Cassin, $4,595).

title: The Tears of John Boehner
description: Crybaby. Wimp. Sensitive man. The reviews of John Boehners sobfest in a 60 Minutes profile last Sunday have been all over the map, fueling a debate on when its appropriate for men in public life to cry.

title: Rising Interest Rates and the Feds Red Ink
China Agrees to Intellectual Property Protections
description: WASHINGTON  Senior Chinese officials pledged on Wednesday to better crack down on software piracy and other violations of intellectual property rights as part of a series of commercial agreements after two days of talks here.

title: Fashion Triumph: Deflecting the Male Gaze
description: LEANDRA MEDINE, a fashion blogger who lives with her parents on the Upper East Side, was thumbing through the hangers in her bedroom closet on a recent Monday morning, pulling out the sort of items that she calls sartorial contraceptives: a blouse with erect shoulder pads from Zara; a floral, curtainlike blazer by Zimmermann; high-waisted lime green trousers by Opening Ceremony; drop-crotch utility pants; an ostrich-feather miniskirt; a cape.

title: Lee Returns, Saying He Never Wanted to Leave
description: PHILADELPHIA  On a frigid Wednesday afternoon with blustery winds and snow showers, Cliff Lee again put on a Phillies jersey and fans began longing impatiently for spring.

title: He Sold a Vision at Fox, and Marketers Bought It
description: FOUR decades later, Jon Nesvig, the dean of network sales executives, can still recall details of his first job.

title: Bloomberg to Publish Editorials
description: Being mayor of New York City would be a large enough platform for just about anyone. But apparently not for Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: Health Suits Stir Concerns on Court Partisanship
description: PENSACOLA, Fla.  With a loose web of conservative plaintiffs leading the charge, and judicial rulings breaking thus far along ideological lines, the drive to scuttle the Obama health care law is once again highlighting the role of partisanship in Americas courts.

title: On Health Law, Check Back in a Generation
description: WASHINGTON  When President Obama signed the health care bill into law last spring, White House aides predicted that the political benefit to their party would be almost immediate, going so far as to suggest that some provisions, like the one requiring insurance companies to cover pre-existing conditions, would help Democratic chances in the November elections.

title: At Issue in Emanuel Hearing: Boxes in Basement
description: CHICAGO  The contents of Rahm Emanuels basement took center stage on Wednesday in an election board hearing to determine whether he can run for mayor.

title: For G.M.s, Finding an Ace Is the Easy Part
description: Every baseball fan  every serious fan, anyway  has a little bit of Raymond Babbitt in him. Thats the Dustin Hoffman character from Rain Man, who knows precisely when Fernando Valenzuela is scheduled to pitch for the Dodgers. The game the ace pitches is the one fans want to see.

title: Wind Power for Boston, Made in China
description: Goldwind USA and A-Power Energy Generation Systems are not the only big Chinese-owned wind energy companies setting up shop in this country.

title: Life Sentence for Plotting To Set Off Blasts at J.F.K.
description: A former Guyanese politician convicted of plotting to blow up fuel tanks at Kennedy International Airport was sentenced on Wednesday to life in prison.

title: U.S. Tries to Build Case for Conspiracy by WikiLeaks
description: WASHINGTON  Federal prosecutors, seeking to build a case against the WikiLeaks leader Julian Assange for his role in a huge dissemination of classified government documents, are looking for evidence of any collusion in his early contacts with an Army intelligence analyst suspected of leaking the information.

title: A Voice for Radio, With Oprahs Ambition
description: At Mercy High School in Farmington Hills, Mich., Dawn Hills classmates voted her most likely to become Oprah. Ms. Hill, 24, is a local producer and a fledgling voice-over artist for commercials on the radio stations WBLS and WLIB. Her primary responsibilities are The Yolanda Adams Morning Show, on WLIB (1190 AM), which plays gospel music, and Middays With Egypt, on WBLS (107.5 FM), which plays R&B. Raised in Detroit, she graduated from Howard University in 2008 and lives in Harlem with two roommates.

title: In Whitmans Pocket, an Imagined Lincoln
description: The librarian wheels out the box on a little wooden trolley that reminds me of a dim-sum cart or a hospital gurney. Inside it is the poets notebook, dismembered with surgical care by a long-ago conservator, each leaf pressed between sheets of adhesive silk as if it were a fragment of the Dead Sea Scrolls. This private, portable thing is now splayed open, immobilized.

title: Coming to Grips With Lugging an iPad
description: CALL it the male iPad dilemma: too large to slip into a pants pocket, too stiff to be curled up like a magazine and too precious to leave unprotected. With its rigid tablet shape, Apples iPad has raised an awkward consideration for many men: how to carry it in a manner that is practical and yet, well, masculine.

title: Walk In, Grab a Muffin and Watch a Newspaper Reinvent Itself
description: TORRINGTON, Conn.

title: Clinton Pledges Bigger Role for Besieged State Department
description: WASHINGTON  Seeking to reassert the State Departments role as the primary agent of Washington overseas, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton on Wednesday announced an ambitious overhaul of diplomacy and development. And she promised to do it without spending a lot more money.

title: Sweden Bombing Doesnt Soil Image of Tolerance
description: STOCKHOLM  As they consider the suicide bombing that recently rocked their country, many Swedes have taken comfort from the attacks most enduring image, as captured by a security camera: a man in a red jacket kneeling by the dying bomber, asking if there was anything he could do for the man while other bystanders, spying unexploded pipe bombs still strapped to the mans waist, backed away, shouting, Bomb! Bomb! Bomb!

title: Security Council Removes Restrictions on Iraq
description: UNITED NATIONS  The United States, tying up loose ends as its occupation of Iraq winds down, pushed through three Security Council resolutions on Wednesday that lifted restrictions left over from the confrontation with Saddam Hussein.

title: In France, Civil Unions Gain Favor Over Marriage
description: PARIS  Some are divorced and disenchanted with marriage; others are young couples ideologically opposed to marriage, but eager to lighten their tax burdens. Many are lovers not quite ready for old-fashioned matrimony.

title: As Koreans Pour In, a Town Is Remade
description: PALISADES PARK, N.J.  Two decades ago, the police here sometimes roused Jason Kim in the wee hours, but not because he was in trouble. There were few Koreans in town, and few of them spoke English, so whenever one was arrested, the police needed Mr. Kim to translate the Miranda warning.

title: Fraud Charges in New Yorks Payroll Overhaul
description: Of all the city programs that have ever gone wrong in New York, few could compare to CityTime, an automated system meant to streamline employee timekeeping.

title: Making It, Until a Slip on the Ice Threw Life Into Crisis
description: In February, Evelyn De La Cruz slipped on a patch of ice on the sidewalk and felt a sharp pain in her left ankle.

title: Black, White and Plaid All Over
description: CALL it chromophobia.

title: Hunt Is On for Serial Killer in Long Island Deaths
description: The theory that the deaths of four people whose bodies were found in recent days on a Long Island beach are victims of a serial killer gained momentum on Wednesday when the authorities determined that all of them were women.

title: Trading Up: Shadow Plaids
description: While colorful plaids can read as weekend wear, black and white plaids have a stylishly professional, low-key mien. Heres an assortment of plaids of a different color to get you started.

title: Photo Replay: Dec. 15
description: A view of the day in sports, from snow-covered ski mountains to snow-covered football stadiums.

title: NATO Push Deals Taliban a Setback in Kandahar
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  As the Obama administration reviews its strategy in Afghanistan, residents and even a Taliban commander say the surge of American troops this year has begun to set back the Taliban in parts of their southern heartland and to turn people against the insurgency  at least for now.

title: Taliban Extend Reach to North, Where Armed Groups Reign
description: KUNDUZ, Afghanistan  This city, once a crossroads in the countrys northeast, is increasingly besieged. The airport closed months ago to commercial flights. The roads heading south to Kabul and east to Tajikistan as well as north and west are no longer safe for Afghans, let alone Westerners.

title: Goodell Is Confident About Chances of Labor Agreement
description: FORT WORTH  Commissioner Roger Goodell said Wednesday that reaching a new collective bargaining agreement by the end of the postseason is realistic, although he declined to characterize the state of negotiations. Goodell and team owners spent their meeting focused primarily on labor issues, although several owners declined to reveal what was discussed behind closed doors.

title: Arms Pact Passes One Test as Senate Acts to Debate It
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate opened debate on Wednesday on a new arms-control treaty with Russia with an early test vote showing that President Obama is right on the edge of securing its approval.

title: Thursday: Ill-Fated
description: There were three parts to cracking todays theme. The first part was actually cracking it. The next was realizing how many phrases can fit the theme (there are even a few more). The last was noticing how the theme entries all fit into place  two stretched the full width of the grid, crossing two others along the way.

title: At Hospital, Preparing for a Strike
description: New York Citys public hospital system has drawn up contingency plans to keep emergency services running at Harlem Hospital Center if physicians fulfill their threat to walk out, hospital officials said Wednesday.

title: Irish Drug Maker Settles Charges of Improper Marketing
description: The Irish pharmaceutical company Elan has agreed to pay $203.5 million to resolve criminal and civil complaints that it improperly marketed the antiseizure medicine Zonegran for weight loss and mood stabilization, the Justice Department said on Wednesday.

title: Espada and Son Plead Not Guilty to Embezzling From Health Network
description: There was no swagger, and no theatrical denunciation of his political rivals.

title: Lottery Numbers
4-Goal Burst by Rangers Takes Focus Off Penguins
description: PITTSBURGH  The Rangers seemed almost like an afterthought Wednesday, with Sidney Crosby and the glamorous Penguins making their HBO debut later in the night, many talking about the Winter Classic on Jan. 1 at Heinz Field, and Pittsburgh leading this game by a goal.

title: A Green Detroit? No, a Guzzling One
description: Portland, Ore.

title: Begging for Your Pay
description: Romulo Saldana was looking for work.

title: Get the Lead Out of Hunting
description: Santa Barbara, Calif.

title: In Skidmore, Mo., a Killing Lingers
description: The memory of the nightmare surrounding the troublemaking of Ken Rex McElroy, and later his killing, continues to loom large in the small town of Skidmore, Mo.

title: N.H.L. Excited About HBO Documentary
description: The hierarchy of the National Hockey League was ecstatic. In the conference room at their headquarters, they had just screened the first episode of 24/7 Penguins/Capitals: Road to the NHL Winter Classic hours before it aired Wednesday night on HBO.

title: Heat and Cavaliers Pass in the Night
description: MIAMI  An N.B.A. season can feel like a highway to forever, but one head-on collision in early December might have shaped the Miami Heat as the irresistible force it was expected to be and the Cleveland Cavaliers as the wreckage that LeBron James left behind.

title: Knicks Cant Beat Buzzer or Celtics
description: The release felt solid  the way it had all game  whether it was a silky jumper or violent dunk. This time, Amare Stoudemire stepped behind the 3-point arc, outside his normal range. The ball left his right hand and settled into the net, igniting the loudest roar Madison Square Garden had heard in years, the apparent game-winner at the buzzer topping Paul Pierces apparent game-winner with 0.4 of a second left.

title: Town Mute for 30 Years About a Bullys Killing
description: SKIDMORE, Mo.  The murder of Ken Rex McElroy took place in plain view of dozens of residents of this small farm town, under the glare of the morning sun. But in a dramatic act of solidarity with the gunman, every witness, save the dead mans wife, denied seeing who had pulled the trigger.

title: Bob Feller, Whose Fastball Dazzled, Dies at 92
description: Bob Feller, who came off an Iowa farm with a dazzling fastball that made him a national celebrity at 17 and propelled him to the Hall of Fame as one of baseballs greatest pitchers, died on Wednesday in Cleveland, where he had played for the Indians for 18 years. He was 92.

title: Last Word: Bob Feller
description: Bob Feller is one of the greatest baseball pitchers ever to play the game. He began his major league career as a teenager in 1936, throwing a fastball the game has not seen since.

title: Seeking an Equation for Wins
description: A look at the the California Institute of Technology mens basketball team.

title: Italy: Court Upholds Convictions of Americans in Kidnapping Case
description: An appellate court in Milan upheld on Wednesday the conviction of 23 Americans charged with kidnapping an Egyptian cleric in 2003 and ordered even harsher sentences. All but one of the Americans are Central Intelligence Agency operatives. Defense lawyers said they planned to file appeals, which would go to Italys highest court. Robert Seldon Lady, a former C.I.A. base chief in Milan, was sentenced to nine years, one more than his previous conviction, while the 22 other Americans received seven-year sentences, up from five years. The Americans were also ordered to pay a total of $1.33 million in damages to the Egyptian cleric,  Hassan Mustafa Osama Nasr, who was kidnapped in Milan. Prosecutors said that he was taken to Egypt, where, he said, he was tortured. Italy has never formally requested the extradition of the Americans. Through their lawyers, they have pleaded not guilty in the past.

title: Curators Criticize Controversial Arts Removal
description: A talk on Wednesday at the New York Public Library by the curators of a controversial exhibition at the National Portrait Gallery in Washington drew a show of support for the gallery, as well as criticism of its parent institution, the Smithsonian, which two weeks ago decided to remove an AIDS-themed artwork from the show after it came under attack.

title: Maynard W. Glitman, Arms Negotiator, Dies at 77
description: Maynard W. Glitman, a diplomat who led the American side in negotiating the intermediate-range nuclear forces treaty, signed by the United States and the Soviet Union in 1987, died on Tuesday in Shelburne, Vt. He was 77 and had homes in Fletcher and Burlington, Vt.

title: France: Freedom for Noriega Rejected
description: A court in Paris on Wednesday rejected a request for the release of the imprisoned former Panamanian dictator Manuel Antonio Noriega, who is serving a prison term in France after his conviction on money-laundering charges. In July, Mr. Noriega, who ruled Panama from 1983 to 1989, was sentenced to seven years in prison for laundering $3 million in Colombian drug money through international banks and into French accounts in 1988 and 1989. Mr. Noriega had been extradited from the United States to France in April after spending 15 years in a Miami prison on charges that included cocaine trafficking. The government of Panama has requested that Mr. Noriega be extradited to serve three 20-year prison terms for human rights abuses and involvement in the disappearance of political opponents. Yves Leberquier, Mr. Noriegas lawyer, asked for just a bit of humanity, noting his clients many years in prison.

title: Germany: A Contribution for Auschwitz
description: Germany will contribute $80.5 million over the next year to help carry out conservation work at Auschwitz-Birkenau, the site of the former death camp, the Foreign Ministry said. Foreign Minister Guido Westerwelle said that with the contribution to the Auschwitz-Birkenau Foundation, Germany bears witness to its historical responsibility to commemorate the Holocaust and to convey this to future generations.

title: Ukraine: Investigation of Ex-Premier
description: Prosecutors are investigating a former prime minister, Yulia V. Tymoshenko, who is accused of mishandling hundreds of millions of dollars when she was in office, officials said Wednesday. title: Florida: Neo-Nazi Guilty of Murder
description: A New Port Richey jury on Wednesday found John Ditullio Jr. guilty of murder and attempted murder. Mr. Ditullio, 24, was accused of stabbing Patricia Wells and Kristofer King in March 2006; Mr. King, who was 17, died. The trial, a second attempt to convict Mr. Ditullio after a mistrial last year, drew national attention because the court paid to have a cosmetologist cover Mr. Ditullios prominent tattoos, including a swastika on his neck. His lawyer, Bjorn E. Brunvand, argued that another man in the neo-Nazi group that Mr. Ditullio hoped to join had actually committed the crimes. The jury deliberated for 11 hours; the penalty phase of the trial will begin Thursday. Mr. Ditullio could be sentenced to death.

title: A Taste of Montreal at Vics Bagel Bar
description: Manhattanites no longer have to trek to Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, and wait on line at Noah Bernamoffs Mile End Deli for Montreal-style meats. At Vics Bagel Bar, 544 Third Avenue (36th Street), the owner, Vic Glazer, gets regular deliveries of smoked meat, smoked turkey and smoked beef salami. The meats are layered into sandwiches, including the Ellen Barkin, using the smoked meat ($7.95). Mr. Bernamoffs wife, Rachel Cohen, is an old friend of Ms. Glazers, which is how the connection was made. Ive known Rachel since we were at Yeshiva together, Ms. Glazer said. Ms. Glazer also sells the smoked meat by the pound, $30; the salami is $28 a pound. If you insist on a Montreal-style bagel, then its Mile End, 97A Hoyt Street (Atlantic Avenue), for you after all. Meanwhile, check out what Robert Sietsema has to say about the Montreal-New York culinary connection.

title: In Pursuit of the Perfect Brainstorm
description: Last month, in a small room on the fifth floor of a high-rise building in San Mateo, Calif., three men sat around a table, thinking. The place was wallpapered with Post-it notes, in a riot of colors, plus column after column of index cards pinned to foam boards. Some of the cards had phrases like space maximizers or stuff trackers written on them. Many had little three-dimensional ink drawings and titles, like color-coded Tupperware horizontal stacker. It looked as if these guys had been locked in and told they couldnt leave until they dreamed up 1,000 of the wackiest home-storage items they could imagine.

title: Composing a Church-Going Western
description: At the party following the New York premiere of True Grit on Tuesday night, the 14-year-old star, Hailee Steinfeld, held court with her 15-year-old best friend, Katee Cassidy, prancing around the Pool Room at the Four Seasons restaurant holding hands. The prancing was greatly helped by the fact that Ms. Steinfeld had changed out of the purple stilettos she wore on the red carpet and into silver glitter hi-tops. Toward the end of the night, another of the movies stars, Jeff Bridges, dressed down too, getting all Dude-like in his wrinkled white shirt and posing for photos with a glass  of what appeared to be water  in his hand. As usual, Joel and Ethan Coen, who wrote and directed the film, declined to talk. But the Bagger was glad to find Carter Burwell, the films composer. Mr. Burwell has always written music for the Coens, as well as for Spike Jonzes films, like Where the Wild Things Are. This awards season he is also represented by The Kids Are All Right. He lives and records in New York; the score for True Grit was composed at the Manhattan Center with a 70-piece orchestra. And it was being fine-tuned until the very last moment  the last recording session was held Nov. 8. Mr. Burwell is a member of the Academy, but, he revealed to us, that didnt make him an expert on who would win the Oscar for best score. (Readers, youre on your own.) But Mr. Burwell did clue us into the process of composing that memorably grand music. An edited version of the conversation follows.

The annual census, which began on Tuesday and runs through Jan. 5, relies on volunteers throughout the Western Hemisphere who head out with binoculars, spotting scopes, bird guides, cellphones, mobile apps and notepads. They scan trees and fields, reporting on every bird they see over a 24-hour period.

JASON MORAN Ten (Blue Note) A pianist often hailed first for his ideas, Mr. Moran has spent the last decade forging an urgent, elegant style with the Bandwagon, which is to say the drummer Nasheet Waits and the bassist Tarus Mateen. This album, true to the pliable strength and tumbling grace of the band, doubles as a testament to jazzs endless renewal.

title: Redrawing Rhythmic Strategies
description: 1. STEVE COLEMAN AND FIVE ELEMENTS Harvesting Semblances and Affinities (Pi). Not that Mr. Coleman, the alto saxophonist, ever disappeared, but this feels like a return, his strongest and prettiest record in more than a decade. The band, with the singer Jen Shyu and the miraculous drummer Tyshawn Sorey, sounds lifted by the musics complex latticework, deeply programmed but set spinning.

Anyone who ever had to watch an instructional film in school should feel right at home here.

title: Slowly Altering Expectations
description: It would be nice to tie up 2010 with some sweeping theme. But the truth is that when you are in the woods, all you can see is the trees. Except of course when someone else paints a picture of your particular forest, and you dont recognize it. Jennifer Homanss Apollos Angels has gotten a lot of attention for its declaration that ballet is dying, but critics have no doubt been muttering this darkly since Louis XIV was the Sun King. Ms. Homanss cutoff point is Balanchines death, but almost 30 years later you can finally see that a new generation has brought a resolute contemporaneity to the form, offering us new ways to look at and think about ballet. Lets start the best-of list there.

title: Vibrant Scenes 20th-Century Base
description: KEELY GARFIELDS intimate dance-theater explorations at Duo Multicultural Arts Center, the inimitable New York City Ballet star Wendy Whelan, Ralph Lemons gorgeous elegy at the Brooklyn Academy of Music: the list of top-notch artists working in this city in 2010 goes on and on. And thats not counting exciting foreign imports like Alain Buffard of France, the American expatriate Rob List and the Brazilian Bruno Beltro. Dance is all over the map these days, with no one ruling orthodoxy, myriad distinctive voices and a sensibility that seems, in all its messy force and interdisciplinary variety, distinctively 21st century. These artists arent fringe or experimental; theyre simply contemporary.

title: Exotic Timbres in the Darkness
description: LE POME HARMONIQUE AND THE JACK QUARTET There is a joke that goes: How many music critics does it take to change a light bulb? None. They dont mind being in the dark. Well, that may be. Darkness played an important role in two extraordinarily moving performances this year. The French early-music group Le Pome Harmonique presented its stunning account of Emilio de Cavalieris Lamentations of Jeremiah at St. Mary the Virgin in January, as a Tenebrae service in which the lighting (mostly by candle) was gradually diminished until the final stanza was performed in darkness. And the Jack Quartet, playing from the four corners of the Austrian Cultural Forums concert hall in September, surrounded its audience  which sat in total darkness for 70 minutes  with the exotic timbres of Georg Friedrich Haass String Quartet No. 3 (In iij. Noct., 2001).

title: Global Puck: Development Program and American Success at the World Juniors
description: It takes several seconds to say United States national team development program, but you can also say U.S.N.T.D.P. or even just N.T.D.P., which is still a bit of a tongue-twister. But the long and the short of it is that this program, operating in the shadows of Michigan Stadium which just last week attracted a world-record crowd to a hockey game, is the main reason why the United States is favored to win gold at the upcoming world under-20 (junior) championship in Buffalo and Lewiston, N.Y. Check that  not just favored to win a gold medal, but to repeat as gold medalists.

title: The Cinematic State of Things
description: IN any given year, if you see enough movies  out of habit, ardor or obligation  you will start to notice patterns and clusters. By December the temptation will be nearly overwhelming to generalize from this data, to turn coincidences into trends and trends into matters of world-historical significance. The ad hoc, arbitrary, week-in-week-out sampling of stories and pictures must add up to something, right? Otherwise why bother?

title: Remembering Feller
description: Days like Thursday, when the sports news offers colliding story lines from different eras, it is hard not to feel a pang of nostalgia for a simpler age. Sure, the days of Bob Fellers prime had their downside  a big one: the military he served in and the sport he played were still largely segregated  but when your choice of news is whether the Jets Rex Ryan knew his strength coach was trying to take out opposing players (or when did he know it), the story of Fellers life seems so much more appealing, even when you know youre peering through the gauze filter of history.

title: Unexpected, Unfiltered, Unbelievable, Unctuous
description: GREAT UNEXPECTATIONS A few new shows in 2010 were surprisingly good, like The Walking Dead, the zombie thriller on AMC, but the best offerings were mostly in their second seasons and predictably well done: Glee, Modern Family and The Good Wife all started in 2009.

description: Photos of Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson, The Merchant of Venice and other shows.

title: Hath Not a Year Highlights? Even This One?
description: O.K., so the big picture wasnt all that pretty. At times 2010 seemed intent on recapping everything that has been least appealing about New York theater in the first decade of the 21st century. Big, empty-headed musicals that coasted on brand-name appeal (The Addams Family); tepid revivals of mothball-scented hits from another era (Promises, Promises); star-heavy productions on Broadway of shows that didnt belong there (Patrick Stewart and T. R. Knight in A Life in the Theater, James Earl Jones and Vanessa Redgrave in Driving Miss Daisy); spectacles in which frantic technical design upstaged the performers (Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown).

title: Park Slope Plane Crash | The Boy Who Fell From the Sky

It was as if some celestial central casting agency had carefully assigned the role of courageous survivor to an 11-year-old boy whose life  had it been spared  would have lent to the senseless wreckage one single note of grace.

title: U.S. Energy Choices and Global Climate Plans
description: Theres plenty to ponder in the newly released summary of the Annual Energy Outlook 2011 by the Department of Energy. While all such forecasts are implicitly uncertain, this one helps clarify where to focus efforts to cut greenhouse gas emissions; reinforces the importance of resolving questions about how to safely expand, while not stopping, extraction of vast domestic reserves of natural gas; and powerfully challenges proponents of accelerated deployment of todays menu of renewable energy technologies or nuclear power plants to lay out a credible strategy for supplanting coal.

title: Following in Fathers Parallel-Universe Footsteps
description: When Tron opened in 1982, it seemed to offer irrefutable proof that the next cinematic revolution would be digitized and possibly in DayGlo. The movie starred Jeff Bridges as a video game designer sucked into an electronic world (a nice metaphor for an industry that often puts technological trippery above art) that was eye-popping and lid-dropping, with jolts of beauty blazing amid a morass of sluggish storytelling. The main attractions  bleeding-edge computer-generated imagery and an alternative reality aglow with pulsing phosphorescent colors usually found under the sea or black lights  pointed toward a brave new world. But the public largely didnt buy into that world, and the film sputtered at the box office.

On Broadway, where the media attention focuses, familiar war horses make regular appearances  you again, Hedda?  while each season another theater is colonized by retro-rock musicals allowing baby boomers to let the good times of yesteryear roll again. You might say the past is the present, and the future too, to borrow a line from an oft-revived Eugene ONeill classic.

With preview performances now under way the delay is intended to provide more time for the creators to stage a new final number, make further rewrites to the dialogue and consider adding and cutting scenes and perhaps inserting new music from the composers, U2s Bono and the Edge, who will resume working full-time on the show in late December.

title: 36 Hours in Paris
description: HAS Paris lost its edge? Mais non! The citys bohemians are just harder to find. The artsy denizens and creative tastemakers, always on the hunt for cheaper rents, have migrated to the citys fringes, like Belleville and the former red-light district of Pigalle. There are even fashion-forward hangouts in the postcard-perfect center  a pop-up restaurant here, a taxidermy-stuffed speakeasy there. And, of course, a modern take on the classic Parisian bistro or boulangerie will never go out of style.

title: Barcelonas Other Architect, Domnech
description: ITS sometimes hard to have a conversation about Barcelona that does not include the name Gaud in it. The world is so gaga for Anton Gaud  the genius of Catalan modernisme (the Spanish version of Art Nouveau) whose early 20th-century buildings are virtual emblems of the city  that most of his modernista contemporaries go little noticed by tourists.

title: How Does Your Hospital Room Make You Feel?
description: During a conversation with the wife of one of my former surgery patients, I was surprised to learn that her husband had chosen to receive his postoperative chemotherapy treatments at a hospital across town from mine. His wife assured me that he had liked the highly respected colleague I had referred him to; what had troubled him was that the doctors office and the hospital chemotherapy infusion suites were, well, depressing.

title: A Hospital Room With a View
description: With the current emphasis on reining in costs, increasing productivity and improving safety, its hard not to view the personal amenities offered by certain hospitals with some level of suspicion. While the well-appointed lobbies, personalized meal services and private rooms with a view  all designed to make hospitals feel un-hospital-like  can be meaningful to patients, families and even clinicians and staff, few of us have ever acknowledged their role in patient care. Instead, we tend to deride these nonclinical services as fluffy perks at best and frivolous manifestations of profit-driven medicine at worst.

title: Asked and Answered | Emma Reeves
description: As the former photography director for Dazed & Confused, AnOther and Tar Magazines, Emma Reeves has worked with some of the sharpest shooters in the game. Shes also made stops at V and The Journal, and worked as a curator. (She pulled together David Armstrongs Mad About the Boy at Half Gallery last month.) So when Christian Parkes, the head of marketing for Levis, reached out to her to create the programming for the brands Photography Workshop at 18 Wooster Street in SoHo, she says, it was a natural fit. The revolving door of installations, spread over 10 weeks and including Tiny Vices, curated by Tim Barber, an exhibition of Taschens mega-book Portrait of a City, speaking engagements by the likes of Bruce Davidson, and a workshop with state-of-the-art Leicas, was by all counts a smashing success. We caught up with the busy multi-hyphenate as she readied for Saturdays triumphant closing party, to talk about Levis, lessons and the potential of participatory retail.

title: Youre Roasted: Comedy Central Plans Satiric Salute to Donald Trump
description: When you examine the balance sheet of Donald J. Trump, is there really anything that funny about him, other than his relentless self-promotional streak, the seesawing fortunes of his Apprentice reality-television franchise, his string of marriages and his enigmatic hairline? Thats for the comedians to figure out: Mr. Trump, the real-estate mogul and media personality, will be the next victim guest of honor at a Comedy Central roast, the cable channel said on Thursday. The Comedy Central Roast of Donald Trump will be taped on March 9  the first such roast to be filmed in New York since 2005, back when Comedy Central felt the comedian Jeff Foxworthy deserved the distinction  and broadcast in the spring. No slander-slinging panelists were immediately announced for the event, but if tradition holds, Mr. Trump can look forward to a speedy elimination from a future season of Dancing With the Stars.

The work was vividly realized by Mr. Gilbert and a fine cast of singers in a sold-out production designed and directed by Doug Fitch, featuring imaginative multimedia and fantastical costumes by Catherine Zuber.

title: Philharmonic Renewed Under a Bold Conductor
description: WITH the arrival of Alan Gilbert as the music director of the New York Philharmonic in 2009 came the promise of youthful vigor and bold initiatives. But who could have anticipated that by the midpoint of Mr. Gilberts second season the Philharmonic would be a potent, even groundbreaking force for contemporary music? The most striking example of Mr. Gilberts expansive view of the Philharmonics potential  and the greatest triumph achieved by any New York musical institution in 2010  came in May, when the orchestra presented the New York premiere of Gyorgy Ligetis opera Le Grand Macabre

description: A reader wanted to know whether she could take her young children to the Peter Luger steakhouse in Brooklyn. Youll see how I answered, and what other readers had to say about that, below. Also: Where to take parents who resemble George Costanzas, from Seinfeld. Now, to the questions!

title: In Old Lyme, Fighting a Curb on Year-Round Use
description: ROSEMARY BREEN owns two houses but is ready to downsize. Approaching 60, and with a disabled husband, Ms. Breen, a school nurse, hopes to sell their colonial in Newington and move to their wood-shingled Cape Cod in Point O Woods, one of several beach communities in the shoreline town of Old Lyme.

title: Producers Ask Audience to Help Bring Back The Scottsboro Boys
description: Undertaking an unusual poll-cum-pledge-drive among theatergoers, the producers of the Broadway musical The Scottsboro Boys, which closed on Sunday because of weak ticket sales, are asking fans and others to commit on the shows Web site to buying $99 tickets if the musical were to reopen on Broadway this spring.

The latest evidence is a local builders plans to erect a 113-unit rental tower on a vacant lot beside the light-rail tracks on the west side, starting work as soon as possible next year.

title: Week 15 in Fantasy Football: Matchups and Q. & A.
description: The brothers Sablich are here to help with fantasy football analysis for Week 15. They will also answer reader questions until 5 p.m. Eastern on Friday. Post a question below and follow them on Twitter for more advice leading up to game time on Sunday.

description: WINTER in New York City usually comes with an urge to hunker down at home to escape the cold. But while the blasting heat from apartment radiators may be warming, its not exactly as cheering as a fireplace.

description: A small study at an urban pediatric clinic suggests that children younger than 12 are routinely consuming so much caffeine that it could interfere with their sleep. The source, almost exclusively, is caffeinated soft drinks, like Coca-Cola.

title: The Far-Ranging Artistic Alliances That Shaped a Sculptor
description: Artists are supposed to be relentless networkers, but the multitasking, multicultural sculptor-designer Isamu Noguchi was industrious even by this standard. The staggering depth and diversity of his connections come to light in On Becoming an Artist: Isamu Noguchi and His Contemporaries, 1922-1960 at the Noguchi Museum in Long Island City, Queens.

description: So far, the news from Port au Prince is grim: cholera infections are on the rise across Haiti, more than 2,000 people have died, and the end is nowhere in sight.

description: IF youve bought all your presents, Christmas Eve is a good moment to visit half a dozen stores that dont sell anything, dont take returns and dont accept credit cards. description: Victorian toymakers spun off products from the latest theatrical productions soon after the plays opened. There was a day when I would have said it would go for a party, Mr. Reid, who operates his mens and womens design business from Florence, Ala., said today, a month after winning the funds top prize.
