Mr. Ozawa, 75, has been debilitated with health problems, including surgery and treatments for esophageal cancer and the worsening of chronic back ailments.

title: Charades of Normalcy After Death of a Child
description: In the movies the death or endangerment of a child justifies both serious acts of violent revenge and violent displays of serious acting. Victorian literature, belonging to an age when people had  and lost  more children than is common today, treated juvenile mortality as an opportunity for high, almost consoling, sentiment. The famous image of Charles Dickens weeping as he sent little Nell into the great beyond is an emblem of cathartic, therapeutic sympathy. We modern souls, with fewer offspring, longer life expectancies and less metaphysical and moral certainty, are less easily soothed by vicarious grief.

title: Heartaches and Harmonies
description: SONGWRITERS have been translating heartache into melody for centuries, scoring the human condition with weather-worn notebooks and battered guitars. As the Irish folk singer Frank Harte once said, Those in power write the history, while those who suffer write the songs.

title: Funny Guys, Serious Business
description: Lets just hope it gets ugly, and then well all have fun, Conan OBrien privately joked about his future at The Tonight Show back in 2004, never imagining just how ugly  and how far from amusing  his clash with Jay Leno would become. But who could have predicted that, instead of passing him the baton, Mr. Leno would beat him about the face and neck with it? Or at least that was the reigning narrative as this strange battle unfolded in January 2010.

title: A Physical Choreography, Turning Women Into Targets
description: On returning to the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater after some months, the initial pleasure is always the same  and its powerful. These dancers! As soon as the curtain lifts, theres a firm fullness of tone; a way of making dance positions register as volumetric solids larger and more three-dimensional than the body itself; a textured, rhythmic acuity; an athletically formal grace; and a glowing love of sheer performance.

You cant walk into a supermarket in December without hearing Tchaikovskys music for the ballet, or at least some version thereof, and white-wigged Nutcracker dolls can be found at the 99-cent store.

title: CBS Survives
description: As the 21st edition of Survivor draws to a close, Wednesdays episode helped lift CBS to No. 1 over all in the nights ratings. According to Nielsens estimates, Survivor: Nicaragua attracted 12.4 million viewers, fewer than CBSs Criminal Minds in the 9 p.m. hour (13.8 million) but the largest audience for the series since its season premiere. Wednesdays episode, the last before the Survivor: Nicaragua finale on Sunday, easily outperformed its 8 p.m. time-slot competitors, including the first half of NBCs reality competition The Sing-Off, which averaged 8.4 million from 8 to 10. NBC ranked second for the night, garnering 6.9 million viewers at 10 for a rerun of Law & Order: SVU, although that too lagged behind CBSs drama The Defenders in the hour (10.2 million). Fox was third with a new episode of Human Target at 8 (5.8 million) and the season finale of Hells Kitchen at 9 (5.9 million). ABC finished fourth with a lineup of sitcom reruns.

title: Ron Paul Appears Poised to Irk the Fed Chief

It promises to be a miserable time for the Fed chairman as he is peppered with hostile questions at oversight hearings and with legislation to force complete audits of Fed operations.

title: A Closer Look at the G.D.P.
description: As the end of the year approaches, it seems appropriate to look at the economy from a macro-perspective  that is, at the level of gross domestic product or G.D.P.  to determine if the economy is growing, and if so, what G.D.P. components are contributing to growth. While this is not a definitive analysis of the economy, it does show if things are moving in the right direction. All of the statistical information that follows is from the Bureau of Economic Analysis, or B.E.A., and is inflation-adjusted.According to the National Bureau of Economic Research, the recession ended in June 2009, or the end of the second quarter of 2009. Since then, the U.S. economy has grown for 5 consecutive quarters at the following quarter to quarter rates: 1.6 percent, 5.0 percent, 3.7 percent, 1.7 percent and 2.5 percent. This is a median growth rate of 2.5 percent. The median growth rate for the first five quarters of the early 1990s and early 2000s expansions were 2.7 percent and 2 percent respectively, placing the growth rate of the current recovery right in the middle of the pack. This also indicates that slower growth at the beginning of a recovery is not atypical.

But as she showed in Alexander Paynes 1999 comedy, Election, in which she played a ferocious high-school climber in a dazzling performance that has hung over her career like an unmet dare, she can be a beautiful menace.

Yet another project nurtured to fruition by the prolific producer and industry multi-hyphenate Larry Fessenden, this grubby dive into drugs, murder, paganism and promiscuity will need more than a cast stuffed with fanboy favorites to hold audiences in their seats.

title: Gaza Mends, but Israelis See Signs of Trouble

Construction projects  sewage treatment plants, schools  are getting started but far fewer than needed. The border with Egypt, once sealed, is open but few people cross because security clearance is hard to get. And rockets and mortar shells fly daily from here into Israel, as Israeli troops carry out brief raids.

title: The Revolution Next Time?

Its first target was modest, a five-year-old federal statute called the Gun-Free School Zones Act that most people had never heard of, which made it a federal crime to possess a gun within 1,000 feet of a school.

title: Up Front: Garrison Keillor

title: Mark Twains Riverboat Ramblings
description: Samuel L. Clemens was a cheerful promoter of himself, and even after hed retired from the lecture circuit, the old man liked to dress up as Mark Twain in a fresh white suit and take a Sunday morning stroll up Fifth Avenue just as churches were letting out and see the heads turn and hear his name murmured, the crowds of Presbyterians and Episcopalians standing awe-struck as the most beloved mustache in America passed by, tipping his silk hat to the ladies. Mr. Twains autobiography was meant to be a last stroll around the block, and to build up suspense and improve sales, Sam told everybody that he was writing one and that it contained material so explosive it would need to be embargoed for a hundred years. That century has passed now and here it is, Volume 1 of The Complete Authentic Unexpurgated Edition, Nothing Has Been Omitted, Not Even Scandalous Passages Likely to Cause Grown Men to Gasp and Women to Collapse in Tears  No Children Under 7 Allowed to Read This Book Under Any Circumstance, which made Sam front-page news when all three volumes of the Autobiography of Mark Twain were announced last spring. The book turns out to be a wonderful fraud on the order of the Duke and the Dauphin in their Shakespearean romp, and bravo to Samuel Clemens, still able to catch the publics attention a century after he expired.

title: Massachusetts: Guilty Plea for Lying Way Into Harvard

Adam Wheeler, 24, was sentenced to two and a half years in prison, 10 years of probation and $45,000 in restitution. According to the sentence, Mr. Wheeler will serve only 30 days in prison. In May, Mr. Wheeler was charged after forging his transcripts and receiving more than $50,000 in scholarships and grants from Harvard. Mr. Wheeler applied to the university as a transfer student, sending fabricated records from M.I.T. and Philips Academy. In reality, Mr. Wheeler attended a public high school in Delaware and Bowdoin College.

title: Letter: Networker on a Mission

The question is whether John Prendergasts simplifications undermine the causes to which he is dedicated. I think they do. They understatethe scale of the interventions neededto effect change, even as they exaggerate the potential of American clout, and they understate the complexity of the problems facing these countries, which can lead him to champion potentially disastrous ideas. Underlying these simplifications is a deeply American faith in our own capacity  for doing good, for getting things done  a faith that Hollywood has always been happy to indulge. I wish that Prendergast would focus more on the capacity of local people, many of whom are working at extraordinary personal risk to bring peace to their lands. The question shouldnt be What can we do to end the suffering in these countries? but rather What can we do to help people within their societies overcome the enormous political and economic challenges they face? The difference is all in where you place the emphasis.

title: Two Sought in Brooklyn Subway Robberies

Being meticulous about paying his bills on time, Mr. Watson thought he would quality for a big reduction in his monthly payments. It turned out that four unpaid medical bills he wasnt even aware of had hurt his credit score. Mr. Watson is now trying to track down the collection agencies that are handling the bills to determine how much he owes.

title: Vatican: Pope Compares Fundamentalism With Secularism
description: Pope Benedict XVI compared religious fundamentalism to secularism on Thursday, decrying violent attacks on Christians in the Middle East and more subtle hostility from Western institutions. It should be clear that religious fundamentalism and secularism are alike in that both represent extreme forms of a rejection of legitimate pluralism and the principle of secularity, he said. He also decried hostility and prejudice against Christians in Asia, Africa and in the Middle East, citing the October attack on a Syrian Catholic church in Baghdad in which 58 people died. Christians are the religious group which suffers most from persecution on account of its faith, he said.

title: China: Last County Linked to Highway System
description: China announced Thursday that it had connected a Tibetan county, Medog, to the nations highway system, ending the relative isolation of the area. Until Wednesday, Medog, in the eastern part of the Tibet Autonomous Region, was the last county in China with no highway linking it to the outside world, officials said. The announcement was made on the front page of China Daily, an English-language newspaper, and signaled the pride that Chinese officials have in the countrys rapid infrastructure development.

title: Italy: Sentence Upheld in Murder of British Student
description: Italys highest court on Thursday upheld the 16-year sentence of a man convicted of killing a British exchange student in Perugia in 2007. Rudy Guede, a Perugia resident born in Ivory Coast, was one of three people convicted of the murder and sexual assault of 21-year old Meredith Kercher during what prosecutors said was a sex-game gone wrong. Mr. Guede had been sentenced to a 30-year term, reduced to 16 on appeal. The other defendants, Amanda Knox, a Seattle college student, and Raffaele Sollecito, her former Italian boyfriend, are appealing prison sentences of 26 and 25 years respectively. Mr. Guedes lawyer, Walter Biscotti, said he was disappointed with the outcome of the trial. We did everything that we could, he said.

title: Running in Place
description: For Damon, the white South African protagonist of In a Strange Room, travel is a mostly pleasureless compulsion. In each of the three linked stories that make up this novel, he moves from place to place and country to country in acute anxiety, like a fever running its course. He is fleeing something  a romantic disappointment is mentioned in the first story, and hints of post-apartheid moral exhaustion pervade all three. Yet what he experiences over the course of his travels is not the fools paradise of distraction from himself but just the opposite: the steady revelation of a central aspect of his character. By the third story, in which he travels to India with a mentally ill friend who comes apart disastrously, some immense, sad reality of life seems to be asserting itself through Damons quest to keep himself moving, long past any hope that his travels will heal him. Written in spare, controlled prose, these stories have a powerful cumulative effect that is on one level hard and comfortless, yet somehow also tender and humane.

title: Paperback Row
description: ARTHUR MILLER: 1915-1962,  by Christopher Bigsby. (Harvard University, $19.95.) Tapping previously unseen material, Bigsby situates the great American playwright (1915-2005) in the political and social battles of his times, lavishing nearly 700 pages on his early work and greatest triumphs  including the towering drama Death of a Salesman.

title: Bush on Bush
description: They call themselves, smugly, 41 and 43, meaning the 41st and 43rd presidents of the United States. Youre supposed to prefer the father, all graciousness and handwritten little notes, over the son, who  even in memoirs written at age 64 after two terms as president  seems callow. But I would take George W. Bushs schoolboy petulance and solipsism, which at least seem authentic and human, over George H. W.s grandee-with-a-switchblade any day. There is something very modern, almost New Agey, and endearingly insecure, about the tone and posture the son adopts in Decision Points. Even as hes bombing Baghdad back to the Stone Age, hes very much in touch with his feelings. In college, he says, he was appalled to learn how the French Revolution betrayed its ideals.

title: The Solitary Life
description: In one of his notebooks from 1820, Giacomo Leopardi, the greatest Italian poet of the 19th century, wrote that it is not enough to understand a true proposition; one must also feel the truth of it. Writers of the Romantic age are supposed to make such statements. Theirs was the era of the spontaneous overflow of powerful feelings and the holiness of the hearts affections. Coming from Leopardi, however, that credo can seem a little peculiar. Stunted by scoliosis, wearied from melancholy and badgered throughout his 38 years by his mother, a reactionary marchesa who stormed around the family palazzo in her riding boots, Leopardi was never an adventurer of felt experience. He spent most of his life confined by his parents to their home in the provincial hill town of Recanati, nestled above the Adriatic Sea.

title: The Patriarch
description: Thomas Jefferson has often been described as an enigma. He was a slave owner who declared that all men are created equal. Despite insisting that he had no political ambition, he spent much of his life in politics. The third president of the United States, he saw himself foremost as a farmer, gardener and philosopher. Jeffersons character was so multilayered and contradictory that successive generations have identified with and celebrated utterly different aspects of the same man. In a similar fashion, historians and biographers have studied various facets of his life  from the obvious, like his political thought, to the more obscure, like his love of wine. Now Virginia Scharff, a professor of history at the University of New Mexico, has sought to understand Jefferson through his relationships with the women he loved: his mother, Jane Randolph; his wife, Martha; his daughters and granddaughters; and his slave mistress, Sally Hemings.

Its a fitting coda to an enchantingly sincere romance about two people in love, or perhaps not quite, who sometimes break into song and dance. Mr. Chazelle, born in 1985, wears his nostalgic influences lightly, including John Cassavetes and the French New Wave, and has said that film was the only way to go for the story and aesthetic he was aiming for. I bet he also collects vinyl.

We didnt see her again until the meal was over; we found her in the kitchen surrounded by the restaurants entire staff. At our hotel, she was instantly scooped up by a grinning receptionist who carried her outside and paraded her up and down the street, introducing her to everyone who lived along that narrow alleyway. In a teeming market in the old Chinese district of Cholon, a small mob flocked around us, hands outstretched to hold her.

CBSs reruns of CSI (9.2 million) and The Mentalist (10.1 million) followed at 9 and 10 and easily led their time slots. description: Karen Manley, the daughter of June E. Manley and Michael W. Manley of Garden City, N.Y., was married there Saturday to Edward M. Eng, a son of Kathleen Eng and Sidney Eng, also of Garden City. Msgr. Brian J. McNamara performed the ceremony at St. Joseph Church.

title: Anne Ferrara, C.J. Papa
description: Dr. Anne Marie Ferrara and C. J. Papa are to be married Sunday evening at the New York Athletic Club. William J. Corbett, a retired village justice of Floral Park, N.Y., is to officiate.

title: Nicola DeAntonio, Anthony Casale Jr.
description: Nicola Marie DeAntonio and Anthony J. Casale Jr. were married Saturday by the Rev. Leo Murray at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Washington.

title: Lauren Cormier, Barrie Taylor
description: Lauren Elyse Cormier, a daughter of Eileen Ahmed Cormier and Raymond G. Cormier of Yorktown Heights, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Barrie Stuart Taylor, the son of Dr. Susan Barrie Taylor and Dr. David D. Taylor of Newbridge, Scotland. Joseph A. DiSalvo, a village justice of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., officiated at the home of the brides parents.

title: Alexandra Chan, Jack Katz
description: Dr. Alexandra Lei Chan and Dr. Jack Harvey Katz were married Saturday evening at Bernards, a restaurant in Ridgefield, Conn. Dominic DAddario, a Connecticut justice of the peace, officiated, with his wife, Mary DAddario, also a Connecticut justice of the peace, taking part.

title: Joanna Dee, Koushik Das
description: Joanna Dean Dee, the daughter of Susan D. Dee and Jeffrey E. Dee of St. Louis, was married Saturday to Dr. Koushik Kumar Das, the son of Dr. Kamala Das and Dr. Kiron M. Das of Basking Ridge, N.J. Gnana Skandan, a Hindu priest, officiated at the Doubletree Hotel in Somerset, N.J.

title: Elizabeth Christensen, Joshua Foster
description: Elizabeth Maddy Christensen and Joshua Daniel Foster were married Friday morning at the Brooklyn Museum of Art. Arnold L. Lehman, the museums director and a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: The Man Who Hated Christmas
description: BOB liked to say how much he hated Christmas. This amazed me and my sister. Wed look at each other: How could anyone hate Christmas? But hed say it again and again: Bess, I hate Christmas. He had a variation on this: Bess, I hate Christmas trees. Hed shake his head thoughtfully and chuckle: Theyre nothing but trouble. You struggle with them and fight over them and then they die and drop needles everywhere and you have to drag them out on the street.

title: Egg, Spinach and, Always, BlackBerry
description: Rarely is Sunday a full day of leisure for Christine C. Quinn, 44, the BlackBerry-addicted speaker of the City Council, who lives in Chelsea. She and her partner,  Kim M. Catullo, 44, a corporate lawyer, may go out to breakfast or for a walk with their dog, Sadie, a shar-pei and Labrador retriever mix. But even on the street, the job does not stop.

title: Twigs and Trains, Illegal Spaces and Chocolate Babka
description: THERE is still time (through Jan. 9) to catch the 19th annual Holiday Train Show at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx. But if you cannot make it, or want to see it later in the year, theres a new picture book titled, appropriately enough, (New York Botanical Garden, $14.95).

title: Conversation Across Centuries With the Father of All Bloggers
description: Sure, you could turn to self-help celebrities like Marianne Williamson or Joel Osteen for advice on how to live. But Sarah Bakewell, an author and part-time cataloger of rare books at the National Trust in London, decided to reach much further back than the best-seller list to the 16th-century nobleman, wine grower and essayist Michel Eyquem de Montaigne.

title: Another Legal Twist In Ansel Adams Case
description: The legal dispute between a California man who says a box of glass-plate negatives he bought at a garage sale are the work of Ansel Adams and the famed photographers trust has entered a new phase.

title: Chronicle of a Changing City
description: MR. FIGAROS barber shop has been a mainstay of Avenue Z in Brooklyn since it was opened in 1977 by Jerry May, the singing barber. Mr. May always drew a crowd as he clipped and crooned imitations of Pavarotti, Jolson, Sinatra and others.

title: Giants OHara, Leading in Pro Bowl Voting, Plans to Play Sunday
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Shaun OHara of the Giants is leading the National Football Conference in fan votes to play center in the Pro Bowl. But he has played only four games.

title: Best Buy Feels the Pressure of Rivals on the Web
description: At barely 10 a.m., holiday shopping was in full swing at a Best Buy on the Upper West Side. A harried father searched for a new Xbox for his children. A personal assistant picked up video game accessories for her bosss twins. One young woman fiddled with a coffeemaker, while another paid for a DVD player.

title: Beneath the Dead Sea, Scientists Are Drilling for Natural History
description: EIN GEDI, Israel  Five miles out, nearly to the center of the Dead Sea, an international team of scientists has been drilling beneath the seabed to extract a record of climate change and earthquake history stretching back half a million years.

title: One Suit, Many Kringles? Not in Santaland
description: The sun had barely committed to its Saturday morning rounds when the people in the plush red suits began dotting the streets of New York.

title: The Tailor Draws a Line
description: Dec. 18, 1860Sometimes a single speech alters the atmosphere, like a bolt of lightning before a rainstorm. One thinks of Barack Obamas oration at the 2004 Democratic convention, which propelled an obscure Illinois state senator into the political stratosphere. Or Ronald Reagans speech at the 1964 G.O.P. convention, which anointed a former actor and T.V. pitchman as the messiah of the conservative movement. Or Lincolns Cooper Union address, which conferred national status upon a mostly failed regional politician.

title: Explaining the Crisis With Dogma
description: What was that about?

title: A Catholic School Meets a Challenge
description: When Eric Ostrow was hired last year to teach drama at Xavier High School in Manhattan, as a newcomer he chose two impeccably innocuous shows for student productions. The first was a comedy, Epic Proportions, and then came the musical Grease, with its script scrubbed of profanity and one characters unwed pregnancy papered over in euphemisms.

title: After Injury, Receiver Told Rodgers to Stay Out
description: Donald Driver saw it in the eyes of Aaron Rodgers. Rodgers, Green Bays quarterback, was not quite right after taking hard hits on back-to-back plays and sustaining his second concussion of the season against the Lions last week, but he still wanted to go back into the game.

title: Fate of Arms Treaty Tied to Policy on Gays
description: WASHINGTON  Vexed and cornered, Republican opponents of the advancing effort to allow gay men and lesbians to serve openly in the military pulled out a final card Friday, suggesting that the future of an arms treaty with Russia was endangered by Democratic efforts to repeal dont ask dont tell at the end of the lame-duck session.

title: U.S. Official Expresses Confidence in Pakistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Hoping to reassure Afghans about cross-border attacks, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff said Friday that it was very possible that Pakistan would be able to root out insurgents from havens inside its territory that serve as a launching point for lethal strikes in Afghanistan.

title: Mexican Leaders Crime Effort Fails to Advance
description: MEXICO CITY  President Felipe Calderns effort to reorganize local police forces and clamp down on money laundering in the fight against organized crime has suffered a setback with the failure of the Mexican Congress to move forward on the initiatives.

title: Judge Says Case Against Immigration Officials in New Haven Raids Can Proceed
description: A federal judge ruled late Thursday that the former chief of the Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency and other senior officials could be held liable in a lawsuit claiming that federal officers violated the constitutional rights of suspected illegal immigrants arrested in predawn raids three years ago in New Haven.

title: Santa via Cellphone: Shopping Online Without a Computer
description: This holiday season, consumers are beginning to shop and make purchases on their mobile phones. The shift from buying presents in front of the computer at home or work to doing it during bus commutes or while standing in line at cafes is small, but, for the first time, noticeable and even significant.

title: Newly Built Ghost Towns Haunt Banks in Spain
description: YEBES, Spain  It is a measure of Spains giddy construction excesses that 250 row houses carpet a hill near this tiny rural village about an hour by car outside of Madrid.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Dec. 17
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: Can Airports Be Fun?
description: Few who fly  or fly coach, anyway  would disagree that the entire experience of air travel from check-in to landing carries with it an overwhelming sense that everyone involved has simply given up. Watch people as they enter airports: shoulders rise, expressions grow steely, civility erodes. Things that shouldnt be a big deal  learning that youll have an on-time departure or receiving a free bag of potato chips  feel like winning lottery tickets, so low have our expectations become.

title: Brooklyns Allure? Fancy Cakes, Dahling
description: FLOWERS are blooming in the dead of winter on the fringes of Brooklyn. Inside Lindsey Gambles bakery, an out-of-the-way, nearly hidden storefront at President and Columbia Streets near the waterfront, butter cream tiers and gum paste orchids climb high. A pile of blue fondant Tiffany boxes seems to tip precariously beside an edible high-heel shoe and diamond ring. Sweet, golden watch parts are about to be placed on a giant Alice in Wonderland cupcake.

title: Two States Sue Bank of America Over Mortgages
description: The attorneys general of Arizona and Nevada on Friday filed a lawsuit against Bank of America, accusing it of engaging in widespread fraud by misleading customers with false promises about their eligibility for modifications on their home mortgages.

title: Laid-Off OTB Employees Face the Future Apprehensively
description: The ceiling of the union hall was festooned for the holidays with red and green streamers, but a gloom hung over the room on Friday morning as a few hundred former employees of the New York City Off-Track Betting Corporation trudged in.

title: Vilified by Fans, but Exiting Victorious
description: LeBron James finally arrived at Madison Square Garden on Friday, 51 days and 26 games later than expected. For this, he was greeted with boos instead of cheers, an interrogation instead of fawning questions and several insulting newspaper illustrations.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Dec. 17
description: More Photographs

title: Much to Worry About, but Mostly, a Son She Outlived
description: Arleen Griffith owes $1,500 in back taxes, wages a daily war against addiction and has asthma, emphysema and sarcoidosis, a potentially deadly inflammation of the organs.

title: How Not to Wreck a Nonstick Pan
description: THIS all began when I was trying to come up with a clever idea for a Hanukkah present for my older son. Having exhausted all the sports-themed possibilities, I decided to buy him a griddle since he has become quite the pancake chef.

title: Tests Detect Alzheimers Risks, but Should Patients Be Told?
description: Marjie Popkin thought she had chemo brain, that fuzzy-headed forgetful state that she figured was a result of her treatment for ovarian cancer. She was not thinking clearly  having trouble with numbers, forgetting things she had just heard.

title: Death of an Omnibus
description: It was big: 1,900 pages. It was expensive: $1.2 trillion. And it was loaded with Washingtons favorite  white meat: more than 6,000 earmarks. But on Thursday night, it went the way of the rest of the dinosaurs: The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, said Thursday night that he was abandoning efforts to pass a $1.2 trillion spending measure to finance the government through Sept. 30 because Republicans would not support it, reported The Timess David M. Herszenhorn. Mr. Reid said he would work with the Republican leader, Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, on a stop-gap spending bill instead. Senate Republicans also said they would not support a House-passed temporary spending measure running through the end of the fiscal year on Sept. 30. Instead, they want to develop a separate measure running only through the early part of next year.

title: A Monsignor Is Defrocked for Abusing a Student
description: A once-influential Roman Catholic monsignor who oversaw fund-raising for the Archdiocese of New York, running the annual Alfred E. Smith political dinner during the tenure of Cardinal John J. OConnor, has been removed from the priesthood after an eight-year church review of sexual abuse accusations against him, the archdiocese announced on Friday.

title: Tug of First Baseball Home Returns Wood to Cubs
description: On Dec. 10, Kerry Wood and his wife, Sarah, attended the funeral for Ron Santo in Chicago. The extended Cubs family said goodbye to a man who devoted his life to the long-suffering team, but the event helped bring Wood back home.

title: Dreaming of a Feinstein Christmas, Just Like the Ones We Used to Know
description: Each December they gather in a room on Park Avenue at 61st Street, huddled into booths and at low tables with chilling Champagne bottles. Some are stars of bygone eras  recently, Joan Collins, Celeste Holm and Florence Henderson were tucked into banquettes at the back of the room. Some are not, like Cynthia Wilson, an awe-struck, gray-haired woman from England who traveled to America expressly to sit in that room for five nights.

title: City Critic: Finding the Real Santa
description: The City Critic meets the one and only real Santa Claus. He lives in a department store.

title: White House Issues Long-Delayed Science Guidelines
description: The Obama administration issued long-awaited, long-delayed guidelines on Friday to insulate government scientific research from political meddling and to base policy decisions on solid data.

title: Mexican Police Drone Plane Crashes Near El Paso Home
description: HOUSTON  A small unmanned plane belonging to the Mexican federal police crashed in a residential neighborhood in El Paso this week, but no one was injured and the drone was quickly returned to the Mexican government, officials from both governments said Friday.

title: The Postman Always Pings Twice
description: Washington

title: Size Protects Government Contractors That Stray
description: WASHINGTON  Weeks into the largest oil spill in American history, government officials met in Washington to discuss ways to compel BP, which leased the drilling rig, to move faster in stopping the spill.

title: With New Tax Bill, a Turning Point for the President
description: WASHINGTON  With the stroke of a pen, President Obama on Friday enacted the largest tax cut in nearly a decade and, in the process, took a big step toward reinventing himself as a champion of compromise in a politically fractured capital.

title: French Vogues Top Editor to Leave at End of January
description: Carine Roitfeld, the sharp-boned, high-heeled stylist who turned French Vogue into a vehicle for profits and glamour, startled the fashion world on Friday by saying she would step down as editor in chief of the magazine.

title: Republicans Prepare for Looming Budget Battle
description: WASHINGTON  The collapse of a government-wide spending package in the final days of this Congressional session sets up a politically charged fiscal showdown early next year, testing the determination of Republicans about to take over the House with promises to slash an array of domestic programs.

title: Leaving for Hawaii, Sans One Obama
description: WASHINGTON  At least some Obamas will be leaving for Hawaii on Saturday.

title: Lottery Numbers
Surging Rangers Face a Stern Test in the First-Place Flyers
description: Rangers Coach John Tortorella is known for his slow burns, but he is a happy man these days. He felt especially good Thursday afternoon, the day after his team rallied for four unanswered goals in the last 10 minutes in Pittsburgh to beat Sidney Crosby and the Penguins, 4-1.

title: Christie Picks Klein Ally for New Jersey Schools
description: Gov. Chris Christie has selected as New Jerseys education commissioner a nationally known school administrator who drove some of New York Citys most controversial education policies, a move that signals the governors continued intent to upend the educational establishment and put his stamp on the states schools.

title: Economic Boom in Washington Leaves Gaping Income Disparities
description: WASHINGTON  As incomes fell across America over the past decade, new census data show that one place registered a remarkable rise: the nations capital.

title: Ex-Detainee Wants Judge to Dismiss Conviction on Single Count in Bombings
description: Lawyers for Ahmed Khalfan Ghailani, the former Guantnamo detainee who was acquitted of more than 280 counts of murder and conspiracy last month in a terrorism trial in Manhattan, asked the trial judge on Friday to dismiss the sole count on which he was convicted.

title: China: 2 Seamen Rescued, but 25 Are Still Missing
description: Two seamen cast overboard when a Vietnamese cargo ship sank in waters between China and Vietnam were rescued Friday, although 25 others remain missing, the Chinese media reported. According to the Xinhua news agency, a Chinese maritime rescue team found the two men in the South China Sea more than 30 miles from where the vessel sank Thursday in what Vietnamese officials described as gale-force winds. The ship, Phu Tan, was traveling between two Vietnamese ports when it capsized in rough seas about 115 miles off the coast of Hainan Island, China.

title: Haiti: Cholera Vaccine Pilot Program Recommended
description: There is enough approved cholera vaccine stockpiled in the world to vaccinate only 50,000 people, a panel of cholera experts convened by the Pan American Health Organization said Friday. Given the shortage, the panel recommended starting a pilot program in Haiti to test vaccination strategies and waiting for more vaccine to be made. A second manufacturer may be approved by the World Health Organization within six months, making it eventually possible to produce one million doses a year. About 110,000 Haitians are known to have had cholera since the outbreak began in October; 2,405 have died.

title: The Gingrich Who Stole Christmas
description: The calendar is collapsing. Only a week until Christmas! Only a month until the beginning of the presidential election!

title: Garden Ticket Sales Strong for UConns Bid to Tie Longest Streak
description: Madison Square Garden has hosted its share of big events, from the Ali-Frazier fights to championships for the Knicks and the Rangers. On Sunday, another momentous one could be added to the list when the University of Connecticuts womens basketball team tries to tie the N.C.A.A. Division I record for most consecutive wins.

title: Unease Grows About Future of Financing for Pell Grants
description: With the lame-duck Congress winding down and a $5.7 billion gap in financing looming for next years Pell grants  and a further $8 billion gap for the following year  there is growing uncertainty about the future of the grants, the nations most significant financial-aid program for college students.

title: New York Flop Becomes a Hit Everywhere Else
description: It closed a month after it opened Off Broadway. Entertainment Weekly selected it as one of the worst shows of 2006. Most New Yorkers dont even remember it. Yet John Carianis Almost, Maine, an earnest 19-character play about the romantic happenings one cold night in northern Maine, has since been produced around the world, including in Australia, Dubai and South Korea. A Spanish-language version will be presented this spring in Mexico City. More than 600 companies, amateur and professional, have put it on in the United States and Canada.

title: Saturday: Kingly Reagle
description: Please welcome Merl Reagle into the guest-solving chair of distinction. Hes a one-man crossword syndicate, with his clever Sunday puzzles appearing weekly in The San Francisco Chronicle, The Washington Post, The Los Angeles Times and many others. He was a star of the movie Wordplay and appeared (nearly human-colored) in an episode of The Simpsons.

title: Whose Party Is It?
description: The far left is foaming at the mouth.

title: Games vs. Governing
description: The Senate still has two major tasks ahead in the remaining days of the lame-duck session: allowing open military service by gay and lesbian soldiers and ratifying the vital New Start nuclear arms treaty with Russia. In both cases, approval will have to come from a solid majority of Democrats and a handful of Republicans who are willing to set aside destructive partisanship.

title: Walter Haeussermann, Rocket Scientist, Dies at 96
description: Walter Haeussermann, a leading member of the team of German rocket scientists headed by Wernher von Braun who were brought to the United States after World War II to help develop ballistic missiles, died on Dec. 8 in Huntsville, Ala. He was 96.

title: Turn In Your Bin Ladens
description: THE 500-euro note is sometimes called the Bin Laden  after all, Europeans may never see the 500 euro, but they know it is out there somewhere. Unfortunately, Al Qaedas leader and the 500-euro bill are connected in another way: high-denomination bills make it a lot easier for terrorists to operate.

title: The World This Week
description: A look back at the big news stories of the week.

title: Protecting the Internet
description: The intensely competitive nature of the Internet is vital to the American economy and democracy. So we worry that rules proposed this month by Julius Genachowski, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, to guarantee the Internets openness may not be able to guarantee the survival of that competition.

title: Cholera and Haiti
description: With a cholera epidemic raging in Haiti, the United Nations recently issued an urgent appeal for $174 million to provide clean water, sanitation, food and medical treatment. As of this week, it had raised 25 percent of it.

title: After Bumpy Year, Woods Takes Back Seat to Youth
description: Has the PGA Tour really decided to de-emphasize Tiger Woods in its promotional materials and switch the focus to the emerging group of strong young players going into 2011? If the first FedEx Cup promotional piece of the new year and remarks by the PGA Tour commissioner are any indicators, the answer is yes.

title: Things Are Coming Together
description: Brenda Vigna is generous, even when there is not much to give. A single mother of four living in a trailer park, she adopted her daughters pregnant classmate out of foster care in 2008.

title: Sharing Stories of a Man Who Loved Big Challenges
description: There were tears and laughter and embraces as the crowd began to build Friday night in the Manhattan apartment of Richard C. Holbrooke at a private memorial gathering for the diplomat they remembered as a boss, a source and a friend.

title: Photo Replay: Heat 113, Knicks 91
description: LeBron James makes his first trip to Madison Square Garden since passing on the Knicks to play in Miami.

title: Bloggingheads:  Giving Diplomats Respect
description: Matthew Yglesias, right, of the Center for American Progress and Daniel Drezner of ForeignPolicy.com discuss the militarization of foreign policy.

title: Photo Replay: Dec. 17
description: A look at the day in sports from a high school championship football game in Pennsylvania to a World Cup skiing event in Val Gardena, Italy.

title: Corrections
description: NEW YORK

title: Venice in Winter: Photos
description: To the Editor: Anyone looking to see more of Venice in Winter (Nov. 28) may have far to look. Bookshelves are crowded with volumes featuring Venice in garish summer finery, or of people wearing masks during Carnival, or of the colorful stucco buildings on Burano. Note: the operative word is color. For those seeking the beautifully atmospheric Venice of mists and shadows, precious few books pertain. These, however, succeed marvelously.

title: Fowler vs. McIlroy, Via Twitter
description: A trans-Atlantic Twitter tempest helped enliven the off-season when Lee Westwood, the worlds new No. 1 player, tweeted about PGA Tour players voting one of their own  Rickie Fowler  as the tour rookie of the year over Rory McIlroy, the 21-year-old from Northern Ireland.

title: Los Angeles: Deluge of Calls in Grim Sleeper Case
description: The Los Angeles Police Department was inundated with phone calls Friday within 24 hours of the release of photographs of women that had been found in the home of the suspected Grim Sleeper serial killer. Hundreds of people claimed to recognize women from the photographs as relatives or friends who were missing or dead, while others claimed to be in the photographs themselves, according to a police official. Lonnie David Franklin Jr. is accused of killing 10 black women between 1985 and 2007. The police released the photographs because they suspected some of the women pictured were his victims as well. Though five people have been tentatively identified, detectives plan to conduct interviews with callers before positively identifying any, according to Mary Grady, a police spokeswoman.

title: The Weekend Word: A Senate Saturday
description: From Todays Times:

title: Rex Ryan Denies Billicks Accusation
description: On Friday, Rex Ryan denied that he had any knowledge of his teamssideline shenanigans and said that Brian Billick should have talked with him first before making such an accusation.A few highlights of Rex Speak:

title: Pakistan Says It Didnt Tell Spys Identity
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  An official of the Directorate for Inter-Services Intelligence, Pakistans top spy organization, angrily denied Saturday that it was responsible for revealing the name of the Central Intelligence Agencys top clandestine officer in Pakistan.

title: The Case for Benching McNabb and Starting Grossman
description: Its hard to advocate that Rex Grossman should be the Redskins starter. (You wont get me to do it.)

title: Urban Forager | Earthy, Crunchy Burdock
description: Foraging in winter has its obvious challenges  freezing temperatures, dying flora, and scarce edible greens save for hardy garlic mustard and field garlic. But even in the hard frost-bitten ground, its still possible to find wild burdock poking its gigantic leaves out from the remnants of fall foliage, reminding us of root-vegetable deliciousness underfoot.

title: The Different Costs of Motherhood
description: Outright sexism is obviously still a part of the workplace today, but its also vastly reduced. The pay gap between men and women of identical qualifications, experience, work hours and career choice has shrunk greatly in the last few decades. Some researchers believe it is now close to zero  not zero, though not far from it.

title: A Fake vs. a Real Tree
description: In these eco-conscious times, many people want to shrink their environmental footprint while still enjoying the trappings of the holiday season. In some cases, the earth-friendly alternative  pass the tofurky  is a pretty obvious choice.

title: Richard Holbrooke, Thirsting for a Role in History
description: LONDON  It was the worst of times in the siege of Sarajevo. No venture outside the Holiday Inn, which had become a media fastness in a city under siege, was safe from the daily staccato of sniper fire, mortars and artillery shells. And there at my door, in the first winter of the war, was Richard C. Holbrooke, asking if he could borrow space on my floor for him and his sleeping bag.

title: Cards? Flowers? In Senate, a Real Pal Objects
description: Senator Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, announced this week that he has early-stage prostate cancer and will be undergoing surgery on Monday. And it is hardly a surprise that Mr. Wyden, who is known for working across the aisle on complicated issues, has received an outpouring of support from his colleagues.

title: The Supreme Court and Obamas Health Care Law
description: When it comes to the future of the Obama administrations health care plan, the judicial math can seem simple.

title: Back Then: 2007
description: Larry King ended his run as the 9 p.m. fixture on CNN last week. Between his radio career and his stint on television, he did about 50,000 interviews. When Jacques Steinberg of The Times visited him in Beverly Hills in 2007, he had recently undergone a procedure for a clogged artery.

title: Suggesting Activities for Shaq in Boston
description: Celtics center Shaquille ONeal has always been a man of many interests. He has rapped, acted, trained with SWAT teams and engaged in amateur philosophy during his many career stops.

title: The Teary, Busy, Ugly Lame-Duck Congress
description: WASHINGTON  There were moments last week when official Washington seemed to careen out of control. Emotions were raw. Plans were in flux. People were on edge.

title: Prime Number
description: 100,000: The approximate number of Cuban cigars seized over a recent two-week period by customs officials at Chicago OHare International Airport, The Associated Press reported last week. Customs officials usually confiscate about 2,000 Cuban cigars over two weeks. But tighter security and new restrictions on air cargo parcels have sent seizures soaring. And what of the cigars? The United States Customs and Border Protection plans to destroy them.

title: Ivory Coast President Orders U.N. to Leave
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast  The president of Ivory Coast ordered United Nations and French peacekeepers to leave the country immediately on Saturday, hours after men in military uniforms fired on a United Nations patrol.

title: Springtime for Hypocrites
description: It has been a great week on the hypocrisy front. A couple of high points:

title: Senate Blocks Bill for Young Illegal Immigrants
description: The Senate on Saturday blocked a bill that would have created a path to citizenship for certain young illegal immigrants who came to the United States as children, completed two years of college or military service and met other requirements, including passing a criminal background check.

title: Senate Repeals Ban Against Openly Gay Military Personnel
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Saturday struck down the ban on gay men and lesbians serving openly in the military, bringing to a close a 17-year struggle over a policy that forced thousands of Americans from the ranks and caused others to keep secret their sexual orientation.

title: Acrostic: Like Mouflons
description: For those who werent able to get the free version of last weekends Puns and Anagrams puzzle, download it by clicking here.

title: When Children Are Caught in the Cycle of Poverty
description: The economic collapse has taken a toll on vast segments of society, but it has affected some groups disproportionately. Among those are children.

title: Bomb Kills 2 Afghans in Attack in Kandahar
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  A suicide car bomb exploded Saturday on the outskirts of Kandahar City, killing two civilians and wounding 11 more, including seven children, Afghan officials said. But the bombers target, a district governor, escaped unharmed.

title: Parliament Vote Puts Iraq Closer to a New Government
description: BAGHDAD  Iraq moved one step closer to finally forming a government on Saturday as lawmakers overturned a contentious decision barring three prominent Sunni Arabs from national politics.

title: Judges Reinstate Travel Ban for Kosovo Ex-Leader
description: PARIS  A former prime minister of Kosovo awaiting trial in The Hague has been told he cannot be given temporary release from prison and return home because his presence there could increase threats to witnesses who have agreed to testify against him.

title: For a Father and Three Sons, Sharing the Role of Caretaker
description: Alan Garcia, 15, sat on a bench while his classmates played basketball. The other students might have thought he was too lazy or too shy to play. The truth was simpler: His family was too poor. Alans father could not afford to buy him a pair of sneakers for gym class.

title: At Camp, a Haven From Troubles
description: Things you do at camp are between you and the people who went to camp.

title: After the Death of Her Mother, Grief and Fear
description: Her hands are stuck in a fist. She cant balance when she walks. When shes mad she starts throwing things, banging on tables and doors and walls. She cant really speak.

title: Flyers Show Discipline
description: The Philadelphia Flyers grabbed first place over all in the N.H.L. last week, unseating rival Pittsburgh and ending the Penguins 12-game winning streak. While the Penguins run attracted attention, the Flyers went 8-1-3 at the same time and have continued winning. They went into Saturdays game against the Rangers having lost only 3 of their previous 25 games in regulation.

title: Take Coyotes Off List of Teams Likely to Move
description: The Phoenix Coyotes seem set to stay in Glendale, Ariz., after last Tuesdays approval by the Glendale City Council to pay $197 million to keep the financially troubled team at Jobing.com Arena.

title: Opening the Bag of Mortgage Tricks

title: Imax Ticket Sales Lift Tron: Legacy

Tron: Legacy, a $170 million sequel starring Jeff Bridges (above) and backed by a three-year marketing campaign, was No. 1 for Walt Disney Studios with an estimated $43.6 million in sales. Imax sales contributed 24 percent of that gross, indicating strong interest from core science-fiction fans; the question now is whether Disney can keep the momentum going over the Christmas holiday period and reach a wider audience. Yogi Bear (Warner Brothers) was second with $16.7 million, an underwhelming total considering this picture had the benefit of higher-priced 3-D screenings. The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader (20th Century Fox) was third with about $12.4 million for a two-week total of $42.8 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office statistics. In its first weekend in wide release The Fighter (Paramount Pictures and Relativity Media) was fourth with $12.4 million, a strong result for a gritty adult drama that cost $25 million to make. The Tourist (Sony Pictures Entertainment and GK Films) was fifth with $8.7 million for a two-week total of $30.8 million. Sonys romantic comedy How Do You Know, directed by James L. Brooks for over $100 million as a vehicle for Ms. Witherspoon, sold $7.6 million in tickets. Fox Searchlights Black Swan, starring Natalie Portman, performed better despite playing in 959 theaters compared with 2,483 for How Do You Know. The weekend total for Black Swan was about $8.3 million.

title: Ozawas Children Accept Award for Him
description: The confluence was almost perfect. The Japanese conductor Seiji Ozawa was to receive the Shigemitsu Award for distinction in international cultural affairs after his Carnegie Hall concert with the Saito Kinen Orchestra on Saturday evening. The award, established a decade ago to honor Mamoru Shigemitsu, the Japanese foreign minister who engineered his countrys entry into the United Nations in 1956, is presented annually on Dec. 18, the anniversary of that event. Peter Grilli, the president of the Japan Society of Boston, won the award last year, and when the society subsequently took over administration of the award, he determined that Mr. Ozawa would become the first Japanese winner. What he didnt realize at the time was that on the very evening of the award presentation, Mr. Ozawa would be conducting Benjamin Brittens great internationalist creation, the War Requiem. In the words of the societys news release, the work echoes the antiwar sentiments of Foreign Minister Shigemitsus General Assembly speech as Japan was inducted into the United Nations. But as it happened, the performance of this imposing work left Mr. Ozawa  suffering from sciatica and still depleted after surgery for esophageal cancer early this year  exhausted and unable to attend the presentation at a postconcert party for the performers at a restaurant near Carnegie. Instead Mr. Grilli  in the presence of Yutaka Shigemitsu, a 92-year-old nephew of the foreign minister, who founded the award  presented the award to Mr. Ozawas daughter, Seira, and son, Yuki.

title: Adding Another Layer to War Requiem Story

To drive the point home in the first performance Britten wanted vocal soloists from Britain (Peter Pears), Germany (Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau) and the Soviet Union (Galina Vishnevskaya, who, barred from traveling to England, had to be replaced by the British soprano Heather Harper).

title: A Pop-Up Larder in Echo Park
description: For 10 days this month, a group of enterprising young women converted a carriage house in Los Angeless Echo Park neighborhood into a larder that they called the Cantry. They christened themselves the Pantlers  after the name given to the servant in charge of the bread and the pantry of a great house  built shelves and lined them with an assortment of canned and pickled goods, tinctures and creams, and drawings and zines. Small jars containing tea lights and flowers were tied to bicycle wheels suspended from the ceiling, becoming clever D.I.Y. chandeliers to light the long refectory-style table made by a woodworker friend. Through word of mouth and Facebook posts, people came to trade and barter their own wares for ginger beer, pomegranate jelly, bacon-infused bourbon, pie fillings and sundry items. A neighbor even offered to trade music for goods. Every night a guest chef cooked a family-style dinner while D.J. friends spun tunes and recipes were shared. The Pantlers are all makers, obsessed with food, gardening and doing things for themselves, and had talked about sharing their kitchen, home lab and garden experiments for over a year before opening the Cantry. If you missed the Pantlers in Echo Park, visit their online trading post and watch for news of the next pop-up larder.
