description: If youre disappointed that 2011 wont offer enough opportunities to see Mark Rylance on Broadway when La Bte wraps up its run on Jan. 9, you wont have to be without him for very long: hell return next year in Jerusalem when that Jez Butterworth play transfers to Broadway in the spring, making good on Mr. Rylances vow in November that it would do so.

title: Zombiegenesis: A Better Picture
description: Actually, this might be a better picture for making the point about how rightists used the temporary bulge in Census hiring to spread the false impression of soaring government employment:

title: Did Anyone See a Naked Lion?
Skype Looks for a Spot in Offices and Cellphones
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Skype has become one of the Internets most popular services  so much so that it is even used as a verb to describe a phone call over the Internet, as in Skype me.

title: Giants Future Depends on Getting Past Collapse
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. A day after collapsing in a 38-31 loss to the Philadelphia Eagles, the Giants were sifting through the wreckage of the demoralizing defeat Monday at their practice facility.

title: Stalin Rose From Czarist Oppression to Transform Russia Into Mighty Socialist State
description: Joseph Stalin became the most important figure in the political direction of one-third of the people of the world. He was one of a group of hard revolutionaries that established the first important Marxist state and, as its dictator, he carried forward its socialization and industrialization with vigor and ruthlessness.

title: JETLINER CARRYING 258 TO U.S CRASHES IN SCOTTISH TOWN
description: LONDON, Dec. 21 -- A Pan Am Boeing 747 on a flight from London to New York with 258 people aboard crashed tonight in a southern Scottish village, British military authorities reported. The airline said it knew of no survivors.

title: Augmented Reality on Your Phone
description: Over the weekend I used a new iPhone application, Word Lens, to perform magic tricks for anyone who would watch. Word Lens isnt really a magic app, but using it was kind of magical for me, almost like seeing Houdini perform in real life. The app is an augmented reality program that can translate text from English to Spanish, and the other way around, instantly through the iPhones camera.

title: Dame Peggy Ashcroft, Acclaimed British Actress, Is Dead at 83;
description: Dame Peggy Ashcroft, an actress who was in the forefront of British theater for more than half a century, died yesterday in London. She was 83 years old.

title: News Quiz | Farewell, 2010
description: Say goodbye to 2010 by taking our 25-question quiz. After you answer each question, click on the related resource to see a Times article, Times Topics page, blog post or graphic. (For a print version of the quiz, download this PDF.)

title: Looking Back at 2010: Teaching Ideas
description: Were suckers for end-of-the-year retrospectives, and for weeks now weve been collecting interesting examples, both from within The Times and from around the Web. Weve also written some puzzles, quizzes and questions of our own.

title: VOYAGER SUCCEEDS IN HISTORIC FLIGHT
description: EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Dec. 23 -- Sweeping out of a clear desert sky and into aviation history, the experimental airplane Voyager landed safely here early today, completing the first nonstop flight around the world on one load of fuel.

title: Wealthiest Negress Dead
description: Mrs. C. J. Walker, known as New York's wealthiest negress, having accumulated a fortune from the sale of so-called anti-kink hair tonic and from real estate investments in the last fourteen years, died yesterday morning at her country estate at Irvington-on-Hudson. She was proprietor of the Madame Walker hair dressing parlors at 108 West 136th Street and other places in the city. Her death recalled the unusual story of how she rose in twelve years from a washerwoman making only $1.50 a day to a position of wealth and influence among members of her race.

title: I.F. Stone, Iconoclast of Journalism, Is Dead at 81
description: I. F. Stone, the independent, radical pamphleteer of American journalism hailed by admirers for scholarship, wit and lucidity and denounced by critics for wrongheadedness and stubbornness, died of a heart attack yesterday in a Boston hospital. He was 81 years old and lived for many years in Washington.

title:
Bush Pardons 6 in Iran Affair, Aborting a
Weinberger Trial; Prosecutor Assails 'Cover-Up'
description: WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Six years after the arms-for-hostages scandal began to cast a shadow that would darken two Administrations, President Bush today granted full pardons to six former officials in Ronald Reagan's Administration, including former Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger.

title: Numberplay: Figuring It Out in Your Head
description: Weve had some puzzles involving pretty heavy calculations in recent weeks, like the analysis of the Newtons Cradle and the quickest probabilistic strategy for Paula the Octopus. The debates on both of these puzzles are still on, and they are not completely resolved. So I thought wed do some lighter stuff here today, involving tricks to doing mental calculations.

title: A Doctors Mammogram Mission Turns Personal
description: Dr. Marisa Weiss scheduled her mammogram this spring, just as she does every year. She had just turned 51, and after having annual scans for a decade, she knew what to expect: her dense breast tissue made reading the films difficult  like looking for a polar bear in a blizzard  and the technician would probably ask her to sit for a few extra views.

title: Anwar el-Sadat, the Daring Arab Pioneer of Peace with Israel
description: "Sadat! Sadat!" tens of thousands of Cairenes chanted at the grinning figure in the open limousine. ''Sadat! The man of peace!'' It was the night of Nov. 21, 1977. President Anwar el-Sadat had just returned from his epochal journey to Jerusalem. Egypt's people were giving their frenzied approval to what his trip had achieved - an Egyptian-Israeli thaw that set the stage for the peace treaty of 1979.

title:
Gorbachev, Last Soviet Leader,
Resigns; U.S. Recognizes Republics' Independence
description: MOSCOW, Dec. 25 -- Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the trailblazer of the Soviet Union's retreat from the cold war and the spark for the democratic reforms that ended 70 years of Communist tyranny, told a weary, anxious nation tonight that he was resigning as President and closing out the union.

title: What Were Reading
description: An aggregation of links by the reporters and editors of Diners Journal.

title: The Scents and Tastes of Home
description: Next week I am planning an update on some of the many people whose stories appeared on Motherlode during the year. (If anyone reading would like to send such an update, the address is belkin@nytimes.com)

title: Five Questions About a List About Movies About Theater
description: Christmas is a season of lists. Santa has one, of course. The New York Timess blogs have several, from T Magazines luxe wish list to the Carpetbaggers pre-Oscar list-o-mania to Paper Cuts book-o-rama.

title: Free Pines in the City, if You Know Where to Go
description: Lush green wreaths and garlands can cost a bundle in Manhattan at Christmastime, but regular users of the Hudson River bike path on the West Side of Manhattan have a better place to gather bounteous boughs by the sack-load for free near 96th Street in Riverside Park.

title: Basking in a Workouts Long, Mysterious Afterglow
description: Its a cold day and you have just finished a grueling session at the gym, sweating away on an elliptical cross-trainer. Or you had a tough workout in the swimming pool. Or in a spin class. Or you just finished a hard run or a long, fast bicycle ride.

title: The Post-Workout Bonus
description: After a vigorous run, ride or swim, the feeling of warmth in your body can linger for hours. But are you burning extra calories once the workout is over? Gina Kolata explores the aftereffects of exercise in todays Personal Best column.

title: Yves Saint Laurent: New Vintage III
description: Only YSL can make vintage as good as new. After the success of not one but two environmentally feel-good capsule collections, New Vintage, initiatedby YSLs creative director, Stefano Pilati, and Julie Gilhart, is having another go. New Vintage IIIs moxie is quite simple: reclaim, recycle and sustain. The collection is materially comprised of garments made from recycled fabric and from existing patterns instead of new ones, to start a dialogue with the market using known codes and a common language that are reassuring and familiar, says Pilati about the 180 pieces that will be available this week. Metallic wide leg trousers, velvet tuxedo suiting jackets and leopard-print wrap dresses with a hint of disco pay a refreshing nod to Saint Laurents iconic 1970s designs. Youll have a second chance to finally own that missed ready-to-wear piece, and no doubt appreciate the brands intelligent use and reuse of its existing resources.

title: Five Years In, Gauging Impact of Gates Grants
description: SEATTLE  Five years ago, Bill Gates made an extraordinary offer: he invited the worlds scientists to submit ideas for tackling the biggest problems in global health, including the lack of vaccines for AIDS and malaria, the fact that most vaccines must be kept refrigerated and be delivered by needles, the fact that many tropical crops like cassavas and bananas had little nutrition, and so on.

title: Tending to Your Eyes
description: Poor vision can lead to job loss, social difficulties and the pain and cost of falls and accidents. And though routine eye exams can help to detect the early signs of vision loss and prevent the progression of some eye diseases, few adults make their annual appointments, writes Jane Brody in this weeks Personal Health column.

title: In Africas Year, Etoo Is Continents Best
description: Samuel Etoo, the face of soccer in Africa, was named the continents player of the year Monday, the fourth time the Cameroon forward has won the award.

title: How a Torn Aorta Can Do Lethal Damage
description: The death of the veteran diplomat Richard C. Holbrooke last week shocked Americans and his many colleagues around the world. Mr. Holbrooke, 69, was a larger-than-life figure, a fearless and robust man who was apparently struck down without warning.

title: Through the Mill
description: Q. Is there a limit to how often paper can be recycled?

title: Sausage Pinwheels
description: 1 16-ounce roll Jimmy Dean pork sausage, preferably spicy1 8-ounce package Pillsbury Crescent Rolls.  1. Bring the sausage to room temperature. Using a rolling pin, roll the crescent dough into a rectangle, pinching together the perforations. Spread the sausage evenly on the dough, leaving a half-inch border.2. Roll up the dough lengthwise and pinch together the seam. Wrap in plastic wrap and refrigerate for at least 2 hours. 3. Preheat the oven to 400 degrees. 4. Slice the roll into -inch slices and place on a foil-lined pan sprayed with cooking spray. (Parchment paper may also be used; no spraying necessary.) Bake for 15-17 minutes or until browned. Serves 8. Recipe from Donna Meade Dean.

title: Pictures of the Day: Belarus and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Belarus, Afghanistan and South Korea.

title: Another Extension for Merchant of Venice on Broadway
description: Hath not a Jew eyes? Hath not a Jew hands? And hath not a Jew some much deserved time away from Broadway coming up? He does, but hed better keep it quick as The Merchant of Venice is extending again.

title: Iran Jails Leading Filmmaker for 6 Years
description: Updated | 5:03 p.m. Jafar Panahi, a celebrated Iranian filmmaker who was arrested in February and accused of working on an anti-regime film, was sentenced to six years in prison on Saturday in Tehran, his lawyer told an Iranian news agency on Monday.

title: Mini Unveils Paceman Concept Ahead of Detroit Auto Show
description: Mini revealed on Sunday its latest concept car, the Paceman: a two-door coupe based on the four-door Countryman model. Described by the company as a sports activity coupe, it will have its debut at the Detroit auto show in January.

title: London: Tuberculosis Cases Have Increased 50 Percent in Last Decade, Lancet Says
description: London is the tuberculosis capital of Western Europe, according to a recent article in the medical journal Lancet, which said that cases there increased 50 percent in the last decade.

title: F.C.C. Poised to Pass Net Neutrality Order
description: 6:42 p.m. | Updated  The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission appears to have the votes he needs to pass new rules for net neutrality.

title: More Critics Join The Social Network
description: All you folks who are tired of the year-end best-of lists  and commenters, we know who you are!  stop reading now, because there are yet more annual kudos to announce. The Social Network continues its sweep of critics, bloggers and other fans of procrastinating on Facebook, earning plaudits from the Chicago Film Critics Association, the professional cinephiles polled by IndieWire and the Palm Springs International Film Festival, which will bestow an ensemble award on the film.

title: Tell Us the Worst Christmas Gift You Ever Received
description: Dear Santa,

title: Off-Season Training Program Has Kept Vonn on Course
description: Lindsey Vonns rigorous and revamped off-season workout program was designed to keep her upright on the course, to keep mistakes from turning into devastating falls. She has put those skills to extensive use this World Cup season.

title: Barneys Chief Sells Chelsea Co-op
description: MARK LEE, the new chief executive of Barneys New York, whose recent decision to fire two longtime buyers at the store caused a stir in the fashion world, has sold his apartment in Chelsea for $2.95 million, the full asking price, according to city records.

title: For Tavis Smiley, a New Home on PBS
description: The broadcaster Tavis Smiley is changing the co-producer of his weeknight PBS talk show to WNET.org, from the Los Angeles station KCET-TV.

title: Spacesuit Archives
description: In a National Air and Space Museum storage facility, there is a collection of 200 historic spacesuits. Science writer Henry Fountain takes a look at these NASA relics.

title: For Air Cargo, a Screening Conundrum
description: Ever since 9/11, each new security threat to airlines has increased the rigor of passenger screening. They have to remove their shoes and carry liquids only in small containers. They have to take off their belts and take laptops out of their cases. Now, they have to submit to full-body scanning machines and intrusive pat-downs.

title: Pictures of the Day: Belarus and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Belarus, Afghanistan and South Korea.

title: Iraqi Premier Proposes Cabinet Ministers to Parliament
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqs prime minister set forward the skeleton of his new government on Monday night, proposing ministers to fill a majority of cabinet seats and bringing a bitter nine-month impasse one faltering step closer to resolution.

title: A Space Wardrobe
description: A collection of spacesuits, some worn by famous astronauts and others that never made it into space.

title: The Right Stuff to Wear
description: SUITLAND, Md.  Stashed in a Smithsonian storage building in this Washington suburb are some of the engineering wonders of the space race.

title: Do Digital Billboards Waste Energy?
description: Last spring, the papers Driven to Distraction series explored the potential risks of digital billboards, which critics sometimes refer to as TV on a stick. Some cities and states are debating whether to prohibit or regulate this new form of advertising for fear that it can distract drivers and raise the rate of accidents.

title: Having Fun Across Generations
description: It must have been a heady week of rehearsals for the Ensemble ACJW, the performing arm of the Academy, a collaboration among Carnegie Hall, the Juilliard School and the Weill Music Institute.  Simon Rattle, in town to conduct Pellas et Mlisande at the Metropolitan Opera, took charge of the prodigiously talented ensemble, augmented this time by alumni of the program and a few guests.

title: A Marriage That Defied Separation and War
description: John and Abigail Adams not only had one of the most documented marriages in early American history, but their partnership  chronicled in some 1,200 letters  was also uncannily modern. It was a marriage based on mutual intellectual passions, enduring sexual and emotional chemistry, and commitment to a shared political vision. For the irascible and highly volatile John, Abigail was a psychological anchor and trusted confidante; for the saucy and independent Abigail, John was a brilliant and courageous visionary who shared her love of books and playful sense of humor. She called him My Dearest Friend. He called her Miss Adorable and his Heroine.

title: Aszure Barton & Artists at Baryshnikov
description: The Canadian choreographer and her group unveiled Busk, a work set to live Gypsy music, at the Baryshnikov Arts Center.

title: Set to Live Gypsy Music, Otherworldly Vignettes of Characters Adrift
description: The Canadian choreographer Aszure Barton gets around. She is the Two and a Half Men of the dance world, although some people might think thats a good thing. For the past several years she has created works for established groups like American Ballet Theater and the Martha Graham Dance Company, as well as choreographed the Broadway production of Threepenny Opera. Last weekend at the Baryshnikov Arts Center  Mikhail Baryshnikov is also a longtime supporter of Ms. Barton  she unveiled Busk, an evening-length work for her own group, Aszure Barton & Artists, that explores aspects of what it means to perform.

title: Drawing on Fond Childhood Memories for a Pairing of Beethoven and Berio
description: The cellist Edward Arron, in introducing the eighth season by the Metropolitan Museum Artists in Concert at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium on Saturday evening, said that he initially heard the opening piece  Beethovens 14 Variations in E flat for piano trio  played by the Beaux Arts Trio in that same hall when he was, to use his term, a little kid. Even then, Mr. Arron said, he was struck by the works theme, which seemed almost comically simple.

title: A Few Instruments Go a Long Way
description: Perhaps your house, like many, has an upright piano in it that doesnt get a lot of use anymore  the children are grown and gone, or the ol hands have a touch of arthritis, or no one ever really learned to play the danged thing in the first place. And perhaps youre moderately annoyed every time you look across the room and see the inactive beast  essentially, a 700-pound, $3,000 picture-frame holder.

title: Explaining the Statistics on Temporary Hires
description: Reading my article on temporary workers in Mondays Times, Daniel Indiviglio, an associate editor at The Atlantic, questions whether companies are really behaving that much differently than they have in previous recessions, when temporary jobs were the first to come back.

title: Another Merry Christmas With the Brandenburgs
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Centers concerts of Bachs Brandenburg Concertos each December have become almost as much a New York holiday staple as the avalanche of Messiah and Nutcracker performances. For more than a decade, the society has offered all six concertos in one sitting in programs that tend to sell out. Any suggestion of abandoning the tradition has been adamantly opposed.

title: 'The Shop Around the Corner'
description: A. O. Scott looks back at the holiday classic starring James Stewart and Margaret Sullavan.

title: Theres No Such Thing as the New Normal
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog, and other drawings are available on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

title: Barbours Comments Focus Attention on Race
description: In a new interview, Governor Haley Barbour of Mississippi recalls the 1960s-era civil rights struggle in his hometown of Yazoo City, saying, I just dont remember it as being that bad.

title: Cables Shed Light on Ex-K.G.B. Officers Death
description: LONDON  Shortly after the radiation poisoning in London of a former K.G.B. officer, Alexander V. Litvinenko, a senior Russian official asserted that Moscow had been tailing his killers before he died but had been waved off by Britains security services, according to a cable in the trove of secret American documents released by WikiLeaks.

title: Critics Choice: New CDs
description: DIDDY-DIRTY MONEY

title: Football and Survivors Prove Popular
description: The two-hour conclusion of Survivor: Nicaragua lifted CBS to second place in the ratings on Sunday night behind only NBCs Sunday Night Football. According to Nielsens estimates, approximately 13.4 million viewers tuned in to the 21st-season finale of Survivor, on the low side for a finale of this franchise but still solid compared to much of the rest of the nights programming. CBSs Sunday night ratings also benefited from strong results earlier for 60 Minutes (17.9 million), which followed an overrun of the networks afternoon football coverage that delayed the start of its prime-time schedule. NBCs Sunday Night Football matchup between the Green Bay Packers and the New England Patriots dominated overall in prime time. Although final audience figures were not available on Monday, preliminary overnight estimates for the game were among this seasons highest but down from last weeks Philadelphia Eagles-Dallas Cowboys broadcast, which drew 25.7 million viewers. ABC was third behind NBC and CBS with back-to-back movies: The Santa Clause 2 from 7 to 9 (6 million) followed by The Santa Clause 3 from 9 to 11 (6.4 million). Fox finished in fourth place with reruns.

title: In Lacrosse, Separating the Harrisons From the Grangers
description: There are so many great traditions at this time of year, and not all of them revolve around the holidays. Take, for instance, Inside Lacrosses annual roundup of the best names in the college game. For the fourth consecutive year, the magazines staff has separated the Draper Donleys from the Redmond Killpacks and delivered the best monikers in the country. Now fans can argue over, among other things, whether Baxter Lanius IV deserved to be a first-teamer over Brantley Beach.

title: The Secession Ball
description: Adam Goodheart, a contributor to Disunion, appeared on WBURs Here and Now to discuss the series and South Carolinas decision to secede from the United States 150 years ago yesterday.

title: Critics Picks Video: The Shop Around the Corner
description: In this last, hurried week of holiday shopping, A. O. Scott looks back at a simpler shopping experience; the kind that could be found at The Shop Around the Corner.

title: More Than One Part of France Is Fizzy
description: OBSESSED with Champagne? I plead guilty. But you must understand, your Honor, its not just Champagne. Im obsessed with almost all sparkling wines.

title: Philip IV, Restored
description: Keith Christiansen and Michael Gallagher of the Met discuss the restoration of a Velazquez portrait.

title: Reconsidered, a Met Velzquez Is Vindicated
description: For nearly 60 years the portrait of a baby-faced Philip IV by Velzquez hung in the Metropolitan Museum of Arts European paintings galleries, a stunning example of the only 110 or so known canvases by that 17th-century Spanish master. Majestic in size, it was rare in its depiction of a young, uncertain monarch and was the earliest known portrait of Philip by Velzquez, who, as the kings court painter, went on to record his image for decades.

title: Eugene Goldwasser, Biochemist Behind an Anemia Drug, Dies at 88
description: Eugene Goldwasser, a largely unsung biochemist whose 20-year pursuit of an elusive protein led to the development of a widely used anemia drug that became one of the biggest products of the biotechnology industry, died Friday at his home in Chicago. He was 88.

title: Bones Give Peek Into the Lives of Neanderthals
description: Deep in a cave in the forests of northern Spain are the remains of a gruesome massacre. The first clues came to light in 1994, when explorers came across a pair of what they thought were human jawbones in the cave, called El Sidrn. At first, the bones were believed to date to the Spanish Civil War. Back then, Republican fighters used the cave as a hide-out. The police discovered more bone fragments in El Sidrn, which they sent to forensic scientists, who determined that the bones did not belong to soldiers, or even to modern humans. They were the remains of Neanderthals who died 50,000 years ago.

title: Council Approves West Side Apartment Towers
description: The City Council on Monday unanimously approved the development of five additional glass apartment towers, a hotel and a school on an eight-acre parcel on the West Side where developers have already turned a onetime railroad yard into an upscale residential community.

title: Scott Conant Says Hes Closing Faustina as the Cooper Square Hotel Changes Hands
description: Scott Conant just called to say he was closing Faustina, in the Cooper Square Hotel, on Wednesday because he was told that the hotel had been sold and that the new owners wanted to run the restaurant there themselves.

title: Recipes for Festive Main Courses That Feed a Crowd
description: Roasted lamb, fresh ham, lasagna and other main courses for a big holiday meal.

title: In Map of Brain Junction, Avenues to Answers
description: Working with human brain tissue removed in surgery, researchers have identified the components of a critical part of the brains architecture: the synapse, or junction where one neuron makes a connection with another.

title: Ending Homelessness
description: Project H3, an outreach program, helps people living on the streets in Phoenix find stable shelter. Video by Scott Foreman.

title: For Activist Funds, a Long-Term Approach to Investing
description: Ann Johansson for The New York Times Jeffrey Ubben, chief executive of ValueAct Capital, an activist hedge fund, says his firm has an advantage over rivals because it focuses on the long run.

title: Homes at Risk, and No Help From Lawyers
description: In California, where foreclosures are more abundant than in any other state, homeowners trying to win a loan modification have always had a tough time.

title: Hardships of a Nation Push Horses Out to Die
description: DUBLIN  In this country of lush green landscapes, celebrated for its traditional love of horses and the generations of racing thoroughbreds it has bred to conquer the racetracks of the world, the Dunsink tip on the outskirts of the Irish capital is a place that wounds the heart.

title: U.S. Military Seeks to Expand Raids in Pakistan
description: WASHINGTON  Senior American military commanders in Afghanistan are pushing for an expanded campaign of Special Operations ground raids across the border into Pakistans tribal areas, a risky strategy reflecting the growing frustration with Pakistans efforts to root out militants there.

title: Young Female Chimps Play Out Motherly Role
description: Young female chimpanzees like to play with sticks as if they were dolls, according to a new study in the journal Current Biology.

title: T. Rexs Relatives Had More Items on Their Menu
description: Although Tyrannosaurus rex liked to dig its teeth into flesh, many of its relatives had beaks, fewer teeth and longer necks and preferred plants, according to a new study.

title: Antitrust Suit in Michigan Tests Health Law
description: DETROIT  When the Justice Department filed an antitrust lawsuit against Blue Cross Blue Shield of Michigan in October, the unusual action was widely seen as a warning shot to dominant health insurance carriers in many other states.

title: Ex-Lobbyist in Alabama Pleads Guilty in Bribery
description: Jarrod D. Massey, a former Alabama lobbyist at the center of a bribery scandal that has shaken the state government, pleaded guilty on Monday in federal court in Montgomery, Ala., to conspiring to pay state lawmakers in exchange for their votes for pro-gambling legislation.

title: Recalling a Brooklyn Disaster Otherwise Forgotten
description: Quite understandably, there were powerful remembrances last week of the December day 50 years ago when death poured down from the skies above New York. Nothing like it had ever happened here: two planes colliding in midair, fiery wreckage landing on city streets, 134 people dying, including 6 on the ground in Brooklyn.

title: Many Challenges, but Also Many Helping Hands
description: They began as arguments do between mothers and sons. Turn down the music. Which boys are you hanging around with? No, you cannot have those sneakers.

title: AT&T Will Buy More Spectrum
description: AT&T agreed to buy wireless spectrum from Qualcomm for $1.93 billion to expand its fourth generation, or 4G, broadband capacity.

description: Objects from the travels of Dan Barry, the This Land columnist for The Times.

title: After Oil Spill Crisis, a Protector Keeps Watch
description: CARLISLE, La.

title: Hot Tropical Air and Travels With Jonesy
description: FLYING has been a part of my life since I was a kid. So when I started working right after college and had to fly a lot, I was already a seasoned traveler.

title: Computers and Cabbage at a Food Bank That Works
description: Not much has been easy for Madelyn Ruiz, a Florida native, since she arrived in New York in October after a job overseas fell through. For the first time in her 33 years, she has been living in shelters, most recently in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

title: Were All Conservatives Now
description: Last week conservative activist David Horowitz, author of the Academic Bill of Rights, e-mailed me to report, in sorrow, that Penn State University had weakened the only academic freedom provision . . . worthy of the name. What the university had done was revise an 1987 statement stipulating that it is not the function of a faculty member . . . to indoctrinate his/her students with ready made conclusions on controversial subjects. That sentence disappeared, as did a warning against introducing into the classroom provocative discussions of irrelevant subjects not within the field of [the instructors] study. The National Association of Scholars Web site declares that academic freedom at Penn Sate is ruined. The left had won again, and the university world remains a bastion of radical political forces.

title: Ill Prepared for Snowfall, Britain Crawls to a Halt
description: LONDON  If there were a contest for the worst weather-related suffering in Britain in the last few days, who would win?

title: The Myth of Fast-Forwarding Past the Ads
description: ZOMBIES attacked during a commercial break on the AMC zombie drama The Walking Dead last month. The flesh eaters were just about to feast on a man and woman when rescue came in the form of the Toyota Corolla, the subject of the 30-second spot.

title: Vick Stirs Debate in the M.V.P. Vote
description: If the N.F.L. season were to end today, who would be the most valuable player? There are two clear choices: New England quarterback Tom Brady and Philadelphias Michael Vick.

title: Justice Dept. Is Criticized as Corruption Cases Close
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department has shut down a wave of high-profile investigations of members of Congress over the past few months, drawing criticism that the governments premier anticorruption agency has lost its nerve after the disastrous collapse last year of its case against former Senator Ted Stevens.

title: New Security Features From Google
description: It is becoming increasingly perilous to surf the Web. Scores of poorly secured sites are being commandeered constantly by criminals and used to abuse visitors.

title: Prospect of WikiLeaks Dump Poses Problems for Regulators
description: Lennart Preiss/Associated PressWikiLeaks founder, Julian Assange.

title: F.E.C. Rejected Counsel With Its Vote on Senator
description: WASHINGTON  When the Federal Election Commission voted last month to close an investigation into a $96,000 payment to Senator John Ensigns former lover, it overrode the findings of its own staff lawyers, documents made public Monday showed.

title: Ivory Coasts Leader Tightens Vise on Man Who Defeated Him in Presidential Race
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast  The president of Ivory Coast on Monday stepped up the pressure on the man who defeated him in an election last month, cutting off food and medical help to his headquarters in a hotel here guarded by United Nations peacekeepers.

title: Diary of a New York Lawyer
States Rights, but to What?
description: One hundred and fifty years ago today South Carolina declared its independence from the United States. The move had been in the offing since early November, when Abraham Lincolns election led the states leaders to fear that Washington would begin to restrict slavery in the territories and in their own state. That was the proximate cause, at least; there was more to it. Beyond the election, South Carolina was no longer happy in a union with the free states, where northern opponents of slavery were allowed to openly denounce the peculiar institution in Congress and in their home states.

title: Discussing Civil Rights Era, a Governor Is Criticized
description: WASHINGTON  In an interview that set off a new round of debate on Monday about racial attitudes and politics, Gov. Haley Barbour of Mississippi, a potential Republican presidential candidate, recalled the 1960s civil rights struggle in his hometown, Yazoo City, saying, I just dont remember it as being that bad.

title: Paterson Fined $62,125 Over World Series Tickets

title: A Plan to Make Homelessness History
description: This is a story about a plan to end chronic homelessness in the United States. Its not an indeterminate war on homelessness, but a methodical approach to do away with a major social problem. Each day, roughly 700,000 people in the country are homeless. About 120,000 are chronically homeless. They often live on the streets for years and have mental disabilities, addiction problems and life-threatening diseases like heart disease, cancer and diabetes. They are also five times more likely than ordinary Americans to have suffered a traumatic brain injury, which may have precipitated their homelessness. Without direct assistance, many will remain homeless for the rest of their lives  at enormous cost to society and themselves.Against this backdrop, the 100,000 Homes Campaign has set the goal of placing 100,000 chronically homeless people  pinpointing those who face the greatest risk of dying on the streets  into permanent supportive housing by July 2013. Its the human welfare equivalent of NASAs race to put a man on the moon. Whether the goal is achieved or not, the campaign is shifting the way cities address a problem that has often been seen as more of a nuisance than a public health emergency.

title: Notes On Government Employment
description: I see that my various posts on government employment have brought out a variety of complaints  OK, there was a temporary spike from the Census thats being misused, but isnt there an upward trend, isnt that a bad thing, etc..

description: Franklin D. Roosevelt had his radio microphone. Robert Gibbs has a Web cam.

description: BEIJING  Star-crossed love between Alexander the Great and his teenage male slave. Ferocious battles that defined an empire. The bloodshed and romance of Ancient Greece.

description: KUALA LUMPUR  Electrical goods, coffee, herbs and spices are among the products that MasterMalaysia Global usually trades with its Chinese partners.

title: A Major Challenge: Getting Money Into China
description: From a cattle ranch in the countrys northeast to a gym in Beijing, Jade Gray has been involved in his share of start-ups since arriving in China from New Zealand in 1996.

title: As China Rises, So Does Vietnam
description: One of the biggest beneficiaries of Chinas rapid economic ascent is not China at all, but rather its historic rival, occasional enemy and fellow socialist neighbor to the south, Vietnam.

title: Seeing Your Children as Perfect
description: About a year ago at this time I ran a post titled How Well Do You Know Your Children. It was specifically about parents perceptions of their childrens nutrition and exercise habits (those with preschoolers reported that their children ate healthy food and exercised regularly, and those with middle-school children reported that theirs did not) and how often our perceptions are wrong (when examined more closely, there was very little difference in eating and exercise between the two age groups.) More broadly, my post raised the question of how regularly there is a mismatch between what we see when we look at our children, and what is really there.

title: When the Diagnosis Is Dead Butt Syndrome
description: My butt, unfortunately, is dead.

title: The End Seems Near for Favre
description: What looked like the end for Brett Favre came ingloriously, if somewhat fittingly, face down on a frozen field, the latest and unwisest of his innumerable comebacks looking less wise with every pained blink. Not even the Mr. Sunshine of Monday Night Football, Jon Gruden, could paint a smiley face on this one. Favre looked old, dazed and thoroughly beaten.

title: Putting a Price on Side Pockets
description: Hedge fund investors stuck in side pockets, those opaque segregated accounts, may be able to buy some clarity.

title: Laundromat Worker Is Shot to Death in Brooklyn
description: A 45-year-old man working at a laundromat in Brooklyn was shot and killed late Monday as he was taking out the garbage from the store, the authorities said.

title: Kings of Leon Concert Postponed After Bus Fires
description: This isnt the kind of hot act that Kings of Leon wants to be known as: two buses belonging to the band caught fire in London, causing no serious injuries but forcing the postponement of a concert at O2 Arena, BBC News reported. A bus at the arena caught fire, which spread to another tour bus in the loading bay, and about 60 firefighters came to the scene on Tuesday morning to put it out. The BBC said ambulance crews had also arrived to treat six people for smoke inhalation, and a spokesman for the London Fire Brigade said the fire had burned out both buses but had not affected the arenas stage or seating area.

title: Losing Hope About a Recovery
description: When will the economy begin to recover? The National Bureau of Economic Researchs Business Cycle Dating Committee says the recovery began in June 2009, but unemployed Americans beg to differ:

title: South and West See Large Gains in Latest Census
description: WASHINGTON  The Census Bureau rearranged the countrys political map on Tuesday, giving more Congressional seats to the South and the West at the expense of the Northeast and the Midwest  changes that will have far-reaching implications for elections over the next decade.

title: Spurned by Groupon, Google Goes Hunting
description: After failing to win over Groupon with a $6 billion bid, Google is courting the social buying sites rivals, according to The New York Post.

title: What Were Reading
description: An aggregation of links by the reporters and editors of Diners Journal.

title: The Curies, Seen Through an Artists Eyes
description: Negative reviews of poetry books are famously rare; takedowns of graphic novels and book-length comics are scarcer still.

title: Elation, Then Life Intervenes
description: I was shaking off the icy December chill from my stinging face as I returned home from school when I saw the Knox College letter patiently awaiting my arrival on the kitchen counter.

title: Unhappy Hamilton Benched by Pistons
description: 3:37 p.m. | Updated The truth has been visible for a while: Detroit guard Richard Hamilton is not a happy Piston.

title: Scream Real Loud: Pee-wee Herman Show Coming Back to HBO
description: Like a self-perpetuating argument composed of the phrase I know you are but what am I?, the Mbius strip that is The Pee-wee Herman Show continues to cycle forward and wrap around itself. On Tuesday HBO said it would shoot the Broadway production of The Pee-wee Herman Show, which stars Paul Reubens as that impish man-child of its title, for a special to be shown next year. Pee-wee historians  and you know who you are  may recall that HBO previously broadcast a Pee-wee Herman Show special in 1981, taped at the Roxy Theater in Los Angeles. That show, which Mr. Reubens and his colleagues at the Groundlings comedy theater began performing in 1980, would go on to form the basis of the Pee-wee Herman Show currently being presented at the Stephen Sondheim Theater on Broadway. HBO said it would tape its new Pee-wee special immediately after the shows Broadway run ends on Jan. 2; a broadcast date wasnt announced.

title: Lawyer Describes Solitary Confinement of Suspected WikiLeaks Source
description: As Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, continues to grant interviews to the worlds media each day  including a revealing discussion with John Humphreys of the BBC on Tuesday  his supporters and critics alike have been offered glimpses of the estate in the English countryside where he is enduring what his lawyer jokingly referred to as not so much a house arrest as a manor arrest.

title: EBay Sends Shoppers to Offline Stores
description: To help last minute holiday shoppers, EBay is sending them to bricks and mortar stores.

title: Neediest | Seeking Self-Control
description: A teenage son works to control his anger and repair his relationship with his mother.

title: Delays Persist for Travelers in Europe
description: LONDON  Prime Minister David Cameron said Tuesday that he had offered military assistance to the owner of Heathrow Airport, still struggling to clear a backlog of thousands of people left stranded by bad weather and the airports inability to deal with the problem.

title: Elder Tech: Whats Important
description: Conversations about elderly parents and technology usually center on safety, in particular on devices designed to alert a call center in case of trouble. But our parents are more than the sum of their maladies. Instead of keeping them safe, cant some of these devices help keep them happy?

title: Why Apple Removed a WikiLeaks App From Its Store
description: Apple on Tuesday confirmed that it had removed from its online store an iPhone and iPad app that let users view the content on the WikiLeaks site and follow the WikiLeaks Twitter account.

title: New York and New Jersey Will Lose House Seats
description: WASHINGTON  New York will lose 2 of its 29 seats in the House, while New Jersey will lose 1 of its 13 seats, both as a result of population shifts recorded in this years census.

title: Santas Request List, N.H.L. Style
description: Christmas is almost here. Have you sent your letter to Santa Claus yet? There may still be time, but many N.H.L. personalities arent taking any chances. Theyve made sure their notes to the North Pole are already in the mail.

title: Arms Treaty With Russia Headed for Ratification
description: WASHINGTON  An arms control treaty paring back American and Russian nuclear arsenals won a decisive vote in the Senate on Tuesday, clearing it for final approval and handing President Obama an important foreign policy victory.

title: Favre Goes Off On a Shield Of His Own Making
description: It was hard to miss the symbolism of the final moments Monday night, when the Chicago Bears, so comfortable in their 40-14 blowout, already had on their division championship hats. The only parting gifts the Minnesota Vikings received were a few snowballs hurled at them by furious and freezing fans, and the sobering sight of their quarterback looking like a punch-drunk fighter who had finally taken one too many walks into the ring after strangely thrusting himself back into a season that had melted down.

title: Barbour Seeks to Clarify Comments on Civil Rights Era
description: Gov. Haley Barbour of Mississippi sought to clarify remarks he made about his hometown during the civil rights era, calling it a difficult and painful era, especially for African-Americans.

title: Firefighter Charged in Fatal Hit and Run
description: A Brooklyn firefighter was arrested on Tuesday in connection with a fatal hit-and-run accident in October that left a Guatemalan immigrant dead.

title: Arlen Specters Closing Argument
description: Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania, a veteran of several Supreme Court nomination battles and a wily Senate tactician for three decades, bid farewell to the Senate on Tuesday with a stinging critique of the state of partisan politics and the conservative demand for ideological purity in Republican politicians.

title: TimesCast | December 21, 2010
description: A look at START nuclear arms treaty in Russia; and the senate on the 9/11 Health and Compensation Act

title: In California, a Wary Eye on Hillsides as Rain Falls
description: LA CAADA FLINTRIDGE, Calif.  The rain had slowed to a mere pitter-patter on the windshield as Sgt. Tracy Stewart began surveying the area early Tuesday morning. Tiny streams of water were running speedily though the gutters and drain basins meant to protect the homes from floods and to ease the risk of mudslides like the ones that crashed through this Los Angeles suburb earlier this year.

title: Samurai Shopper | A Year of Favorites
description: The Samurai Shopper must admit to a few Mary Poppins moments, particularly at holiday time, when pure sentiment meets unmaxed credit cards. But lets please skip the raindrops and roses and whiskers on kittens and get to my lime green fuzzy friends frog slippers, from Haven Spa (150 Mercer Street).

description: LOS ANGELES

title: Blackstone Names 11 New Senior Managing Directors
description: The Blackstone Group, the private equity behemoth, named 11 new senior managing directors on Monday, effective Jan. 1, according to an internal e-mail.

title: Brightscopes Top-Rated 401(k) Plans
description: The quality of your 401(k) plan can have a big impact on your retirement savings. Overall costs of the plan matter, as does the breadth and quality of the investment options. The size of the employer match, if any, makes an enormous difference too in whether youll meet your savings goals.

title: Browsing: Last-Minute Gift Guide
description: Still looking for that special something to say I love you, I respect you, Thank you, or I am ambivalent about you? Here are some last-minute gift ideas for procrastinators.

title: Q&A: Where to Go With a $1,500 Flight Credit?
description: I have a $1,500 flight credit with Continental that I need to use, and Im planning a 9- or 10-day trip sometime in January or February, but I dont have my heart set on a destination. My only stipulations are that the destination be reasonably inexpensive (looking to spend around $100 to $150 a day) and reasonably safe for a 24-year-old female solo traveler. Ive traveled solo to Indonesia, Jordan, Syria and Tanzania. Any ideas would be greatly appreciated.

title: Which States Will Gain or Lose Seats in Congress
description: The Census Bureau released estimates Tuesday that show which states will lose or gain congressional districts.

title: 10 Champagnes Worth Seeking Out
description: My column in the dining section this week is on the world of French sparkling wine beyond Champagne. To a certain extent, you could look at these bottles as Champagne replacements. They are cheaper  topping out at $30, which is about where basic Champagne begins nowadays. They can certainly step in and serve in the celebratory role at which Champagne excels.

title: The Sounds of Silence Lose in British Chart Competition
description: Two ambitious Web campaigns were not enough to prevent a TV talent-show contestant from reaching the top of the British singles chart the week of Christmas  an annual race that has become something of a national sport for British music fans.

title: Israel Plans Public Appeal to Ask U.S. to Free a Spy
description: JERUSALEM  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel will officially and publicly appeal to President Obama in the coming days for the release of Jonathan Jay Pollard, the American serving a life term in a North Carolina prison for spying for Israel, Mr. Netanyahus office announced Tuesday.

title: When Good Teaching Pays Off
description: Earlier this year my colleague David Leonhardt wrote about a new study that found that a good kindergarten teacher could greatly improve students future earnings. On that basis, an especially strong kindergarten teacher is arguably worth about $320,000 a year, which is the present value of the additional earnings that a full class of students can expect to earn over their careers.

title: F.C.C. Approves Net Rules and Braces for Fight
description: 8:52 p.m. | Updated  Want to watch hours of YouTube videos or sort through Facebook photos on the computer? Your Internet providers would be forbidden from blocking you under rules approved by the Federal Communications Commission on Tuesday. But if you want to do the same on your cellphone, you may not have the same protections.

title: Those Ornery Sisters of The Fighter
description: Pork, Tar, Red Dog, Beaver: these are not craft beers or bad-idea candle scents, they are the nicknames of the big-haired, big-mouthed sisters in The Fighter. The seven siblings of half-brothers Micky Ward and Dicky Eklund so captivated the films director, David O. Russell, that he told the Bagger that he wished he could make a TV show just about them. (Sounds like a TBS reality series to us.) In The Los Angeles Times, Steve Zeitchik takes a look at the actresses  some professional, some not  who round out the Ward-Eklund clan, many of them chosen from the 3,000 people who turned up for an open casting call in Lowell, Mass., where the movie is set and filmed.

title: Deutsche Makes Deal In Tax Case
description: Deutsche Bank agreed to pay $553 million and admit to criminal wrongdoing on Tuesday, settling a long-running investigation into tax shelter fraud that prosecutors say generated billions of dollars in bogus tax benefits.

title: Can Milwaukees Offense Survive Jenningss Injury?
description: The news of an injury to a star player is never cheery, but the announcement that a broken foot will cost Brandon Jennings upwards of four weeks of action is particularly dismal for the struggling Milwaukee Bucks. Jennings isnt Milwaukees best player on either end of the court, but his absence from the lineup should serve as a reminder that things can always get worse for the leagues worst offense.

title: Observers Comment on Eclipse: How Tiny We Are
description: Many people skipped sleep, or set their alarms, to make sure they were awake to see the lunar eclipse Tuesday morning.

title: Pictures of the Day: The Moon and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from New York, Britain and Afghanistan.

title: ABC World News Plans Report on Ford Windstar Recall
description: Christopher Jensen, a Wheels blog contributor who often writes about recalls and safety issues, is to appear Tuesday night on ABC World News With Diane Sawyer in a segment about axle failures on Ford Windstar minivans. The report is expected to be broadcast again Wednesday morning on Good Morning America.

title: UConn Women Own the Longest Streak
description: HARTFORD  For decades, U.C.L.A.s winning streak seemed as round and fundamental and permanent as the shape of the ball itself.

title: Doug Aitken at MoCA, Part Three
description: The Moment goes behind the scenes with Doug Aitken at MoCA for an exclusive three-part video piece. The third and final installment: Happening.

title: Secret Recording of British Minister Who Declared War on Murdoch Media Empire
description: Updated | 4:22 p.m. Britains business secretary, Vince Cable, was stripped of his power to regulate media companies on Tuesday after an audio recording of him telling undercover reporters that he had declared war on the press baron Rupert Murdoch was obtained and published online by the BBC.

title: Democrats Optimistic About Census
description: The conventional political wisdom is that the results of the 2010 census, announced Tuesday, are a big win for Republicans, who are largely dominant in the states where population increased.

title: Visitors Center Planned for Louis Armstrong House and Museum
description: Blueprints and design have just been completed for a visitors center dedicated to the life and artifacts of Louis Armstrong, according to Michael Cogswell, director of the Armstrong House and Museum, in Corona, Queens. The center will take a year and a half to build, and will sit across the street from the three-story brick house on 107th Street, which has been open to the public since 2003.

title: Anella
description: ANELLA is an intimate little art house of a restaurant on a block in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, that might be a rough part of Paris or an old part of Boston, some forgotten corner of a city that can reach back into the 19th century for building stock and scale. The wind whips in off the East River there sharp as razors, and old women squabble in Polish on the street. You will need your adventure boots to get there, perhaps.
