title: Eurofile | Dutch Treat
description: There are dozens of reasons to love Amsterdam, but the food isnt one of them. To be sure, the city has several terrific Indonesian restaurants, like Sampurna and Blue Pepper, legacies of Hollands colonial past. (Indonesia was a Dutch colony for more than three centuries.) And theres De Kas, which serves excellent produce-driven menus in a beautifully restored 1926 greenhouse. I also love running amok at De Kaaskamer, the ideal spot for a tour of Dutch cheeses. But unlike most other major European cities, Amsterdam is a gastronomically deracinated destination. The streets are lined with gauche gaucho steakhouses, middling pasta palaces, wok wielders, burger joints and shawarma stands galore, and, more recently, a torrent of Mad Med tapas taverns.

title: Born Yesterday May Return to Broadway With a New Star
description: A Broadway revival of Garson Kanins play Born Yesterday is in the works for spring 2011, possibly with a relatively unknown actress in the lead role that Judy Holliday made famous more than 60 years ago, two theater executives familiar with the plans said on Tuesday.

title: New York, New York
description: What do Yogi Berra, Brandon Knight, Phil Lombardi, Hal Reniff and Roy Staiger have in common?

title: A Chess Set Fit for a King or an Emperor
description: The Russian Museum of Ethnography in St. Petersburg, Russia, is displaying a remarkable chess set as part of an exhibition of the Jewelry House Anna Nova.

title: E.E.O.C. Sues Kaplan Over Hiring
description: Sending a sharp warning to employers nationwide, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission sued the Kaplan Higher Education Corporation on Tuesday, accusing it of discriminating against black job applicants through the way it uses credit histories in its hiring process.

title: Black Swan a Rappers Delight
description: From the department of rappers doing things pretty much unrelated to hip-hop  see: Wayne, Lil, U.S. Open picks  comes this video, of Sean Price, of the Brownsville, Brooklyn-based Boot Camp Clik, reviewing Black Swan for NextMovie. He gave it his version of the thumbs-up: I didnt fall asleep.

title: Clashes in Belarus Show Resilience of Both Sides
description: MINSK, Belarus  It was the middle of the night when security services stormed the headquarters of Charter 97, an opposition Web site that is a rare window here onto a world beyond the control of the president and his security apparatus. There was time for just one final message.

title: A Poor Little Rich Girl at Christmas
description: WHAT is it about the holidays that so particularly illuminates the architecture of families? Just as the twinkling lights of a Christmas tree, flashing on the faces that surround it, can alternately bathe them in a warm glow or render them macabre, the season seems to cast the structures of family into weird relief. This is true of all families, no matter where they lie on the scale of class or economics, or so a recent conversation with Ivana Lowell suggests.

title: Giving Gifts to Bosses and Employees
description: Some people I know recently got into a debate over whether to give gifts to their boss or people they supervise. One person always gave such gifts, while the other never had.

title: Cuomo Brings Suit Against Ernst & Young
description: New York Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo has sued Ernst & Young, accusing the accounting firm of helping the now defunct firm Lehman Brothers "engage in a massive accounting fraud".

title: Abuses Cited in Enforcing China Policy of One Child
description: BEIJING  Thirty years after it introduced some of the worlds most sweeping population-control measures, the Chinese government continues to use a variety of coercive family planning tactics, from financial penalties for households that violate the restrictions to the forced sterilization of women who have already had one child, according to a report issued by a human rights group.

title: LVMH Raises Its Herms Stake to 20% Despite Scrutiny of Acts
description: PARIS  The fashion magnate Bernard Arnault has added to his holding in the luxury retailer Herms International, undeterred by a controlling family seemingly united against him and regulatory scrutiny of his methods.

title: Why Cuomo Is Suing Ernst & Young
description: The attorney general of New York, Andrew M. Cuomo, is accusing Ernst & Young of helping the now-defunct firm Lehman Brothers engage in a massive accounting fraud. In this video, Peter Lattman, a DealBook reporter, explains the complex transaction at the heart of the case  which made the companys books look healthier than they actually were.

title: Downtown Las Vegas Draws Developers
description: LAS VEGAS  The Strip was long the place where developers bet big. They competed to put up the most extravagant and largest hotel-casinos  and with rooms nearly always full, banks falling over themselves to lend and thousands of visitors arriving every day, their gamble made sense.

title: New Yorks Schools Seize a Chance to Expand
description: After the Norcor Management Corporation bought the Sunnyside Jewish Center in Queens in 2006, it demolished the synagogue in expectation of building residential housing on the site. But like so many projects, the plans were dashed in the wake of the real estate crash, and the parcel has sat vacant for years.

title: Craft Distilleries Come Alive in the Northeast
description: Once thriving, stills are proliferating again, not just with farmers adding value to their crops, but with disgruntled professionals jumping ship and young urbanites tapping a trend.

title: In Pitchings New Era, Son Makes Father Smile
description: The year of the pitcher ended with a flurry of fastballs and splitters and sliders from the wispy frame of the San Francisco Giants Tim Lincecum. He did it with crisp efficiency, allowing a run and striking out 10 Texas Rangers over eight innings in Game 5 of the World Series.

title: City Sparring With the E.P.A. Over a Plan to Check Schools for PCBs
description: The Environmental Protection Agency plans to begin inspecting school buildings in New York City next month for contamination with the toxic chemicals known as PCBs in response to a pilot study that found that the substance was leaking from old light fixtures in some schools.

title: What Were Reading: Johnny Depp and the New Tax Law
Five-Million-Book Google Database Gets a Workout, and a Debate, in Its First Days
description: Ngram, Googles new searchable dataset of words and phrases from 5.2 million published books, got quite a workout on its first day. Within 24 hours after its launching last Thursday afternoon, more than a million queries were run.

title: An Interfaith Christmas Tree
description: Hayley Krischer is Jewish. There is a Christmas tree at her house this year, for the first time in her life. As she explains in a guest post today, it is partly for her son, whose dad is Christian, but also for her daughter, whose dad isnt, and mostly because this is the sort of thing that a guilt-ridden, over-compensating, divorced parent does this time of year.

title: Philosophers for Kung Fu: A Response
description: Thanks to all the readers who have commented on my previous article in the Stone Kung Fu for Philosophers. I found many comments thoughtful and inspiring, for which I am deeply grateful. Instead of trying to respond to all, as it is obviously impractical, I would like to offer some additional remarks to supplement my previous article as my response.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: 'Somewhere'
description: Sofia Coppola, the director of Somewhere, discusses a scene from her film.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: Somewhere
description: Somewhere, the new drama from Sofia Coppola, was honored earlier this month with a special filmmaking achievement award from the National Board of Review. A look at the highs and lows in the life of a movie star, the film was picked as one of the top 10 movies of the year by A. O. Scott.

title: Cherry Lane Theater Artistic Director to Leave and Sell Building
description: Angelina Fiordellisi, the artistic director of the nonprofit Cherry Lane Theater, a Greenwich Village institution since 1924, will step down next year, she said on Tuesday. She said that she plans to sell the building, at 38 Commerce Street, and that constant financial struggles in recent years and the changing nature of the business had led to her decision.

title: Asked & Answered | Ronnie Spector
description: There may be no bigger Christmas booster on this planet than Ronnie Spector. The Rock & Roll Hall of famer and former Ronette has been recording Christmas music for nearly half a century, ever since her renditions of Christmas classics appeared on the 1963 album A Christmas Gift For You. The original bad girl of rock has just released a new Xmas-themed album (Best Christmas Ever), played her 10th annual Christmas show at B.B. King Blues Club and apparently already sent her wish list to Santa. The Moment caught up with this quintessential New Yorker to discuss all things Noel.

title: Incentives Matter
description: The Wall Street Journal has an excellent article today on Life Partners, a company that buys life insurance policies from elderly people and then sells interests in them to investors. It seems that  surprise  Life Partners almost always forecasts that policy holders will die earlier than they do. It also charges hefty fees to investors, ensuring that it will make plenty of money even if investors do not do very well.

title: Potatoes and Swiss Chard in a Side Dish That Can Star
description: JIM LEIKEN, the executive chef at DBGB Kitchen & Bar on the Bowery, was looking for hearty, rusty garnishes to go with the whole roast suckling pig feasts that the restaurant is known for. I wanted an impressive presentation, but something that was fun to share for a big table of people, he said. What he came up with was this potato gratin with Gruyre and Swiss chard. It is a celebratory, filling dish that can easily move in from its satellite role to the centerpiece of a holiday meal.

title: A Man So Stubborn He Wouldnt Listen Even to Moses
description: Korach, an ambitious but flawed parable by the legendary downtown impresario Judith Malina, explores the travails of anarchists over the millenniums. We will lose every battle except the last one, announces Emma Goldman in one of the plays time-hopping video re-enactments.

title: In a Sophisticated Showbiz World, Simple Mimes Can Still Hold Sway
description: In 1977 The New York Times ran an article on Mummenschanz with the title Youve Never Seen Mimes Like This. That was a long time ago.

title: Watching the Costs in a Buyout Revival
description: The buyout industry should slowly emerge from its fund-raising drought in 2011. Investors will be more inclined to put money into private equity after having more capital returned to them in 2010. But it is still a buyers market, and the time is ripe for investors to push hard to overhaul the fees they pay.

title: House Passes Overhaul of Food Laws
description: The House of Representatives gave final approval on Tuesday to a long-awaited modernization of the nations food safety laws, voting 215 to 144 to grant the Food and Drug Administration greater authority over food production.

title: Vain Glorious | Spin Your Wheels in Miami
description: What: Soul Cycle South Beach

title: Reflections on the Literary Decline of the Subway
description: Poetry and prose on the subway may be going the way of the dodo. As The Times reported Tuesday morning, the Train of Thought series, which placed literary quotations from the likes of Kafka and Schopenhauer in the unlikely locale of a packed New York City subway car, is being removed to make way for a promotional campaign by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: Putin Makes Symbolic Visit in Ethnic Strife
description: MOSCOW  Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin appeared to offer support to soccer fans on Tuesday in a potentially explosive ethnic conflict with migrants from the North Caucasus region, most of them Muslims who have flooded the countrys major cities in search of work.

title: Australian, 84, Jailed for Faking War Record
description: An 84-year-old Australian man has been sentenced to six months in jail for having fraudulently claimed hundreds of thousands of dollars in veterans benefits he was not entitled to because his war record was entirely fictitious.

title: Vatican Adds Nuance to Popes Condom Remarks
description: ROME  The Vatican on Tuesday issued its most authoritative clarification on Pope Benedict XVIs recent remarks that condoms could sometimes be used for disease prevention, saying that the pope in no way justified their use to prevent pregnancy.

title: Bradley Picks Two Dozen for Winter Camp
description: The 2010 World Cup is history. The 2011 Concacaf Gold Cup is on the horizon, as is the 2012 London Olympics. Qualifying matches for the 2014 World Cup in Brazil will be here before you know it.

title: Will the Feds Debit Fee Rule Help Merchants?
description: Last Thursday, after the Federal Reserve floated an aggressive plan to limit the amount banks can collect from retailers for debit card transactions, MasterCard Worldwide registered its disapproval with a statement that provocatively cast the issue as a conflict between retailers and their customers. If adopted as proposed, Mastercard said, the regulations would shift merchant costs directly to consumers.

title: Pictures of the Day: The Moon and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from New York, Britain and Afghanistan.

title: Strong Send-Off For The Sing Off
description: The Alabama gospel group Committed won the second edition of NBCs reality competition The Sing Off on Monday as 8.5 million viewers tuned in, according to Nielsens estimates. The two-hour finale helped lift NBC to second place for the night, trailing CBS and its lineup of repeats. At 10, NBCs preview of its new sitcom Perfect Couples garnered only 3.8 million viewers, considerably less than CBSs comedy reruns earlier in the night, including How I Met Your Mother at 8 (6.6 million) and Two and a Half Men at 9 (9.2 million). CBSs Hawaii Five-0 repeat led the 10 p.m. hour with 7.5 million viewers. ABC was third over all, as Skating With the Stars attracted just 4.8 million at 8 and back-to-back reruns of ABCs Castle fared only slightly better from 9 to 11 (6.4 million). Fox finished fourth as its new game show, Million Dollar Money Drop, drew a meager 5.3 million viewers from 8 to 10.

title: Theater Group in Belarus Is Forced Underground
description: The Belarus Free Theater, one of the revelations of the 2008 Under the Radar alternative-theater festival, is scheduled to return for the 2011 edition of the event, which begins early next month. But a real-life drama has suddenly intruded: both founders of the troupe are now in hiding, and another member is in jail, as the result of a government crackdown on protests against a presidential election that human rights groups have described as rigged.

title: Dancing Around History
description: Today it is hoped we shall get the old Lady South Carolina out of the crowd without damaging her hoops or tearing her dress, wrote planter John S. Palmer to his wife on December 19, 1860. Likening secession to the social graces required of southern belles, Palmer captured the mood of Charleston, where the state secession convention had recently convened.

title: Wearing Braids, Seeking Revenge
description: That old-time American religion of vengeance runs like a river through True Grit, a comic-serious tale about some nasty, brutish times. Beautifully adapted by Joel and Ethan Coen from the parodic western novel by Charles Portis, it turns on a 14-year-old Arkansas girl who hires a one-eyed fat man to hunt down her fathers killer. First published in 1968, Mr. Portiss tall tale was brought to the screen the next year custom-fitted for John Wayne, who rode the role of that fat man, Rooster Cogburn, straight to an Oscar. Now its the thinner scene-stealer Jeff Bridges who sits and sometimes drunkenly slumps in the saddle.

title: Congress Waddles Ahead on Cleaning Up Diesel Fuel
description: On Tuesday, presumably one of the last days of the 111th Congress, the House gave final passage to a five-year extension of the Diesel Emissions Reduction Act, which aims to clean up old diesel engines. The bill authorizes the $500 million in spending over the next five years but does not actually appropriate any money; that is a battle for the next Congress.

title: Spider-Man Matinee Is Canceled
description: The producers of the new Broadway musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark canceled its Wednesday matinee to add safety precautions after a lead stunt actor playing the superhero sustained serious injuries from falling more than 20 feet into a basement beneath the stage during Monday nights show. He was the fourth performer to be hurt working on Spider-Man since September.

title: Mozart for the Little Ones, Where the Special Effects Are Always 3-D
description: Last week came word that the official opening of Julie Taymors troubled-plagued $65 million production of the Broadway musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark was being pushed back again, this time for a month, until Feb. 7. Then, on Monday night, another accident occurred, when an actor fell from a set during a preview performance.

title: Poparazzi | Smiley Virus
description: There was a time when dignity in e-mails was important to me. Each sentence needed to have correct capitalization, punctuation, and certainly never a superfluous exclamation point or twee smiley face. That time is now in the distant past!

title: Wall St. Computers Read the News, and Trade on It
description: The number-crunchers on Wall Street are starting to crunch something else: the news.

title: Private Equity Looks Abroad, But May Be Blind to the Risks
description: Stephen A. Schwarzman, the chief executive of the Blackstone Group, is Paris-bound. Mr. Schwarzman will spend the next four to six months in France working on international opportunities for Blackstone.

title: The Pampered Life, Viewed From the Inside
description: The opening shot of Somewhere, Sofia Coppolas exquisite, melancholy and formally audacious fourth feature, prepares you for what is to follow in a characteristically oblique and subtle manner. A black Ferrari circulates on an otherwise empty desert speedway, driving in and out of the stationary cameras range as the noise of its engine oscillates between a distant whine and a full-throated roar.

title: Round Two: Is Google a Monopoly?
description: Now that Google is reportedly on the prowl for the next Groupon, its time to revisit the debate of whether Google should be allowed to add to its empire.

title: E-Mails Big Demographic Split
description: In an article in Tuesdays Times, I wrote about the changing status of e-mail. Once it was cool to merely have an e-mail account (or several), but many young people now think of it as old school, and much prefer the zip of texting, instant messaging and social networks.

title: Fierce Tests of Endurance and the Resilience of the Spirit
description: Secret Sunshine  a 2007 film by Lee Chang-dong now making a tardy but welcome American debut  takes place in a South Korean town called Miryang, described by one of its residents as just like every other place. This is true enough, and Mr. Lee is certainly attentive to the routines and rhythms of everyday life. But there is nothing ordinary about this movie, or about the story it tells.

title: The Lives They Lived
description: A collection of narratives that celebrate lives.

title: Patriarch Faces Future: Who to Lead Nutty Clan When He Is Gone?
description: Apparently, because all the good jokes were used up in the first two Fockers movies, the wisenheimers behind the latest installment in this unnecessary trilogy decided to bring in some spew, opening a sick toddlers mouth like a fire hydrant and letting it rip.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening

title: Dining Calendar
description: Sampling Privileges

title: Festive, Easier-to-Use Holiday Oven Gloves
description: After the hostess dropped the roasting pan at a holiday dinner because of her bulky oven mitts, Pierre Carrilero, a knitwear designer, decided an improvement was needed. His oven gloves, made from a knitted heat-resistant viscose fiber called Lenzing FR, are bright red, patterned with nonskid silicone snowflakes and thickly lined, and come halfway up to the elbow. They offer protection from up to 428 degrees. Since they also guard against cold, theyre as excellent to wear for cleaning snow off the car as for hauling the turkey out of the oven.

title: Don Bocarte Octopus, Precooked, From Spain
description: Ambitious cooks might tackle octopus for the Italian Feast of the Seven Fishes on Christmas Eve by pounding, freezing and simmering it to soften the meat. But all it takes now is buying precooked, vacuum-packed and perfectly tender octopus tentacles from Spain. They come ready to slice into a cold seafood salad, to warm by slipping the package into a pan of boiling water or to sear briefly in a heavy pan or on the grill with a slather of sauce. I mixed rounds of it in a warm salad with chunks of boiled potatoes, a shower of minced celery and parsley, plus capers, olive oil and vinegar.

title: Jamaican Blue Mountain Coffee From Bob Marleys Son
description: Rohan Marley got into the coffee business more than 10 years ago. A Rasta from Jamaica called offering land, he said. Since then, Mr. Marley, a son of the reggae legend Bob Marley, has overcome financial and bureaucratic hurdles to acquire the estate, produce 100 percent Jamaican Blue Mountain coffee and start selling it. (Other Marley coffees, not from Jamaica, have been available for nearly a year.) Years ago, Blue Mountain had been prized and costly, but its reputation was spoiled by blends that skimped on the Blue Mountain, which Jamaica no longer allows. Marleys Blue Mountain is a fairly light roast, floral, chocolatey and earthy, with bright acidity.

title: Just Dont Call It Moonshine
description: IN an aluminum shed among postcard orchards in Columbia County in New York, Derek Grout inspected a collecting tank of his state-of-the-art copper-pot still. A blocked vent had caused the tank to buckle. Im just kind of glad we didnt kill ourselves, he said with a laugh. Got to bang that out.

title: Eolo Sicilia a Tavola
description: 190 Seventh Avenue, (21st Street), Chelsea, (646) 225-6606, eolonyc.com.

title: Deccan Kabab
description: 74-06 37th Road (74th-75th Streets), Jackson Heights, Queens, (718) 565-5155.

title: Zapping the Holiday Candy
description: IM not a big candy eater, but around the holidays I find myself longing for a few pieces of chewy Turkish delight. Despite the name and exotic rose-water flavor, its among the humblest of confections, made from just cornstarch and sugar. But it takes me back to the first Christmas I can remember, when the grandmother I hadnt yet met, who was Indian and lived in England, sent me a box. For me it still carries the taste of strangeness and confusion and wonder.

title: A Meditation on Captivity, Featuring an Orangutan
description: A childs voice whispers Nnette!, and immediately we are in the patient and curious world of the French filmmaker Nicolas Philibert. Best known in the United States for To Be and to Have  his captivating 2002 portrait of a rural schoolteacher  Mr. Philibert has switched his gaze to a primate with rather less agency: a 40-year-old female orangutan in the zoo at the Jardin des Plantes in Paris.

title: Prep Stays Hot as Lilly Pulitzer Is Sold for $60 Million
description: A retrospective of Lilly Pulitzers offerings, linked to from Oxfords Web site.

title: A Mans Slow Suicidal Walk to Starvation in the Forest
description: If The Sound of Insects were a book, about halfway through youd probably want to slam it shut and throw it against the wall. Actually it did start as a book  or two. The Swiss director Peter Liechti has adapted a novel by the Japanese writer Shimada Masahiko, itself based on the real diary of a man who went to the forest to commit suicide by the torturously slow method of starving himself to death.

title: U.S. Adds to Iran Sanctions Shortly After Nuclear Talks
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Tuesday imposed new sanctions on Iran, serving notice that it will not ease the pressure on Tehran just because it has begun talking again with the West about its nuclear program.

title: Lots of Laughs, and Even More Sales
description: IN the fall of 2008, when the Snuggie, a blanket with sleeves, was introduced in an infomercial, it was mocked by television hosts including Jay Leno and Ellen DeGeneres and went viral, garnering millions of viewings on YouTube and spawning hundreds of parody commercials.

title: Times Sues City Police, Saying Information Has Been Illegally Withheld
description: The New York Times has sued the New York Police Department, saying the department had routinely violated a state law that requires government agencies to provide information to the press and the public.

title: Frank Baldino Jr., Founder of Pharmaceutical Company, Dies at 57
description: Frank Baldino Jr. who founded the pharmaceutical company Cephalon, best known for the drug Provigil, which is used to increase alertness, died Thursday in Philadelphia. He was 57.

title: How to Submit Modern Love Essays
description: The editors of Modern Love are interested in receiving deeply personal essays about contemporary relationships, marriage, dating, parenthood...any subject that might reasonably fit under the heading Modern Love. Ideally, essays should spring from some central dilemma the writer has faced in his or her life. It helps if the situation has a contemporary edge, though this is not essential. Most important is that the writing be emotionally honest and the story be freshly and compellingly told.

title: Colleges Rethink R.O.T.C. After Dont Ask Repeal
description: The Senate vote to repeal the 17-year old dont ask, dont tell policy against gay men and lesbians serving openly in the armed forces removes a reason that many elite colleges have cited for barring the Reserve Officers Training Corps from recruiting on their campuses.

title: Names of Big Tens New Football Divisions Are Criticized
description: Ever since Penn State became the 11th member of the Big Ten in 1990, the name of the countrys oldest athletic conference has been a target of jokes and even ridicule. The conference is again under attack, this time for naming its two new football divisions the Legends and the Leaders.

title: The Mexico Quandary: Safety or Savings?
description: WHEN Alex Trettin and his wife, Jenn, suggested to family and friends that they take a group vacation to Mexico, the reaction was mixed. About half of the group of 29 immediately signed on for the November trip to the Riviera Maya, south of Cancn, where they would visit Maya ruins, fish and lounge by the pool at an upscale resort for the bargain price of $150 a person a night. The other half hesitated, citing concern about Mexicos continuing drug war.

title: Hit by a Truck and Given Up for Dead, a Woman Fights Back
description: He reached for her hand. It had been five weeks since the accident. Emilie Gossiaux, 21, lay in a bed in the surgical intensive-care unit at Bellevue Hospital Center. She could not see. She could not hear. Beyond asking for water, she spoke very little. Her boyfriend, Alan Lundgard, 21, took her left palm in his.

title: Energy Policy in Iran Leaves Many Gasping
description: TEHRAN  One of Tehrans signature landscapes  the imposing, rugged line of the Alborz Mountains at the citys northern boundary  has suddenly become an elusive one. Instead, Tehranis eyes, and complaints, have turned toward a dense and noxious wall of smog that has only rarely lifted during the past two months.

title: Far From Family, an Immigrant Fights Cancer and the Cold
description: Every weekday at 8 a.m., Efrenngton Armijos, 50, makes an arduous trek. Bundled up in layers  but wearing loafers that expose his ankles  he braces himself for Decembers piercing weather.

title: Felton Gives Knicks a Point of Comparison
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Teammates would probably love and appreciate Raymond Felton even if he did not buy them stylish stereo accessories. But it does not hurt.

title: Comments by Overseer of BP Fund Irk Lawyers
description: For months, lawyers suing BP have fumed as Kenneth R. Feinberg, the administrator of the $20 billion fund to compensate victims of the Gulf Coast oil spill, has encouraged people to seek relief from the fund instead of through the courts.

title: In a Sign of Foreclosure Flaws, Suits Claim Break-Ins by Banks
description: TRUCKEE, Calif.  When Mimi Ash arrived at her mountain chalet here for a weekend ski trip, she discovered that someone had broken into the home and changed the locks.

title: Fair Play Shows Up in the Standings
description: EDINA, Minn.  Some youth games in this hockey-mad state were a bloodbath just a few years ago, said Bill Smith, a coach in this Twin Cities suburb for more than 20 years.

title: Report: House Staffers Could Make More on the Outside
description: Budgets in the House of Representatives will soon undergo some trimming, if Representative John A. Boehner, the incoming speaker, has his way. But according to a new report, congressional staffing levels have already fallen off over the last three decades and many House staffers could be paid significantly more for similar work in the private sector.

description: Belgrade Lakes, Me.

title: Bloomberg Makes a Proposal on Youth Prisons
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Tuesday that he would ask New York State to turn over control of prisons and services for juvenile offenders to local governments, a move that he said would end the failed and costly practice of shipping troubled young people from New York City to upstate facilities far from their families.

title: Former Inspector Who Faked Safety Tests Is Sentenced
description: A federal judge on Tuesday sentenced an ailing former safety inspector to more than five years in prison for faking hundreds of asbestos and lead test reports, saying that his crimes were monumental and had put New York Citys residents at risk.

title: Detainee Review Proposal Is Prepared for Obama
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas advisers have been drafting an executive order that would set up a system for periodically reviewing the cases of Guantnamo prisoners whom courts have approved for detention without trial, officials said.

description: To the Editor:

description: Hartford

title: Firefighter Charged With Speeding and Texting Before Hit-and-Run
description: An off-duty Brooklyn firefighter was speeding in his sport utility vehicle and sending a text message from his cellphone when he struck and killed a Guatemalan immigrant in October, an indictment unsealed on Tuesday charged.

title: Lottery Numbers
Stopgap Bill Hamstrings Government Programs
description: WASHINGTON  The Securities and Exchange Commission has stopped hiring and halted most travel by agency officials.

title: U.S. Proposes Posted Notice of the Right to Unionize
description: The National Labor Relations Board said on Tuesday that it would require companies to post notices on their bulletin boards  and perhaps send out e-mail to inform employees of their right to unionize under federal law.

title: Walsh Out of Sight, but Not Out of the Loop
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Donnie Walsh missed the resurgence and the regression, Carmelos visit, Pierces shot and LeBrons demolition. But he plans to be back in his familiar seat at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night when the Knicks host the Oklahoma City Thunder.

title: Minister Loses Sway After Remarks
description: The British business secretary, Vince Cable, was stripped of authority for media and telecommunications policy and barred from a role in the News Corporations proposed takeover of the British Sky Broadcasting Group after he was quoted on Tuesday as saying he had declared war on Rupert Murdoch, the companys chief executive.

title: Cerberus, Recouping Costs, Will Sell Chrysler Financial
description: The private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management will get back much of its troubled bet on the auto industry as a result of Tuesdays sale of Chrysler Financial to Toronto-Dominion Bank for $6.3 billion.

title: Payroll Project Designer Loses a Transit Contract
description: The state comptroller said on Tuesday that his office had rejected a new $118 million contract between New York City Transit and a Virginia engineering company whose huge information technology project it has designed for the city is now at the center of an alleged $80 million corruption scheme.

title: My Magi: Crab, Crocodile and Sea Horse
description: WASHINGTON

title: Obama Nuclear Agenda Only Gets Harder After Treaty
description: WASHINGTON  The new arms control treaty with Russia, whose ratification now seems assured, was initially envisioned as a speed bump on President Obamas nuclear agenda, a modest reduction in nuclear forces that would enable him to tackle much harder issues on the way to his dream of eventually eliminating nuclear weapons altogether.

title: The Tax-Cap Illusion
description: At a time when Americans are feeling overburdened, capping property taxes can sound like a great idea. It certainly does to Andrew Cuomo, the governor-elect of New York. But a tax cap sounds a lot more helpful than it is. It is a blunt instrument that ends up punishing many of the taxpayers and communities in need of relief.

title: American Airlines Leaves Orbitz
description: The AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, said Tuesday it would immediately stop displaying and selling tickets through Orbitz Worldwide after winning court permission to pull its listings from the online travel site.

title: Gov. Barbours Dream World
description: In Gov. Haley Barbours hazy, dream-coated South, the civil-rights era was an easy transition for his Mississippi hometown of Yazoo City. As he told the Weekly Standard recently, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was an unmemorable speaker, and notorious White Citizens Councils protected the world from violent racists.

title: Bearzots Defiant World Cup Triumph Changed Soccer in Italy
description: The Italy team that won the 1982 World Cup in Spain outpaces the 2006 championship squad in celebrity, even 28 years removed from the Azzurris triumph. The 82 team defied both convention and expectation under Coach Enzo Bearzot, who galvanized a group of players beleaguered by scandal and criticism, including the excitable striker Paolo Rossi and the Bunyanesque goalkeeper Dino Zoff.

title: New York Will Lose Two House Seats, and New Jersey One
description: WASHINGTON  New York will lose 2 of its 29 seats in the House, while New Jersey will lose 1 of its 13 seats, because of population shifts reported by the Census Bureau on Tuesday.

title: Wednesday: Sic et Non
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  This is the second crossword from Michael Sharp. My post on his debut was not only great fun to compose, it generated by far the most e-mail of anything Ive written for The New York Times. Judging by my in-box, the self-proclaimed King of CrossWorld is a decidedly divisive figure. Blogging under the pseudonym Rex Parker, hes famous for his venomous attacks on puzzles he finds subpar. To his credit, though, hes not afraid to put his own work on the line, knowing it may invite the same kind of criticism.

title: An Unpaid Debt
description: Anyone who was in New York City on Sept. 11, 2001, remembers how the ash, paper and dust of the collapsing towers blew across Lower Manhattan. For days afterward, there was that peculiar smell  of burned paper and chemicals and death. That was the air that filled the lungs of tens of thousands of firefighters, police officers, nurses, paramedics, soldiers and civilian volunteers who toiled for months to uncover the dead.

title: State Taking Steps to Control Nassaus Finances
description: A state oversight board on Tuesday moved a step closer to seizing control of Nassau Countys finances, saying the county had failed to close a $350 million budget deficit despite months of dire warnings.

title: Housing for Hurricane Victims
description: The recession has made it impossible for Louisiana and other gulf states to replace thousands of affordable housing units swept away five years ago by Hurricanes Katrina and Rita. Congress tried to fix this problem last week with a one-year extension of a tax-credit program that encourages companies to invest in affordable housing as a way of offsetting tax liabilities.

title: A Scientist, His Work and a Climate Reckoning
description: MAUNA LOA OBSERVATORY, Hawaii  Two gray machines sit inside a pair of utilitarian buildings here, sniffing the fresh breezes that blow across thousands of miles of ocean.

title: Mauna Loas Measurements
description: Scientists at the Mauna Loa Observatory in Hawaii have been measuring carbon dioxide in the atmosphere for decades.

title: Does the Keeling Curve Still Need a Keeling?
description: In my long article in Wednesdays paper on the rising level of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, I mention that two programs financed by taxpayers conduct measurements at the Mauna Loa Observatory in Hawaii and other locales. Some people who read the article may ask themselves: Do we really need two?

title: Last-Ditch Move to Block Repeal of Dont Ask, Dont Tell Fails
description: 12:18 a.m. | Updated Just hours before President Obama planned to sign on Wednesday the repeal of the militarys 17-year ban on gays serving openly in the armed forces, Republicans tried one last legislative maneuver to block the change.

title: Interview With Will Shortz
description: This is my final interview for Wordplay, and Ive saved the best for last. The name Will Shortz is on every crossword that The New York Times has published since Nov. 21, 1993. He doesnt create them himself. Rather, he relies on a carefully nurtured army of freelance constructors who flood his mailbox with submissions, all competing for that most coveted spot in puzzledom, the crossword page in The Times. Only a fraction make it to print.

title: A Tough Sell at Sears
description: This holiday season, Sears and Kmart, which merged in 2005, are pushing a single message: Buy with layaway, buy with coupons, buy now and pay later, buy with loyalty rewards points  but please, just buy.

title: For Golfers, Fore Isnt Last Word on Ducking
description: An errant shot that left a man blind in one eye has produced a message for golfers: you are not responsible for all of your bad shots.

title: U.S. Ordered to Pay Group of Muslims
description: WASHINGTON  A federal judge ordered the government on Tuesday to pay nearly $2.6 million in lawyers fees and damages to officials with a shuttered Islamic charity in Oregon who the judge said were wiretapped without a court order under the surveillance program approved by President George W. Bush after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

title: With 89th Consecutive Win, UConn Sets New Division I Record
description: With UConns 93-62 defeat of Florida State at sold-out XL Center, the Huskies surpassed the 88 games won by the U.C.L.A. men, coached by John Wooden, from 1971 to 1974.

title: History Beyond Boston
description: When I was growing up in the Boston suburbs, we never gave the city much thought. It was good for a Red Sox game, the occasional school field trip to Paul Reveres house, and, in high school, the liquor stores that didnt card. (Wait, did I say that out loud?)

title: DNI Clapper Looks Stumped by ABCs Sawyer
description: 11:16 p.m. | Updated

title: Left at a Loss
description: Across Africa and the developing world, a new global land rush is gobbling up large expanses of arable land and displacing farmers.

title: African Farmers Displaced as Investors Move In
description: SOUMOUNI, Mali  The half-dozen strangers who descended on this remote West African village brought its hand-to-mouth farmers alarming news: their humble fields, tilled from one generation to the next, were now controlled by Libyas leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, and the farmers would all have to leave.

title: Photo Replay: Dec. 21
description: The day in sports included World Cup Alpine skiing in Courchevel, France, and a record night on the basketball court in Hartford.

title: Insurance Institute Names Top Safety Picks for 2011
description: The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety revealed on Wednesday its picks for the safest vehicles of 2011.

title: Phys Ed: Lifting Weights After Breast Cancer
description: Last year, an influential study examined whether breast cancer survivors with lymphedema could safely lift weights. Lymphedema, a painful and even disabling swelling of the arm, is a dreaded complication of breast-cancer surgery, especially if a woman had lymph nodes removed. Experts long thought that hefting weight of almost any kind would contribute to lymphedema in breast-cancer survivors and advised them to avoid picking up or carrying heavy purses, grocery bags, suitcases or their own children and to steer away, by all means, from formal weight training. But in last years study, breast-cancer survivors with a history of lymphedema who completed a slow, progressive program of weight training suffered fewer subsequent flare-ups of the condition than women who didnt train, suggesting that weight lifting might actually combat lymphedema, not cause it.

title: Word of the Day | dubious
description: dubious \d-be-s also dy-\ adjective

title: Yankees to Pay Lowest Luxury-Tax Bill Since 2003
description: Not much has gone the Yankees way this off-season, but some relatively good news arrived Tuesday, when they were assessed their lowest luxury tax bill since 2003.

title: Lapse in Use of Border Documents
description: HOUSTON  A year and a half after the federal government strengthened rules on the documents needed to enter the country, millions of people are still being allowed to enter without passports or other hard-to-forge identification cards, a government audit has found.

title: Marcia Lewis, Stage Actress and Singer, Dies at 72
description: Marcia Lewis, an actress and singer known for bringing a comic brassiness to Broadway revivals of Grease and Chicago, died on Tuesday in Nashville. She was 72.

title: Eric Schmertz Dies at 84; Settled Many Labor Disputes
description: Eric J. Schmertz, who as one of the nations most relied-upon labor peacemakers helped resolve thousands of labor disputes, getting both the Rockettes and New York City cab drivers to end strikes in the 1960s, died on Saturday at his home in Mount Kisco, N.Y. A former dean of the Hofstra University School of Law, he was 84.

title: Helping Hallmark Greet Season After Season
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  Christmas hasnt come yet but Hallmark, like a fashion house, is already hard at work on next years line. There will be fewer cards with generic sayings like happy holidays and seasons greetings, continuing the backtracking from a much-criticized faith-neutral trend.

title: Patricia Thompson, TV Producer and Documentary Maker, Dies at 63
description: PARIS  Patricia Thompson, a Paris-based American television producer and an Emmy-winning documentary filmmaker, died here on Monday. She was 63.

title: Britain: Crossbow Cannibal Sentenced
description: A 40-year-old man who called himself the crossbow cannibal was sentenced to life in prison without parole on Tuesday after pleading guilty to the murders of three prostitutes in an 11-month period ending last May. In one of the killings, the victim was killed by a crossbow shot, dismembered and partly eaten before her remains were dumped in a river. The police said they would continue to investigate the possibility that the murderer, Stephen Griffiths, may have been a long-term serial killer. Mr. Griffiths, a Ph.D. student in criminology, told the police he had drawn some of his ideas for his killing rampage from 19th-century murders he had studied.

title: Mauritius: British Actions Protested
description: The island republic of Mauritius sued the British government on Tuesday, saying Britains decision to declare the disputed Chagos archipelago a marine reserve violated the 1982 United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea. The archipelago, a cluster of tiny islands in the Indian Ocean that includes the American military base on Diego Garcia, was kept by Britain when it granted Mauritius independence in 1968. In an interview, Prime Minister Navinchandra Ramgoolam of Mauritius said Britain had classified the area as a marine protective area to prevent the return of 2,000 islanders it forced out during the cold war  a claim bolstered by documents leaked recently by WikiLeaks. This whole matter has been based on deceit, and we are very angry, Mr. Ramgoolam said.

title: Ivory Coast: Embattled Leaders Offer
description: The Ivory Coast leader Laurent Gbagbo said Tuesday night that he would accept a commission of investigation from overseas to examine the results of the presidential election last month, which the United Nations and foreign powers say he lost to Alassane Ouattara. Speaking on state television, Mr. Gbagbo said he did not want any more bloodshed. Meanwhile, the United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, expressed concern over the safety of the peacekeeping mission in Ivory Coast; Nigeria evacuated its diplomats; the United States announced a travel ban on Mr. Gbagbo and his associates; and Mr. Ouattaras government called for a campaign of disobedience.

title: Israel: Tensions Rise Along Gaza Border
description: A rocket fired from Gaza fell close to a kindergarten in an Israeli village on Tuesday morning. Earlier, the Israeli Air Force struck several targets in Gaza in retaliation for a recent increase in rocket and mortar shell fire. Small groups appear to be behind the fire, but Israel says it holds Hamas, the Islamist organization that governs Gaza, responsible. Briefing a parliamentary committee, the Israeli military chief of staff, Lt. Gen. Gabi Ashkenazi, said the situation was fragile and explosive.

description: The following are among the findings of the census:

title: News Quiz | December 22, 2010
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Corrections
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: LVMH Raises Its Herms Stake to 20%
description: The fashion magnate Bernard Arnault has added to his holding in the luxury retailer Herms International, undeterred by a controlling family seemingly united against him and regulatory scrutiny of his methods, David Jolly reports in The New York Times.

title: Arizona: Hospital Loses Catholic Affiliation
description: Bishop Thomas J. Olmsted of Phoenix announced on Tuesday that St. Josephs Hospital and Medical Center could no longer identify itself as Roman Catholic because it violated church teachings by ending a womans pregnancy in 2009. Hospital administrators said the procedure was necessary to save her life, and stood by their decision even after Bishop Olmsted excommunicated a nun on the hospital ethics committee. The hospital, which receives no money from the Phoenix diocese, can no longer hold Masses. But Catholics can continue to work and be treated there.

title: Florida: Miami Mayor Faces Recall
description: Mayor Carlos Alvarez of Miami-Dade County faces a recall after opponents gathered enough signatures to force an election. The drive came after the county raised the property-tax rate to balance its budget. The county commission must call an election in 45 to 90 days, Harvey Ruvin, clerk of courts, said Tuesday. Recalls are also being sought in Chattanooga, Tenn., and Omaha after proposed tax increases.

title: In California, a Wary Eye on Hillsides as Rain Falls
description: LOS ANGELES  For a week now, Southern California has been doused, deluged and dumped on. And the most powerful drenching yet came Wednesday, as rain hammered the entire region causing flooding, mudslides and evacuations in the deserts, beach towns and valleys.

title: South Koreas Latest Military Exercises Draw Little Reaction From North Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Despite previous warnings of retaliation from North Korea, the South Korean military continued to defy the North on Wednesday by beginning a three-day naval drill in the Sea of Japan and scheduling an exercise by the army and air force about 30 miles from the North-South demilitarized zone.

title: Test Yourself | Math, Dec. 22, 2010
description: Test your math skills with todays question, created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article G.M. Finds a More Receptive Public.

description: Todays word, in association with the invaluable Oxford English Dictionary, is

title: But Are They Qualified? Iraqi Reactions to a New Government
description: BAGHDAD  Tuesdays news that Iraqs fractious lawmakers were finally ready to seat a new government after nine months of political deadlock fell during a 40-day Muslim holiday of mourning. But even without this somber overlay, reactions to the news were muted.

title: A Portrait by the Artist as a Young Man
description: WHO was Velzquez?

title: The Streets Were Alive. Levitt Was There.
description: As I became interested in photography, my older sister, Virginia, introduced me to the work of Helen Levitt by giving me a copy of A Way of Seeing (1965), an album of her wanderings through the neighborhoods of New York, capturing life in the street in the 1940s. Ms. Levitt immediately became my favorite photographer. She still is.

title: Andrew Johnson Dead
description: Andrew Johnson, expanded-President of the United States and member of the Senate from Tennessee, died at the house of his daughter, Mrs. W.R. Brown, near Elizabethtown, Carter County, Tenn., at 2 o'clock yesterday morning. The history this man leaves is a rare one. His career was remarkable, even in this country; it would have been quite impossible in any other. It presents the spectacle of a man who never went to school cession of posts of civil responsibility to the highest office in the land, and evincing his continued hold upon the popular heart by a subsequent election to the Senate in the teeth of a bitter personal and political opposition. Andrew Johnson was born in Raleigh, N.C., Dec. 29, 1808. His father, Jacob Johnson, who was in the humblest circumstances, was drowned while attempting to save the life of Editor Henderson, of the Raleigh Gazette, in 1812, and six years later young Andrew, at the age of ten, was apprenticed to a tailor named Selby. School was then out of the question, of course, and the outlook was that the young man would grow up to an illiterate life. But the intelle and the outlook was that the young man would grow up to an illiterate life. But the intellect that was in him was aroused through the instrumentality of a Raleigh gentleman, whose practice it was to read aloud to the tailor's employees from books of published speeches. The speeches of some of the British statesmen particularly attracted his attention, and he set about learning to read with the same determination which characterized his later life. By resolute application after work hours and in moments taken from sleep, he soon succeeded and was able to read the speeches and other books for himself. He left Raleigh in 1824, before his apprenticeship had expired, and went to Laurens Court House, S.C., where he worked two years at his trade, and then, after a return to Raleigh and a brief stay there, he removed with his mother to Greenville, Tenn. He soon married, and was fortunate enough to get a wife who was a helpmeet to him in every sense of the word. She set herself at once to supply his greatest lack, became his teacher, giving him such oral instruction as was possible while he was at work, and teaching him writing, arithmetic, and other branches at night. Under her faithful tuition he acquired a fair education. The native forces of his mind supplied the remaining elements of his success.

title: Lucretia Mott
description: Lucretia Mott died last evening at her residence, near Philadelphia, in her eighty-eighth year. Mrs. Mott, whose name was probably as widely known as that of any other public woman in this or the preceding generation, was born in the old whaling town of Nantucket on the 3d of January, 1793. Her maiden name was Coffin. When 11 years old, her parents removed to Boston, where she went to school, finishing her education at a young ladies' boarding school in Dutchess County, N.Y., in which, when only 15 years old, she became a teacher. In 1809 she rejoined her parents, who had removed to Philadelphia, and in 1811, two years later, was married to James Mott. She was then in her nineteenth year. Her husband went into partnership with her father, Mr. Coffin, and Mrs. Mott again turned her attention to educational matters. In 1817 she took charge of a school in Philadelphia, and in 1818 began to preach. She made extended pilgrimages through New-England, Pennsylvania, Maryland and parts of Virginia advocating Quaker principles and waging at the same time a vigorous warfare against the evils of intemperance and slavery. In the division of the Society of Friends in 1827 she adhered to the Hicksites. Mrs. Mott took a prominent part in organizing the American Anti-Slavery Society in Philadelphia in 1833, and was a delegate to the famous World's Anti-Slavery Convention in London in 1840, where, in company with other female delegates, she was refused admission on account of her sex. She was also prominent in the original Woman's Rights Convention held at Seneca Falls, N.Y., in 1848, over which her husband, James Mott, presided. During the last 30 years she has been conspicuous in such gatherings and in annual meetings of the Society of Friends. Among her published works are "Sermons to Medical Students" and "A Discourse on Women."

Victoria Beckhams first collection, a modest offering of just six styles ($1,800-$13,950), focuses on a central and alluring theme: 24 hours in the life of Victoria.

title: Involuntary Transparency

title: The Nutcracker Chronicles: Clara Without a Home
description: BERKELEY  In October I made my first visit to Hearst Castle. This month, farther up the California coast, I acquainted myself with a different aspect of its architect, Julia Morgan. In 1908 she designed what is now the Julia Morgan Center for the Arts but was then a Presbyterian church. Still beautiful today, it is not just all wood but all redwood.

title: Vineyard Theater Rounds Out Season By Interviewing the Audience
description: Next up at the Vineyard Theater, Off Broadway, are the new play Picked by Christopher Shinn (Dying City, Where Do We Live?) and a work developed by Zach Helm, perhaps best known as the screenwriter of Stranger Than Fiction, which depends largely on audience participation, the theater company announced on Wednesday.

title: Comcast Takeover of NBC Is Delayed Until Next Year
description: 10:00 p.m. | Updated  The long-awaited completion of the takeover of NBC Universal by Comcast will have to wait until the new year.

description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration filed a case against China with the World Trade Organization on Wednesday, siding with an American labor union, the United Steelworkers, in accusing Beijing of illegally subsidizing the production of wind power equipment.

title: Jackson No Match for Swift and Boyle
description: On the Billboard album chart this week Taylor Swift edges past Susan Boyle to return to No. 1, and Michael Jacksons posthumously assembled new album opens at No. 3, with strong sales around the world.

title: What You Get for ... $545,000
description: BOTKINBURG, ARK.

title: Deaf Player at Cal State Northridge Has a Real Feel for the Game
description: ANAHEIM, Calif.  During the California, Berkeley mens basketball season opener last month against Cal State Northridge, the Straw Hat Band and the student cheering section tried to rattle Matadors forward Michael Lizarraga with chants of tuna every time he touched the ball.

title: Seeking a Meaningful Price on Carbon
description: One month ago, Wesleyan University hosted a weekend conference called Pricing Carbon. It was a revival meeting of sorts, bringing together about 500 economists, campaigners, scientists, students and lawmakers seeking, despite recent setbacks, to apply the age-old polluter pays principle to carbon.

title: The Doors Light One Last Fire in Response to Morrisons Pardon
description: A posthumous pardon granted by the State of Florida to Jim Morrison earlier this month was apparently not the end of a four-decade-old saga that began when Morrison, the Doors front man, gave a raucous performance at a Miami auditorium in 1969 that resulted in his being convicted of indecent exposure.

title: Now Skating | Icy Hot
description: Growing up on the East Coast, I used to regard mild-clime cities with pity around the holiday season. Winters without snow seemed an unnatural, slightly tacky curiosity (Plastic flamingo Santas? Twinkle-lit palm trees?). Then I moved to San Francisco, where winter is a slow, wet leak from fall to spring. Theres no clearly definable season between November and March, and one is as apt to break out the scarf in foggy July as in misty, flower-blooming December. All of which is to say Ive gotten more flexible about wintertime expectations.

title: Rome Museum Joins Young Architects Program
description: The Museum of Modern Art and MoMA PS1 have added a third partner to their jointly run annual Young Architects Program. The two museums will collaborate with MAXXI, the National Museum of the 21st Century Arts in Rome, in this years competition to transform the courtyard of MoMA PS1 in Long Island City, Queens, for the summer. There will also be a separate installation at MAXXI in Rome.

title: 9,300 Off-Road Buggies Recalled for Unintended Acceleration
description: About 9,300 off-road electric buggies are being recalled because of the danger of sudden, unintended acceleration, the Consumer Product Safety Commission stated in a news release Wednesday.

title: Computers That Trade on the News
description: The number-crunchers on Wall Street are starting to crunch something else: the news.

title: Can We Feel Good About Our Necks?
description: NECKS dont lie. Sagging there betrays age like the rings on a tree, and now-common Botox and fillers in the face make neck imperfections stand out in stark relief. In her 2006 best-seller, I Feel Bad About My Neck, Nora Ephron, by then 65 and a resolved turtleneck wearer, raged against the injustice of having no remedy for her slackening throat skin, short of surgery.

title: A Works Long Road to New York
description: In 1958, while in the Army, the composer Christian Wolff wrote a piece titled For 6 or 7 Players, then mailed his manuscript to his mentor, John Cage, without keeping a copy. Mr. Wolffs work, also known as Music for Merce Cunningham, was meant for use in Rune, a dance by Cunningham, but never served that purpose.

title: Obama Press Conference Will Cap Day of Accomplishment
description: The smile on his face said it all.

description: Lionheart has wisely developed a cottage industry in thematic Christmas programs, each built around the repertories and traditions of a single country.

title: Take it From Jordan: Quick Works in Ads Too
description: Somewhere along the way, Adidas lost track of what it was trying to market with their signature sneakers for Dwight Howard and Derrick Rose.

title: A Lisping Moment in History
description: When the Bagger met Tom Hooper, the director of The Kings Speech at the movies New York premiere weeks before Harvey Weinstein started rounding up anybody affiliated with it for promotional duties, we had an interesting talk about how the films narrative is helped by the formality of the period. Theres a lot of drama created by the constraints of how difficult it is for an Australian guy from a different class to interact with the king, Mr. Hooper said. Its like what they say about romantic comedies - whats the obstacle in them getting together? You have to invent them. When you go back in time, often theres so many obstacles, because of the social structures. Thats delicious, watching Geoffrey negotiate that with Colin.

title: Despite Economic Woes, Spain Continues Investment in Trains
description: MADRID  Spain overtook France this month as the country operating Europes biggest high-speed rail network, underlining the extent to which infrastructure spending has been at the heart of the countrys boom-and-bust economy.

title: Mats Zuccarello to Make Rangers Debut Against Lightning
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  With Marian Gaborik out for Thursdays home game against the Tampa Bay Lightning with a recurrence of his groin problems, the Rangers have summoned Mats Zuccarello from their A.H.L. affiliate in Hartford to make his N.H.L. debut.

title: Stop and Frisk? No, Stop n Swap
description: For New Yorkers whose New Years resolutions include getting organized or cleaning out their closets, the nonprofit group GrowNYC, which promotes recycling in the city, has scheduled stop n swap events in all five boroughs starting Jan. 8. The swaps are scheduled on Staten Island on Jan. 8, in Manhattan on Jan. 22, in the Bronx on Feb. 5, in Queens on Feb. 12 and in Brooklyn on Feb. 26. You can read about it from our colleagues at the Green blog.

title: Cupcakes for the Endangered Species Coalition
description: WE are saving panda bears here tonight, right? asked Waris Ahluwalia, the jewelry designer. Arden specifically told me that, if I showed up, I would save at least one panda bear.

title: Which Truth About Santa?
description: This morning, on Day 1 of our Santa-truth-athon, a guest post explored how often random strangers seem to promise visits from Mr. Claus to our children. This afternoon, a second reader explores unthinking sabotage from a less expected place  her childs school.

description: Six more banks have repaid the government bailout funds they received during the financial crisis, reaping $2.7 billion in proceeds for taxpayers, the Treasury Department announced Wednesday afternoon.

description: This has been a great year for the next new electronic thing. The iPad, new iPhone, the Nexus S, HTC Evo and other Android phones, the Kindle 3 and Microsofts Kinect caught the eye of consumers.

title: A Savory Pancake of Root Vegetables
description: I havent made latkes this season, maybe because Ive been getting my maximum daily requirement of oil in other forms. But the other night, when I was cooking dinner for a few friends and was in the kitchen wanting a snack as I finished making the meal, I ventured into alternative latke territory.

title: Reality About to Hit 76ers
description: I regret to inform you, adoring basketball public, that the franchise once known as the Philadelphia 76ers has been completely eviscerated. Im truly sorry for your loss.

description: IN 2003, for his thesis at Parsons the New School for Design, David Yassky wrote of womens fascination with wedding dresses, a subject Vera Wang once described as a mad, divine obsession.

title: Photo Replay: Dec. 22
description: The day in sports included college basketball in Lexington, Ky., and ice sailing in the Netherlands.

title: Hive Health at the Solstice
description: Being a schoolteacher doesnt allow me much time for beekeeping maintenance during the shorter days of winter. I leave for school in the dark (actually at sunrise, which can be quite spectacular) and I come back home in the dark. My only bee-related activity is to switch on the floodlights when I get home to make sure the hives havent been knocked asunder by any bears (unlikely, this year, after New Jerseys recent bear cull).

title: So Long, Bailey Building & Loan
description: This is the time of year when families gather to watch Jimmy Stewart play George Bailey, the small-town banker who learns the value of extending credit to his neighbors with a little angelic intervention in Its a Wonderful Life. Though Mr. Bailey remains emblematic of a benign banking system, most Americans probably dont realize hes the most endangered species in finance.

title: Rodgers Likely to Start Against Giants
description: Aaron Rodgerss streak of 46 consecutive starts at quarterback for the Green Bay Packers was interrupted last week after a concussion  his second this season  on Dec. 12 against the Lions. And as much as he wanted to play, it wasnt advisable or feasible for him to start against New England last week. Time off and monitoring from the Green Bay medical staff have helped and now, Rodgers appears ready to start in a pivotal matchup with the Giants on Sunday.

title: A Cynical Position Overcome With Yoga
description: Why did Claire Dederer take up yoga? Short answer: for the same kinds of reasons that Elizabeth Gilbert changed her life in Eat, Pray, Love, and to much the same funny, charming, self-deprecating, stealthily inspirational and (quite possibly) best-selling effect.

title: Small-Business Research Bill Becomes Law, Sort of
description: Back in July 2009, the Small Business Innovation Research program seemed on the cusp of a new lease on life and a makeover. The program, in which the big research grant-making federal departments and agencies set aside a small fraction of those grants for small business, was set to expire at the end of the month, but the House had passed H.R. 2965, the Enhancing Small Business Research and Innovation Act of 2009. The Senate had followed suit, renaming the bill the S.B.I.R./S.T.T.R. Reauthorization Act of 2009. (S.T.T.R. stands for Small Business Technology Transfer, a similar program.)

title: On Our Radar: Coal Shortage Worsens in China
description: Power cuts and blackouts hit factories and residential neighborhoods in central China as coal supplies dwindle at generating stations. Supplies were strained after a surge in power demand after a cold weather front hit the region this week. Two power stations have completely run out of coal, and 14 other stations have only a few days supply, reports said. [Global Times]

title: Memorable Moments of 2010: Metropolitan
description: These images complement 2010: The Year in Pictures.

title: Not Too Large, Not Too Small, but Spoiling for a Fight
description: Male hissing cockroaches in Madagascar are aggressive creatures that ram one anothers heads and flip one another over. They can also flick their abdomens to forcefully whack another male.

title: The Gift of Guns, Courtesy of Cerberus
description: For employees of AlixPartners, finding a last-minute holiday gift may have gotten a little easier.

title: Skype Goes Out
description: 10:10 a.m. | Updated A day after suffering a widespread outage of its Internet telephone service, Skype was continuing to try to fully restore service. In a blog post at around noon on Thursday, the company said that it had seen evidence of a significant increase in the number of people online to around 10 million (it has hosted as many as 25 million on normal days). Skype added that instant messaging and group video conferencing would take longer to restore.

title: We Are Not Doomed to Endless Gridlock
description: President Obama on Wednesday declared the lame-duck session of Congress to be the most productive post-election period that we have had in decades and promised to continue seeking common ground next year.

title: The Key Was Getting West to Hold Tight to That King
description: Ask any of the top New York area players for their favorite event on the local calendar and many will answer that its the Von Zedtwitz Double Knockout. As the name implies, a team must lose twice to be eliminated. And often when the final is played, one team is undefeated and the other once defeated. Then the once defeated must win two matches to take the title.

title: Hollywoods Class Warfare
description: THE idea of the universal middle class is a pervasive expression of American egalitarianism  and perhaps the only one left. In politics the middle has all but swallowed up the ends. Tax cuts aimed at the wealthy and social programs that largely benefit the poor must always be presented as, above all, good for the middle class, a group that thus seems to include nearly everyone. It is also a group that is, at least judging from the political rhetoric of the last 20 years, perennially in trouble: shrinking, forgotten, frustrated, afraid of falling down and scrambling to keep up.

title: He Looks Like a Big, Scary Guy, but Really ...
description: MICHAEL SHANNON arrived at Frankies Spuntino in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, and avoided the busy back room, preferring to slip into a lone table up front. But at 6 foot 4 with a giant noggin topped off by a brow that could serve as a balcony, hes tough to miss. Add in the fact that he has been nominated for an Academy Award (Revolutionary Road), is currently starring in a bravura one-man show off Broadway (Mistakes Were Made) and finished a season as a vividly conflicted character in a big cable series (HBOs Boardwalk Empire), and his days of landing unnoticed are over. The table in front hangs out over the sidewalk, with a kind of proscenium above it, and passing Brooklynites couldnt help but stare: Oh yeah, that guy, the big, scary one.

title: The Smallest Dancers Steal Their Own Show
description: Something romantic about the 19th century made it a great era for artists to enter into the imaginations of children. Thanks to Tchaikovskys music  with its blend of fantasy, humor, suspense and vehemence, and its Gullivers Travels-type changes of scale between the miniature and the colossal  its not too much to place the The Nutcracker ballet among the many great 19th-century depictions of childhood. It takes company among E. T. A. Hoffmanns original Nutcracker tale, Jane Eyre, David Copperfield, Hans Christian Andersens tales, Huckleberry Finn, the Alice books and the opera Hnsel und Gretel.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: 'Blue Valentine'
description: Derek Cianfrance, the director of Blue Valentine, discusses a scene from the film which is on DVD May 10.

title: A Marriages Death, and Post-Mortem
description: BLUE VALENTINE, the festival hit that played at Sundance and Cannes this year and made headlines when it received an NC-17 rating (since changed to an R), is not the first drama to toy with chronology in telling the story of a tumultuous relationship. Harold Pinters 1978 play Betrayal (filmed in 1983) depicts an adulterous affair from end to beginning. A couple of recent French domestic tragedies, Gaspar Nos Irrevrsible and Franois Ozons 5 x 2, similarly chart a backward progression, from misery to bliss. Madcap love stories like Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind and (500) Days of Summer have also experimented with scrambled timelines.

title: Where the Beers and the Jeers Flow Freely
description: New Years Eve 2008. My boyfriend and I are at our local bar in Brooklyn. He is drinking a pint of Smithwicks, and I am nursing a Jameson, neat. I take small sips, and the bartender eyes me. Cheap date, I am.

title: Schmoozing in the Service of an Oscar
description: On Monday night in a basement screening room in Midtown Manhattan, using little more than the allure of a free cocktail and a passing hors doeuvre, the Oscar-season force that is Harvey Weinstein gathered together a few potentially influential people for a screening of The Kings Speech. Kathleen Turner, Joel Grey and Bill Irwin turned up, as did the filmmaker Derek Cianfrance. Not two weeks before, Mr. Weinstein, who runs the Weinstein Company with his brother, Bob, had successfully petitioned the Motion Picture Association of America to change the rating for Mr. Cianfrances labor-of-love relationship film, Blue Valentine, from NC-17 to R. So there Mr. Cianfrance was, indebted, gamely chatting with all comers in the service of someone elses moody drama.

title: Shopping With Seth Box
description: The director of education for Mot Hennessy USA searched for Champagne-worthy glassware.

title: With Common Application, Many Find a Technical Difficulty in Common, Too
description: The Common Application, the admission form accepted by more than 400 colleges and universities, was created in part to ease the burden on high school seniors. No longer must applicants fill out a dozen different forms to apply to a dozen schools, including the nations most selective.

title: Memorable Moments of 2010: Sports
description: Thursday, 4:45 | Updated We hear you. Any collection of pictures that purports to show memorable moments in sports ought to include the World Series champions  yes, we can say it, the San Francisco Giants  and more than one photo from the World Cup. So here they are. Also, please be sure to see 2010: The Year in Pictures.

title: A Common Glitch in the Common Application
description: If you or your child has ever struggled with the print preview function of the Common Application  which sometimes reveals that a short-answer essay that appeared to fit as it was entered into the form has now been cut off midsentence  you may want to look at an article just posted on The Timess Web site.

title: Restaurateur Ejects Los Angeles Times Critic
description: If you are an owner of a restaurant that keeps a critic waiting for a table, you could spend the rest of the night trying to make it all better. Or you could just throw the critic out on the street.

description: A new category of cameras can fit in a pocket, but still have sensors large enough to give sharp photos with good color, even in low light.

title: Putting the Sweet in Swedish
description: A wave of new places is bringing some excitement to Stockholms cafe scene.
