description: IF Kenneth Bowser, a New York documentary filmmaker, succeeds in his crusade to rehabilitate the 1960s protest singer Phil Ochs, hell have his daughter to thank.

title: Brown Leaves Early, This Time From Bobcats
description: Larry Browns stay with the Charlotte Bobcats ended much the same way his other jobs had  prematurely.

title: Google Adds the Human Body to Its Search Functions
description: On Dec. 16, Google released the first version of its Body Browser, a simulation of the human body. Users can travel, as in the 1980s movie Innerspace, through various layers of human anatomy, zooming in on internal organs, navigating around bones and peeling back layers of the human body until all thats left are the stringy tangles of the nervous system.

title: Happy Holidays From the Nets, JibJab Style
description: The Jets werent the only team dealing with home video issues this week.

title: While Choptank Dries Out, Spasso Prepares to Make a Splash
description: Timing is everything. Just ask Bobby Werhane. Choptank, his Maryland seafood restaurant on Bleecker Street, flooded last week. The restaurant is a double storefront and though only half of it was affected by the water gushing down from an upstairs apartment, his attempt to keep the dry half open ended after the health department said that the fruit flies gathering there would result in a C grade. So the whole thing is closed until mid-January.

title: Theater Talkback: A Holiday Wish for Better Holiday Theater
description: Despite being described as instantly forgettable and a theatrical lump of coal by some critics, Elf, the adaptation of the Will Ferrell movie, has become a huge hit, grossing more than any show on Broadway last week except for The Lion King and Wicked. Audiences have also ignored the dismissive reviews for Donny & Marie: A Broadway Christmas, one of only a handful of shows that topped $1 million in weekly ticket sales.

title: Life on a Houseboat Moored on the Nile
description: CAIRO

title: Support for Israels Settlements From Europes Right
description: As my colleague Ethan Bronner reports, Israelis are divided over a West Bank settlement construction boom.

title: 9/11 Payments Must Start Next Month, Judge Says
description: Just as the Senate passed a bill to cover the medical costs of 9/11 rescue and cleanup workers, a federal judge in Manhattan said on Wednesday that payments to a subset of those workers  the more than 10,000 plaintiffs who settled their lawsuits with the city last month  must start going out by late January.

title: Trading Up: Jewelry for Men
description: Its hard to find simple, discreet jewelry. Here are some examples and suggestions to help you start your search.

title: In the Web of Jewelry for Men
description: WOMEN may have valid gripes with fashion and its narrow definition of an acceptable body image. But they cant say they dont have choices. In terms of style, professional men have their own corset to wrestle with, one with mere millimeters of wiggle room for lapel size, collar length, tie width and cuff length, and a palette drab enough to make a sparrow feel pavonine by comparison.

title: Ready for the Golf Years, a Couple Holds an Estate Sale
description: Mimi and Bob Buzbee moved into a golf course community in Austin, Tex., two weeks ago but left many of their belongings in their old house across town. The couple hired a local estate sale organizer, Downsizing Estates, to sell the items for a 40 percent commission before the house closes at the end of this month.

title: For Estate Sales, Boom Times
description: IT took a few years but Rachel Reeves of Long Beach, Calif., found the exact bedside tables she was searching for at an estate sale last month. Made in the 1950s from cherry wood, they had a colonial revival look, with tapered legs and carved ridges in the drawers. And at $20 for the pair, the price was right.

title: My Own Private Wyoming
description: IN 1995 I bought a three-year-old log house in Centennial, a tiny southeastern Wyoming town on the slope of the Medicine Bow range in the Rockies. The setting was close to a national forest and exquisitely beautiful, with many miles of ideal mountain hiking, bicycling and ski trails. But the house was wrong for me. During the frustrating time that I lived in it, I wrote an article describing what I thought was my ideal house and began looking for property on which I could build. It took more than 10 years to find what I believed to be the right place.

title: Pies on Earth
description: A holiday greeting by. R.O. Blechman

title: A French Museum Inspires a Mexican Chair
description: Casamidy is based in San Miguel de Allende, a bastion of colonial Mexico, but many of the companys furniture designs are drawn from other cultures. Its new Hiver Opera side chair is an example.

title: A Designer Who Gives Christmas Trees an Afterlife
description: Many people feel a sense of regret when it comes time to dispose of a Christmas tree. After being decorated and celebrated, the tree is unceremoniously abandoned, which can seem both heartless and wasteful.

title: Champagne Glasses
description: AS director of education for Mot Hennessy USA, Seth Box is responsible for spreading the word about his companys spirits, wines and Champagnes  including Dom Prignon, Krug, Veuve Clicquot, Mot et Chandon and Ruinart  to as many people as possible. Simply put: he regularly takes people out for drinks.

title: This Lamps Wiring Is There for All to Enjoy
description: For its new Wire Nest lighting series, the Gold Leaf Design Group in Chicago has taken a mundane material  iron wire  and turned it into a focal point.

title: Top Hat, an Imports Store, Opens in SoHo
description: Nina Allen, who imports intriguing oddities through her wholesale company Sweet Bella, seems happy not to be noticed. When she recently decided to open a store, she chose a charming block on Broome Street, between Ludlow and Orchard, that lacks the traffic of the SoHo blocks farther west.

title: For the Hyper-Neat, a Special Strain Comes With the Season
description: THE only things that mess up the designer Mary McDonalds exquisitely staged, picture-ready holiday parties are the guests.

title: Sales at Room & Board, MoMA Design Store and Others
description: All porcelain animal busts are 50 percent off at Site, both in-store and online (the ram head, usually $250, is $125; the gazelle, pictured, usually $150, is $75); 35-11 34th Avenue (35th Street), Astoria, (718) 626-6030 or shopsiteonline.com.

title: For City Fowl, a Coop to Cluck About
description: For urban farmers looking to retain some big-city sophistication, there is a New York-style solution for housing egg-laying birds: the Chicken Co-op ($3,500). Designed by James Ramsey of RAAD Studio in Manhattan, the three-story structure features stacked nesting rooms and floor-to-ceiling windows.

title: A Dyed-and-True Imprint
description: IT is rare for fabric makers to get much buzz, let alone credit in fashion bibles like Vogue and Lucky magazines. But Audrey Louise Reynolds, a 27-year-old self-taught designer who lives in Brooklyn, has emerged as the fashion worlds artisanal fabric dyer.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: Hacker Attacks
description: Hacker attacks are nothing new, but several popular Web sites have been targets in the past few weeks. Bettina Edelstein discusses the recent security scrambles with Brian Stelter, the New York Times reporter who covered the security breach at Gawker Media this month.

title: 12 Days of Christmas Gifts Cost 9.2% More This Year
description: Even those with a big year-end bonus may think twice about showering a loved one this year with the fanciful mix of piping pipers, leaping lords and assorted birds lauded in choruses of the classic carol The 12 Days of Christmas.

title: Renewed Interest in Converting Natural Gas Into Diesel
description: WASHINGTON  Diesel and jet fuel are usually made from crude oil. But with oil prices rising even as a glut of natural gas keeps prices for that fuel extraordinarily cheap, a bit of expensive alchemy is suddenly starting to look financially appealing: turning natural gas into liquid fuels.

title: Beauty Spots
description: BUFF AND BUBBLY Harried Upper West Siders looking to set down their shopping bags for a manicure should consider Polished Beauty Bar (polishedbb.com), an eco-friendly nail salon on West 78th Street between Broadway and West End Avenue. Polished is offering a free glass of Champagne for every festive color chosen from its 300-shade, nontoxic Zoya collection (no formaldehyde, toluene or DBP  dibutyl phthalate) through Dec. 31. Monday to Wednesday, receive a free manicure with every pedicure (a $43 value for $30, plus tax and tip).

title: Palmer Trading Company: A Twice-Told Tale
description: July 1, 1974

title: European Deal Makers Place Hopes in Emerging Markets

They may face deportation, according to the Immigration and Customs Enforcement department. They did not have access to secure areas of the airport, authorities said.

title: Alaska: Court Ruling Favors Murkowski
description: Joe Miller, the Republican Senate candidate, lost another legal battle when the State Supreme Court ruled Wednesday that voters do not have to spell a write-in candidates name perfectly for their vote to be counted. Citing decades of legal precedent, the court ruled that votes should count as long as election officials can determine a voters intent. The court also ruled that there was no evidence of fraud or other irregularities in the election. Unofficial state election results show Mr. Miller losing by more than 10,000 votes to Senator Lisa Murkowski, whom he defeated in the Republican primary in August. Ms. Murkowski later returned to the race as a write-in candidate. She declared victory on Nov. 17, after a hand count of write-in votes showed her well ahead. Mr. Miller has not conceded, and he has prevented certification of the race through repeated legal challenges in state and federal court.

There would be less negativity in society if we each woke up with a smile, she said. Ms. Chapman, 28, attracted the most attention of those in the spy ring, and since her return to Russia, has continued to enjoy the spotlight. She posed in lingerie for a Russian mens magazine, and her public appearances are regularly featured in the Russia media.

title: Irans New Foreign Minister Appears in Istanbul
description: Ali Akbar Salehi made his first international appearance as Irans foreign minister on Wednesday at an economic summit meeting in Istanbul. Mr. Salehi, a former head of the Iranian Atomic Energy Council, was named to replace Manouchehr Mottaki last week in a surprise move by President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran, who also attended the Istanbul meeting. Mr. Salehi reiterated his trust in Turkeys diplomatic efforts to help find a resolution in coming talks over Irans nuclear program between Iranian officials and the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council  the United States, Britain, France, Russia and China, as well as Germany. Turkey is hosting the meeting. When Mr. Salehi was named to the new post, some Iran observers speculated that Mr. Ahmadinejad might try to replace him with a permanent candidate from his inner circle.

title: Argentina: Ex-Dictator Sentenced in Murders
description: Jorge Videla, a former Argentine dictator, was sentenced to life in prison on Wednesday in the murder of 31 political prisoners who were killed after the 1976 coup that swept him into power. Mr. Videla, 85, is considered to have been the main force behind the violence known as the dirty war that included the forced disappearances of up to an estimated 30,000 people through 1983. In April, Argentinas Supreme Court overturned a 1990 pardon for Mr. Videla and other military men involved in the dictatorship, paving the way for him to be tried for murder, kidnapping and torture, in the case that led to Wednesdays sentence. He was sentenced to life in prison in 1985 after another trial, in which he was convicted of murder, torture and other crimes. On Tuesday Mr. Videla told the court that yesterdays enemies are in power and from there, they are trying to establish a Marxist regime.

title: Iraq: Safety Concerns Mute Christmas Celebrations

In the southern city of Basra, home to about 2,000 Christians, church leaders said they had canceled a New Years Eve celebration. Since the assault on the Baghdad church, a new wave of Christians has been fleeing to northern Iraq or abroad.

title: Seeing Things | Seasons Seatings
description: Although its lovely to have a fresh Christmas tree, the sight of all those bedraggled branches left at the curb in January is nothing short of depressing. But in London this season, theres an alternative to the wood chipper: the Christmas Tree Project, a collaboration betweenGallery Libby Sellers and the up-and-coming designer Fabien Cappello. The project is an extension of Cappellos 2009 graduation work at the Royal College of Art, and will recycle spruces, pines and firs into unique, handcrafted three-legged stools designed by Cappello. The stools, which cost about $621 each, can be ordered from the United States too. Obviously, a buyer from the States wont be able to send in a tree to be recycled, but there will be plenty of orphans available in London, where its estimated that most of this years 976,000 Christmas trees will simply be thrown away. And not only will the trees get new lives; the Woodland Trust, a leading conservation organization in Britain, will get a portion of the profits.

What if Im the one 35-year-old who drops dead of a brain tumor while you try to figure out whats wrong? he asked.

But a certain other show has been generating more news and attention than any Broadway production in many years; even if the Daisy folks put wires on Ms. Redgrave and sent her flying above the audience, it still wouldve been hard to break through the press coverage over at the Foxwoods Theater this week. (Anyway, Ms. Redgrave flies just fine with her feet on the ground, thank you.)

Larry Brown resigning from an N.B.A. team (or being fired, or mysteriously finding the locks changed on his office door) falls into the category of the sun rising in the morning or snow falling in winter. title: A Rock Star and His Cartoonist Alter Ego
description: MY CHEMICAL ROMANCE is a cartoony kind of band, and that suits the frontman, Gerard Way. Since the group  including the guitarists Ray Toro and Frank Iero and Mr. Ways younger brother, the bassist Mikey Way  formed in 2001, it has developed a glam-emo aesthetic that seems sprung from a dark and glossy comic book. Its new album, Danger Days: The True Lives of the Fabulous Killjoys (Reprise), is full of anthemic tracks that imagine a postapocalyptic future. Gerard Way, 33, created Umbrella Academy, a comic book published by Dark Horse about a family of atypical superheroes. Melena Ryzik spoke by phone with Mr. Way at a tour stop in Detroit about discovering his favorite album of the year, Treats, by the Brooklyn band Sleigh Bells, and how he was influenced by Brit pop growing up in New Jersey. At the time, everything in America was so macho, he said. The British stuff was the opposite of macho. I heard the Smiths, and that really changed everything for me. This is an edited version of their conversation.

title: 36 Hours in Marrakesh, Morocco
description: IN 1939, George Orwell wrote of Westerners flocking to Marrakesh in search of camels, castles, palm-trees, Foreign Legionnaires, brass trays and bandits. Ever since, the city has been ravishing visitors with its teeming souks, ornate palaces and sybaritic night life. In recent years, a succession of high-end openings and restorations  most notably, the lavish reopening of the hotel La Mamounia  has transformed the city into an obligatory stop for jet-setters. Yet despite Marrakeshs new cachet, the true treasures of the enigmatic city still hide down dusty side streets and behind sagging storefronts.

title: Los Angeles Museum to Oversee Watts Towers
description: The Los Angeles County Museum of Art said on Thursday that it had completed an agreement with the City of Los Angeles that puts the museum in charge of efforts to repair and preserve the Watts Towers, the cathedral-like spires and crockery-encrusted forms built by the self-taught artist Simon Rodia in his spare time over more than three decades. The towers, which were once almost demolished by the city and then later designated a national landmark, were damaged slightly in the 1994 earthquake and again during a 2008 windstorm.

title: Extremist in Monastery Is Still One Outside It

A virginal 20-year-old theology student who is first seen in a monastery where she is preparing to take her vows, Hadewijch, as she is called by the nuns, spends much of her time on her knees, praying before a cross on the wall above her bunk bed in a bare, cell-like room.

title: Face the Music
description: One of my relatives, a professional pianist, held a party last year. When we arrived, he was playing piano in the living room, where drinks were being served. Hes having another party this year, but I dont want to sit through a forced recital. We go to his performances and enjoy them, but theres a time and place for everything, no?

title: Spiritual Seeker With a Taste For the Satirical
description: Every so often we are shocked  shocked!  to learn that a great artist was not such a great human being. In these disillusioned modern times, we have learned to separate artistic and literary achievement from the artists moral character. We may admire the works of Tolstoy, Cline, Picasso and Pollock and overlook their failings as people. Still, the fantasy that spiritual and artistic evolution should go hand in hand is hard to give up.

Mark Bradford, a 49-year-old Californian, is one of these rethinkers, and a lean, bright 10-year survey of his work at the Institute of Contemporary Art here gives a sense of what hes been up to.

title: Shopping, not Watching
description: In advance of Christmas few Americans opted to tune in to network television during prime time on Wednesday. According to Nielsens estimates a rerun of CBSs Criminal Minds led the night with just 6.9 million viewers at 9 p.m., while a repeat of the networks 10 p.m. legal drama The Defenders drew 5.6 million. Although both shows delivered high enough ratings to put CBS on top for the night, the networks annual special A Home for the Holidays lagged behind all three of its major network competitors in the 8 p.m. time slot, attracting 3.9 million viewers. Fox and NBC tied for second place over all with Fox broadcasting new episodes of Human Target (5.8 million) and Million Dollar Money Drop (4.8 million) and NBC earning relatively decent ratings for repeats of Law & Order: SVU at 9 (5 million) and 10 (6.5 million). NBCs new episode of Undercovers at 8 garnered 4.2 million viewers. ABC finished close behind the other networks in fourth place with sitcom reruns from 8 to 9:30 followed by a holiday special CMA Country Christmas, which averaged 4.3 million viewers from 9:30 to 11.

Parliament passed a motion on Wednesday night asking the government to pull out of the treaty recognizing the court. title: The Man Who Brought Trout to a Valley of Gravel
description: PAGOSA SPRINGS, Colo.  The Rio Blanco tumbles out of a range of 12,000-foot mountains in the San Juan National Forest into a picture-perfect valley thats reminiscent of a miniature Yosemite. In its upper reaches, the Blanco runs in a whitewater cascade, where native cutthroat trout thrive. In the valley, on the meadowland of El Rancho Pinoso, a privately owned ranch that rents out cabins and provides fly-fishing access, the water slows and deepens, providing an excellent habitat for introduced rainbows that frequently exceed 20 inches.

description: NATIONAL

title: A Harmonious Split, Unlike the Others
description: Larry Brown, the serial monogamist of basketball coaches, broke up with another team this week, in traditional Larry Brown fashion. He griped about his players, blamed himself and then disappeared with a news release, as he has so many times before.

title: 7 People Shot, 3 Fatally, on Violent Day in Newark
description: Seven people were shot, three of them fatally, in an explosion of violence in Newark on Thursday evening. The bloodshed was part of a spate of shootings and violent carjackings  including the carjacking of a state official  in the city over the last month.

title: Ranger Has Impressive Debut in an 11-Round Shootout Loss
description: The Norwegian Hobbit Wizard did a lot of things right and only one thing wrong in his N.H.L. debut, the Rangers 4-3 shootout loss to Tampa Bay at Madison Square Garden on Thursday night. The Hobbit Wizard is better known as 23-year-old Mats Zuccarello, a 5-foot-7 wing from Oslo who starred for Norway at the Vancouver Olympics, spent two seasons as a top scorer in the Swedish Elitserien and was called up by the Rangers on Wednesday from the Connecticut Whale of the American Hockey League.

title: Blockbuster Creditor Sues Icahn
description: A creditor in the Blockbuster bankruptcy sued the billionaire Carl C. Icahn over claims that he improperly converted his equity stake to debt to take control of the company after its reorganization.

title: Clay Cole, Host of Teenage Dance Shows, Dies at 72
description: Clay Cole, whose dance program The Clay Cole Show had a loyal following among adolescent television viewers in the New York area in the 1960s and gave many groups, including the Rolling Stones, early exposure on American television, died on Saturday at his home on Oak Island, N.C. He was 72.

description: Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark went off without injury or any major technical hitch on Thursday night in its first performance back on Broadway since a stunt actor was badly injured after falling more than 20 feet during a scene in Monday nights show.

description: MUMBAI, India  Indias financial capital was on high alert Friday after authorities said four terrorists had entered the country and were plotting attacks here during the holidays.

title: Santa Safari
description: I went on safari this season to track down the true Santa Claus. I found whole herds of them. But which was real? At my first stop, the annual parade of Sidewalk Santas sponsored by the Volunteers of America, I saw several dozen walking up Fifth Avenue as tourists gawked. The next stop was SantaCon, an event that defines itself as a chance for guys and girls of legal age to dress up like Santa and go cavorting around town. I was startled by the sight of hundreds of Santas crowding streets and bars before gathering at Bethesda Fountain in Central Park. Among them was at least one Jack Skellington Santa, channeling the spirit of The Nightmare Before Christmas,alongside a Santa whose suit was adorned with a much-repeated line from A Christmas Story: Youll shoot your eye out, kid. I found a rickshaw wallah who dresses like Santa. I asked him why. It seems to make people happy, he said. I tracked down the Santa of the Radio City Christmas Spectacular  a Kentucky native, it turns out  in his dressing room at the music hall, where hes been reporting to work for 24 years. Of course, I went to the prime preserve, at Macys Santaland. There, I found a 4-year-old girl curled up on Santas lap and thought of Edmund Gwenns portrayal of Kris Kringle in Miracle on 34th Street. It dawned on me that everyone Id seen was the real Santa, because Santa is whomever we want him to be.

description: My dog and I reacted to my rejection from Yale in largely the same way.

description: SHANGHAI  Prosecutors in Shanghai said on Friday that they had detained three government officials for their role in a high-rise apartment fire here last month that killed 58 people and injured about 70 others.

description: NEW DELHI  In a ruling that outraged human rights advocates, an Indian court on Friday sentenced a doctor to life imprisonment on charges that he committed sedition by aiding Maoist rebels in rural India.

description: In an article in Wednesdays Times, I discussed the rapid increase of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, and the scientific debate over the likely consequences of that rise. One point I did not emphasize much is the extent to which we all own a piece of this problem.

title: Insurance Rate Forecast: Cloudy, Chance of Rises
description: FOR many drivers, trying to figure out where auto insurance premiums are headed is like trying to catch butterflies: just when you get close, they fly off in another direction.

title: More Consumers Are Letting Insurers Monitor Their Mileage
description: CAR insurance rates have always been based on risk, and risk has usually been measured by the number of miles driven. So drivers often underreport the miles they travel to keep their rates low  at the expense of other drivers.

title: The Zeros
description: Nickname for those on Wall Street who may receive no bonuses at all this year.

title: Did He Leave a Forwarding Address? Yes, the North Pole
description: The theme of the party was Christmas 1962; when I opened the door to Jim and Dylans apartment in Chelsea, I felt as if I had been transported back in time. Their place was draped in white lights and evergreen boughs, strewn with lines of pastel ornaments and 1960s Christmas wrap.

title: Reviewing the Chevrolet Volt
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, Lawrence Ulrich evaluates the 2011 Chevrolet Volt.

title: Burning Calories, but Not a Hole in Your Wallet
description: CLAIRE ALBA is determined to nail two New Years resolutions at once: staying fit and saving money.

title: Saving Money on Fitness
description: Expensive gym memberships and fancy equipment are not a requirement to stay fit. Those looking to cut back on their expenses may find big savings in changing where and how they exercise.

title: Putting That Tax Holiday to Work
description: The biggest Christmas present that many people will get this year comes from the federal government. And most will probably fritter it away.

title: Ideas for Using the 2011 Payroll Tax Break
description: In this weekends Your Money column, I encourage readers to be deliberate with the extra money most people are getting in 2011 thanks to a 2 percentage point break on Social Security taxes. It could be worth more than $4,000 in some affluent households, but because it will arrive in many paychecks in regular drips and drabs over the course of the year, plenty of people will fritter it away unthinkingly.

title: Jewelry Theft Can Take the Sparkle Out of a Holiday
description: THERE is nothing like jewelry to brighten Christmas morning. But while these presents may have been wrapped and put under the tree with care, they are more likely to vanish this month and next than at any other time during the year.

title: Medvedev Praises Obama for New Start Treaty
description: MOSCOW  Russias president, Dmitri A. Medvedev, on Friday called the New Start treaty a cornerstone of security for the coming decades, and spoke warmly of President Obama, saying that under very difficult circumstances, he managed to make the Senate ratify this document.

title: BlackBerrys and iPads Come to the House Floor
description: Tucked into a new rule proposed by the incoming House Republican majority are three little words that could fling the chamber  for good or ill  into the 21st century: that impairs decorum.

title: Tapping a Rough-and-Tumble Life
description: FOR 17 years he was the beefy, impassive security guard on the 11 p.m.-to-7 a.m. shift at the lobby desk of Brittany Hall, a New York University dormitory just off Broadway. He checked ID cards, broke up fights and confiscated beer from under-age drinkers with the quip Im going to show you the true definition of alcohol abuse, before pouring it into the trash. Now and then a student would chat him up for company in the wee hours  learning that he was born in the Bronx in the summer of 68, that he was a Marine in the 1980s, that he had been an N.Y.U. student but left after junior year and rode a Harley out to San Francisco to read his own poetry where the Beats once blew. But mostly people passed right by, or regarded him as a curiosity, like the student who once said, Omigod, the security guard is reading Shakespeare.

title: Self-Portrait Of the Oilman As Collector
description: AT an Amsterdam auction in 1938 an anonymous American walked away with a Rembrandt for a rock-bottom $65,000. Joseph Duveen, long the pre-eminent art dealer on both sides of the Atlantic, was peeved. Who is this American, he asked his agents in Europe.

title: Friday Reading: The Best Magazine Essays of 2010
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Museum Shows Leap Beyond The Frame
description: ON the surface the atrium of the Museum of Modern Art would seem to be a dismal place for dance. There is nothing resembling a proscenium stage in its sparkling white vicinity. The floor isnt sprung. Crowds can be as thick as Grand Central at rush hour, and those milling about arent exactly compelled to stand at rapt attention. In a museum setting performance art  by way of, say, Marina Abramovic  is one thing. Dance is something else: peripheral, elusive and in need of expensive lighting equipment.

title: Alt-Verdi: Otello, Differently
description: THERE are several classic recordings of Verdis late masterpiece Otello. If you could own only one, the new version conducted by Colin Davis (LSO Live 0700; two CDs) would probably not be the best choice.

title: Talking Points From a Year Onstage
description: THE full-time critics Top 10 lists are settled, and Tony nominations are months away. But the slowest time of the theater year gives other reviewers, writers and editors for The New York Times the chance to recall some of the more offbeat highlights of 2010  and to look well beyond the confines of Broadway, where plenty of the limelight shines already. Here are moments we wont soon forget:

title: Want to Be a Star? Take Your Lumps
description: OPERATIC history abounds in tales of unknowns who stepped in when a star bowed out and emerged as stars in their turn. Thanks to two such episodes in cities far away, the Russian soprano Marina Poplavskaya, 33, is now in the singular position of headlining back-to-back Metropolitan Opera premieres of major productions she has pretested elsewhere, both of works by Verdi.

title: Dec. 26  Jan. 1
description: Dance

title: Merry Christmas
description: The Schotts Vocab blog is taking some festive time off, and would like to wish all co-vocabularists a very Merry Christmas.

title: Multimedia King? Survey Says, Steve Harvey
description: LETS review Steve Harveys year. (This may take a while.) His syndicated radio show has an audience of six million, and President Obama has been one of his guests. A version of the show appears in prime time on the Centric cable channel. He became the host of the long-running Family Feud game show. His advice book Act Like a Lady, Think Like a Man spent a good part of the past two years on The New York Timess hardcover advice best-seller list, was No. 1 for 23 weeks, and is being made into a movie by Screen Gems. The recently published sequel, Straight Talk, No Chaser, had an initial printing of 750,000 copies and makes its debut at No. 1 on the advice list on Sunday.

title: Trilling Songbirds Clip Their Wings
description: AS symbolic shifts go, two recent events in pop music couldnt have been more illuminating. On Nov. 24 Burlesque, a big-screen musical starring Christina Aguilera, opened and landed with a thud, both critically and at the box office. On Dec. 2 came the Grammy Award nominations. Among releases up for the album of the year award are those by Lady Gaga and Katy Perry; Ms. Aguilera, who also released an album, Bionic, in 2010, was ignored.

title: Tree Man | The Long Goodbye
description: The is the last of a series chronicling the experiences of a Christmas tree seller on Broadway.

title: Film About Transgender Father Is Banned in Thailand
description: Thailands film board has banned a movie about a transgender father struggling to raise two children, The Associated Press reported on Friday. The National Film Board ruled on Wednesday that the film, Insects in the Backyard, cannot be shown in Thailand because it contains scenes that are immoral and pornographic. The board objected to several scenes, including at least one that showed an explicit depiction of two men having sex, culture and film officials said.

title: 2010: The Year in Pictures  Bearing Witness
description: In the Week in Review section of The New York Times our colleague Michael Kamber has written a powerful essay on conflict photojournalism which contains a moving tribute to Joao Silva, the New York Times photographer who lost both his legs to a land mine while on patrol with American forces outside Kandahar on Oct. 23. He is currently undergoing rehabilitation at Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington, where he will remain for the foreseeable future.

title: Greek Bishop Equates Zionism to Satanism
description: A Greek Orthodox bishop who was criticized by Jewish groups, the Greek government and some coreligionists for blaming Greeces financial problems on a conspiracy of Jewish bankers and claiming that the Holocaust was orchestrated by Zionists issued a statement on Thursday in which he denied that he was anti-Semitic but also equated Zionism to Satanism.

title: A Holiday Smile
Nigeria Drops Bribery Charges Against Cheney
description: The Nigerian authorities have dropped criminal bribery charges against Halliburton and Dick Cheney, the former vice president, following the oil services giants agreement to a $35 million settlement, the company said in statement this week. Nigerian officials said last week that the settlement would amount to $250 million.

title: Last-Minute Gifts: E-Books
description: Ive been giving you last-minute gift suggestions music, videos and video games.

title: More Storms Snarl European Travel
description: Another storm hit western Europe, slowing air travel from Paris, Amsterdam and Germany. Heathrow in London, though, began operating close to normally, after delays and cancellations earlier this week.

title: For Investors, the Glow Is Off U.S. Stock Funds
description: THE love affair of American investors with the stock market appears to have ended.

title: Yes, There Are Prisons
description: In answer to Scrooges question, yes indeed there are. And lots and lost of prisoners.

title: Three Pianos to Play a Week Longer
description: Let the wine keep flowing: Three Pianos, a boisterously irreverent salute to Schubert in which three pianists get increasingly party-hearty while running through the whole of his 24-song cycle Winterreise, has extended its run at the New York Theater Workshop by a week. The show will finish on Jan. 16, making room for rehearsals of the theaters next production, Peter and the Starcatcher.Created and performed by Rick Burkhardt, Alec Duffy and Dave Malloy, Three Pianos originated at the Ontological-Hysteric Theater and after a short successful run was added to the New York Theater Workshop schedule, where critics were again largely positive.

title: The Nutcracker Chronicles: Nut/Cracked
description: By this stage of December, its increasingly hard work to fend off the music of the Sugar Plum solo. Last weekend in Las Vegas I was eating a burger when I heard the familiar twinkle-twink celesta music, looked up and saw a TV ad for a GMC Sierra ending with the onscreen title Nutcracker. The next day in a cab from JFK I encountered the same music  this time accompanying a section of Jimmy Kimmel Live illustrating some aspect of the Twelve Days of Christmas.

title: Covering Climate from Cancn to Katmandu
description: Long before negotiations over strengthening an ailing climate treaty concluded in Cancn, Mexico, with a muted, incremental agreement to keep on negotiating, it was clear that this wasnt going to be much of a news event.

title: Lawsuit Filed Over Black Swan Production Credit
description: A New York film production company has sued its former president, claiming that gross lapses in judgment cost the company millions of dollars in lost revenue and a producer credit on the movie Black Swan, Reuters reported on Thursday. The defendant, Aaron Kaufman, called the claims baseless. Black Swan, starring Natalie Portman, is considered an Oscar favorite and has been nominated for four Golden Globe awards. In a lawsuit filed in Manhattan federal court, the production company, Overnight L.L.C., led by Rick Schwartz, accuses Mr. Kaufman of misrepresenting his skill and experience and pretending to be knowledgeable about the financing of motion pictures when he was not. Mr. Schwartz, who was credited as executive producer on Black Swan, has helped produce the movies Machete, Gangs of New York, The Aviator and The Others. Mr. Kaufman said it was only after he joined the company and helped secure a role in the production of Machete and Black Swan that Mr. Schwartz was able to produce any films.

title: Up Front: Dale Peck
description: The novelist and literary critic Dale Peck is also the author of several childrens books.

title: Thomas Bernhard, the Alienator
description: For the sympathetic Anglophone charged with reviewing newly translated texts by the Austrian playwright and novelist Thomas Bernhard, the task is a paradoxically onerous one. Put aside the near certainty that Bernhard would have disparaged anything you might say about his work  not just disparaged it, but attacked it with an acid-tongued rant that eviscerated your words, your intellect and your pathetic petit-bourgeois existence. You still have to deal with the almost overwhelming ambition, common to Bernhard fans, to correct his woeful stature in the English-speaking world, as well as the equally oppressive realization that opportunities for doing so are fast running out.

title: Whats So Funny?
description: The British historian Paul Johnson manages to make Humorists, his collection of 14 biographical essays about funny people, fairly pedestrian for most of its brief length. Until the last few pages, when he makes it odious.

title: Broiled Sardines With Lemon and Thyme
description: Mark Bittman makes fresh sardines, restaurant-style, with crisp skin and smoky flavor.

title: Chasing Virtue
description: Early in Poser, Claire Dederer describes a regular walk she takes with a new-mom friend in her North Seattle neighborhood: We made a circle around Green Lake, and so our talk traveled. We started with our babies and tried to decipher all the new rules we had to follow. The talk opened out to work, maybe briefly touched the real world, and then, like a tight magic circle, closed back in on babies again. It was a dark enchantment.

title: Very Last-Minute Gifts: Digital Craft Patterns
description: If you are reading this for gift ideas at this hour, you are probably at wits end. I already tried e-books, music, videos and video games.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: A Trip to Ancient Japan
description: The latest volume  No. 55!  of the series Inuyasha lands at No. 10 on the manga list this week. Inuyasha is about a high-school girl who is not only pulled into Japans ancient past, she is also bound to a demon. In this installment, Inyuasha mounts an attack on the demon, Naraku, who is up to his usual deceptions. Over by the paperbacks, it was only a matter of time until this happened: the list has been taken over by the slacker series Scott Pilgrim and the zombie survival drama that is The Walking Dead.

title: No Quotation Marks on These Sardines
description: FOR years, the only kind of sardines available to the average American were packed in oil, water or tomato sauce, sold in little rectangular cans, first with keys and later with pop-tops.

title: Ringing in the New Year With Blini
description: People make the party, but blini are always an exciting addition. As Martha Rose Shulman writes in this weeks Recipes for Health:

title: Restaurant-Style Fresh Sardines
description: If you think all sardines are canned, youre in for a treat. Fresh sardines are enjoying something of a renaissance, and in this Minimalist column, I suggest an easy way to cook them.

title: Arabian Knight
description: Lowell Thomas, the pioneering American journalist and filmmaker, was buying dates on a Jerusalem street soon after the holy city had been wrested from Turkish control by British forces in 1917, when he spotted a group of Arabs, led by a most remarkable figure. A single Bedouin who stood out in sharp relief from his companions; . . . in his belt was fastened the short curved sword of a prince of Mecca, . . . marking him every inch a king. . . . This young man was blond as a Scandinavian. . . . His expression was serene, almost saintly, in its selflessness and repose.

title: Play Their Hearts Out
description: Chapter One

title: Breaks of the Game
description: In 2004, the star-making machine, in the form of a Sports Illustrated reporter, descended on a 14-year-old basketball player from Fontana, Calif., named Demetrius Walker. The scouting newsletter The Hoop Scoop had recently proclaimed Walker the best eighth grader in the country; now the pre-eminent sports magazine was going to take that hype to a new level. While the article about Walker carried the requisite caveats  about whether he would fulfill his potential and whether it was even fair to be placing such expectations on a kid  it described him as 14 going on LeBron. The reason was not just Walkers physical gifts, but also his Amateur Athletic Union coach, Joe Keller, who, according to Keller himself, was keeping Walker on a righteous path  arranging for him to be home-schooled by a tutor, checking to make sure he did his academic work and paying as much attention to the boys well-being as to his jump shot. Im not going to get a thing out of this, Keller told S.I. My only hope is that maybe, one day, when Demetrius is in the N.B.A., he can come back and sponsor my team.

title: For Years End, Decadent Quiche
description: I GAVE up the whole notion of New Years resolutions decades ago. After years of having my best December intentions fade to dust by the end of the first week of January, I stopped making promises.

title: Recipe for Friendship
description: As Always, Julia is an epistolary love story, a romance that began with a fan letter and the gift of a paring knife. The letter was to the writer and historian Bernard DeVoto, who had written in Harpers about impossibly dull stainless-steel knives. The fan was an ambitious American cook, Julia Child, then living in Paris. The reply came from DeVotos wife and general factotum, Avis. Within months, she and Child had gone from Mrs. to Avis and Julia, my pet! Even in the 1950s, things moved fast.

title: Long, Last, Happy
description: Water Liars

title: Oh, the Sweet Terror
description: Barry Hannah, who died of a heart attack on March 1, was a matchless stylist  a word hed most likely have hated, but all the same. Flip any of his eight novels and four previous story collections open and some rocket of prose will come bursting out:

title: Notes From a Kidnapping
description: After the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, the Pulitzer Prize-winning reporter David Rohde says, he considered joining the military or becoming a paramedic. Instead, he was thrilled to be dispatched by his editors at The New York Times to Afghanistan, to cover the fighting there.

title: The Gothamist
description: Early in Edith Whartons House of Mirth, Lily Bart is offered some wisdom about how to live in the dazzling yet potentially deadening realm of the rich and well born: The real alchemy, her suitor, Lawrence Selden, tells her, consists in being able to turn gold back again into something else; and thats the secret that most of your friends have lost.

title: Faith and Modernity
description: Every winter Fox News, seeking to stir up anger through the land, uncovers evidence of a war on Christmas. Secular humanists ignorant of religion and hostile to its traditions, someone in the studio will declare, want us to say Happy Holiday or give Kwanzaa equal standing. But Christmas, as its name suggests, is about Christ. These enemies of Christianity will stop at nothing to get their way. Not even Santa Claus is sacred to them.

title: Starry Messenger
description: Galileo Galilei, martyr of science in the picturesque 19th-century expression, has undoubtedly attracted more biographers than Copernicus, Kepler, Newton and Einstein combined. His run-in with the Roman Catholic Church over the motion of the earth, his forced confession and his famous stage-whispered riposte  e pur si muove, but yet it moves (which surely was never delivered)  are all the makings of high drama.

title: Thieves Paradise
description: Among the unfortunate legacies of the financial crisis of 2008 is a tendency among commentators to soft-pedal the outrage over what happened. In too many accounts, blame is considered impossible to assign given the complexities of modern-day finance. Those inclined to point fingers at Wall Street or Washington are frequently derided as innocents who do not grasp how the world really works.

title: A City and Stage
description: Extraordinary Renditions is either Andrew Ervins first collection of stories or his first novel. Even his publishers seem unable to decide. It consists of three overlapping narratives, all set in contemporary Budapest, with some coincidences of character, location and incident; but its hard at times not to feel that the underlying rationale binding these stories together is a simple pun. The title refers, obviously, to the practice, developed by the United States government, of moving terrorism suspects to countries less concerned by judicial process for interrogation. Not much less obviously, rendition can also refer to a musical performance.

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: DANIEL  By Henning Mankell.Translated by Steven T. Murray.  New Press, $26.95.

title: Record Set for Worlds Youngest Chess Champion
description: Hou Yifan, a 16-year-old chess player from China, became the youngest world chess champion on Friday, toppling a record held since 1978.

title: 16-Year-Old Is Youngest Chess Champion in History
description: Hou Yifan, a 16-year-old Chinese chess player, is on top of the womens chess world.

title: Editors Choice
description: CANTI,  by Giacomo Leopardi. Translated by Jonathan Galassi (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $35.) With Galassis definitive English translation, Leopardi may at last become as important to American literature as, say, Rilke or Baudelaire, poets of comparable genius.

title: Paperback Row
description: ANATHEM,  by Neal Stephenson (Harper Perennial, $16.99.) Set in a world similar but not identical to our own, Anathem imagines a monastic order whose members contemplate issues of math, physics and philosophy, and live their lives without electronic technology. But Stephensons hero, an ascetic named Erasmas, and his order are called back into the world to save civilization from an extraterrestrial crisis. Stephenson delights in the language and etymology he has designed for his fictional world . . . and in the 7,000 years of detailed history he has given it, Dave Itzkoff wrote in the Book Review.

title: One Sentence Says It All
description: No book worth its salt is meant to put you to sleep, says the garrulous shoemaker who narrates the Czech novelist Bohumil Hrabals Dancing Lessons for the Advanced in Age (1964), its meant to make you jump out of bed in your underwear and run and beat the authors brains out. Thirty-three pages into what appears to be an unbroken highway of text, the reader might well wonder if thats a mission statement or an invitation. Dancing Lessons unfurls as a single, sometimes maddening sentence that ends after 117 pages without a period, giving the impression that the opinionated, randy old cobbler will go on jawing ad infinitum. But the gambit works. His exuberant ramblings gain a propulsion that would be lost if the comma splices were curbed, the phrases divided into sentences. And theres something about that slab of wordage that carries the eye forward, promising an intensity simply unattainable by your regularly punctuated novel.

title: Baker Street Irregular
description: Any fanatical admirer of Sherlock Holmes knows how he spent the Great Hiatus, those dark years between his dramatic tumble over the Reichenbach Falls in The Final Problem and his sensational re-emergence in The Empty House. (Unbeknownst even to Watson, Holmes faked his own death and had been traveling incognito in Persia, Egypt, Tibet and other exotic locales.) But aside from writing The Exploits of Brigadier Gerard and several other works, touring in Egypt, lecturing in America, serving as a war correspondent in Sudan, supervising a hospital in Cape Town during the Boer War and standing for Parliament, what was Arthur Conan Doyle doing before he brought his great detective back from the grave?

title: A Variety of Ways Not to Have Christmas
description: Its a holiday from work and school. Its wrapping paper torn and scattered about the tree. For the fortunate, its a family dinner with good food and minimal drama. But for two groups of people in particular, Christmas is a time to feel like a minority.

title: The Week in Pictures for Dec. 24
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include unemployed OTB workers, the next phase of the High Line, and Christmas lights.

title: Arrests Made in Stradivarius Theft
description: Three people were arrested for stealing an antique violin worth nearly $2 million from an internationally acclaimed musician while she stopped for a snack at a London sandwich bar, the Associated Press reported on Friday. The South Korean violinist Min-Jin Kym was eating at a sandwich shop outside Euston Station on Nov. 29 when she noticed that her black violin case  which contained a Stradivarius and two valuable bows  was missing, according to the police. The violin, made in 1696, is one of about 400 made by Stradivarius that are still known to exist. The police arrested and charged John Maughan, 26, and two teenagers on Wednesday. The names of the youths, 16 and 14 years old, were not included in news reports because of British law. Mr. Maughan is in custody and the two teenagers are free on bail. The instrument has not yet been recovered and an insurance company has offered a reward for information. Ms. Kym, who is 32, began playing the violin at 6, made her international debut with the Berlin Symphony Orchestra when she was 13 and has performed with other leading orchestras.

title: G.E. to Sell Mexican Mortgage Unit to Santander
description: General Electrics finance unit, GE Capital, agreed on Friday to sell its Mexican consumer mortgage division to Santander of Spain for 2 billion pesos, or $162 million, part of the industrial giants strategy to sell off noncore financial assets.

title: Hollywood Dispute Pits Parking Against Organic Food
description: LOS ANGELES  On weekdays, Ivar Avenue is a quiet strip of Hollywood, with a theater, a recording studio, a Jack in the Box, a gay and lesbian elderly housing complex and a film school. Every Sunday morning, it becomes the Hollywood Farmers Market, four bustling blocks of farm and food stands offering everything from oyster mushrooms to California sea bass to a crowd of 8,000 people.

description: Which product was sold in stores first: Post-it Notes or the Sony Walkman?

title: The Nutcracker Chronicles: The Not So Greatest Russian Nutcracker
description: Oh, these competitive Russians! No sooner did I begin this Nutcracker marathon in mid-November by watching the so-called Great Russian Nutcracker (the Moscow Ballet, on simultaneous tours of both East and West Coasts of America) than news arrived of a quite different touring production called The Greatest Russian Nutcracker. And whereas the Great Russian avoids the main ballet metropolises (I saw it at West Point), the Greatest Russian was coming to a place near me  the Tribeca Performing Arts Center.

title: A Santa App for Christmas
description: With Santa about to arrive, there is precious little time left to ramp up childrens excitement to visions-of-sugarplum levels.

title: Air Travel Survey Reveals Negative View of Screening
description: A survey of business and leisure air travelers commissioned by the U.S. Travel Association found that more of them described the current screening process as inconsistent, stressful, or embarrassing than described it as being fair or effective. But most respondents for the survey, released this week, said they believed it is possible to achieve an air travel screening system that is both secure and efficient.

title: Top of the World To You
description: Id like to wish the top of the world to you.

title: Democrats Seek Changes to Senate Procedures
description: WASHINGTON  Frustrated by routine filibusters and other procedural blockades, Senate Democrats are urging their leadership to negotiate with Republicans to change the rules that govern how the Senate does business.

title: Iraqi Christians Exercise Caution for Christmas
description: BAGHDAD  As they gathered to celebrate the birth of Jesus, the congregation here first contemplated death, represented by a spare Christmas tree decked with paper stars, each bearing a photograph of a member of a nearby church killed in a siege by Islamic militants in October.

title: For Some Iraqi Christians  Shelter in Istanbul
description: ISTANBUL  A small community of Iraqi Christians is spending this Christmas Eve in a small basement chapel at a community center in Istanbul, straining its 150-person capacity.

description: Kenrokuen Garden is the year-round star attraction in Kanazawa, a history-rich city in on Japans western coast.

title: In Kanazawa, Japan, Ancient Beauty Fuses With Modern Art
description: ON a sunny early November afternoon in the Japanese city of Kanazawa, the alchemy of autumn had already begun transforming the citys beloved Kenrokuen Garden from an oasis of leafy greens into a gold-tinged sanctuary. Workers were busy constructing yukitsuri  thick ropes tied to fragile tree branches, intended to brace them against heavy snowfalls  in dramatic pyramids that soar over the gnarled wood. And the transformation continues as the seasons progress.

title: Deaf Divers Sign in the Soundless Depths
description: AFTER sunset one evening in August, Wendy Dannels prepared for the first night dive of her life off Moalboal, a resort town on the Philippine island of Cebu. She was on a 10-day diving trip on a boat called the Philippine Siren.
