description: A slide show of images of cultural events this week.

title: Hawaiis Governor Takes On Birthers
description: HONOLULU  Gov. Neil Abercrombie of Hawaii, who befriended President Obamas parents when they were university students here, has been in office for less than three weeks. But he is so incensed over birthers  the conspiracy theorists who assert that Mr. Obama was born in Kenya and was thus not eligible to become president  that he is seeking ways to change state policy to allow him to release additional proof that the president was born in Honolulu in 1961.

title: Where the Clintons Spent the Night Before the Night Before
description: A call came in to the newsroom on a quiet Christmas Eve day with this little gem:

title: Dcor Preference: Historical Fiction
description: Though Angie Lake bought an apartment built postwar, she strove to make the interior look as if it had been around much longer.

title: Breakfast and Brunch Recipes
description: Ricotta pancakes, baked eggs with prosciutto, caramel-apple muffins and more dishes for the weekend.

title: Postwar in Name Only
description: ANGIE LAKE proudly describes herself as a prewar person, the sort of New Yorker deeply enamored of built-in bookshelves and decorative molding on every available surface. As she sums it up: I always lived in a place with a fireplace. And by that I mean a real fireplace.

title: Punch Pushes Cocktails Off the Menu at the Drink in Williamsburg
description: One of the unavoidable drinking trends of the fall has been punch. Hardly a cocktail bar has opened in New York in the past few months without giving a nod to the crystal bowl. Forty Four at the Royalton Hotel, 1534 on the Lower East Side and SoHos Lani Kai have all made room for punch in their programs. But the recently opened The Drink in Williamsburg has so devoted themselves to the format that the flowing bowls have actually knocked individual cocktails off the menu.

title: Styles, Trs Plural, Play Stages in Paris
description: PARIS  Is there any other ballet company in the world that offers the choreographic range of the Paris Opera Ballet with comparable panache? At the moment the almost imperial grandeur of the troupe is omnipresent at both the gleamingly modern Opra Bastille, with Rudolf Nureyevs Swan Lake, and at the gilded Palais Garnier, with a triple bill of works by George Balanchine, Trisha Brown and Pina Bausch.

title: Taurasi May Face Olympic Ban for Positive Drug Test
description: The Turkish basketball federation said Friday that the star player Diana Taurasi had tested positive for a stimulant that was identified as modafinil, a drug that enhances wakefulness and vigilance and is designed to treat narcolepsy, sleep apnea and sleep disorders related to shift work. Modafinil is also used off-label to combat jet lag and attention deficit disorder and recreationally to enhance alertness. The stimulant does not cause the anxiety and jitteriness associated with amphetamines.

title: In Britain, Many Glass Slippers to Fill
description: LONDON  Some sort of collective artistic unconscious determined that Cinderella would be the Nutcracker of this years Christmas dance season in Britain. There are no fewer than four productions dotted about the country, two of them in London: the Royal Ballets grand 1948 production by Frederick Ashton, and Matthew Bournes vividly imaginative reworking of the tale as a World War II romance, set during the Blitz. (The other two are versions by Ashley Page for the Scottish Ballet, and by David Bintley for the Birmingham Royal Ballet.)

title: Downsizing Without Downsides
description: THOUGH Wayne Gordon and Margaret Brown loved their three-bedroom condo on the Upper West Side, once their only child had grown up and moved out, they themselves were eager to move. Their home was too big and, especially, too expensive.

title: Trisha Brown at MoMA
description: The company will be included in the Modern's Performance Exhibition Series.

title: City Room: The Clintons Out on the Town
description: Wonder where the Clinton clan was on Thursday night? My colleague, Jodi Rudoren, has all the details over at The CityRoom blog. (Hint: think Father of the Bride and The Way You Look Tonight.)

title: Taking Risks, Making Odds
description: LAS VEGAS  Miles away from the glamour of the Las Vegas Strip, past foreclosed homes and dusty tracts of desert, the Wall Street bond powerhouse Cantor Fitzgerald has placed millions of dollars of its own money on the table.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Dec. 24
description: More Photographs

title: Falcons Snelling Raising Awareness About Epilepsy
description: It was a routine school day morning for Jason Snelling, who was 15. His big brother was leaning over his bed, trying to wake him. As with any teenager, it sometimes took coaxing and vigorous pushing and pulling to get him out of bed. This time, however, things went much differently than expected.

title: Exalted Views, Down-to-Earth Prices
description: AS Fitzgerald might have said, people who live on hills are different from you and me. From Murray Hill to Carnegie Hill in Manhattan, from Brooklyn Heights to Park Slope in Brooklyn, New Yorkers with cash to spend have long sought the high ground. In Staten Island, Todt Hill is a coveted area, as are Grymes Hill and Dongan Hills Colony. But for all its elevation, Ward Hill, on the islands north shore, has managed to remain below the radar.

title: A Mysterious Picasso Trove Gains More Accusations but Less Clarity
description: PARIS  At least this much is clear: the art  271 previously unknown sketches, watercolors and collages  is indeed the work of Picasso. But despite several weeks of accusations, counterclaims and deepening investigations, the mystery at the core of the case of Picasso and the electrician seems no closer to being solved.

title: Food, Film and Parking
description: After 19 years in existence, the Hollywood Farmers Market, which operates on Sundays along Ivar Avenue between Hollywood and Sunset Boulevards, is at the center of a fight that has put on display three of this citys most powerful passions.

title: Ready for Christmas? They Are, and Theyve Got 25,000 Coming.
description: This is what you call a full-court press, said Brother Edward McCarthy, a Jesuit and handyman in his 70s who has been working as a jack-of-all-trades at St. Patricks Cathedral in Midtown Manhattan for 32 years.

title: Footnote
description: Members of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, Suzanne Farrell Ballet, Parsons Dance and other troupes will take the stage for a fund-raising performance for the New York City Dance Alliances new foundation on Monday at the Joyce Theater. Money from ticket sales will go toward the foundations college scholarship program for young dancers. Tickets and information: (855) NYC-5678.

title: Grinches Are Good For ABC on Thursday
description: Back-to-back versions of Dr. Seuss How the Grinch Stole Christmas lifted ABC to second place in Thursdays prime-time television ratings. The half-hour animated special from 1966 narrated by Boris Karloff drew 6.2 million viewers at 8 p.m. while the 2000 live-action remake with Jim Carrey as the Grinch averaged 6.6 million viewers from 8:30 to 11, according to Nielsens estimates. Both versions easily outperformed reruns of NBCs sitcom line-up and Foxs two-hour block of Million Dollar Money Drop (4.9 million). CBS led the night, however, with repeats including CSI at 9 (7.8 million) and The Mentalist at 10 (8.7 million).

title: New Laws in Venezuela Aim to Limit Dissent
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  The National Assembly has approved a sweeping set of laws that impose penalties for spreading political dissent on the Internet, grant decree powers to President Hugo Chvez for 18 months and prevent legislators from breaking with his political movement.

title: Looking Back at a Prizewinning Defense
description: As much of the tournament bridge world takes a break for the holidays, lets look back at a brilliant defense played in 1980, at the European Junior Championship, held in Tel Aviv. The diagramed deal occurred during the match between Britain and Greece.

title: Jackie Robinson, TV Host
description: Jackie Robinson once hosted a TV show exploring the ethical issues of the day with a panel of guests from different faiths and religious groups.  Her are excerpts from a 1958 episode.

title: How Opera Challenges Translators
description: In a late scene of Mozarts Zauberflte, the hardy bird catcher Papageno, despairing that he may never have a mate, berates the world and decides to end it all. Seeing a tree, he makes a big show of his misery and threatens to hang himself.

title: Archive Shows Robinson As Moderator on Morality
description: Unearthed in a college archive, the grainy black-and-white dramatization, made in 1958, tells the story of a bungled purchase order and a boss who wanted the guilty partys scalp. The companys managers faced a glaring choice: fire an inept clerk who had it coming anyway, or jeopardize the career of a highly valued executive who, in this instance, was the one who actually slipped up.

title: Big Deal | Fully Furnished With Anecdotes
description: Sometimes a glance at properties for sale in a given week reveals a lot more than prices in the ever-changing  or not-changing-fast-enough  New York real estate market.

title: Brunos Lawyers Ask Court to Overturn His Conviction
description: Lawyers for Joseph L. Bruno, the longtime Republican leader of the New York State Senate, have asked a federal appeals court to overturn his conviction on fraud charges, following a landmark Supreme Court decision that whittled down the law under which he was found guilty, and to prohibit the government from retrying him.

title: Alexei Ratmanskys The Nutcracker
description: Images from the new American Ballet Theater production.

title: A Nutcracker Sprouts Alter Egos
description: Once youve seen a number of different Nutcrackers, you might think you know all the main ways that the old ballet can be retold. But you dont.

title: Hamas Confirms Commitment to Cease-Fire
description: GAZA  After a week of heightened tensions along the Gaza-Israel border, Hamas on Friday renewed its commitment to a cease-fire with Israel in an apparent effort to head off further escalation.

title: Before Winter Classic, Penguins and Capitals Play Another Classic
description: If there was ever a game that lived up to the hype, this was it. The arch-rivals Capitals and Penguins faced off in Washington on Thursday night, just nine days before their matchup in the Winter Classic. In front of a standing room only crowd, a national television audience and the glare of the HBO cameramen who made their way through Washingtons locker room with a palpable sense of entitlement, the Penguins edged the Capitals, 3-2, in a shootout.

title: Commemorating Bach, Holiday and a Conductor
description: The St. Cecilia Chorus has a long, distinguished history that stretches back to 1906 and includes the first New York performance of the Mahler Third Symphony and the United States premieres of some 60 works. It is an amateur ensemble in the best sense: its singers are in it for the love of the music, and if at times they sing with greater enthusiasm than finesse, their performances have a spirit that carries them through some of the most demanding scores in the choral repertory.

title: Christmases Past, Present and Sci-Fi
description: Just a handful of television narratives have become synonymous with the holiday season: a misfit reindeer with the support of an outcast elf provides crucial help to Santa Claus on a foggy Christmas Eve night; a sensitive boy takes pity on an underdeveloped would-be Christmas tree; a humanoid alien traverses time and space in a high-tech ship camouflaged as a vintage British police call box.

title: A Publicists Sly Push for the Novel True Grit
description: LOS ANGELES  Now it can be told.

title: Early Bid for a Reactor Site Draws Opposition in Texas
description: WASHINGTON  Twenty years ago, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission rewrote its procedure for licensing reactors to cut the time it would take to build new ones. Now an important part of the system is getting its first test, as a Chicago-based nuclear utility clashes with a well-to-do group of Texas ranchers over preapproval of a site about 120 miles southwest of Houston.

title: Global Puck: At the World Juniors, Americas Chance to Shine
description: The U20 World Championship in Buffalo and Niagara that starts on Sunday might well be the most important I.I.H.F. event USA Hockey has ever hosted outside the Olympics. It is an event guaranteed to be successful at the box office because of its proximity to Canada (more specifically, southern Ontario), but it is also a chance for American hockey fans to assert themselves at the worlds premier pre-N.H.L. event. In some respects, it might come to define USA Hockeys presence in the American sporting landscape.The World U20 (Junior) Championship started in 1977 in Czechoslovakia. The host cities of Zvolen and Banska Bystrica were considered small  appropriate sites for the inaugural event. The next year the tournament went to Quebec and games were played primarily in Q.M.J.H.L. cities like Chicoutimi, Hull, Cornwall and Quebec City. A few games were played in Montreal but the events profile didnt get a huge boost across Canada because the gold-medal game featured the Soviet Union and Sweden (the former winning, 5-2).

title: It Seems the Grinch Stole This Years Holiday Movies
description: LOS ANGELES  Have a happy holiday. But dont look for much help from Hollywood.

title: Air Travelers Face Snarls for Holidays
description: ATLANTA  Reaching cruising altitude between New York and Atlanta on Friday afternoon, the courtly pilot on Delta Flight 1947 broke some happy news for Yuletide romantics, or something less so for those hoping to make a Christmas Eve redeye: a possible white Christmas in the Deep South, something that has not been seen in Atlanta since the 1880s.

title: Corks Worth Popping for 2011
description: Long Island sparkling wines, which can brighten New Years parties and meals, take two forms. Light ones are best used as aperitifs and with finger foods, weighty ones as meal accompaniments. In both cases, their swirling pinpoint bubbles whet the appetite.

title: Dean Foods Settles Antitrust Case
description: Dean Foods settled an antitrust lawsuit with Northeast Dairy Farmers, agreeing to pay $30 million in damages and buy milk from producers in the region. Dean Foods and the Dairy Farmers of America cooperative were sued last year by the rival group and accused of operating a monopoly in the Northeast. Farmers received lower prices because Dean bought milk exclusively from the cooperative and its affiliates, according to a complaint in federal court in Burlington, Vt. The court has not yet approved the settlement.

title: Baked Goods and Much More
description: Colchester Bakerys glittering, lighted sign is as much a community landmark as the bakery itself, which is still operated by the family that established it, in the same spot, in 1947. Period piece though the sign may be, however, the inside of the bakery is a wholesome blend of traditional and modern.

title: That General-Store Feeling
description: Fairchilds Market in Roseland is part gourmet deli, part wine shop and part gift shop. It also feels something like an old-fashioned general store.

title: Mylan to Pay $65 Million Over Drug Prices
description: Mylan, a generic-drug maker, agreed to pay $65 million to settle a lawsuit by the federal and Texas governments asserting that the company had inflated prescription drug prices, increasing the cost of reimbursing pharmacies and other providers. The company admitted no wrongdoing in agreeing to the payment. Since 2003, Mylan has been sued by 18 states making similar allegations, according to the companys 2009 annual report. Last year, Mylan, AstraZeneca and Johnson & Johnson agreed to pay $124 million to settle claims they violated laws by underpaying Medicaid rebates, the Justice Department said.

title: South Africa Invited to Join Emerging Nations Group
description: South Africa has been formally asked to join a group of major emerging markets, bolstering its position as Africas champion. This so-called BRIC group comprises Brazil, Russia, India and China. President Hu Jintao of China wrote a letter to his South African counterpart, Jacob Zuma, to inform him of the decision. He invited him to the BRICs third meeting of heads of state in Beijing next year, the Chinese foreign minister, Yang Jiechi, said in a statement on his ministrys Web site. South Africa, which has a population of 49 million, compared with Chinas 1.36 billion, is betting on raising its clout on the world stage by joining BRIC, while strengthening political and trade ties within the bloc.

title: Versailles Adds a Meal (to Eat Before Dessert)
description: SINCE 1980, Versailles in Greenwich has been a local institution, for croissants or a full breakfast in the morning or a cafe meal at lunch. But since Sept. 14, when this patisserie-cum-cafe moved a few doors down Greenwich Avenue to a slightly larger space, it has served dinner as well. Its business card attests to its versatility: Boulangerie  Patisserie  Bistro Caf.

title: Daddy, Read for Me
description: THERE once was a man who read an unabridged dictionary from cover to cover to keep from losing his mind. Solitary confinement can do that to you, make you read what you would never look at on the outside, and then read more and more of it, to preserve your sense of humanity, maybe, but certainly to maintain whatever flimsy connection you hold to the world beyond your prison cell.

title: A Day to Cure What Ails You
description: The designer Isaac Mizrahi serves as a judge and a co-host with Iman on Bravos style smackdown, The Fashion Show: Ultimate Collection. Mr. Mizrahi, 49, sells his lifestyle collection on QVC and has his own store in Manhattan. A productive insomniac, he lives in Greenwich Village with his dog, Harry, and often spends Sunday afternoons at a museum, like the Guggenheim, where he recently did a reading. ROBIN FINN

title: New Restaurant Beckons Old Friends
description: By the time a restaurant opens in New York, there is already a crowd of critics jostling to weigh in on the Internet, so the owner needs to practice, practice, practice with free preview dinners before they get there, said Bobby Werhane, who is opening this casual Italian spot on Hudson Street in the West Village on Wednesday. For the price of a tip and filling out a questionnaire, about 30 friends and relatives of Mr. Werhane sampled cured meats, pastas and dessert last Wednesday night.

title: I Love a Man in Uniform. Especially the Red, Fluffy Kind.
description: BUSY as they were with party-going, gift-acquisition and pine-tree-gazing in Rockefeller Center, some New Yorkers still had time last week for lust. At least according to the following poems about Christmas and romance that were found in the Missed Connections section of craigslist.ny.org. They are published verbatim, with only line and stanza breaks added; the titles are the subject headings. ALAN FEUER

title: Departing Schools Chief: We Werent Bold Enough
description: JOEL I. KLEIN invited me to breakfast last year at an Upper East Side haunt, one of those places where a bowl of yogurt goes for $23 and waiters circle the room sweeping up crumbs like pigeons at a feast.

title: Mediterranean Flavors, By Way of Sicily
description: IF I were writing a how-to manual for restaurateurs, this might be a rule: Give people with reservations their choice of table, and let the walk-ins have whats left.

title: A Marvel That Kept New Yorkers Looking Up
description: It was going to be a long night. The longest night of them all, in fact, the winter solstice. This one would seem even a little longer than most, since for 72 minutes the moon, full and bright as a spotlight, would be dimmed by a total eclipse.

title: Pakistani Outposts Struck by Large Taliban Assault
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  A Taliban group forced into a remote border area by Pakistani military operations struck back Friday with a large and highly coordinated attack against the governments paramilitary forces, Pakistani officials said.

title: Rock n Roll Legends Posed and Exposed (but Only a Little)
description: There are many ways to experience rock musicians. You can listen to their songs, watch them perform or, if they live long enough, read a chronicle of their exploits, like Keith Richardss recently published Life. Another option is to view photographs like those on display in Rock On! Masterworks of Rock Photography at the Heckscher Museum of Art in Huntington.

title: Tchaikovsky and Space Invaders: Not So Far Apart
description: IF Beethoven and Tchaikovsky were alive today, they would be composing music for video games. At least that is what Tommy Tallarico, the prolific composer behind the soundtracks to nearly 300 popular video games, including Earthworm Jim and Tony Hawks Pro Skater, contends.

title: African Huts Far From the Grid Glow With Renewable Power
description: KIPTUSURI, Kenya  For Sara Ruto, the desperate yearning for electricity began last year with the purchase of her first cellphone, a lifeline for receiving small money transfers, contacting relatives in the city or checking chicken prices at the nearest market.

title: A Meal Worth Eating, and Seeing, Too
description: IN his popular and informative book Kitchen Confidential, Anthony Bourdain speculates that brunch presents an opportunity for restaurants to serve less desirable food. That may occasionally be true, although restaurants need not wait until high noon on Sunday to clean out the fridge.

title: Latin Fusion, Fully Orchestrated
description: ITS refreshing to encounter a place like Perfecto Mundo in Commack serving vibrant food with distinctive flavors instead of the dreary combination plates so often found in Latin restaurants. If that food is sometimes overly orchestrated, the quality and ambition of what comes out of the kitchen are commendable.

title: Dantes Hell, With Those Who Can Relate
description: IN early December, seven men wearing identical pine-green work pants chanted these words from Dante Alighieris Inferno: Non  sanza cagion landare al cupo. Their ponderous voices, accompanied by dirgelike sounds from an electric guitar, filled a classroom at Sing Sing Correctional Facility in Ossining, N.Y., where they are all inmates. It is not without reason that we are taking this journey, they sang in Italian.

title: Charlotte, the Queen of Spin Doctors
description: Its scary to move to a new home all by yourself, torn away from those who raised you. Its even scarier to learn from a recently acquired friend at the new place that the only reason youre being treated so well (served big troughs full of yummy food like leftover pancakes every day) is that youre going to be butchered and eaten.

title: Rex Ryan News Conference: Sanchez Is Probable
Arms Talks Now Turn to Short-Range Weapons
description: WASHINGTON  Fresh from winning Senate approval for a new strategic arms treaty, President Obama plans to return to the negotiating table with Russia next year in hopes of securing the first legal limits ever imposed on the smaller, battlefield nuclear weapons viewed as most vulnerable to theft or diversion.

title: On Slurs: A Response
description: Thanks to all who read and responded to my post for The Stone, Speech and Harm. What follows is a general response to those comments, writtenwith Luvell Anderson.

title: A Daughter of Malaysia Finds Her Political Star Rising
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia

title: Changing the Family Traditions
description: Mary Devitts family counted on certain traditions each Christmas. Her mother cooked the entire meal and served it on the good china, carefully arrayed on a tablecloth shed appliqued with holly sprigs. The centerpiece was always the same, a Royal Doulton figurine of a little boy with a Christmas tree. Her father sliced the turkey, using the carving set reserved for special occasions.

title: Revenge Cited in Rome Embassy Attacks
description: ROME  Anarchists who sent letter bombs to the embassies of Switzerland and Chile here on Thursday were trying to avenge their comrades in those countries, a top Italian security official said Friday, as the city remained on alert for more potential attacks.

title: Editor Said to Get Life Sentence for Uighur Reports
description: BEIJING  An ethnic Uighur journalist working for state radio has been sentenced to life in prison on charges that he spread subversive information around the time of deadly rioting in the western region of Xinjiang last year, a Uighur exile group said Friday.

title: With Smith Out, the Giants Lose a Leading Man
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Around the Giants practice center, receiver Steve Smith has earned a reputation as an amateur videographer, filming short clips of his teammates that he posts on social-networking sites.

title: Bavaria Booms, but Germans Feel Economic Malaise
description: ERLANGEN-HCHSTADT, Germany  By nearly every measure this industrial region in Bavaria, home to exporting giants like Siemens Healthcare, Adidas and Puma, is at the center of Germanys resilient economic success, driving the nations growth even as much of Europe struggles to stay solvent.

title: Doctor Says a Device He Invented Poses Risks
description: Dr. Scott D. Augustine, the inventor of a widely used piece of surgical equipment, now has a better idea  he wants hospitals to stop using the device during certain operations, asserting that it poses a danger to patients.

title: Thinking of Aretha
description: Nineteen sixty-seven was a tough year in many respects  riots, protests, an unwinnable war  but I cant think of it without thinking of the glory of Aretha Franklin, a woman in her mid-20s, introverted and somewhat shy, who sang soul and rock n roll with the power and beauty of a heavenly choir.

title: Spanish Takeover Bid Rattles German Markets
description: Talk about a takeover with a twist: few would believe that a debt-heavy construction conglomerate that relies on the stagnating Spanish economy for most of its revenue could take over a 137-year-old, cash-rich German blue chip.

title: Turkey: Military Exercises Planned
description: Turkey, Afghanistan and Pakistan agreed to hold a joint military exercises in March and to cooperate against drug trafficking, terrorism and extremism, the presidents of the three countries announced Friday after a summit meeting in Istanbul. High-level military officials and intelligence experts from the three countries met in Ankara earlier in the month to discuss strategy, the Turkish Foreign Ministry said.

title: Christmas With Lincoln
description: December 25, 1860

title: A Bittersweet Christmas Story
description: Snow was predicted for Lincoln, and there was every reason to think it would be a really fine Christmas.

title: The First Lady on the Trail of Santa
description: HONOLULU  While President Obama and daughters Malia and Sasha slipped off to the beach on Christmas Eve, Michelle Obama, the first lady, took care of a little holiday business: answering telephone calls from children inquiring as to the whereabouts of Santa Claus.

title: Fans Unforgettable Day, in Year Hed Like to Forget
description: From his front-row seat in the end zone at Heinz Field last Sunday, Robert Formola watched his favorite football team, the Jets, defeat the Pittsburgh Steelers. He sat with the family of cornerback Darrelle Revis, watched quarterback Mark Sanchez scramble for a touchdown and screamed as the Jets defense recorded its final stop as time expired.

title: Ryan Expects Sanchez to Start Against Bears
description: Barring a significant setback, quarterback Mark Sanchez will start Sunday for the Jets against the Chicago Bears. With a victory, the Jets would clinch a wild-card playoff berth.

title: Suffer the Little Children
description: As we celebrate this Christmas with the sound of tiny feet rushing toward a tree to rip open presents, lets take a moment to consider the children less fortunate  the growing number who live in poverty in this country.

title: Newcomers From Russia Are Reviving a Church
description: Olga Komenkos girlhood memories live within the walls of the domed and cupolaed Orthodox Church of the Holy Trinity at Pennsylvania and Glenmore Avenues in East New York. There, she danced Thursday evenings away with other young parishioners at weekly socials, wrote letters to servicemen during World War II and was married in 1944.

title: Redistricting Looms Large in Congress
description: The political jockeying over how to draw new Congressional districts began in earnest this week after new census data showed almost a dozen seats shifting to the South and West, leaving Republicans poised to build on their gains from Novembers midterm elections and forcing several northern Democratic incumbents to begin plotting to save their jobs.

title: Ravens Rice Isnt Bigger, Just Better
description: OWINGS MILLS, Md.  Wilbert Montgomery, the Baltimore Ravens 56-year-old running backs coach, has been working with his star pupil, Ray Rice, for almost three years  or long enough for Montgomery and Rice to communicate without even speaking.

title: G.O.P. to Open House to Electronic Devices
description: WASHINGTON  The iPad is coming to Capitol Hill.

title: The Street-Level Solution
description: When I was growing up, one of my fathers favorite sayings (borrowed from the humorist Will Rogers) was: It isnt what we dont know that causes the trouble; its what we think we know that just aint so. One of the main insights to be taken from the 100,000 Homes campaign and its strategy to end chronic homelessness, which I wrote about in Tuesdays column, is that, until recently, our society thought it understood the nature of homelessness, but it didnt.

title: To Virginias Family, Yes, Santa Claus Is Still Real
description: A 6-year-old girl was sitting in the back seat of her grandfathers truck last month, debating the existence of Santa Claus. She had questions and theories and logistic concerns, but mostly she had doubts. Her 9-year-old brother in the seat beside her was equally unconvinced. Their grandparents stared silently ahead, pretending not to listen.

title: Revival of a Church
description: Rev. Vladimir Alexeev has brought life back to the Orthodox Church of the Holy Trinity in East New York.

title: The Tannenbaum Chronicles
description: This year, my favorite Christmas story involves Rachel Maddows mother. A friend gave her a remote control for the Christmas tree, said Maddow. It was the best present ever, liberation from a lifetime of crawling under the tree every morning and night to put in or pull out the plug.

title: 4 Friends Toast of 60 Years: Merry Anniversary!
description: Sixty-one years ago, on Christmas Day, two Brooklyn couples held separate weddings in Manhattan. The next morning, before setting off on a joint honeymoon, they met at the Waldorf-Astoria for breakfast.

title: Past, Present and Yet to Come
description: What are your Christmases made of? A tree full of ornaments as old as you are? A customary feast, if not of roast beast? Perhaps theyre composed of wassail and yule, nog and Nel, Scrooge, Scrooged, Pickwick and Charlie Brown. Or Handel and Berlioz, Garland, Cole, Crosby and Clooney, the Rockettes and the dance of a Sugar Plum Fairy, even Bedford Falls and The Bishops Wife. To Christians everywhere, Christmas comprises, above all, a decree from Caesar Augustus and in the same country shepherds abiding.

title: Victims Kin Heartened by Commutation Reversal
description: The phone rang at 9 a.m. Friday with unexpected news from Michigans governor, and Larry Puma let the relief wash away the pain of the past two days, though not the last 22 years.

title: With a Spike in Crime and Police Layoffs, Anxiety Deepens in Newark
description: NEWARK  The violence that broke out on St. James Place here on Friday morning had a familiar ring.

title: When Hockey Moms Lace Up
description: For most of her 44 years, Terri Reid hated hockey.

title: Citys Horse Racing Channel Flickers Back Onto Screens
description: A few letters on the sign above the door of the off-track betting parlor just below Times Square still flicker neon-red, but the inside is completely dark. Stickers on the door make clear that legal horse betting in a public place no longer exists here or in most parts of the city.

title: Roy R. Neuberger Dies at 107; Applied a Stock Traders Acumen to Art
description: Roy R. Neuberger, who drew on youthful passions for stock trading and art to build one of Wall Streets most venerable partnerships and one of the countrys largest private collections of 20th-century masterpieces, died on Friday at his home at the Pierre Hotel in Manhattan. He was 107 and had lived in New York City for 101 years.

title: Looking Forward to a Dorm Room to Call His Own
description: Preston Chaney is a man of few words. If he were given to boasting, he might reveal that he is the first person in his family to graduate from high school, and will be the first to attend college.

title: David Fay, Director of U.S.G.A., to Retire at End of Year
description: David Fay, whose 21-year tenure as the executive director of the United States Golf Association, the sports governing body, has been characterized by an encyclopedic knowledge of the rules, a wry sense of humor and decidedly populist sensibilities, announced in a statement Friday that he would retire at the end of the year.

title: Sally Goodrich, Who Aided Afghans After 9/11 Loss, Dies at 65
description: Just three months after losing her son Peter on Sept. 11, 2001, aboard United Airlines Flight 175  the second plane to crash into the World Trade Center  Sally Goodrich received a diagnosis of ovarian cancer.

title: NATO Night Raid in Kabul Leaves Afghan Guards Dead
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  NATO forces, acting on apparently faulty intelligence, killed two Afghan private security guards and wounded three others in a gun battle early Friday that could lead to renewed criticisms of foreign forces by President Hamid Karzai.

title: Lottery Numbers
On a Small Scale, Sustainable Energy Transforms Lives
description: Tiny renewable energy systems that light just one home at a time are playing an epic, transformative role in the lives of poor people in developing countries who live far the electricity grid.

title: Pace Signs Deal to Build a Dormitory in Lower Manhattan
description: Pace University signed an agreement with a developer this week to build a 24-story residence hall in Lower Manhattan as part of a plan to consolidate its far-flung operations and create a downtown campus.

title: A Coming Assault on the E.P.A.
description: Republicans in the next Congress are obviously set on limiting the Environmental Protection Agencys authority under the Clean Air Act to regulate a wide range of air pollutants  even if it means denying the agency money to run its programs and chaining its administrator, Lisa Jackson, to the witness stand. Fred Upton, who will become the next chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, says he plans to call Ms. Jackson so often for questioning that hell guarantee her a permanent parking space on Capitol Hill.

title: Dan Kurzman, Military Historian, Is Dead at 88
description: Dan Kurzman, who wrote military histories that illuminated little-known incidents in World War II and an exhaustively reported account of the first Arab-Israeli war, died Dec. 12 in Manhattan. He was 88 and lived in North Bergen, N.J.

title: The Police and the Schools
description: School officials across the country are revisiting zero-tolerance disciplinary policies under which children are sometimes arrested for profanity, talking back to teachers or adolescent behavior that once would have been resolved in meetings with parents. The reappraisals are all to the good given that those who get suspended or arrested are more likely to drop out and become entangled in the criminal justice system permanently.

title: Saturday: Santa, Santa, Santa
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Today we have a rare New York Times puzzle from the editor of the Newsday crossword, Stanley Newman. You can learn all about him, his many books and his Crossword University cruises at his Web site. I love this quote: In 1990, Stan fulfilled a lifelong dream by appearing as a contestant on a TV game show. During his three weeks of appearances on The Challengers, hosted by Dick Clark, his cash winnings totaled $112,000, plus several cases of Rice-a-Roni and Niagara spray starch.

description: In this weekends Wealth Matters column, Paul Sullivan offers a sobering (though practical) reminder that any fancy new bauble ought to trigger an instinct to insure it. Jewelry tends to disappear more often around this time of year than any other, whether its because of theft or mere loss.

description: KAILUA, Hawaii  If there is one thing President Obama craves during his leisure time, it is privacy.

title: Second Sunday: Wry Tangles
description: Each answer in these puzzles will make one 90-degree turn somewhere along its length. Where it turns, and in which direction, is for you to discover. The starting square for each answer is given, as is its initial direction (north, east, south or west). Every square in the completed grid is used in exactly two answers  no more, no less.

title: Fiji? Bermuda? Shell Take Antarctica
description: THIS is my seventh season conducting research in Antarctica, or working on the ice, as we call it. Im usually here for three months at a time. My current stint, at the Lake Fryxell field camp in the McMurdo Dry Valleys, is for only a month, which is a luxury. But if that sounds as if I dont enjoy it, thats not true at all. Theres nothing else Id rather do.

description: Dwyane Wade had a television show, too. It was not in prime time, or sponsored, or technically his. But 33 hours before LeBron James made The Decision last July, Wade went on ESPN to announce he would re-sign with the Miami Heat.

title: A Mortgage Nightmares Happy Ending
description: TWO and a half years ago, Robert and Amy Ahleman, a construction contractor and a financial services employee, were mired in a mortgage nightmare. After missing just one loan payment on their modest, well-kept bungalow in Bensalem, Pa., the couple began receiving notices from their lender. Default fees and eviction threats followed.

title: Christmas Cheer Around the World
description: People celebrated Christmas from Lithuania to Afghanistan.

title: How Superstars Pay Stifles Everyone Else
description: This article was adapted from The Price of Everything: Solving the Mystery of Why We Pay What We Do, by Eduardo Porter, an editorial writer for The New York Times. The book, to be published on Jan. 4 by Portfolio, examines how pricing affects all of our choices.

description: In 2010, celebrations for some, chagrin for others.

title: Behind the Many Faces of Innovation, 2010
description: LAST week was Doyle Dosss busiest of the year. An advocacy group for the homeless had called from St. Louis to buy 12 of his Kandle Heeter Candle Holders, which promise dry, radiant space heat from a candle for just $29.95 each. He also had a bunch of laminated wildlife portraits  priced at $14.95 and sized to make your refrigerator happy  to put in the mail, and so many wearable hummingbird feeders on order that he had to hire part-time help to build them all.

title: From Cooking to Candles
description: MY parents had high expectations for my sister and me. My father consulted in developing countries for various companies and was an adventurer. He was gone for six months of the year; wed join him during summer vacation. Once my mother, father, sister and I were dropped off in the bush in Alaska with nothing but small blow-up boats and had to fend for ourselves for a week. Were all accomplished fishermen.

title: Opponents Timeout Calls Put Heavy Wait on Kickers
description: Giants kicker Lawrence Tynes recalls almost nothing of the moment that, but for a lucky break a few minutes later, might have defined his career. The Green Bay Packers called a timeout right before he tried a field goal at the end of regulation of the N.F.C. championship game in the 2007-8 season. Tynes remembers that. And he recalls thinking he should have gone back to the sideline to try a few more practice kicks in the brutally cold weather.

title: Fears Growing of Mugabes Iron Grip Over Zimbabwe
description: HARARE, Zimbabwe  The warning signs are proliferating. Journalists have been harassed and jailed. Threats of violence are swirling in the countryside. The presidents supposed partner in the government has been virulently attacked in the state-controlled media as a quisling for the West. And the president himself has likened his party to a fast-moving train that will crush anything in its way.

title: Deepwater Horizons Final Hours
description: The worst of the explosions gutted the Deepwater Horizon stem to stern.

title: Molded by Father and Brothers, Sullinger Becomes Star at Ohio State
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  When the text messages pop up in Ohio State Coach Thad Mattas phone, they always bring a laugh but barely ever a response. They come from the former Ohio State guard J.J. Sullinger, who simply types, Youre welcome.

title: Taliban Challenge U.S. in Eastern Afghanistan
description: JUMAH KALA, Afghanistan  The villagers gathered on mounds of dirt to watch as the American armored vehicles rolled in. The streets were narrow and banked by high mud walls; the bulky vehicles could barely squeeze through. The villagers had not seen a coalition patrol here in at least two years, they told the American commander as he stepped out to greet them.

title: Junior Hockey Tournament a Major Happening in Buffalo
description: BUFFALO  It often feels extremely Canadian in this border city, where the Maple Leaf flies alongside the Stars and Stripes in front of City Hall, the average attendance for box lacrosse is 18,000, and the Sabres dominate the wintertime sports news.

description: CARSON, Calif.  They walked through dawns thick fog to the practice turf  two dozen boys as old as 17 and as young as 9, giving up a Saturday morning to the coach in the Panama hat.

description: The home team wore green and the visitors red, and for one festive afternoon, the Madison Square Garden floor looked like a whirling tornado of Christmas wrap.

description: Agneta Welber has lost track of how many home health aides have come and gone over the past five years. Some lasted long enough to cash a check and not come back. Others, she said, took one look and walked out.

title: Schools of Hard Knocks
description: HEADLINES on the sports pages in recent years paint a picture of scandal and violence in football: college students playing for pay; recruiters doling out money under the table; professional agents trolling campuses from North Carolina to Southern California. And in both the N.C.A.A. and the N.F.L., crippling tackles cause head injuries bad enough to lead to dementia and suicide.

title: Ensconced in the Presidency, With No Budging in Ivory Coast
description: ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast  The lush green drive to the presidents residence offers a glimpse of why its current occupant, Laurent Gbagbo, is fighting so hard to stay put. The privilege of this hushed spot is a planet away from the dusty squalor of nearby neighborhoods, where his security forces make nightly raids on his opponents, witnesses and human rights groups say.

title: Cables Portray Expanded Reach of Drug Agency
description: WASHINGTON  The Drug Enforcement Administration has been transformed into a global intelligence organization with a reach that extends far beyond narcotics, and an eavesdropping operation so expansive it has to fend off foreign politicians who want to use it against their political enemies, according to secret diplomatic cables.

title: Crossing Over

title: Obama Returns to End-of-Life Plan That Caused Stir
description: WASHINGTON  When a proposal to encourage end-of-life planning touched off a political storm over death panels, Democrats dropped it from legislation to overhaul the health care system. But the Obama administration will achieve the same goal by regulation, starting Jan. 1.

title: In Budget Crunch, Science Fairs Struggle to Survive
description: DARIEN, Ill.  When one teams model helicopter broke before a recent science competition here, the students made a replacement at the last minute using a pizza box and a rubber band.

description: LOS ANGELES  Body bags go for $20. Yellow crime scene tape is $6. Toe tags are normally $5, but they were sold out this month. The merchandise comes in a white plastic shopping bag that says Los Angeles County Department of Coroner.

title: Morris L. Cohen, Leader Among Legal Librarians, Dies at 83
description: Morris L. Cohen, a book lover who shunned the practice of law because it was too contentious and became one of the nations most influential legal librarians, bringing both the Harvard and Yale law libraries into the digital age, died Dec. 18 at his home in New Haven. He was 83.

title: The Looming Crisis in the States
description: For most of this year, the state of Illinois has lacked the money to pay its bills. Some of its employees have been evicted from their offices for nonpayment of rent, social service groups have laid off hundreds of workers while waiting for checks, pharmacies have closed for lack of Medicaid payments. Faced with $4.5 billion in overdue payments, Illinois has proposed a precarious plan to sell its delinquent bills to Wall Street investors in exchange for cash, calculating that the interest it must pay the investors will be less than the late fees it owes.

title: Avastin
description: The Food and Drug Administration is preparing to withdraw its approval for using Avastin, a tumor-slowing drug, to treat advanced breast cancers that have spread to other parts of the body. It was a reasonable decision, based on scientific evidence. The drug has failed to extend lives in clinical trials, and it carries a small risk of devastating, sometimes fatal, side effects.

title: Frank Bessac, Scholar and Adventurer, Dies at 88
description: In 1949, as the forces of Mao Zedong routed the nationalists of Chiang Kai-shek and the Communist revolution spread north and west across the vast Chinese frontier, Frank Bessac, a 28-year-old Fulbright scholar in anthropology, was living among the Mongols near what is now Alashan in the Gobi desert.

title: The Dump

title: Who Killed the Disneyland Dream?
description: OF the many notable Americans we lost in 2010, three leap out as paragons of a certain optimistic American spirit that we also seemed to lose this year. Two you know: Theodore Sorensen, the speechwriter present at the creation of J.F.K.s clarion call to ask what you can do for your country, and Richard Holbrooke, the diplomat who brought peace to the killing fields of Bosnia in the 1990s. Holbrooke, who was my friend, came of age in the Kennedy years and exemplified its can-do idealism. He gave his life to the proposition that there was nothing an American couldnt accomplish if he marshaled his energy and talents. His premature death  while heroically bearing the crushing burdens of Afghanistan and Pakistan  is tragic in more ways than many Americans yet realize.

title: That Over-Investment in Military Tools
description: My Sunday column argues that as we debate budget cuts in the coming year, we should remember that we have invested enormously in military power and far, far less in diplomacy, education and other fields. If were trying to figure out how to raise our standard of living, or at least preserve it, the evidence is pretty good that well get a better return on investment in early childhood education than in, say, a military base in Germany.

title: Winter and Spring Shows for 59E59 Theaters
description: Clifford Chases allegorical first novel, Winkie, about a teddy bear who comes to life, is arrested on 9,000 charges including terrorism and treason, and befriends a lesbian Muslim cleaning woman, will be presented as a stage play starting in March at Off Broadways 59E59 Theaters, the company announced Sunday. Clifford Chases Winkie is adapted by Matt Pelfrey and directed by Joe Tantalo, whose theatrical troupe, Godlight Theater Company, is producing. The production will run from March 5 to April 10. Among other shows in its winter and spring 2011 season, 59E59 Theaters will present The Promise, a thriller by Douglas Maxwell about a retired Glasgow school teacher who emerges as a protector of a 6-year-old Somali refugee who refuses to speak and who is eventually labeled a witch by town leaders. Directed by Johnny McKnight, the production by the Scottish theater company Random Accomplice is scheduled to run March 29 to April 17, to coincide with Tartan Day (April 6) and other celebrations of Scottish heritage in New York.

title: Vineyards Next Plays

Mr. Helms show will begin preview performances on Feb. 3, open on Feb. 10 and run through Feb. 27. It will be followed by Mr. Shinns Picked, the story of a young actor dealing with life changes after a famous director casts him as the lead in a big-budget Hollywood movie. Picked is scheduled to begin performances in mid-March; members of the cast and creative team will be announced later.

title: Hefner Is Engaged, Again
description: Merry Christmas, Hugh Hefner! The 84-year-old founder of Playboy gave an engagement ring on Saturday to Crystal Harris, his 24-year-old girlfriend and a Playboy Playmate (the couple, above), Mr. Hefner announced on Twitter. When I gave Crystal the ring, she burst into tears, Mr. Hefner wrote. This is the happiest Christmas weekend in memory. He later added, just for clarity, that the two were engaged. Mr. Hefner married his first wife in 1949, and they divorced a decade later; he married his second wife in 1989, and their divorce was finalized early this year.

title: Strong Start for Coen Brothers True Grit
description: Holiday moviegoers were out for blood: Joel and Ethan Coens True Grit opened to stronger-than-expected results, while the Universal comedy Little Fockers underperformed. Little Fockers, which cost $100 million to make and generated negative reviews, was No. 1 with about $34 million for the weekend ($48 million total), a soft result that did not meet pre-release estimates. Paramounts True Grit, starring Jeff Bridges as a cranky bounty hunter and made for $38 million, was second with $25.6 million  doubling pre-release projections  for a new total of $36.8 million. Tron: Legacy (Disney) fell to third place with about $20 million for a two-week total of $88.3 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office statistics. Tron: Legacy, which carried a $170 million budget and marketing costs of well over $100 million, is struggling to cross over to a broad audience, at least in North America, and must now rely on strong overseas sales for profitability. The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader (Fox) was fourth with $10.8 million for a new total of about $64 million. Yogi Bear (Warner Brothers) was fifth with $8.8 million for a new total of $36.8 million. Also notable were Foxs Gullivers Travels, an expensive Jack Black vehicle that bombed in its first weekend with $7.2 million, and The Kings Speech, an Oscar hopeful from the Weinstein Company that sold a solid $4.6 million in limited release.

One of the girls told everyone that Marias green eyes were the same color as her cats, which confirmed a collective sense that Maria was not quite of them, particularly after she made the mistake of telling them she was adopted.

title: To Wagner, With Love and Morbidity
description: A brooding seventh grader whose pallor and bad attitude have earned her the nickname Morticia, Maria knows that her love of music  which takes her to mountains and lush islands and most of all great, teeming cities  sets her apart from the other kids.

title: Amid Inquiries, Experts Get a Cold Shoulder
description: Authorities arrested Don Chu, a Primary Global Research executive from Somerset, N.J., at 6:05 a.m. on Nov. 24. Within 24 hours, employees halfway around the world in the expert-network firms Manila office received a directive from their chief: stop recruiting outside consultants and do not return to work until Dec. 2.

title: The Arts in 2010
description: With its costs and its casualties (including Christopher Tierney, standing above), Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark became the most scrutinized new show on Broadway this year, though its still in previews.

title: A Cultural History of the Moon
description: Images from the book Moon depict the cultural history of the Earths natural satellite through history, science and literature.

title: Exploring Our Relationship With the Lonely Moon
description: The Moon is Earths only satellite, a quarter of its size, moving around our home planet in cold and lifeless isolation, in an orbit that increases an inch and a half a year.

title: Triplets, 7, Win a National Chess Title
description: Sometimes, Katerina Varsou needs to work or needs a break from playing with her sons, Andreas, Nicholas and Constantine Oskiper, 7-year-old fraternal triplets. So she tells them to amuse themselves.

title: Mexico: Family of Dead Activist Flees to U.S.
description: The relatives of an activist who was shot dead outside the Chihuahua state governments office have fled to the United States, state officials said Monday. Marisela Escobedo was killed on Dec. 16 as she mounted a vigil demanding the arrest of the man who confessed to killing her daughter Rub. The suspect, Sergio Barraza, was freed by a court in April. The decision was later reversed by a higher court, but by then he had vanished. Graciela Ortiz Gonzlez, the state secretary for government, said Monday that family members had crossed the international bridge to El Paso, Texas, despite state offers of protection.

title: Here Are the Snows of Yesteryear
description: Though few blizzards have surpassed the one were digging out from now, several have rivaled it. And almost every season has a snowstorm or two that lodge in memory  at least, until the next one comes along. Paradoxically, they are at once photogenic and monotonous. It takes imagination and a sharp eye to find a moment that stands apart. This is a gallery of such moments culled from the work of Times photographers, beginning with the blizzard of 1996.

title: Nuclear Builders Keep Their Options Open
description: The nuclear construction business looks highly uncertain at the moment, but companies that are interested in building are still keeping their options open, and spending money to do so.

title: Critics Picks Video: Waking Life
description: This week A. O. Scott takes a look at Richard Linklaters 2001 film Waking Life, which turned the streets of Austin into a surreal dreamscape.

title: Crossing the Finish Line for Cacaos Genetic Map
description: This year, a team of researchers financed by the candy maker Mars announced that they had, for the first time, completely sequenced the DNA of a cacao tree, which produces the main ingredient in chocolate.

title: My Anxiety in Flight, After Free Fall in an Elevator
description: ILL be the first one to admit that Im not a great frequent flier. Its not just the delays and cancellations; its actually the process of flying.

title: Baghdad on Two Wheels
description: Just in case you missed it, our colleague John Leland had a piece in todays Times on the return of bike culture in the Iraqi capital. The riders, both Sunni and Shiite, come to a wide boulevard beside the Tigris River on Friday nights. And tricks, not the complexities of Baghdad life, ruled the night.

title: An Accuser Becomes the Accused
description: A year and a half after the killing of a prominent human rights advocate in Russia, no suspects have been arrested. But her outspoken colleague is being charged with criminal defamation.

title: Retail Sales Rebound, Beating Forecasts
description: Americans are splurging as though its 2007 again.

title: Living and Studying Alopecia
description: Angela Christiano, 45, an associate professor of dermatology and genetics at Columbia University Medical Center, studies hair. Last summer, she announced the discovery of the genes implicated in alopecia areata, the hair-loss disease that she herself suffers from. We spoke for two hours in her Washington Heights laboratory and then later on the telephone. An edited version of the two conversations follows.

title: A Hair Loss Researcher With Purpose
description: Angela Christiano, an associate professor of dermatology and genetics at Columbia University Medical Center, studies the genetics of alopecia areata, a condition that causes sudden hair loss. Her work has led to the discovery of several genes implicated in the disease. What makes Dr. Christianos work unique, however, is that she has personally suffered from the hair loss of alopecia.

title: Sotomayor Guides Courts Liberal Wing
description: WASHINGTON

title: Gaza Flotilla Activists Ejected From New York Gallery
description: Updated | Saturday | 12:17 p.m. Four activists from a group called U.S. Boat to Gaza were forced to leave an art gallery in New York this month for wearing T-shirts with the title of the show they were viewing, Next Year in Jerusalem, by the German artist Anselm Kiefer, written in English, Hebrew and Arabic.

title: In Trenton, Emergency Puts Senator Back at Helm
description: Stephen M. Sweeney said he never expected to be running New Jersey again, but there he was on Sunday, with a severe snowstorm in progress, declaring a state of emergency.

title: In Pursuit of a Mind Map, Slice by Slice
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass  Dr. Jeff Lichtman likes his brains sliced thin  very, very thin.

title: An Off-Kilter City, Marooned in Powdery Dunes
description: There were streets with snow piled tight and high against the chilly skyscrapers like mini-ski slopes. And then around the corner, barely anything at all. One street Vermont; the next Oklahoma.

title: The Thinnest Cut: A Device for Discovery
description: As a graduate student, Kenneth J. Hayworth had a most unusual hobby: He built brain-slicing machines in his Los Angeles garage.

description: Jeff Vervoort, left, an associate professor in radiogenic isotope geochemistry at Washington State University, and John Goodge, a professor of geological sciences at the University of Minnesota-Duluth, are writing from their research expedition in Antarctica.

title: Economic Optimism? Yes, Ill Take That Bet
description: Five years ago, Matthew R. Simmons and I bet $5,000. It was a wager about the future of energy supplies  a Malthusian pessimist versus a Cornucopian optimist  and now the day of reckoning is nigh: Jan. 1, 2011.

title: A New Team Helps Steer Restaurateurs Through a Thicket of Red Tape
description: Opening a restaurant in New York City can be as frustrating as trying to brown a wet sirloin. Given worries over fire safety, food-borne illness and waste disposal, a new restaurant may have to contend with as many as 11 city agencies, often with conflicting requirements; secure 30 permits, registrations, licenses and certificates; and pass 23 inspections.

title: Those Doorman Thank-You Notes Never Quite Said It Right
description: During the years I lived in a doorman building in Murray Hill, I remember devoting what seemed like a good part of a day to tipping the men who worked there, usually a day or two after Christmas, regrettably, but always before the New Year. There was the often snowy trek to the bank and back, the late shopping for Christmas cards, and then the writing of thank-yous, some of them more elaborate than others.

title: Lawmakers Finance Pet Projects Without Earmarks
description: WASHINGTON  No one was more critical than Representative Mark Steven Kirk when President Obama and the Democratic majority in the Congress sought passage last year of a $787 billion spending bill intended to stimulate the economy. And during his campaign for the Illinois Senate seat once held by Mr. Obama, Mr. Kirk, a Republican, boasted of his vote against Speaker Pelosis trillion-dollar stimulus plan.

title: Managing Scientific Inquiry in a Laboratory the Size of the Web
description: Hanny van Arkel had been using the Galaxy Zoo Web site less than a week when she noticed something odd about the photograph of IC 2497, a minor galaxy in the Leo Minor constellation. It was this strange thing, she recalled: an enormous gas cloud, floating like a ghost in front of the spiral galaxy.

title: Republican Challenging Alaska Senate Result Shifts Course
description: Joe Miller said late Sunday that he would no longer try to prevent the certification of the Alaska Senate race, but he did not concede and he did not congratulate the unofficial winner, Senator Lisa Murkowski.

title: After-School Arts Education Gives Lower East Side Students a Lift Academically
description: Ten-year-old Destiny Howard swaggers onstage, flinging her arms overhead in exaggerated disgust.

title: A Venezuelan Oasis of Elitism Counts Its Days
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  The golfers still argue over handicaps. The waiters still serve flutes of Mot & Chandon. Sunlight still kisses the grounds laid out in the 1920s by Olmsted Brothers, the esteemed American landscape architects.

title: Chasing Heat With Wrecking Ball
description: Before the Miami Heat could rise and despair could set in, N.B.A. executives and fans began reaching for coping mechanisms last summer.

description: David A. Paterson, New Yorks soon-to-be former governor, has given a bunch of farewell interviews in recent weeks, some of them reflective, some wistful and some, to be frank, a tad whiny about why things didnt always go right for him.

title: 2 Senators Raise Questions on Use of Medtronic Device
description: Two senators are raising new questions about an experimental use of a Medtronic device in spinal surgery on veterans and soldiers at the Walter Reed Army Medical Center from 2002 to 2004.

title: The Big Chill
description: Miamis reputation for balmy winters has suffered an unexpected blow this month: waves of cold weather. With wind chills factored in, the temperature has repeatedly sunk to the mid-30s, far below average. Hats and scarves have replaced shorts and tank tops. And cold-induced crankiness has become common.

title: Lottery Numbers

title: Mets Acquire Backup Infielder
description: The Mets made another low-key move Monday, acquiring Chin-Ling Hu, a shortstop with little major league experience who team officials hope can be their backup middle infielder. Hu, 26, was acquired from the Los Angeles Dodgers for the minor league left-hander Michael Antonini.

title: Decision on Transgender Player
description: More than two months after a transgender woman sued the Long Drivers of America claiming discrimination, the group said in a statement that it planned to follow a recent rule change by the L.P.G.A. and allow transgender women to compete. But the Long Drivers of America also said it had no plans to conduct any womens long-drive events in the future but would allow women to compete in open or senior mens events. It did not rule out future womens events.

title: Companies Promote Health and Brands, Making Playgrounds
description: MARKETERS like Kraft Foods, MetLife, CVS and Dr Pepper/Snapple Group are steering millions in charitable dollars to a new and somewhat unlikely project  building neighborhood playgrounds for children.

description: Alcatel-Lucent agreed to pay $137 million to resolve federal criminal and civil investigations into accusations that it had paid bribes in Costa Rica, Taiwan and Kenya.

title: Three Flags
description: Charleston, S.C. Dec. 28, 1860Dawn broke that morning to reveal three flags above Charleston Harbor: the palmetto, the star, and the Stars and Stripes. Each bore its own bellicose message.

title: Narrative and the Grace of God: The New True Grit
description: Movie critic Dan Gagliasso doesnt like the Coen brothers remake of the Henry Hathaway-John Wayne True Grit. He is especially upset because the moment he most treasures  when Wayne, on horseback, takes the reins in his teeth and yells to Lucky Ned Pepper (Robert Duvall), Fill your hand you son-of-a-bitch  is in the Coens hands just another scene. The new film, Gagliasso complains, literally throws that great cinematic moment away.

description: Mississippi had a problem born of the age of soaring student testing and digital technology. High school students taking the states end-of-year exams were using cellphones to text one another the answers.

title: Choreographing a Snowplow Ballet, to Mixed Reviews (Again)
description: In the citys plan, it is envisioned as something like a ballet of behemoths, with a fleet of more than 2,000 garbage trucks swooping through the streets, brushing aside tons of snow as quickly as possible. But like most things in New York, each snowstorm brings a flurry of disagreement over how well that production has come off.

title: Somalia: Rebel Leader Threatens U.S.
description: A senior leader of the Shabab rebels threatened on Monday to attack the United States and urged President Obama to join Islam. The leader, Sheik Fuad Mohamed Khalaf, said he would send a message to America, which fought against God. We are united to put you in misery, and anyone who fights against God will not get help, Sheik Khalaf said. The Shabab, who seek to overthrow the weak transitional federal government here, are not known to have carried out attacks outside of Somalia except for a pair of bombings in Uganda in July that they claimed responsibility for. Sheik Khalaf also addressed Mr. Obama, saying: Give in and join Islam. God will reward you twice, or you will go the way former leaders like those who fought against Islam went.

title: Blizzard, and Inflexibility, Knock Out Air Travel
description: ALWAYS look on the bright side of life, suggested G. Bruce Hedlund, who has been a pilot for a major domestic airline for over a quarter century. Actually, being an airline captain, Mr. Hedlund is of a breed that seldom looks on the bright side of anything, but at least he is trying, given the current travel havoc caused by the bad weather.

title: Blizzards and Business Dont Mix, but a Little Planning Can Help
description: In the Bronx, hundreds of thousands of pounds of meat came to a standstill. On Broadway, one of the busiest times of the year was anything but, and near Wall Street, traders were taking over downtown hotels to make sure they would be at work when the bell rang.

title: East Digs Out After Blizzard Leaves a Trail of Disruption
description: Airports and railroads limped back to life, but thousands were still stranded. Roads remained glazed and city streets choked with snow. Subways and buses ran sporadically. Power was still out for thousands. Business was bad, and there were grim tales of people snowbound for hours in cars, buses and trains.

title: Dolphins Know Where It All Went Wrong
description: Plenty of teams are wondering what might have been as they prepare for Week 17  yeah, were looking at you, Dallas and Houston  but the Dolphins tumble from preseason contender to late-season punch line can almost certainly be traced to their 1-7 record at home.

title: Stranded on the Subway, Some Through the Night

He hopped on a C train, transferred to a D and was riding on an aboveground N when he called his wife around 10:55 to let her know that he was only three stations away.

title: N.B.A. in India, in Search of Fans and Players

After Yao, a 7-foot-6 center from Shanghai, was drafted by the Houston Rockets in 2002, the league attracted hundreds of millions of new fans in China. And though Yao is out for the season with a stress fracture that could end his professional career, the N.B.A.s international march continues.

It was 16 months after the murder of Ms. Estemirova, a renowned human rights advocate in the tumultuous region of Chechnya, and now the legal system was taking action.

Nearly every mode of transportation in and around New York City, and much of the East Coast, had been suspended or was severely hampered. This was all the more troublesome because it caught so many holiday travelers in transit.

description: Martin A. Makary, a surgeon and public health researcher at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore, had a long talk with a patient last week. The man had a tumor in his pancreas that was probably benign but might not be. Should Dr. Makary remove it? Or should the man have regular scans to see whether it grew?

title: In NBCs Shadow, Comcast Ponders an Olympic Plunge
description: Does Comcast cherish the Olympics with the same fervor as did General Electric, which has paid billions to make NBC the network of the Summer and the Winter Games for a generation?

title: Airport Delays Are Expected to Persist for Several Days
description: Buried beneath snow for more than 24 hours, New York area airports turned Tuesday to the growing backlog of canceled flights, an accumulation that could take far longer to address than the blizzard itself.

title: Letters: The Year in Ideas
description: The cover of the The Year in Ideas (Dec. 19) closed out the decade with a delightful conflation of change and continuity. Our two children pulled out their smartphones, scanned in the balloon Q.R. code and treated their parents to the animated primer on wind-power innovation. The science was succinctly educational, and the smiling birds, bats and bees were ecologically hopeful. Once we finished viewing all the animations, we were ready for the video unpacking the covers mandala-like code. Upon seeing the mindful construction of the artwork and its gleeful deconstruction, one of us exclaimed, Hey, this is high-tech rangoli. For centuries, Indian folk artists have used rice flour to meticulously create auspicious motifs that would be swept away by the evening breeze. Like modern-day innovators who are aware of the cycle of creative destruction, rangoli practitioners have internalized metaphors for impermanence and embraced the winds of change.MANGLA R. OZA AND RAJESH C. OZAPalo Alto, Calif.

title: New York Struggles as Blizzards Impact Chastens Bloomberg
description: As New York City struggled with huge snowdrifts left by a crippling blizzard the day before, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg acknowledged on Tuesday that the cleanup had been slower than expected and the impact worse than had been apparent when the snow stopped falling.

title: Remembering the Blizzardopolis of 47
description: My friend Robert White, the tenor, called to say it was the 63rd anniversary of the time he spent four days with the five DeMarco sisters. Dont get confused by the numbers. He was talking about the big snowstorm of 1947.

title: Letters: A Physicist Solves the City
description: As a physicist myself, I read with great interest Jonah Lehrers article about Geoffrey West, who is interested in developing a general theory of cities from first principles. Physicists  myself included  are intrigued by the idea that application of rigorous laws in the world of natural science can inspire similar applications in other areas, including social ones.

title: Red Wings Osgood Reaches Milestone
description: It took three tries for the veteran Detroit Red Wings goalie Chris Osgood to reach his big milestone, but the wait was worth it.

title: Letter: In Pursuit of the Perfect Brainstorm
description: Regarding David Segals article about the new breed of consultants helping corporations come up with fresh ideas, governments also need help. We need such consultants in the public sector to help our governments transform to meet the budgetary and service challenges of the 21st century. In business, there is one bottom line to innovate to: profit. In government, there are many interests and dynamics that can undercut innovation. We need to develop specific techniques that address the unique situation of government. In my work to help governments innovate, I have found that separating stakeholders input from the design process is very useful. We need more ideas, more support and more commitment to innovation in government. I hope next year we see these ideas highlighted. Beverly SteinPresident, the Public Strategies GroupPortland, Ore.

title: Snow Days: A Short Pause for the Bagger
description: But never fear  the Bagger will be back on Monday, with plenty more Oscar-season news and nonsense. Look for the the Producers Guild of America nominations on Tuesday, and later in January, coverage of the Golden Globes winners, Oscar nominations and all things Sundance. title: The Nutcracker Chronicles: In Virginia, a Nutcracker for Every State
description: RICHMOND, Va.  If Patrick Henry said Give me liberty or give me death (there are doubts), he said it here in St. Johns Church. The State Capitol, dated 1788 and recently restored, is the second oldest in continuous use in America. The Virginia Museum of Fine Arts has the largest collection of Faberg Imperial Easter Eggs outside Russia. I want to see these and other sights. At this stage of my Nutcracker tour and after a delayed flight, however, I confess I dont have the energy. I love the view of a wide arc of the James River from my hotel room and go to bed before the performance.

title: Eagles Are Knee Deep in Controversy After Postponement
description: It is a rare moment when a snowstorm-prompted game postponement turns into a referendum on the nations level of wussiness, but such is the occasion when someone slips a radio microphone near the mouth of Pennsylvania Gov. Ed Rendell. He unleashed his own unique kind of storm on the N.F.L. for moving his beloved Eagles game to Tuesday instead of playing it Sunday in a blizzard.

title: Putting a Siberian Snow Connection to the Test
description: Is wintry winter weather more predictable than we thought? Judah Cohen thinks hes proved that the answer is yes. Hes the commercial climate analyst who wrote an op-ed article for The Times charting a connection between global warming, snow in Siberia and outbreaks of cold weather in parts of the Northern Hemisphere and whose work was discussed here yesterday.

title: Box Office Remains Strong for Spider-Man in Challenging Week
description: An accident at the Dec. 20 performance of Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark that injured the actor Christopher Tierney had no immediate effect on that Broadway musical at the box office. According to data released Tuesday by the Broadway League, Spider-Man, which canceled two of its planned performances for the week ending Dec. 26 while new safety protocols were put in place, grossed $944,138 for its four shows and played to 100 percent capacity. That figure, however, does not reflect any money that might be given back to audience members at the Dec. 20 show, which ended abruptly after the accident. They have been offered refunds or tickets to later Spider-Man performances.

But when he did so last month, the nation took notice: He is a rabbi, ultra-Orthodox himself, whose outspokenness ignited a fresh, and fierce, debate about the rapid growth of the ultra-religious in Israel.

title: Fellow Writers To Help Charles Bock with Most Literary Rent Party Ever
description: The writer Charles Bock made a great many literary friendships during the years while he struggled to complete his first novel, Beautiful Children. When Mr. Bocks wife, Diana Colbert, was discovered to have leukemia and underwent a bone marrow transplant in the fall of 2009, many of those friends pitched in to offer household help. In October, Ms. Colberts leukemia returned (she is scheduled for another transplant next month), and three of the Bocks friends, the novelists Fiona Maazel and Mary-Beth Hughes and the writer Leigh Newman, decided they needed to help even more. We said everything that can be done, should be done, Ms. Maazel recalled. So on Feb. 6th, at P.S. 122 in the East Village, the Bock friends are throwing what theyre calling the most literary rent party ever.

title: Thais Look to the Supernatural
description: BANGKOK  Dont be fooled by the skyscrapers, the roads clogged with the latest luxury cars or the high-tech gadgetry in pockets and purses. This country of 65 million people has embraced modernity, yes, but many Thais will tell you that ghosts and spirits still wander the streets and inhabit buildings. Important business decisions often require consultations with a fortune teller. Cabinet ministers and military officers are sometimes so concerned with numerology and advice from their shamans that politics in Thailand could be called the black art of the possible.

title: Now Baking | Provence Rises in Midtown
description: I have a new bread we are doing, a breakfast bread, Katzie Guy-Hamilton told me by e-mail from her new post as executive pastry chef at the Grand Hyatt Hotels barely opened restaurant New York Central. Nobody makes it in New York, and I would like to think ours is amazingly delicious. What was this bread? Its name sounds a lot like gibberish, literally. Its gibassier, and Guy-Hamilton explained that hers is an enriched dough with anise seeds, orange blossom water and candied peel. I shape it into rounds, cut little claws and then it gets a showered with sugar before baking.

title: The Mob Work Is Tough; Then He Has to Go Home
description: Aging stage actors typically dream of playing King Lear, but many of their younger screen counterparts these days will settle for nothing less than Jesus. Not literally: the part of the actual New Testament Jesus tends to be a limited role best suited to actors of limited range, like Jim Caviezel (The Passion of the Christ) or Jeffrey Hunter (King of Kings). But there is something irresistible about modern men of sorrows who sacrifice themselves for the sins of others, and certain movie stars  Kevin Costner and Will Smith, most strikingly  have not hesitated to exercise the Messiah Clause in their contracts.

While the year is 1956, and the show is set during Christmastime in suburban Queens, the anything-goes plotting and blithely artless performances made me think of early John Waters Baltimore instead.

description: Me! Me! Me! That is the cry, now often heard, as history is retold. Tell my story, in my way! Give me the attention I deserve! Havent you neglected me, blinded by your own perspectives? Now let history be told not by the victors but by people over whom it has trampled.

title: Readers Recall Another Mayor, and Another Storm
