description: The Oz in Mamoru Hosodas excellent anime feature Summer Wars isnt somewhere over the rainbow but just a keystroke away. Its a global virtual reality, and when things go wrong in Oz, watch out, real world: traffic tangles, and water mains burst. Worse, someone could launch a missile attack.

title: In Remote Corner of Portugal, a Photographer Finds More Than He Expects
description: What is the opposite of precocious? If no suitable word exists, somebody should invent one  in English, French or, ideally, Portuguese  to describe the 102-year-old filmmaker Manoel de Oliveira. He has completed a dozen features and a handful of shorts since 1998, which is to say since his 90th birthday. His latest feature, a tale of supernatural romance called The Strange Case of Angelica, arrives in New York on Wednesday, and while it is evidently the work of an artist with great stores of wisdom and a long view of history, it also has a playful, wry quality that can only be described as youthful.

title: Chronicling Loves Fade to Black
description: There is a song about the thin line between love and hate, but most movies pick a side and stay on it. Blue Valentine, a long-gestating project directed by Derek Cianfrance, examines a young couple falling in and out of love, and makes of that thin line a vast and blurry no mans land. Speaking of music, Leonard Cohen has a song about being danced to the end of love, but Mr. Cianfrances characters, Dean (Ryan Gosling) and Cindy (Michelle Williams), stumble and crawl in that direction, having forgotten the nimble, playful steps they once knew.

And for dinners before 9 p.m., it pays to find out what time you must leave.

title: Brees and Brady Keep Padding Touchdown Streaks
description: With 3 minutes 24 seconds left in the fourth quarter Monday night against the Atlanta Falcons, Drew Brees found the rookie tight end Jimmy Graham for a 6-yard touchdown pass. The throw gave New Orleans the lead and eventually a victory, and it clinched an N.F.C. playoff berth. But the pass also kept alive an impressive streak: Brees has thrown for a touchdown in 26 consecutive regular-season games (he also threw a touchdown pass in all three postseason games last season). Brees is still far from breaking the record, 47, set by Johnny Unitas 50 years ago.

He all but thanked the secessionists for preferring to be a large piece of nothing, to being any longer a small piece of something.

title: Syracuse Punter Inspires His Teammates, Even if He Cannot Play
description: A half-dozen husky Syracuse football players in gray sweatsuits strolled into a ballroom at the Grand Hyatt late Tuesday afternoon for a news conference. The punter, the only man in the group with a jagged red scar on the back of his shaved head, drew the most attention.

title: A Tight End Happy to Have Hands of Clay
description: LEESBURG, Va.  On the football field, Washington Redskins tight end Chris Cooley likes to throw his body at defenders, as he did on a go-ahead touchdown Sunday at Jacksonville. But in his suburban house, he prefers throwing pottery  that is, making bowls, mugs and vases.

title: Brooklyn Immigrant Congregations Clash
description: The United Methodist church in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, is anything but united.

title: Sam Sifton's Best Dishes of 2010
description: The restaurant critic for The New York Times describes the 15 best dishes he ate in the city this year.

title: Buka
description: THE giant African land snail can grow up to a foot long and weigh more than a pound. But the three specimens ($10) on our plate at Buka, denuded of their shells and curled in tight black whorls, looked about as imposing as jumbo shrimp.

title: Watercress With a Maroon Leaf to Accent Your Salads
description: Red watercress  although maroon is more like it  has even more peppery bite in its green-veined pointy leaves than regular watercress and, its growers say, more antioxidants. An employee of B & W Watercress in Florida, said to be the worlds biggest grower, discovered it growing wild, so the company began cultivating it. Use it raw in salads, because cooking turns the red to dark green.

title: From Agnolotti to Ziti, a Book Pairs Pastas and Sauces
description: Distinctions among pasta are mostly about shape, and thus you have The Geometry of Pasta, an arresting book by Caz Hildebrand and Jacob Kenedy that covers pasta shapes alphabetically from agnolotti to ziti, more than 80 of them represented by strong black-and-white drawings. Fregola, gnocchi and couscous are included. A careful matching of sauce recipe to shape is the books mission, and there is considerable cross-referencing from one to another, and a useful index of sauces in the back. I loved the strozzapreti with calamari and broccoli that called for cooking the pasta and vegetable together in the same pot.

title: Inexpensive Restaurants That Stood Out in 2010
description: THE best of the casual restaurants reviewed this year proved that delicious doesnt have to mean expensive.

title: A Brooklyn Market With Local Pride
description: Among the attractions at the fledgling Brooklyn Victory Garden market are fresh Bo Bo chickens, prized in Chinatown and sold with the head and feet  parts worth collecting for your restorative chicken soup this winter.

title: A Critics Choice of Restaurant Newcomers
description: FOLLOWING is a list of my favorite new restaurants among those that I reviewed in 2010. They are presented in alphabetical order. But Torrisi was awesome.

title: Sparkling Pear Cider, a Gentler Start to the New Year
description: To keep that New Years celebration on the light side, consider sprightly and subtly sparkling pear cider from Ireland. Its delicately sweetened, delivers only 4.5 percent alcohol and behaves properly in a flute for toasting. Magners has been known for its more traditional apple cider for 75 years.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening

title: Dishes That Earned Their Stars
description: I MADE a list of the 15 best things I ate in New York City in the past year of reviewing restaurants for The New York Times. It is an accounting that comprises restaurant dishes of uncommon excellence and flavor. Together they underscore New Yorks place as one of the planets best cities in which to dine out.

title: Dining Calendar
description: A Melodious Prix Fixe

title: Whole Wheat Spaghetti With Spicy Chickpeas, Rosemary and Bonito Flakes
description: Adapted from Mark Ladner, Del Posto, Manhattan

title: For a Snow-Crippled City, a Morsel of Humble Pie From the Mayor
description: On the third day, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg tried on empathy. Sort of.

title: Share Rules Could Prompt an Offering by Facebook
description: Facebook likes big numbers  it now has more than 500 million users, each one of whom can have as many as 5,000 friends. Yet as a privately held company, its ownership base must remain small, or it will have to disclose publicly its financial results.

title: To Governor, Postponing a Game Is for Losers
description: PHILADELPHIA  Whether rooting on the University of Pennsylvania basketball team or analyzing the Eagles on a weekly postgame television program, Gov. Edward G. Rendell has long been an outspoken Philadelphia sports fan.

title: Bad Advice From Duke Ellington
In 2011, Let Coughlin Light a Fire
description: To the many thousands of Giants fans passing judgment on Tom Coughlins coaching future, give Coughlin a thumbs up. Let him live for another season.

title: Accounts Diverge Sharply in Night Raid Gone Wrong
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  No one seems certain who fired the first shot in the early morning hours of Dec. 24 as commandos from the coalition forces here descended on a Kabul office building in search of two cars loaded with explosives.

title: With Ambulances Stuck in Snow, City Resorted to Triage
description: A woman with stroke symptoms in Midwood, Brooklyn, waited for an ambulance for six hours, finally arriving at the hospital with telltale signs of advanced brain damage. In Forest Hills, Queens, bystanders waited for three hours next to a man lying unconscious in the snow before they were able to flag down help. And in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, a mother in labor who started calling 911 at 8:30 a.m. on Monday did not get an ambulance until 6 p.m., too late to save the baby.

title: Answering Critics, Police Release Minor-Crime Data
description: The New York Police Department has begun providing broad access to data on misdemeanor crimes in the city, putting the information on its Web site.

title: Lottery Numbers
Man Charged in Death of Woman Found in Suitcase
description: An East Harlem man was arrested on Monday and charged with the murder of a woman whose body was found stuffed in a suitcase left on East 114th Street in Manhattan, the police said.

title: Russia: Inquiry on Airport Service in Storm
description: President Dmitri A. Medvedev on Tuesday ordered an inquiry into whether the authorities had mishandled the response to weather-related cancellations of hundreds of flights at Moscows two major airports. An ice storm over the weekend paralyzed service at the two airports, Domodedovo and Sheremetyevo, leading to widespread complaints from passengers that officials were unprepared and had no contingency plans. State television reported disturbances at both airports as passengers tried to force their way into departure areas. Some expressed anger over lack of information and over what they called price gouging at airport restaurants and shops.

title: China: Apology for Farmer Locked in Mental Wards
description: A Chinese farmer who was imprisoned in mental hospitals for six and a half years as punishment for seeking government redress in a land dispute has been given the equivalent of $45,300 and an apology by officials of the Henan Province county that had engineered his confinement, Caijing Magazine reported. According to the magazine, which reported the settlement, the farmer, Xu Lindong, left, resisted accepting the award for seven months because it required him to abandon his right to sue the two mental hospitals that had confined him. Some human rights advocates say they believe that a growing number of agitators who seek government redress are confined in Chinese mental hospitals.

title: E. Gene Smith, Who Helped to Save Tibetan Literary Canon, Dies at 74
description: E. Gene Smith, a Utah native who through persistence, ardor and benevolent guile amassed the largest collection of Tibetan books outside Tibet, saving them from isolation and destruction and making them accessible to scholars and Tibetan exiles around the world, died on Dec. 16 at his home in Manhattan. He was 74.

title: Obamas Traveling Team Stays Focused on Terror
description: KAILUA, Hawaii  President Obama was peeved. It was Christmas 2009 and a Nigerian had been accused of trying to blow up a plane bound for Detroit. Mr. Obama was supposed to have state-of-the-art secure telecommunications capabilities inside his luxury beachfront rental home here. Instead, he was stuck relying on operators to connect him to his top counterterrorism adviser, John O. Brennan. Once, as he was trying to reach Mr. Brennan, the call dropped.

title: No. 14 Minnesota Men Lose
description: Jordan Taylor scored 22 points and Jon Leuer added 16 to lead Wisconsin (11-2) to a 68-60 upset of No. 14 Minnesota (11-2) in the Big Ten opener for both teams.

title: Making It Clear That a Clear Parking Space Isnt
description: Scenes from South Bostons parking wars.

title: Plowed? Yes. Salted? Sure. Cleared? Thats Murky.
description: It is the central question of this weeks snowstorm: How did the citys efforts to plow and clear its more than 6,000 miles of streets rate against the jobs that it did in response to other powerful snowfalls?

title: Wednesday: June
description: Todays theme addresses the age-old crossword gripe that N and  are two totally different letters. Both of those letters appear in the grid, but never crossing each other. No now-you-see-it-now-you-dont TILDE  for a day anyway.

title: Concrete Jumble: New Year New York
description: A short film by Gary Leib celebrating the new year.

title: A New Jersey City Digs Out From 32 Inches
description: RAHWAY, N.J.  When John M. Rodger, the Rahway police chief, looked outside on Monday morning and could not see his wifes Chevrolet Suburban in the driveway, he knew his vacation to South Carolina was a goner.

title: For $10, $20, Clearing Cars and Walks, in a Flash
description: Some are just out of prison, others have Ivy League degrees. Many are day laborers who speak no English. A few are women. All are entrepreneurs, in an all-cash, tax-free enterprise that exploits desperation and deadlines.

title: What Rule of Law?
description: President Dmitri Medvedev of Russia claims to champion the rule of law. He also claims that he, not Prime Minister Vladimir Putin, calls the shots in Moscow. Mr. Medvedev can prove both true by using his pardon power to ensure that Mikhail Khodorkovsky faces no additional prison time after being convicted on trumped-up embezzlement charges this week. Mr. Khodorkovsky, once Russias richest man, has already served seven years as a result of Mr. Putins judicial vendetta against him.

title: A New Day for Wilderness
description: One of the sorrier blots on George W. Bushs sorry environmental record was a midnight deal in 2003 between Gale Norton, then the secretary of the interior, and Michael Leavitt, then the governor of Utah, that withdrew 2.6 million acres of public land in Utah from consideration as protected wilderness.

title: An Iraqi Government, Finally
description: Nine long months after parliamentary elections, Iraq has a new government. Its leaders cant waste any more time on petty maneuvering.

title: No-No Boy
description: Courage takes many forms. Frank Emi, who died in California on Dec. 1, age 94, had the steadfast kind, well suited for lonely struggles and ostracism.

title: A Pinpoint Beam Strays Invisibly, Harming Instead of Healing
description: The initial accident report offered few details, except to say that an unidentified hospital had administered radiation overdoses to three patients during identical medical procedures.

title: After Disruptions on Rails and at Airports, Halting Steps Toward Normal Service
description: New Yorks many forms of mass transit stumbled back to life on Tuesday, a day after fierce snow and wind knocked out much of the citys vast network of buses, trains and planes. But while some parts of the city moved toward regaining mobility, other areas barely budged.

title: Corrections
description: BUSINESS DAY

title: Knicks Get Another Hard Lesson From Heat
description: MIAMI  The foul was unnecessary, ultimately meaningless, but LeBron James gave it anyway, for emphasis, for the Knicks to remember in the months to come. The message: nothing will come easy against the Miami Heat, not even in the final seconds of a game in which the outcome is clear.

title: A New York City Weekend for $100
description: HOW much spending money should you set aside for a weekend in New York City that includes taking in some theater, museums and experimental film, dining out at restaurants for every meal and having a few beers, too?

title: Vacation Rentals Pile on Luxuries
description: A SELF-DESCRIBED hotel snob, Jennifer Treadwell prefers to stay at Four Seasons and similar upscale hotels when she goes on vacation, for the high level of service and luxurious amenities they provide. The idea of renting a vacation home, where she would presumably bring her own bed sheets and toilet paper, was never very appealing. Then she discovered the Cottages at Cape Kiwanda on the Oregon coast, where $500-a-night two-bedroom cottages offer flat-screen televisions, surround-sound systems, spa-style robes, iPod docks, in-room Internet access and whirlpool tubs. Guests have access to a fitness center nearby and a concierge who can book an oceanfront massage or surf lesson or recommend nearby hiking trails.

title: My $100 Weekend in New York: Where the Money Went
description: Whats the lowest possible budget you need for a great weekend in New York? I figured $100 would do the trick, as long as you can find a free place to crash. (Recommendations: your college roommates couch, your ex-girlfriends futon, your rich distant cousins pied-a-terre, or Couchsurfing.)

title: Making a Complex Machine Even More Complex
description: Linear accelerators create X-ray beams aimed at cancer or other problems. Some are retrofitted with a cylindrical assembly  called a cone  which concentrates the radiation for more precise treatments. Because the beams are so intense, a single error can cause serious injuries or death.

title: John Warhola, Brother of Andy Warhol, Dies at 85
description: John Warhola, an older brother of the Pop artist Andy Warhol and one of the original three trustees of the Andy Warhol Foundation for the Visual Arts, died on Friday in Pittsburgh. He was 85 and lived in Freedom, Pa.

title: Frances Ginsberg, American Soprano, Dies at 55
description: Frances Ginsberg, an American soprano heard regularly with the New York City Opera in the 1980s, died on Friday in the Bronx. She was 55 and had lived in Manhattan and Milan.

title: China: Investigative Reporter Dies After Beating
description: Sun Hongjie, a journalist who was beaten into a coma this month in northwest China, died Tuesday morning, a colleague said. Mr. Sun was an investigative reporter for The Northern Xinjiang Morning Post. Colleagues declined to say whether he had been killed because of his reporting. Police officials said that Mr. Sun and a friend had argued, and that the friend had arranged the assault.

title: Israeli Army Kills Militant in Gaza
description: The Israeli Army killed a 21-year-old member of a militant group loyal to the Hamas leaders of Gaza and wounded three others on Tuesday. The army said it had been aiming at militants planting explosives near the border, according to The Associated Press. But residents said the man had been watching the security fence separating Gaza and Israel; militants watch the fence so they can give warning if Israeli forces appear ready to attack.

title: Phys Ed: If You Are Fit, You Can Take It Easy
description: New Years resolutions tend to war with wintertime malaise. Resolution urges you to work out. Malaise suggests that you linger in bed. But theres good news for those of us torn between these impulses. A number of newly published studies offer compelling reasons to get out and exercise on the one hand, as well as new estimates of just how little we can do and still benefit on the other.

title: Obama Back on the Links
description: KAILUA, Hawaii  President Obama is an avid golfer. But his friend Marty Nesbitt may have gotten the best of him on the links here Tuesday afternoon.

title: Alaska: State to Declare Victory for Murkowski
description: A federal judge on Tuesday cleared the way for Alaska election officials to declare Senator Lisa Murkowski the winner of the states Senate race. Ms. Murkowski ran as a write-in candidate after losing to Joe Miller in the Republican primary. Unofficial results have showed her winning by more than 10,000 votes, but Mr. Miller has delayed certification through legal challenges, arguing that write-in votes must be spelled perfectly. The Alaska Supreme Court ruled against him last week. On Tuesday, Judge Ralph R. Beistline of United States District Court dismissed his federal case. Shortly after the ruling, the state announced it had certified the results. It later corrected the announcement to say it would certify the race on Thursday.

title: Maine: 7 Hurt as Sugarloaf Ski Lift Derails
description: A chair lift derailed Tuesday at the Sugarloaf ski resort in Carrabassett Valley, injuring seven people after five chairs plunged about 30 feet into snow. Officials at the resort, about 120 miles north of Portland, could not immediately explain the accident, but said none of the injuries appeared to be life-threatening.

title: Now Pouring | Some Like It Cold
description: One could imagine the likes of Rhett Butler raising a glass at the bar at Husk, the award-winning chef Sean Brocks new restaurant in the historic center of Charleston, S.C. Husk offers hearty, somewhat masculine fare with a common theme: If it aint Southern, it aint walkin in the door, Brock says. This manifesto carries over to the bar, which is adjacent to the restaurant in a restored antebellum structure and boasts a killer bourbon list. Exquisite small-batch varieties are served in glasses made from recycled wine bottles, each with a punt in the bottom, which creates a kind of moat for the amber liquid. When a hand-molded sphere of clear ice is set on top (for cooling without dilution), the only real contact between ones 23-year-old Pappy Van Winkle and its icy companion is while sipping. Its a pretty neat experience.

title: Daily Lexeme: Knipperdolling
description: Todays word, in association with the prodigious Oxford English Dictionary, is

title: Pete Padilla of Calexico, My First Mentor
description: In the 20th century, Pete Padilla was the dean of professional photographers in Calexico, Calif., the border town in which I grew up. He was also the only professional photographer in Calexico.

title: The Recovery That Was  and Then Wasnt
description: Weve talked before here about whether a fleeting economic recovery began early this year. Two pieces of data mentioned in my column this week offer more evidence that a recovery did in fact start, only to falter in the spring.

title: Looking For Better Sound? Heres a Tip
description: Comply Foam Tips are.well, foam tips that replace the run-of-the-mill tips that come with most earbuds  those phenomenally popular products that are supposed to fit comfortably inside ones ear (the ear canal, specifically), block out ambient noise and, in a perfect audio world, enhance the sonics of the music.

title: A Deferral Is Not a Rejection
description: These past few weeks have brought a combination of really good news and a moderately stressful lack of news.

title: The Holiday Stimulus Package, Continued
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: Another Rex Ryan Moment: Making the Playoffs
description: Rex Ryan was conducting a grim news conference after the Jets lost to the Bears in Chicago on Sunday. A few minutes into it, he learned that the Jets had made the playoffs, thanks to Jacksonvilles loss to Washington. For those who missed it, his reaction (above) was priceless.The video at Jets.com gives a fuller picture, showing the somber run-up to that moment and a later question from a reporter about whether Ryan felt relieved. Ryan joked: Not really, no relief at all! No relief at all! (That video also showed a distraught Mark Sanchez not knowing how to react to the mixed news. He said hed have to ask his teammate Mark Brunell how he was supposed to feel.)

description: In The Times:

title: South Korean President Open to Talks With North
description: SEOUL, South Korea  In an unexpected diplomatic overture that could lead to the resumption of negotiations with North Korea, the president of South Korea said Wednesday that he would endorse restarting the six-nation talks aimed at dismantling the Norths nuclear weapons program.

title: With New Show, Rare View of Romes Palazzo Farnese
description: Armored cars and gun-toting Italian police flank the entrance of the Palazzo Farnese, a hulking Renaissance palace that serves as the French Embassy in Rome. Though access to the imposing structure is generally limited for security reasons, the Palazzo will be open to visitors through April 27 for an extraordinary exhibition. The show, titled From Renaissance Palace to French Embassy, takes a look at the history, art and architecture of the palace.

title: Fire and Ice
description: It may seem a strange time to say so, but 2010 remains on pace to be the hottest or second-hottest year ever recorded, according to NASA:

title: Vick Is King of Fantasy, but Reality Intrudes
description: Michael Vick gave his fantasy football owners another turbo boost Tuesday night. Because it was Week 16, when most fantasy seasons end, he also gave many of them a league championship.

title: For Ford, a Green Roof That Springs Eternal
description: Fords Detroit-area River Rouge factory, celebrated in paintings by Charles Sheeler and other artists, stands with the Brooklyn Bridge and early skyscrapers among iconic American structures, able to accommodate more than 100,000 workers at its 1930s production peak. Growing in symbolism is the factorys green roof, now celebrating its 10th anniversary.

title: JetBlue Terminal, Kennedy Airport, 6:45 A.M.
description: Our correspondent reports: Treacherous lines at check-in and security. Scene inside terminal fairly tame. Food plentiful. Makeshift campsites scarce. Big boards were listing most departing flights as on time.

title: Control a PC, Straight From Your Phone
description: If youre a heavy iPhone user who also owns a PC, youve probably experienced the annoyance of having to get up from a comfy couch or an office meeting to go back from your phone to your computer for something.

title: Norilsk Nickels Feud With Rusal Enters a New Phase
description: The fight between Norilsk Nickel and Rusal has entered a new round.

title: The Caregivers Bookshelf: Memorys Echo
description: Ptolemy Usher Grey, whos 91 and living in confused isolation in Los Angeles, keeps radio and television news blaring all day long, partly to keep himself from drifting ever farther into the past, partly because hes afraid that if he turns them off, he wont remember how to turn them back on.

title: Are Small Businesses Going to Be Saviors or Victims?
description: Over the last two years, it has been widely reported that small businesses create more jobs than big businesses and thus are critical to the recovery. It has also been widely reported that small businesses are getting squeezed  by the credit freeze, by skyrocketing costs like health and unemployment insurance, and by cheap imports, to name a few examples.

title: Playoff Forecast: Giants Have 19 Percent Chance to Get In
description: From NFL-forecast.com:

title: Meet the Twiblings
description: Midway on our lifes journey, I found myself in dark woods, the right road lost. Ive actually never read The Inferno, but I found that line in my mind every morning when I woke to do my hormone injection and especially on the darkest mornings  the ones when I went into the clinic to have my unpregnant blood drawn to confirm another I.V.F. cycles failure. Of course, I had considered my life ruined many times before  other medical and romantic crises  but I was always wrong. This issue, though  childlessness  really did seem different. My two closest girlfriends chose not to have children and didnt regret it, and I envied them, but I didnt know how to feel as they did. No one gets everything they want in life, but to be childless felt like being deprived of something essential: the primal human experience. When I was 39 and single, I was in northern Uganda, and a woman there asked about my children. I said I didnt have any, and she solemnly told me that she would pray to God to remove my curse. Instead of shrugging it off, I thanked her.

title: Their Bodies, My Babies
description: Melanie Thernstrom and her husband, Michael, set out to make a baby.

title: Suicide Bombers in Iraq Kill Police Commander
description: BAGHDAD  An attack by three suicide bombers in the northern city of Mosul killed a top police commander there and destroyed the police headquarters on Wednesday morning, adding more unrest to a region already torn by extremist violence.

title: Euroskeptics
description: Nice piece by Landon Thomas on the sort-of vindication of Euroskeptics. But to really have a sense of how it has played out, you have to know a bit more about the arguments.

title: Day 3: Have They Plowed Your Street Yet?
description: The math, at least from one angle, doesnt really seem that unforgiving: 6,000-plus miles of roadway in the city; 1,700 plow trucks and 300 front-end loaders. Thats about 3 miles per snow-removal vehicle. You would think that 48 hours after the snow stopped, all the streets would be clear.

title: Let the Melting Begin
description: Wednesday will be partly cloudy and even warmer, with highs in the upper 30s. Get ready for all the snow to start melting.

title: The Year In Questions: 2010
description: Should old news items be forgot, and never brought to mind?

title: What Were Your Favorite Dishes of 2010?
description: I took my shot, made my picks, even added a sidebar on my favoriterestaurants of the year. What about you? Post your favorite restaurant dishes of the year below, in the comments.

title: The Most Interesting Senate Race of 2012? It Might Be Virginia
description: Will Virginia be home to the most competitive and politically interesting Senate race in 2012?

title: The Year in Design | My Favorite Thing
description: I see a lot of innovative design; thats why my job is so much fun. But its not often that I see something that offers a glimpse into the future. Thats how I felt when I walked into Sonys exhibition in Milan during the 2010 furniture fair. The Japanese company had asked the British designers Edward Barber and Jay Osgerby, of the firm BarberOsgerby, to create an exhibition to showcase its Monolithic Design concept, in which its home entertainment products are seamlessly integrated into interior design. The exhibition itself was indeed interesting  BarberOsgerby designed an anechoic chamber, lined with foam blocks in the shape of triangular solids, in which to demonstrate projects like Sonys pairing of a big-screen TV and near-field speakers to create a personal entertainment space, and a TV cabinet, made with a 3-D printer, that was porous enough to transmit sound from the speakers inside it. This was all very cool, but the part of the exhibition that was really thrilling was a group of objects that combined light and sound.

title: Crude Oil Prices Stay Strong, Helping Indexes to Rally
description: The major stock indexes extended their rally on Wednesday, led by energy companies as crude oil remained above $90 for a fifth consecutive day.

title: Police Arrest 5 in Danish Terror Plot
description: A group of men arrested in Denmark on Wednesday were about to mount a Mumbai style attack on the Danish newspaper that ignited Muslim fury around the world by publishing satirical cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad in 2005, the head of the Danish Security and Intelligence Service said.

title: 2010: The Year in Mashed-Up Pop
description: Dont pop those Champagne corks just yet: the year isnt over until D.J. Earworm, the San Francisco song-spinner and mash-up creator, says farewell to the top pop hits of 2010 in one last video mix (which we were pointed to by the good folks at Billboard). Yes, youll have to bear witness one last time to Lady Gagas prison dance and Katy Perrys provocative pastries, and hear bits and pieces of Keshas TiK ToK in several dozen places, but when its all over, you might even shed a nostalgic tear for 2010  or be very relieved that 2011 is almost upon us.

title: Giant Icicle Terrorizes Cobble Hill
description: A giant icicle hung over Court Street in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, on Tuesday, causing the police to cordon off part of the sidewalk. Eventually, a police officer whacked it with a shovel, bringing it down safely. The Pardon Me for Asking blog has the dramatic play-by-play.

title: Seven Brazilian Birds on U.S. Endangered List
description: Seven South American birds with dwindling populations will be listed as endangered under the Endangered Species Act, the federal Fish and Wildlife Service announced on Tuesday.

title: Leonard Green Weighs B.J.s Takeover Bid
description: The private equity firm Leonard Green & Partners, fresh off its proposed buyout of Jo-Ann Stores, may be ready to make a move on B.J.s Wholesale Club, the New York Post reported on Wednesday.

title: Sara Lee Slims Down Some More
description: Sara Lee announced on Wednesday that it had reached an agreement to sell its White King and Janola cleaning brands to Symex Holdings of Australia for about $50 million.

title: Time to Swap a Blanket of Snow for a Straitjacket?
description: Over the past three days, Tunesia Jeter and her son Amari Santana, who turns 5 on Friday, have read books, played Wii, baked a red velvet cake and watched Toy Story 3.

title: Wednesday Reading: More Families Living Together
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: 2011: Beet-Rum Mousse
description: By Alexander Talbot and Aki Kamozawa, authors of Ideas in Food and the founders of IdeasInFood.com.

title: 1966: Chocolate-Rum Mousse
description: This recipe appeared in an article by Jean Hewitt in The Times.

title: Recipe Redux: Chocolate-Rum Mousse, 1966
description: Chocolate-rum mousse, which ran in The Times in 1966, was a remarkably efficient recipe in two distinct ways. First, it invoked nearly every food trend of its moment: chocolate desserts were an exotic new fix; any respectable grown-up dessert contained rum; mousse suggested that you understood French cooking, or at least pretended to; two cups of cream was de rigueur; and the recipe assumed you owned one of the kitchens latest appliances, the home blender.

title: Mayor Bilandic, Redux
description: I am in a part of Brooklyn where the buses are not running and neither is the subway line near my home. I walked from the next line over last night and discovered the snowdrifts were still unshoveled at some intersections and on whole blocks of Church Avenue, which I walked along to get home.

title: In China, Car Buyers in a Backup
description: GUANGZHOU, China  Li Bo, a 28-year-old lawyer, was one of three friends who put down deposits of 50,000 renminbi, or $7,500, in May at a car dealership to each buy a popular model, the Audi Q5, which sells for the equivalent of $72,000, including taxes, in China.

title: John Leguizamos New One-Man Play Is Broadway Bound
description: 4:58 p.m. | Updated

title: What Were Reading
description: An aggregation of links by the reporters and editors of Diners Journal.

title: At the End of the Day Wins Coveted Trite Award
description: Once again, we bow down to Gene Collier of The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette and his annual roundup of sports cliches  you know, the ones we can only hope to contain.

title: Who Benefits from Long-Term Unemployment?
description: The share of the labor force that has been out of work for at least six months remains near an all-time high. Long-term unemployment is clearly terrible for the millions of people who find themselves in that situation. But it does have a flip side for the rest of the labor force: unemployment in this downturn has been concentrated among a surprisingly small number of people.

title: Outlaw Chess Players Likely to Have Charges Dismissed
description: Updated, 1:15 p.m. | The men who were hit with criminal summonses for playing chess at a playground in Inwood Hill Park in Upper Manhattan are in line to have their charges, which carried penalties of up to 90 days in jail and a $1,000 fine, dismissed.

title: Many City Bus Routes and Some Subways Are Still Out
description: Some rough patches remain in our regions normally seamless transportation web:

title: Twitter Is Newark Mayors Friend as He Digs Residents Out
description: The contrast on Twitter couldnt have been more stark.

title: Cyborgs Onstage, Robots in the Wings
description: ON Friday a time machine will land on the stage of the Abrons Arts Center. The crew  an astronaut, a squishy space alien and a cyborg with a mustache  will try to transport audience members to the future, saving them from an event so potent it turned this entire planet into a grave. Unfortunately this future features endless copulation and meals salvaged from ones own bodily waste. To get there, spectators will first have to survive goofy costumes, low-tech special effects, alien mucus sacs and at least one appalling dance number.

title: A Little Good, a Little Evil, a Lot of Ritual
description: WHEN Rajiv Joseph was 13, he was voted Most Likely to Become a Priest by the other eighth graders at Gesu Catholic School in Cleveland. He wasnt especially pious, he said  just quiet, private, observant. Little did his classmates know that their designation was apt. An altar boy, he had for years imagined becoming a priest. He loved the theatricality of Bible stories, like the big reveal of the risen Jesus on the road to Emmaus. He loved the rituals of the Roman Catholic Mass, like the blessing of the Eucharist as the body of Christ. Most of all, matters of morality and faith tumbled around in his mind. Eventually Mr. Josephs interest in girls made celibacy a nonstarter, but his interest in good and evil, in sin and redemption, found powerful expression in his calling as a playwright.

title: In Praise of Nurses

But with perfectly clear skies and neatly shoveled snow, it looked like the Eagles jumped on a toboggan and sped downhill yelling, Wheeeee!

title: New Stamps to Honor Musicians, a Lawyer and a Fearless Space Explorer
description: A new set of commemorative stamps announced by the United States Postal Service may not send your mail to infinity and beyond (barring any routing errors), but it can send your correspondence to its destination bearing the grinning lantern-jawed countenance of Buzz Lightyear. Characters from the Disney/Pixar features Toy Story, Cars, Ratatouille, Up and Wall-E will be among the entertainment figures honored on stamps that the Postal Service will begin selling next year. (The Disney/Pixar stamps, which will go on sale Aug. 19, can be seen in their entirety by clicking here or on the image above.)

title: Taymor Withdraws from New York Times Event
description: Julie Taymor, the director of the Broadway musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark, has withdrawn from a public forum planned as part of The New York Times Arts & Leisure weekend next month. The event, at which Ms. Taymor was to be interviewed by Patrick Healy, a Times reporter who writes about theater, was scheduled for Jan. 8. A press representative for Ms. Taymor wrote in an e-mail that with the changes in the Spider-Man production schedule, Julie will be deep in rehearsals and will not be available to participate in the interview. Ticketholders are being notified of the cancellation by mail and e-mail, and will be receiving refunds from OvationTix, the ticket service provider for the event. Customers with additional questions can call 888-NYT-1870.

title: After Online Protest, Sothebys Withdraws African Mask From Sale
description: A rare West African ivory mask, taken by the British during a 19th-century invasion of the city-state Benin in present-day Nigeria, was withdrawn from a Sothebys sale after online protests, The Independent reported. The mask, which dates from the 16th century and is thought to have been worn by the king of Benin on ceremonial occasions, is the last known example of its type in private hands and was expected to fetch as much as $7 million.

Just south of La Guardia Airport in East Elmhurst, Queens, the triangle contained more than 80 short neighborhood blocks still covered with treacherous mounds of snow. It was 7 p.m. Tuesday, some 36 hours after the storm had ended.

description: IT was a year in which the daughter of one president was married in a largely private ceremony on a gorgeous summer day and one in which the daughter of a possible future president went on a prime-time dance show to give a big middle finger to all the people out there that hate my mom and hate me.

And that can mean advantages for small-business owners, provided they know how to find a law firm that suits their needs and they know the right questions to ask.

title: Fine Is Likely to Be Final Play in Favres N.F.L. Career
description: Brett Favres 20 years in the N.F.L. will most likely end on Sunday, when the Minnesota Vikings play their final game of the season. On Wednesday, the N.F.L. added an ignominious coda to Favres career, fining him $50,000 for what it said was a lack of candor and a failure to cooperate with a league investigation. He was accused of sending graphic photos and suggestive messages to a woman while both were employed by the Jets in 2008.

title: Monetary Fiction
description: Ezra Klein asks whether there are any novels about monetary policy. Well, for my sins I once read the book pictured above  a 1978 novel about hyperinflation in America. The villain was a thinly disguised George McGovern; there was a romance involving a character obviously based on Marina Whitman. I cant tell you how much it pains me to realize that I still remember all of that; what a waste of neurons!

Looking at the sculpture of a two-foot-long baby made of material from a spinnaker by the Canadian artist Max Streicher suspended above the staircase, any guest to his home might agree.

title: Why Wait 200 Years? Arcadia Revival, With Billy Crudup, Coming to Broadway Next Year
description: While just over 15 years have elapsed since Billy Crudup made his Broadway debut in Tom Stoppards Arcadia, the actor is moving ahead two centuries to portray another character in a Broadway revival of that play slated for next year. In the original Broadway production of Arcadia, which shuttles in time between the 19th century and the present, Mr. Crudup played Septimus Hodge, a tutor and friend of Lord Byron. In the revival, which is headed for the Ethel Barrymore Theater, Mr. Crudup will play Bernard Nightingale, a modern-day professor investigating Byrons life.

Everyone was a star, or so it seemed, at the annual Christmas night dinner in the baronial Lincoln Center duplex of Sissy and Max Strauss. Each holiday, more than a hundred opera singers and other displaced performers and their entourages who find themselves in New York marooned far from home gather to wine, dine and, naturally, entertain one another.

Pooks, referring to Moda Operandi, makes a good point about the difficulty of judging collections online (those runway pieces can weigh a ton), and I would add that the quality of fabrics may take a hit in the coming year or two as designers look for better-priced alternatives or cut corners. There has been a substantial increase in the cost of raw materials, especially cotton. And thanks to Kimb for information about getting the right fit online. title: The Great Unraveling
description: When Henry Louis Gates Jr. told Sgt. James Crowley of the Cambridge police, You dont know who youre messing with, he was speaking truth to power, albeit in a manner more akin to arrogance than erudition. The big shock here, according to the Pulitzer Prize-winning columnist Eugene Robinson, is not that a Harvard professor misused the subjective case (who for whom) and inelegantly ended a sentence with a preposition; it is, rather, that Gates belongs to an elite enclave beyond the sergeants experience or imagination. Gatess life as an academic superstar places him among a select group of black Americans aptly labeled Transcendent by Robinson. Think of Oprah Winfrey, Beyonc, Kobe Bryant, Vernon Jordan and Richard Parsons, the retired chief executive of Time Warner.

title: Elegy for England
description: Impossible  and not even desirable  to disassociate this book from the circumstances of its composition. Tony Judts plight before his death last August was not as extreme as that of Jean-Dominique Bauby (who communicated The Diving Bell and the Butterfly a letter at a time, by blinking an eye), but by any reasonable standards, it was devastating.

title: A Novelist Prepares
description: In 1966, an ambitious, depressed and unhappily married young woman came home to find her husband quietly enjoying a mug of coffee and a pile of her journals. As she later recalled, I expressed moral outrage and he calmly replied that they were interesting to read and revealed things about me it was important for him to know. This husband did not last long. But the journals endured, and now, with the second volume of The Making of a Writer, Gail Godwin is offering their revelations to a wider audience.

title: Editors Choice
description: HERO: The Life and Legend of Lawrence of Arabia,  by Michael Korda (Harper/HarperCollins, $36.) For all its undisguised admiration for T. E. Lawrence, Kordas biography leaves the impression that his heroism lay in a particularly stubborn brand of personal eccentricity.

title: The Last Mitford
description: How do you even begin to write about two of the most storied people alive? One  the Anglo-Irish travel writer Sir Patrick Leigh Fermor, now 95  infiltrated Crete during World War II, disguised as a shepherd, and captured a German general (an exploit that won him a Distinguished Service Order and inspired a film starring Dirk Bogarde). Fermors great friend Deborah Vivien Freeman-Mitford Cavendish, known as Debo, the Dowager Duchess of Devonshire, now 90, is the youngest (and last surviving) of the endlessly fascinating Mitford sisters, the six daughters of the eccentric Lord and Lady Redesdale. In 1956, in a letter Fermor wrote to friends after spending a holiday at Lismore, the Devonshires castle in Ireland, he tried to describe his hostess. She was funny, touching, ravishing and enslaving, he wrote, which made up for her engagingly unashamed philistinism. The duchess told Fermor she hated books  with the exception of Beatrix Potters Ginger and Pickles, the tale of a dog and cat who run a country grocery. Fermor was utterly charmed, and the visit spurred a correspondence that has spanned six decades.

title: Nonfiction Chronicle
description: THE LOST PEACE  Leadership in a Time of Horror and Hope, 1945-1953.  By Robert Dallek.  Harper/HarperCollins, $28.99.

title: The Nonconformist
description: Alice Neel has never commanded the household-name status of Georgia OKeeffe or Frida Kahlo, art heroines who have been the subject of multiple biographies. But within the art world, she remains a beloved and influential figure. The pre-eminent painter-chronicler of New York bohemia, Neel specialized in frank, nervy portraits of artists and intellectuals and various other marginalized types, like black children, pregnant women and old men. More often that not, her subjects are shown in minimally decorated apartments, sitting by themselves or with a friend. They make you feel as if you have wandered into a room where they will continue sitting long after you have left. They are not classically attractive, with their shaggy hair and spindly, crooked German Expressionist fingers, but everyone  babies included  has a look of wide-eyed intelligence.

title: Bookwoman
description: Sixteen years after the death of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis from non-Hodgkins lymphoma, she remains indelible and yet unknowable, a glamorous, mysterious icon forever hidden behind oversize sunglasses. The subject of endless scrutiny, from schlocky best sellers to academically astute studies, her 64 years of life have seemingly been dissected hour by hour. Yet this season brings two new biographies that deal with the very same period: the 19 years she spent in publishing as an editor for Viking Press and then Doubleday. Reading Jackie by William Kuhn and Jackie as Editor by Greg Lawrence represent a rebranding of the legend, a strenuous effort to burnish her literary legacy.

title: In Aphrodites Arms
description: My grandmother was born to Polish immigrants in Brooklyn, the fifth of six children and the first to be born in America. Its safe to say that she struggled with the myth of the American dream. Some of her family succeeded, some did not. Everyone needs mazel, or luck, shed say in Yiddish by way of explanation. Even the dog.

title: Forbidden Planet
description: In August 2006, the International Astronomical Union voted to ax Pluto from our solar systems pantheon of planets, rechristening it a dwarf planet. The ballot took place because Mike Brown, an astronomer at the California Institute of Technology, had detected a potential 10th planet, and the union had to decide how to categorize it. Admit the object to the roster and you pave the way for a solar system with over 100 planets. (Astronomers expect the Kuiper belt, the region beyond Neptune where the potential planet was found, to contain many similar objects.) Exclude it and you must also banish Pluto.

title: Paperback Row
description: A BOMB IN EVERY ISSUE: How the Short, Unruly Life of Ramparts Magazine Changed America,  by Peter Richardson (The New Press, $17.95.) The San Francisco Bay Area magazine Ramparts didnt live long  it started in 1962 as a quarterly and folded in 1975  but this compact history credits the magazine with reviving the tradition of muckraking, exposing C.I.A. excesses and elevating the careers of notable journalists like Warren Hinckle, Robert Scheer, Adam Hochschild and Jann Wenner.

title: In Europe, Mixing Union and Diversity
description: Politically, it is not at all difficult to conceive of Europe as a single entity, composed of the more than 800 million people extending far beyond the 27 countries that already belong to the European Union. But is there also something we can call European literature, and if so, what are the elements that make it distinctly European?

title: Shopping With Ted Allen
description: The host of Chopped on the Food Network went shopping for items that would come in handy during kitchen cleanup.

description: LEAVING the premier of You Wont Miss Me, in which Stella Schnabel plays an unstable actress recently released from a psychiatric hospital, a young woman was overheard to mutter to a friend, Oh, Stella, she was just playing herself.

title: HIV Deaths Fall Below 1,000
description: Deaths from HIV in New York City fell below 1,000 in 2009 for the first time since the disease exploded in the 1980s, the city health department announced today.

title: Working (Part Time) in the 21st Century
description: In the Netherlands professional women have been able to work part-time for years. Now many men are doing the same, leaving them with more time for family.

title: A Fossil Hunt in Ethiopias Mush Valley
description: Bonnie F. Jacobs, a paleobotanist at Southern Methodist University, writes from Ethiopia, where she is studying fossils of ancient plant and animal life. The current field season in the Mush Valley of Ethiopia is financed by a grant to Ellen Currano of Miami University, Ohio, from the National Geographic Society Committee on Research and Exploration.

title: Big Apple Circus Goes Indie
description: On Jan. 3 and 4, an independently produced event modeled and named after the Rolling Stones 1968 Rock and Roll Circus hits Lincoln Center, with a lineup of indie music darlings like So So Glos, Amazing Baby, Japanther and Nick Zinner of the Yeah Yeah Yeahs. But its more than just a concert staged under the big top: food trucks from Mexicue, Van Leeuwen and Asia Dog will be present, and Tuesdays show includes Big Apple Circus performances. The Moment caught up with Jessica Resler, founder of the brand development firm Muffincupcake, who engineered the project along with the event producers Adarsha Benjamin and Vance Garrett.

title: On Our Radar: Fishing Nets Killed More Turtles Than BP Oil, Official Says
description: The impact of BPs oil spill on threatened and endangered sea turtles in the Gulf of Mexico was serious but not catastrophic, the administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, Jane Lubchenco, writes in an essay published Wednesday. Furthermore, the majority of the 600 dead turtles found during the spill appear to have been killed by fishing operations, not oil. The heightened scrutiny of the Gulf of Mexico during the oil spill brought to light the need for stronger cooperation between N.O.A.A., the gulf states and the fishing industry to address the significant ongoing problem of sea turtles drowning in fishing operations, Dr. Lubchenco says. [Miami Herald]

description: Is it possible that a secret colony of Mexican jumping beans has crossed the border and infected the video game designers of Austin, Tex.?

title: The Tried and the True Step in After the Storm
description: The New York Philharmonic almost never cancels rehearsals. If the orchestra is in town, the players somehow manage to get to Avery Fisher Hall, no matter the weather or impediments to travel.

title: Broadway Actors Who Are Bracing for Final Curtain
description: In the theater every closing night stirs up a bevy of feelings: sadness, elation, relief, anxiety. Those and many other emotions will be running high across Broadway soon, as 15 productions  almost half the shows currently playing  are scheduled to go dark by the end of January. (Reasons for the mass exodus vary; some shows are closing because of sagging ticket sales, others are finishing limited engagements.)

title: Students Meet the Eroica Challenge With Gusto
description: Quantifying what a group of young musicians has learned during a 10-day program like the New York String Orchestra Seminar, currently in session at Mannes College the New School for Music, is probably impossible. And in any case the results of these intensive master classes, coaching sessions and performances may not be fully apparent until the participants have had time to let their experiences settle into their playing.

By the time her D.J. played the third Nicki Minaj song of the night you had to wonder if it was a taunt.

title: Whatever the Night, Football Wins for NBC

That is where Dwaynes Photo, a small family business, is processing the last rolls of Kodachrome. A. G. Sulzberger is there and has filed this report. Eastman Kodak stopped making the film in 2009 and gave the last roll to Steve McCurry. He shot the last three frames of that roll in Parsons before handing it in to Dwaynes. title: New Look for Mecca: Gargantuan and Gaudy
description: JIDDA, Saudi Arabia  It is an architectural absurdity. Just south of the Grand Mosque in Mecca, the Muslim worlds holiest site, a kitsch rendition of Londons Big Ben is nearing completion. Called the Royal Mecca Clock Tower, it will be one of the tallest buildings in the world, the centerpiece of a complex that is housing a gargantuan shopping mall, an 800-room hotel and a prayer hall for several thousand people. Its muscular form, an unabashed knockoff of the original, blown up to a grotesque scale, will be decorated with Arabic inscriptions and topped by a crescent-shape spire in what feels like a cynical nod to Islams architectural past. To make room for it, the Saudi government bulldozed an 18th-century Ottoman fortress and the hill it stood on.

title: Junk

Well take a break from these serious-minded colloquies, however, for a lighthearted diversion: the selection of the Word of the Year, the lexical item that best captures the zeitgeist. In a year that brought us vuvuzelas (the dronelike plastic horns at the World Cup in South Africa) and mama grizzlies (Sarah Palins cadre of fierce women in the midterm elections), theres no obvious front-runner in the sweepstakes for WOTY (pronounced WOE-tee). title: Christian Bale Summons a Fallen Mans Delusions
description: THE first time you see Christian Bale in The Fighter, you might gasp. Hes playing a true-life broken-down ex-boxer, Dicky Eklund, and hes sitting on an ugly sofa wearing acid-washed jeans, a half-buttoned shirt, a glaze of oily sweat and not an ounce of fat. With his hunched shoulders and sunken eyes he looks caved in, almost collapsed. The life starts to seep back in when he begins talking, but when he loosely swats the air, his fingers remain splayed as if they had forgotten how to curl into fists. As the words keep coming, so does the life, and soon those hands are coiled hard, jabbing the air and knocking down ghosts.

title: When Moving Seems Impossible
description: Patricia Wendler had been trying to sell her Southport, N.C., home for four years. Just before Thanksgiving, she finally got an offer, with one major contingency: Mrs. Wendler, 80, had less than three weeks to move, or no deal.

title: Natalie Portman Embraces Monster and Victim
description: THE subject of Black Swan  a leading candidate for the most misunderstood film of 2010  is the relationship, in art, between technique and emotion. Ballet, the specific art form in question, is shown to require endless practice and grueling physical discipline. Bodies, in particular the bodies of young women, are stretched and twisted into unnatural postures, and the cost of the fleeting, breathtaking grace they attain is reckoned in close-ups of battered, bloody feet and tendons pulled almost to the snapping point. The toe shoes that are among the principal tools of this torment also seem to be surrogates and scapegoats; they are scraped, mutilated and disfigured by the dancers in a symbolic re-enactment of the violence they perform upon themselves in their ruthless pursuit of perfection.

title: Outrage at Unplowed Streets? Its a New York Tradition (and Sometimes Merited)
description: It is as much a part of a New York City blizzard as slush and cold and the color white itself: postblizzard outrage over the municipal response to said blizzard. One can imagine the very earliest settlers of New Amsterdam railed at their Dutch leaders after blizzards. The path to my farm is not plowed! Its been three days! Het sneeuwt!

title: Straddling Worlds of Performance
description: APAP: for many a New York choreographer, theres no more frightening sequence of letters in the English language. Pronounced A-pap and used as shorthand for the Association of Performing Arts Presenters annual winter conference starting Friday, its a chaotic gantlet of showcases and networking, spread over a very long weekend. The goal is to get your performance booked outside New York. The more typical result is exhaustion, resentment and ruined nerves  especially for those artists whose boundary-pushing work doesnt mesh with artistic directors looking for easy box office sells.

title: A Maestros Four-Decade Evolution
description: AS if to make up for his reduced presence there, the Metropolitan Opera has favored us with two giant boxed sets, of 32 CDs and 21 DVDs, in celebration of James Levines 40 years with the company. They are quite wonderful, confirming all sorts of happy memories  which in my case date back to a performance in Los Angeles of Tosca in 1971, three weeks after he made his Met debut in the same opera. They restore ones faith in all that Mr. Levine has been, and in what he may one day again become.

title: Godard as Oscar Provocateur
description: WHEN the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences gathered on Nov. 13 to give out the honorary Oscars known as the Governors Awards, one of the evenings honorees, Jean-Luc Godard, was not present. Not even in spirit. Mr. Godard, then just three weeks shy of his 80th birthday, kept his customary distance from his American admirers, several of whom stepped up to the microphone that night to toast him in terms that, in their amiable vagueness, betrayed the general bafflement that was, and is, the most characteristic effect of his stubborn art.

Prince Albert, or Bertie, as his cheeky, would-be miracle worker, Lionel Logue, insists on calling him, is a stickler for formality and protocol. Lionel, an Australian brewers son, with a wife and two children, is an impudent free spirit and true believer in equality.

title: Hold That Obit; MoMAs Not Dead
description: WHEN I walk through the Museum of Modern Art these days, it sometimes feels as if the place has come back from the dead  even if Im not always so crazy about the life it happens to be leading. Theres often a confusing, disjunctive quality to it, especially where contemporary art is concerned, as the museums programming lurches from crowd-drawing, performance-art spectacles in the atrium to relatively dry and didactic exhibitions in its galleries. But at least theres a pulse.

title: Looking Back on a Year of Parenting
description: Cash Van Rowe just celebrated his first birthday last week. The story of his birth appeared on Motherlode on Jan. 6, 2010, when, in one of the first of the 408 posts here this past year, his mother, Heather, wrote about how her partner, Britt, delivered their baby at home in (another) epic snowstorm. There was noise, and drama as the emergency workers fought their way through the drifts. Later, in the hospital, there was silence, as the pediatrician brought the news that Cash had Down Syndrome.

title: Global Entertainment
description: Maps have always had admirers: people collect them, display them, linger over them in museum exhibitions. Yet it is only in recent years that geography, organized not on paper but online, has really arrived as popular entertainment  as diverting as the latest stupid video your Facebook friends are linking to yet somehow more virtuous or, at times, titillating. Or both.

title: The Caste Buster
description: I came to Umred to write about a riot. A few months earlier, power blackouts that rural Indians always suffered silently triggered a violent reaction. Why? Umred was just another small town in the middle of nowhere, dusty and underwhelming. But Umred had begun to dream, townspeople told me, because of television, because of cousins with tales of call-center jobs and freedom in the city. Once Umred contracted ambition, blackouts became intolerable. A psychological revolution, a revolution in expectations, had taken place.

title: Splitting the Costs
description: My mother and her sister bought a diamond ring, splitting the cost and agreeing to share the profit when my mother could resell it at her small antiques shop. Unfortunately, the ring was stolen, apparently pocketed by a customer. My mother has no insurance but offered to reimburse her sister for her share of the ring, and my aunt accepted. Theyre fine with this, but it gnaws at me that my aunt took advantage of my mother. Didnt she? NAME WITHHELD, MASSACHUSETTSYour mother did right by offering to reimburse your aunt; your aunt did no wrong by accepting, as both of them apparently understand. The only one flustered is you. You should defer to their judgment and undergo some sort of deflustering.

title: My Cart, My Self
description: I bought a lot of things online over the holiday season, and now Im facing the New Year hangover  not credit-card debt but the blitz of recommendations for books and movies and other products that were generated by the secret software that Amazon and other companies use to analyze and predict my tastes. Im not sure what I think of the selections, though. Im not sure how well these computer programs know me. Some of their choices seem simplistic or patronizing, while others strike me as random, even crazy. And some are dead on, of course, which I find troubling. The only thing worse than being misperceived by a machine is being expertly perceived by one.

title: Starter Buddha
description: Autumn in Beijing, where we had gone to live, and my husband and I were surrounded by Chinese antiques at the biggest flea market in town  detritus of a country embracing free-market enterprise. There were rows of vintage Mao wristwatches, red and black feng-shui meters, brightly embroidered Tibetan booties and slim, early-Communist-era cigarette cases. We could buy tea-stained calligraphy scrolls and vintage Cultural Revolution posters. We could bargain over the earliest Chinese radios and glass mirrors with etchings of the Imperial family. We could bargain over just about anything.

title: Life of the Party
description: When the 112th U.S. Congress is officially sworn in on Jan. 5, two black Republicans will be among the new majority in the House of Representatives. One thing that you guys arent talking about is the fact that there were 42 African-Americans that ran on the Republican ticket in this election cycle; 14 made it to the general election, and 2 of us were elected to the House.

title: Rewired
description: Fiber optics have finally arrived in my neighborhood! One frigid day, workmen from FiOS, the Verizon service renowned for providing home Internet service at the speed of light, showed up with ear protectors and jackhammers. Then, as workmen have done regularly for more than a century in Brooklyn, they tore up the road. Like miners in reverse, they laid down pure telecommunications ore, threading strands of silver-black fiber-optic cable under Hicks Street, a lopsided, part-cobblestone thoroughfare down which chugged the Hicks Street Line, a railroad that ran at the turn of the 20th century.

title: North Korea Gets a Special Kick Out of Bend It Like Beckham
description: While youre trying to decide whether you should spend your New Years Day watching a Three Stooges marathon on AMC, a Doctor Who marathon on BBC America or a Twilight Zone marathon on Syfy, think of the people of North Korea, whose television options consist of state-run news programs. But on Sunday, The Associated Press reported, North Korean television audiences were given a rare break from this routine when the British comedy Bend It Like Beckham was shown there. The film, which stars Parminder Nagra as a young woman from a Sikh family with dreams of soccer stardom; Keira Knightley as her best friend; and Jonathan Rhys Meyers as the dreamy coach they both have eyes on, was shown over the weekend by the arrangement of the British Embassy. According to the BBC, a message was shown during the film saying that the broadcast was done to mark the 10th anniversary of diplomatic ties between North Korea and Britain.

title: 36 Hours in Santa Cruz, Calif.
description: FORGET what you heard about Santa Cruz being the city that sleeps. Yes, this sunny coastal town still has its countercultural wackiness. You can still watch surfers shred waves, ride a seaside roller coaster on the Santa Cruz Beach Boardwalk and hear a street musician sing Pink Floyds Goodbye Cruel World. But Santa Cruz has been stirred by the tech boom in nearby Silicon Valley. In the past, rabid localism meant getting a black eye at the Stockton Avenue surf break. Now, the term refers to the restaurant that uses eggs from its own chicken coop, and the woman who churns organic ice cream with fennel foraged from a nearby field. And sleek lounges offer reasons to stay up until 2 a.m., an eternity by old Santa Cruz standards.

title: A Decades-Long Study Is Finally Published
description: An architectural monograph, in progress since the 1950s, was finally published a few weeks ago. Richard Nickel, a photographer in Chicago, started working on it as a graduate student, focusing on early skyscrapers by Louis Sullivan. In 1972, at 43, he was killed by falling debris at a demolition site he was exploring.

title: We Have Met the Enemy
description: Chapter 1: A Democracy of Excess

title: Weak-Kneed Willpower Faces Temptations Lure
description: If you want a little insurance to help keep those New Years resolutions, you might consider turning to StickK.com. Started by two Yale professors and a graduate student in 2008, the Web site provides a binding contract to help you meet a particular goal, whether it is shedding pounds, quitting smoking or finishing Proust. Fail to live up to your end of the deal, and you have to pay a person or charity that you have designated in advance. You can even increase the incentive by choosing an anti-charity, a cause that you would normally oppose. Gun-control advocates, for example, could decide to forfeit their money to the National Rifle Association if they falter, while anti-abortion advocates might choose NARAL Pro-Choice America.

title: A Crusading Knight and Cute Concrete
description: In the movie universe, the first worth anticipating in the new year is Season of the Witch. For one thing, who doesnt love that Donovan song, though this film, due next Friday, apparently has nothing to do with it? And for another, who doesnt love finding out whether Nicolas Cages latest career choice is yet another crash-and-burn?

title: Clintons Boyhood Home Becomes Park Service Site
description: The modest American four-square home in Hope, Ark., where the 42nd president lived his first four years will become the latest National Park historic site on Sunday.

title: On Warming, Antarctica, Clouds and Peer Review
description: .In recent weeks there were several notable developments on persistent and consequential climate questions  the extent of warming in Antarctica and the behavior of clouds in a warming world. I wasnt able to deal with them here at the time because of the climate negotiations and other news, but better late than never.

title: Pictures of the Day: Denmark and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Denmark, Israel and Afghanistan.

title: Hockey Has Deep Roots in Pittsburgh
description: PITTSBURGH  If Minnesota is the State of Hockey, if Detroit is Hockeytown and if Buffalo is the City of Hockey, then surely this city at the confluence of three rivers is Hockeytahn, as they say here in their singular drawl.

title: For Sushi Chain, Conveyor Belts Carry Profit
description: SAYAMA, Japan  The Kura revolving sushi restaurant chain has no Michelin stars, but it has succeeded where many of Japans more celebrated eateries fall short: turning a profit in a punishing economy.

title: Whats Your Tech Resolution for 2011?
description: This past holiday weekend, after dinner plates were cleared away, the leftovers were safely stashed in the fridge and warm slices of pie began to circulate around the living room, the conversation slowly shifted to the inevitable: our resolutions for the coming year.

description: David Carr and Brian Stelter discuss OWN, Oprah Winfrey's new "feel-good" cable network.

title: Polenta Made Creamy With Celeriac
description: With polenta, there are many ways to go. First, theres the initial decision about whether to use fine or coarse grind and white or yellow cornmeal, and the choice of liquid (water? stock?). Then we face the question of consistency (soft or firm), and finally there are all the possible mix-ins and garnishes. You see a lot of butter and cheese, for instance, and milk, cream or mascarpone are not unknown. That said, the best polenta Ive ever eaten was in Venice, and it was just white corn meal and water  served with spectacular, sweet tiny gray shrimp from local waters.

title: Christine Dennison and Tim Taylor
description: WHEN they fell in love, Christine Dennison and Tim Taylor were literally at the top of the world. It was there, during an Arctic journey, that they realized they shared the same passion for adventure, if not quite an equal zest for a trip down the aisle.

title: In a Word for Third, a Shovelful of Indignity
description: This week has been an educational one in New York City.

title: Photo Replay: Dec. 30
description: The day in sports included horse racing in Dublin and skiing and skating in Switzerland.

title: From a Moment of Fear, a Lifetime of Clarity
description: ONE evening last spring, five months before our wedding, my partner and I were mugged at gunpoint by a jittery, saucer-eyed man as we walked home from the MacArthur BART station in Oakland.

title: New York State Buys Conservation Rights for 89,000 Acres of Forest
description: The state of New York paid $30 million on Friday to secure extensive conservation rights on 89,000 acres of forest in the Adirondacks, another big step toward protecting lands once owned by the Finch paper company.

title: CBS Wins a Slow Night
description: CBS was the most-watched network in prime time on Wednesday, a night of low-rated repeats. According to Nielsens estimates, CBSs rerun of Criminal Minds earned the largest audience, with 9.3 million viewers at 9, while the network won the 8 oclock hour too, with a repeat of NCIS: Los Angeles (6.9 million). NBCs rerun of Law & Order: SVU (6.8 million) edged ahead of The Defenders on CBS (6.5 million) in the 10 p.m. time slot, although an earlier repeat of SVU drew just 4.5 million viewers at 9. NBC ranked second for the night over all. ABC finished close behind with repeats of its comedy lineup, including two Modern Family episodes in the 9 p.m. hour (6.1 million) and back-to-back reruns of Cougar Town in the 10 p.m. hour (3.3 million). Fox was fourth.

description: Critics and writers for The New York Times write about shows and performances they are looking forward to seeing on New York stages in 2011.

title: Vespers Born of Determination and Joy
description: You wouldnt have thought that it was too much to ask. For years Jolle Greenleaf, a soprano with a light, bright tone and impeccable delivery who specializes in early music, looked forward to performing in Monteverdis epochal 1610 Vespers during the 400th anniversary of its publication.

description: COUNTDOWN TO 12!

description: Ken Johnson picks some of his favorite works in New York museums.
