title: Perfect Poise, Pulled From Jaws of Distortion
description: COMTESSE DHAUSSONVILLE, BY INGRES, THE FRICK COLLECTION If not always for the same reasons, people of both genders love to feast their eyes on beautiful women. So it is no coincidence that some of the worlds most compelling works of art are weddings of female and painterly beauty. One is at the Frick Collection: Comtesse dHaussonville (1845), a near life-size portrait of a lovely young woman standing before a mirror in a blue satin dress. Rendered by Ingres in a cool, neo-Classical style, she tilts her head, holds an index finger to her chin and gazes back with lowered eyelids and a quizzical, enigmatic expression.

title: Keeping Score: Hall of Fame, by the Numbers
description: The reasons for voting for one player for Hall of Fame induction over another are as varied as the 500-plus writers, statisticians and bloggers who vote for the Hall of Fame. Generally, a players candidacy comes down to how a voter views the players career record and contribution to the teams he played for. These are, not coincidentally, the areas that sabermetrics (the analytical study of baseball) is most focused on.

title: Extravagant or Modest, Inaugurations Vary With the Star of the Show
description: As far as political theater is concerned, an inauguration is a classic of the genre: an opportunity for a politician to bask in the trappings of a new office, to set forth a new political order and to revel once again in the triumph of an election.

title: U.S. Unveils Plan to Sell Stake in Ally, Once GMAC
description: 7:50 p.m. | Updated The federal government said on Thursday that it was planning a complex transaction that would temporarily increase its ownership position in the former lending arm of General Motors to nearly three-fourths of the company while also paving the way to cash out its stake.

title: Four Spas in New York
description: Russian & Turkish Baths, Body by Brooklyn, Spa Castle and Juvenex Spa.

title: Take a Plunge, Soak Up Heat, Try a Scrub, Stay Off Your Feet
description: ITS a typical weekend afternoon at Body by Brooklyn, a spa in the boroughs Clinton Hill neighborhood. In the wet room men and women in bathing suits step in and out of the Turkish steam room, two saunas and a cold plunge pool, or sip iced drinks as they rest on reclining chairs near the Jacuzzi.

title: The Case Against Katsav
description: JERUSALEM

title: Landscapes and Still Lifes of New Territories
description: FAVORITE paintings in New York museums? You dont have to be an art critic to have a few, or a few dozen. Winnowing these treasures down to five  the assignment here for three critics for The New York Times  is a pleasant, invigorating yet implicitly arbitrary endeavor. The resulting lists can only be characterized conditionally, as personal, partial or provisional.

title: An Evangelical Backlash Against Environmentalism
description: Over the last decade, many evangelical Christians have embraced the doctrine called creation care, which uses a scriptural basis to promote good stewardship of the earth and its resources. For these believers, problems like climate change threaten to greatly intensify third-world poverty, making actions to reduce global warming emissions an urgent Christian issue.

title: John Simon Steps Into the Blogosphere With a Few Words About Spider-Man
description: After 50 years writing criticism for newspapers, magazines and literary journals, John Simon has become a blogger. His first post is on Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark. And  surprise, surprise  hes got a contrary take.

title: Overlooked Works That Deserve Another Glance
description: MANUEL OSORIO MANRIQUE DE ZUIGA, BY GOYA, METROPOLITAN MUSEUM OF ART Theres a reason that this painting is one of the first you see when you walk up the Mets main staircase, pass through the heavy glass doors into European Paintings, and turn right (as museumgoers invariably do). It isnt just the color  an arresting tomato red against green-gray  or the adorably precocious subject, the third son of the count of Altamira. Its the unsettling way in which Goya complicates 18th-century ideas about childhood.

title: Dance Listings for Dec. 31- Jan. 7
description: Dance

title: Deciding Whether to Buy or Rent
description: IN todays market, with uncertainty the sole certainty up ahead, the age-old question  rent or buy?  becomes increasingly perplexing.

title: Time to Turn the Cultural Page
description: IT wasnt easy for critics to choose the best cultural offerings of 2010. But whatever moments onstage still linger in our memory, Jay Gatsby himself would advise against dwelling too long on the year that was. Now is the time to look forward: what performances in 2011 will inspire, shock, cheer us, maybe even change our world?

title: Reader Photos: Extreme Holiday Sweaters
description: Readers have sent photographs of their boldest, most garish sweaters.

title: Christians Are Casualties of 10 Baghdad Attacks
description: BAGHDAD  One week after an Islamic extremist group vowed to kill Christians in Iraq, a cluster of 10 bomb attacks rattled Baghdad on Thursday night and sent additional tremors of fear through the countrys already shaken Christian minority.

title: Q & A
description: An Error in Calculating Maintenance Charges

title: The Vatican Creates a Financial Watchdog
description: VATICAN CITY  Amid a judicial investigation into its famously secretive bank, the Vatican created its own financial watchdog on Thursday and issued sweeping and tough new laws aimed at meeting international standards against money laundering and terrorist financing.

title: Courbet, Bellini, Guston
description: A look at some of Karen Rosenbergs favorite works in New York museums.

title: Admiring Mir
description: Roberta Smith picks some of her favorite works in museums in New York City.

title: A Home That Is Sometimes a Salon
description: RODNEY TERICH LEONARD, a gregarious jack-of-many-trades, adores a crowd. His annual birthday tributes to the singer Nina Simone, held in his exquisitely restored duplex in a West Harlem brownstone, are the talk of the neighborhood. So are what he calls his salons, lively events celebrating the Harlem arts scene. He can entertain 80 for cocktails without breaking a sweat.

title: N.F.L.s Statement on Punishment of Jets
description: The N.F.L. fined the Jets $100,000 on Thursday for the sideline wall and trip orchestrated by the strength coach Sal Alosi against a Dolphins punt gunner earlier this month.

title: TimesCast Year in Review: Haiti
description: As part of a TimesCast series on the major stories in 2010, a look at Haiti.

title: At Vero, Small Plates for an Italian Sampler
description: TWO of the hottest restaurant trends on Long Island are wine bars and small-plate dining. Vero, in Amityville, combines them, along with two other attributes that give it an edge over the competition: an experienced owner and a talented chef.

title: The Sunday Roast Sandwich
description: The Belgian fries at Press 195, a two-month-old restaurant in Rockville Centre, are the stuff that cravings are made of. Burnished and crunchy outside, soft and creamy inside, they come with a selection of dipping sauces like chipotle mayo (fries, $6.50 for a large cone; sauces, 75 cents apiece).

title: Long on Space, Water and Industry
description: ON the first Sunday in December, the St. Stanislaus Kostka School held its annual Christmas bazaar. Attendees sampled Polish specialties and bought chances to win prizes that included a 40-inch plasma television. Afterward, people filed outside to watch Sayrevilles annual holiday parade, cheering on the bands and floats as they marched up Main Street and catching candy tossed by volunteer firefighters from their lighted-up trucks.

title: Sandwich Twins
description: About two and a half centuries have passed since the hungry Fourth Earl of Sandwich, unwilling to pause during a card game, called for his now famous snack  a handy little meal that has grown in popularity and complexity ever since.

title: A Merger of Cuisines, With Sushi in the Fore
description: LIKE many other Asian restaurants that strain their resources in an attempt to satisfy the tastes of all potential customers, Oishii Asian Fusion succeeds only some of the time. Although a couple of dishes that I tried recently  like the tasty tuna tortilla, similar to a small pizza of tuna slices drizzled with a tangy Japanese mayonnaise  merged or fused elements from non-Asian cuisines, this restaurants menu is more pan-Asian than fusion, with specific offerings culled from the Far East and Southeast Asia.

title: A Slice of Virtue
description: Chris and Kate Saville set out to create a pizza that would be as nutritious as it was tasty. They came up with the Flatz Company, a sleek shop they opened in Wyckoff a year ago. There, they serve crispy, thin-crust whole wheat flat pies with at least 45 grams of protein and 8 grams of fiber each; a small slice  there are eight slices in a 12-inch pie  has 5 grams of fat.

title: A Chinese Take on Sushi and Sashimi
description: THERES an easy camaraderie behind the sushi bar at Taka Sushi in Summit, where the three or four chefs smile and murmur among themselves as if sharing an inside joke. Maybe the joke is that nearly all of them are Chinese, not Japanese, recruited from New York City and trained by the restaurants head chef, Bid Chen, who regularly works alongside them and also happens to be Chinese. Or perhaps its just the secret delight that comes with cranking out some of the best fish in the area.

title: An Alternative to Beef: Bison
description: If eating healthier food is your New Years resolution, you might want to visit Creamery Brook farm, where the principal product is bison meat, significantly lower in fat (and higher in iron and protein) than beef, pork and chicken.

title: South Indian Flavors, Served Cafeteria-Style
description: AT the turn of the new year, with post-holiday wallets slim and bellies amply filled, Udupi Bhavan, a very inexpensive South Indian restaurant in Middletown, holds special appeal.

title: Ex-Candidate Says Inquiry Into Finances Is Political
description: WASHINGTON  Christine ODonnell, the losing Republican candidate for Senate in Delaware, defended herself on Thursday against accusations that she misused campaign money for personal expenses and said a reported criminal investigation of her activity was a politically motivated attack by Democrats.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in Connecticut this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to the Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Parliament Takes on Contractors in Somalia
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  Somalias Parliament demanded Thursday that the government immediately suspend the operations of several foreign security contractors because the lawmakers said they had no idea what the contractors were actually doing.

title: Peace Hovers in Sudan, but Most Soldiers Stay Armed
description: JUBA, Sudan  Nearly six years ago, northern and southern Sudan signed a peace agreement after decades of civil war, hoping to finally bring the suffering to an end. Hundreds of thousands of soldiers had fought one another, some growing up on the battlefield. In the south, millions of people lost their lives, villages disappearing beneath plumes of smoke.

title: Practice Those Plis
description: THE notion that film inspires fashion is one of the style worlds hoariest clichs. But in the case of Black Swan, in which Natalie Portman plays an ambition-maddened dancer, that chestnut bears some truth. Darren Aronofskys Grand Guignol of a film both reflects  and anticipates  a trend in the making, its multilayered tutus, feathers and cobwebby knits attesting to a shift in the fashion wind.

title: In Mel Gibson Case, A.C.L.U. Fights Move to Bar Ex-Lovers Lawyer
description: LOS ANGELES  Larry Kings long-running interview program on CNN may be gone. But it is not forgotten  at least, not in the courts here.

title: Judge Dismisses Hedge Funds Case Against Porsche
description: A federal judge in Manhattan on Thursday dismissed a $2 billion lawsuit brought against Porsche by 10 hedge fund managers, stating that the New York court had no jurisdiction over lawsuits related to foreign securities  an outcome predicted in an October Deal Professor column.

title: On the Runway: Ballerina Chic
description: Kate and Laura Mulleavy of Rodarte are not the only designers with ballet on their minds.

title: Spider-Man Confirms Departure of Actress Natalie Mendoza
description: Michael Cohl, the lead producer of the Broadway musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark, formally announced in a statement on Thursday that the actress Natalie Mendoza was leaving the show. Ms. Mendoza, who portrayed the mythical spider-woman Arachne in the musical, suffered a concussion in the shows first preview performance in November and had not appeared in it since Dec. 20, when a co-star, Christopher Tierney, was injured in a mid-performance accident. Word of Ms. Mendozas exit surfaced earlier this week, but neither she nor Mr. Cohl nor the Spider-Man director, Julie Taymor, had commented on it at the time.

title: And Then, in a Grimy Squish, Came the Slush
description: Snow is fun for children and happy people. But what of the misanthrope, the bitter, the left-behind and burned-out? For them, the big moment arrived Thursday, finally, with the highest temperature in days turning beautiful, white snow into frigid, quasi-liquid gray and providing free entertainment for those who revel in the misfortune of others.

title: Nonprofit News May Thrive in Comcast Takeover
description: Included in Comcasts promises regarding its acquisition of NBC is a little-noticed plan that may stimulate the growth of nonprofit news organizations.

title: Twins Facebook Fight Rages On
description: SAN DIEGO  Some people go to court hoping to win millions of dollars. Tyler and Cameron Winklevoss have already won tens of millions. But six years into a legal feud with Facebook, they want to give it back  for a chance to get more.

title: Lobbying Law Keeps Conflicts Out of Public Eye
description: When Texas lawmakers begin grappling with the states huge budget shortfall next month, they will not be working alone: cities, counties and other public entities  and, of course, corporations and special interest groups  will send hundreds of lobbyists to the Capitol to defend their interests.

title: Bears Have Look of a Champion With Cutler
description: Brian Urlacher, one of a handful of relics remaining from the Bears 2006 Super Bowl team, is of the opinion that the current squad is better than that one, largely because Jay Cutlers big-armed presence at quarterback provides a home-run capability the 06 Bears lacked with little Rex Grossman doing the throwing.

title: Shaping a Network With Oprahs View
description: For decades cable channels have been built around specific interests like news, sports or classic movies. Beginning this weekend, there will be something altogether different: a cable channel shaped around a person, Oprah Winfrey.

title: A Federal Lifeline for Hard-Pressed School Districts
description: When Farmington Central School District 265 learned it was eligible for an infusion of $417,000 in federal aid to save jobs this school year, the district had the option to spend it on anything from new hires to raises for teachers, or even to meet benefits liabilities.

title: Clicking Like on Palins Use of Facebook
description: It seems that Facebook users understand what many a political journalist has come to know: Sarah Palin is quite adept at employing social media.

title: Emanuel-Clinton Linkage Began Early and Goes Deep
description: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: N.F.L. Reduces Three Big Fines for Hits to the Head
description: The N.F.L.s crackdown on hits to the head has generated plenty of controversy this season, in part because of the big fines levied against players who make the hits. But a person with knowledge of the leagues system on fines said the fines on Atlanta cornerback Dunta Robinson, New England safety Brandon Meriweather and Pittsburgh linebacker James Harrison for flagrant hits on defenseless receivers had been reduced.

title: Red Tourism Thrives in Yanan, China
description: Local officials and businesspeople in Yanan, China, are profiting from a boom in red tourism, in which Chinese, many of them young professionals, journey to famous revolutionary sites.

title: Tricky Call for New Governors: Price of Inaugurals
description: MIAMI  To warm up the Florida crowds for his inauguration as governor, Rick Scott has been flying around the state this week on a seven-city appreciation tour. For the main event on Tuesday, he will lead a parade featuring 26 marching bands, followed by a black-tie dinner for 2,100 people, with oysters Rockefeller and fried calamari served in mini-martini glasses. Real classy, said Christy Noftz, who is overseeing the catering.

title: Revolution Isnt a Party, but It Draws Tourists
description: YANAN, China  The explosives had been set, the watchtower manned and the dirt battlefield cleared of rubble. Communist soldiers armed with rifles took up positions at the foot of the barren hills. Their foes, the Kuomintang, loomed in the distance, advancing on the garrison town of Yanan.

title: Clock Ticks for a Jet, and a Record Approaches
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  As if fullback Tony Richardson needed a reminder, the faux street sign hangs inside his locker at the Jets facility, depicting a hobbled old man, bent over, leaning on a cane. Geezer crossing, the sign reads.

title: As for Empathy, the Haves Have Not
description: THE GIST The rich dont get how the other half lives.

title: E.P.A. Limit on Gases to Pose Risk to Obama and Congress
description: WASHINGTON  With the federal government set to regulate climate-altering gases from factories and power plants for the first time, the Obama administration and the new Congress are headed for a clash that carries substantial risks for both sides.

title: No Traditional First-Lady Role for Busy Sandra Lee
description: She will spend the night in Albany with him on New Years Eve, stand by his side as he is sworn in to office and might even greet guests who come to congratulate him at the governors mansion.

title: America Is Waiting for the Economic Ripple Effect
description: What does the American economy need to get back on its feet? What would help tremendously is fewer roommates.

title: Sisters Prison Release Is Tied to Donation of Kidney
description: Two Mississippi sisters serving double life sentences for their roles in an $11 armed robbery will be released, but only on the condition that the younger sibling donate her kidney to her sister, whose organs are failing, state officials said Thursday.

title: New Capital for Groupon Sets Stage for an Offering
description: The 30-year-old founder and chief executive of Groupon, Andrew Mason, could raise as much as $950 million from investors in the next few weeks, laying the groundwork for a multibillion-dollar initial public offering in 2011.

title: Rethinking the Old Public Functionary
description: By late December 1860, President James Buchanan was easily the most despised man in America, and particularly in the North. The President, one supporter observed glumly, seems to be execrated now by four fifths of the people of all parties  and this in New York City, the center of the cotton trade and the most pro-Southern city in the free states.

title: Academic Economists to Consider Ethics Code
description: WASHINGTON  When the Stanford business professor Darrell Duffie co-wrote a book on how to overhaul Wall Street regulations, he did not mention that he sits on the board of Moodys, the credit rating agency.

title: Governor Cuomo
description: Andrew Cuomos inauguration ceremony on Saturday will be comparatively modest  a long way from former Gov. George Patakis black-tie gala and marching bands. That is appropriate at a time when New York State is mired in both a fiscal and political crisis.

title: Haitis Vote
description: An agreement reached this week between the government of Haiti and the Organization of American States points the way out of the countrys paralyzing presidential election crisis. The deal will allow experts from the O.A.S. to re-examine the results of the Nov. 28 vote to try to clear up the uncertainty over who won second place and will go on to a January runoff.

title: Still Cruel, Less Usual
description: The tide continued ebbing on the death penalty this year. States are putting fewer people to death, and juries continue to favor the punishment of life without parole over execution when given the choice. A report released this month by the Death Penalty Information Center counted 46 executions in 2010. That is nearly 12 percent fewer than a year ago, and down sharply from the 85 executions of 2000.

title: Anchor Is Sidelined
description: Will Selva, an ESPNews anchor, has been sidelined after apparently plagiarizing several sentences of an Orange County Register newspaper column on Tuesday night. Selva said in a statement that he had made a horrible mistake by copy-and-pasting the text of the story and forgetting to then write a script in his own words. The words were originally written by Kevin Ding, who covers the Los Angeles Lakers for The Register.

title: When Election Police Go Easy
description: You would not lose a bet at the Caucus Room, the watering hole for power lobbyists, by wagering that the most dysfunctional agency in Washington is the Federal Election Commission. For years, far too many commission members have put their partisan loyalties far above that of the public interest.

title: Weathering the Storms of Voter Discontent
description: WASHINGTON  Long is the list of elected officials who, unbowed by terrorist threats, sex scandals, mobsters, pandemics, school system meltdowns, transit strikes or random acts of corruption, found themselves doomed by precipitation.

title: Kansas St. Is Undone by Syracuse and Penalty
description: Kansas State wide receiver Adrian Hilburn polished off the final touchdown of the inaugural Pinstripe Bowl at Yankee Stadium on Thursday by stopping outside the back of the end zone, not far from the visitors dugout and a 3-foot-high bank of snow, then saluting the Wildcats fans.

title: The New Voodoo
description: Hypocrisy never goes out of style, but, even so, 2010 was something special. For it was the year of budget doubletalk  the year of arsonists posing as firemen, of people railing against deficits while doing everything they could to make those deficits bigger.

title: Lottery Numbers
The Arena Culture
description: Academic life encourages specialization and technical thinking, and, oddly, there are few fields in which this is more true than philosophy. The discipline that should be of interest to everybody is often the most impenetrable.

title: Lobbyists Client List Puts Him on the Defensive
description: WASHINGTON  After decades of work for some of this countrys most powerful lobbying firms, Lanny J. Davis, the lawyer who once helped defend President Bill Clinton from impeachment, is suddenly scrambling to defend himself.

title: Real Life Among the Old Old
description: I RECENTLY turned 65, just ahead of the millions in the baby boom generation who will begin to cross the same symbolically fraught threshold in the new year to a chorus of well-intended assurances that age is just a number. But my family album tells a different story. I am descended from a long line of women who lived into their 90s, and their last years suggest that my generations vision of an ageless old age bears about as much resemblance to real old age as our earlier idealization of painless childbirth without drugs did to real labor.

title: Paterson and Federal Officials Reach Pact on Immigration
description: Gov. David A. Paterson, seeking to assuage critics of a new government program to strengthen immigration enforcement, said Thursday that he had negotiated a pact with federal officials to help protect illegal immigrants in New York without criminal records.

title: A New Ambassador to Syria, but Little Hope of Change
description: WASHINGTON  When Robert S. Ford, a career diplomat with deep experience in the Middle East, presents his credentials as ambassador to Syria, he will be the first person to hold the job since 2005, and the public face of the Obama administrations belief in engagement over isolation.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: As Collapse at New Jersey Towers Is Repaired, Tenants Trickle Back In
description: HACKENSACK, N.J.  It sounds like a small thing, but for Debi and Gary Presslaff, it was quite a milestone: last week, they and their two dogs woke up in their own home.

title: Report Shows North Korea Has Upgraded Its Military
description: The North Korean military, the worlds fourth largest, has bolstered its special forces units since 2008 and has deployed a new battle tank, called the Storm, the South Korean Defense Ministry said Thursday in a policy report. The report, based on a review conducted every two years, said the Norths overall troop strength remained the same, at an estimated 1.1 million. Only China, the United States and India have larger militaries. The South Korean military has 688,000 troops, making it the sixth largest, according to GlobalSecurity.org, a public policy organization. About 28,500 American troops are based in South Korea. Defense officials in Seoul said Thursday that the North had steadily upgraded its capacity and was better able to strike the South in unconventional and unpredictable ways.

title: Eric Wilsons Key Fashion Moments of 2010
description: 1. Looking back at what truly resonated with audiences outside of the fashion elite, it is tough to think of anything more substantial than the hullabaloo that took place this summer over a single dress  one that hardly anyone had a chance to get a good look at. That, of course, was the white strapless beaded wedding gown worn by Chelsea Clinton at a top-secret ceremony in Rhinebeck, N.Y., on July 31. As it happened, it was a dress by Vera Wang, seen by the public in only a handful of official portraits released by the Clinton family. The dress had some silvery belt thing at the waist and a very tight fitted bodice, and what looked like a rushing waterfall of tulle below the waist. To no small degree of dissatisfaction among the fashion press, Ms. Clintons gown was not destined to be hugely influential in the tradition of bridal gowns worn by glamorous members of prominent political or royal families (i.e., Carolyn Bessette-Kennedy, Princess Diana, Ivanka Trump). But frankly, she could have worn burlap and remained at the top of this list, since half the fun was in all the anticipation and speculation. You can only imagine what 2011 has in store for Kate Middleton.

title: Cathy Horyns Key Fashion Moments of 2010
description: 1. I wouldnt have picked Diors January couture collection as a major fashion moment (John Galliano punched an out-of-date ticket for the Gibson Girl), but the scene illustrated the tension between the weird and the wonderful that exists in fashion. Dior held the show in the house, so everything was creamy with intimacy  just what editors love as they plop down next to friends  but it soon registered that Tavi Gevinson, the 13-year-old blogger, was in the front row. Some of the editors really hit her with looks. At the Armani show that night, the stares were openly hostile. It was obvious the older Italian ladies didnt care to see a child in their midst. And Tavi wore a big bow-shaped hat that pointedly emphasized her juvenile stature. The fact is half the people were still in the dark about what was happening. Blogs? Strange ruminations from a girls bedroom in Chicago? They were still politely applauding satin ball gowns that Charles James would have whipped up in his sleep at the Chelsea Hotel.

description: Dr. Joshua D. Sparrow, a child psychiatrist, recently  took reader questions on children, stress and the holidays. Here, Dr. Sparrow responds to a reader concerned about helping her adopted children adapt to the stresses of the holiday season.

title: And the Winner IsIstanbul
description: In early 2010, as our readers were no doubt whittling down their list of New Years resolutions, we asked them a question that is a bit more fun to contemplate: where do you want to travel this year?

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: Another New Look at Superman
description: Superman: Secret Origin, published by DC Comics, enters our hardcover list at No. 3 this week. The six-part story, written by Geoff Johns and illustrated by Gary Frank, is a retelling of the formative days of the Man of Steel  from his childhood in Smallville to his move to Metropolis. This recipe for this retelling of the super-saga contains a smidgen of the television series Smallville (like the brief friendship between Clark Kent and Lex Luthor) and a pinch from the 1978 Superman film  Mr. Franks depiction of Superman is obviously based on the actor Christopher Reeve.

title: Following Weight-Loss Surgery, Unexpected Expenses
description: As obesity rates continue to rise, more and more people are seeking surgery for weight loss. From 1998 to 2004, the number of bariatric operations performed in the United States rose 804 percent. While insurance may cover much of the expense of surgery, the high costs of care following the operation often catch patients by surprise. Lesley Alderman explains in todays Patient Money column:

title: Global Stock Markets Fight to Return From Recession
description: The global recession that began three years ago lives on in many ways. While most economies are now growing, few developed countries have recovered all the ground they lost. In nearly every country, the gross domestic product in the most recently reported quarter was smaller than at the peak.

title: The Blood Suckers Next Door
description: The vampire novel is a crowded genre these days. To distinguish itself, a book will need inventiveness, wit, beauty, truth and a narrative within which these attributes can flourish. The Radleys, by Matt Haig, has got them, if sometimes in alloyed form.

title: All People Are the Same to God':  An Insiders Portrait of Joseph Kony
description: Among the men at large in the world who have been credibly accused of war crimes, Joseph Kony, the leader of the Lords Resistance Army, occupies an almost otherworldly place. The document that is the subject of Fridays post, LRA Religious Beliefs, shows many of the reasons why.

title: Salads With Crunch, Sweetness and Zest
description: Creating a great salad requires the right blend of ingredients, as Martha Rose Shulman explains in this weeks Recipes for Health:

title: Up Front: Why Criticism Matters
description: We live in the age of opinion  offered instantly, effusively and in increasingly strident tones. Much of it goes by the name of criticism, and in the most superficial sense this is accurate. We do not lack for contentious assertion  of love it or hate it, of wet kisses and takedowns, of flattery versus snark, and assorted other verbal equivalents of the thumb held up or pointed down. This conversation is often lively. Sometimes it is fun. Occasionally it is informed by genuine understanding as opposed to ideological presumption.

title: Australia Floods Show No Signs of Retreating
description: Rising waters have knocked out roads and several highways in northeastern Australia, trapping motorists, marooning entire towns and driving thousands from their homes as flooding stretched into its second week on Saturday. More than 200,000 people have been affected so far by the floods, local news media reported.

title: The Will Not to Power, but to Self-Understanding
description: Three years ago, Cynthia Ozick published an essay in Harpers Magazine lamenting the decline of criticism, which she argued was impoverishing literature itself. Without the consciousness that only a critical infrastructure can supply, Ozick wrote, readers and writers are doomed to talk at cross-purposes, or at random; it takes a corps of influential critics to unite individual reactions into a common discussion. Indeed, this excellent novelist and excellent critic concluded, Superior criticism not only unifies and interprets a literary culture but has the power to imagine it into being. To see what we are missing, all we have to do is contrast our own moment with the postwar decades when Lionel Trilling prevailed at Columbia, and Edmund Wilson, Irving Howe and Alfred Kazin enlivened the magazines.

title: Beyond the Critic as Cultural Arbiter
description: Fifty years is a long time in any national literature, but in the extreme environment of American culture, fiction seems to find an incubator for unusually rapid growth. A half-century takes us from the era of formulaic romances and Gothic novels to the metaphysical theater of Moby-Dick; from Mark Twain working on his autobiography to John Barths first novel. Yet across the 50 years since Alfred Kazin lectured about the function of the critic, academic literary criticism in America has arguably changed more than the modern novel, while the kind of critic that preoccupied Kazin  one who writes for the public, lives in literature and tries to create standards  now finds her function revised by technological changes that have reconfigured an audience that was once atomized by Americas urban sprawl.

title: Inside the List
description: GUTENBERG MEN: The cover of the Jan. 9 Book Review contains a rare convergence of best sellers. The New York Times reporter David Carr (who spent three weeks on the nonfiction list with his 2008 memoir, The Night of the Gun) reviews a biography by Douglas Coupland (whose novel Microserfs was a business best seller in 1995) about the media-studies pioneer Marshall McLuhan (who had simultaneous paperback best sellers in 1967 with The Medium Is the Massage and Understanding Media).

title: Masters of the Form
description: The inspiration for the six essays anchoring the Book Review this week was Alfred Kazins polemic The Function of Criticism Today, written in 1960 (and published in Commentary). But Kazin belongs to a long tradition of critics who have cast a keen eye over their vocation. In fact, Kazins essay echoes T. S. Eliots Function of Criticism, published in 1923, which itself echoed Matthew Arnolds celebrated Function of Criticism at the Present Time, written in 1864.

title: From the Critical Impulse, the Growth of Literature
description: Your judgment ... is true, but not all of it, Tolstoy once wrote to the critic N.N. Strakhov, who had shared with the writer some comments on Anna Karenina. That is, it is all true, but what you have expressed does not express all that I meant. ... It is one of the true things that can be said. If I wanted to express in words all that I meant to express by the novel, then I should have to write the same novel as I have written all over again.

title: The Intellectual at Play in the Wider World
description: I dont think of myself as a literary critic. I write about novels and short stories. But I am reluctant to describe what I do as literary criticism, as I like to move quickly beyond the literariness of a text  whether narrative techniques or quality of prose  and its aesthetic pleasures, to engage with the authors worldview, implied or otherwise, and his or her location in history (of nation-states and empires, as well as of literary forms).

title: With Clarity and Beauty, the Weight of Authority
description: Is it time to write about the Death of the Critic, the proliferation of the app, the rise of the screen, the end of the discerning reader who curls up on a sun-dappled couch and devotes herself to serious books and their interpreters? Has the critic become a quaint and touching figure engaged in an irrelevant, positively medieval pursuit, like monks illuminating manuscripts?

title: Translating the Code Into Everyday Language
description: I tend to shy away from big, sweeping, era-defining statements. Its the fastest possible way to be wrong about the world, and usually just an excuse for various forms of sloppy thinking: cherry-picking, scapegoating, doomsaying, fear-mongering, sandbagging, arm-twisting, wool-gathering, leg-pulling. And yet it would be hard to dispute that over the last 5 or 10 years, the cultures relationship to time has changed pretty drastically. The shift is so obvious that its boring, by now, even to name the culprits: Google, blogs, texting, tweets, iPhones, Facebook  a little army of tools that have given rise to (and grown out of) radically new habits of attention. Many of us are now addicted, on the dopamine-receptor level, to a moment-by-moment experience of life thats defined by a behavior sometimes referred to as time slicing: jumping every few seconds between devices or windows or tabs, constantly swiveling the periscope of our attention around and around the horizon to see where the latest relevant data-burst might come from.

title: Oprahs List: The Finalists for Your OWN Show
description: Oprah Winfreys new cable network, scheduled to begin broadcasting Saturday, has announced the 10 finalists who will compete on Your OWN Show: Oprahs Search for the Next TV Star for the right to become hosts of a program on the network. They include Zach Anner, a travel guide who uses a wheelchair, who was involved in an online-voting controversy related to the selection of the contestants over the summer; a minister from Texas who dropped out of high school and lived on the streets; and three aspirants who want to be hosts of cooking shows.

title: Hedo Turkoglu: Same as He Ever Was
description: Hedo Turkoglu is back in a Magic uniform, and all is supposedly well again. On Thursday night Turkoglu had 17 points and 9 rebounds against the Knicks, and he scored a season-high 20 points in New Jersey only three days before. On first glance, a disappointing two-year stretch of Turkoglus career seems to have come to a close thanks to a midseason return to Orlando; he is scoring more, handling the ball more, and has again assumed the role of a late-game shotmaker.

description: The year 2010 was a fascinating one in the hockey world. And since its almost over, everyone who writes about hockey is required by law to do a year in review piece.

title: Removing the Incentive to Skirt the Rules
description: The N.C.A.A.s finding that Cam Newtons father, Cecil, sought payment for his sons enrollment at Mississippi State is only the latest in a long history of pay to play schemes in college sports. It has caused plenty of discussion, not only over whether Cam Newton shuold be allowed to play for Auburn in the B.C.S. championship game against Oregon on Jan. 10, but also over whether players like him should be paid.

description: As the clock to 2011 winds down, JPMorgan Chases chief, Jamie Dimon, took a moment to send the firms 222,000 employees some warm thoughts for the new year.

title: Here They Go Again? ABBA Members Raise Idea of a Reunion
description: My, my, how can we resist them? Speculation about a possible reunion of the Swedish pop group ABBA, perhaps the most popular band in the world during the 1970s, is bubbling up again, following remarks by two members of the quartet. In an interview published in the British magazine M, the singer Agnetha Faltskog ruled out reuniting for a full-fledged tour like the Rolling Stones and other old bands do now, but said, I could see us doing something together in the future, perhaps in connection with a charity event.

title: Stanfords Harbaugh Remains Coy About His Future

title: The Nutcracker Chronicles: In ABT Version, A Master Shows His Hand
description: Throughout Act One of Alexei Ratmanskys new production of The Nutcracker for American Ballet Theater, youre in the hands of a master. I can question perhaps 10 moments in it (the fight between soldiers and mice is relatively weak, for instance, while the concluding pose for the Snowflakes, lying back onto the floor as if exhausted, is a puzzle), and those incidental problems hardly matter. His version of the story is completely original in feeling, the whole tone of the drama frequently changes as you watch, and I have seen no work by this choreographer that better shows his powers.

title: Want a Hit? Keep It Simple
description: LATELY Ive been having a recurring sinking sensation. A hit on the radio gets my attention and doesnt repay it; it adds up to little more than a dull thumping Eurodisco beat and a robo-tuned voice repeating an inane hook, something like the Ay-oh, gotta let go, in Taio Cruzs Dynamite, or Justin Bieber piping, Baby, baby, baby, oh or the Black Eyed Peas chanting Imma Be more than 100 times (though at least that song goes through some rhythm changes).

title: Michael Jackson Special Postponed
description: Following a barrage of complaints by some heirs and fans of Michael Jackson, the Discovery television network on Friday postponed indefinitely its plans to broadcast a re-enactment of the singers 2009 autopsy. Michael Jacksons Autopsy: What Really Killed Michael Jackson was scheduled to be shown in several countries in Europe, though not the United States, on Jan. 13.

title: A Diet for an Invaded Planet: Invasive Species
description: Theres a new shift in the politics of food, not quite a movement yet, more of an eco-culinary frisson. But it may have staying power; the signs and portents are there. Vegans, freegans, locavores  meet the invasivores.

title: Comic Counterculture in the Northwest
description: IN the music video that kicks off Portlandia, a new comedy series making its debut Jan. 21 on IFC, Fred Armisen walks the streets of Portland, Ore., singing to a flat, synthesized soundtrack and praising the city as a flannel-clad slackers paradise where young people go to retire. As Mr. Armisen marches along the Willamette River waterfront, he is joined by stylish women wearing vintage eyeglasses, bearded men in leather jackets, circus clowns and finally by his co-star, Carrie Brownstein, who arrives with several facial piercings.

description: Burbank, Calif.

title: Damascus
description: To the Editor: Regarding, 36 Hours in Damascus (Dec. 5): Although the article suggests that a hotel in the New City would be central, nearly all sights of interest are in the Old City, within easy walking distance of any hotel there. The traffic elsewhere is ghastly, and taxis, though cheap and plentiful, may be as baffled as you are as to where you are trying to go. Carry a map. Finally, the Naranji restaurant, at the corner of Straight Street by the Roman Arch, is the place to see and be seen, with a lovely roof terrace, friendly service, and decent food to boot.

title: Crested Butte
description: To the Editor: I am always delighted to see Crested Butte Mountain Resort, in Colorado, get attention in your ski guide about resorts (Dec. 12). However, although the steeps are amazing at the Butte, the terrain is actually wonderfully varied. This experienced but 62-year-old lady had no problem taking run after run on multiple trails with her snowboarding 20-something son. I love to tell people I ski Crested Butte because it has such a reputation for challenging terrain, but truth be told it is highly manageable and great fun for the average skier. And, if youd rather not be with the super chic but with the super cool, this is the place for you.

title: Books in San Francisco
description: To the Editor: Gregory Dicums lively tour of A Book Lovers San Francisco (Dec. 5) gives us many more reasons to visit everyones favorite city. But how could you miss William Stout Architectural Books (stoutbooks.com) at 804 Montgomery Street  one of the best in the world of its kind?

title: Cubas Soap Subsidy Goes Down the Drain
description: Its becoming more expensive to live  and keep clean  in Cuba, where the average wage hovers around $20 a month. Soap, toothpaste and detergent were set to be cut from monthly ration books as of Saturday, joining other items the government recently concluded were nonessential, including cigarettes, salt, peas and potatoes, The Associated Press reports. The government says the cuts are necessary to continue free or heavily subsidized education, health care, housing and transportation programs. Its already hard to make ends meet as it is, and this is only going to make it harder, said Elias Conde, a 38-year-old father of two. But were used to them taking things away. Today its soap, and tomorrow itll be something else.

title: To See a Universe in the Tiny Details of Chinese Artifacts, Boxes to Birds

This made sense in the heyday of the countercultural revolution; manufactured objects were a major source of environmental and spiritual pollution. That is just as true today, and suspicion of the expensive, well-made object persists in circles of the contemporary-art world where neo-Marxist thinking lingers.

title: The Hammond B-3 Lion Roars, Backed by His Pride

Hear it after its settled a little, when its sound untangles, and the arrangements become refined. Give the soloists time to figure out what roles they will play, how to control themselves within the whole. Let a scene develop too: big bands sound best encircled by returning customers.

title: CBS Leads With Reruns
description: CBS dominated another night of repeats in the ratings on Thursday as its sitcoms and crime shows easily led during every time slot of the night. According to Nielsens estimates The Mentalist delivered the largest audience with 9.9 million viewers at 10 p.m. CBSs rerun of CSI was close behind at 9 with 9.2 million viewers, about as many as tuned in to The Big Bang Theory on that network at 8 (9.1 million). CBSs rerun of $#*! My Dad Says earned the networks lowest ratings for the night with 7.3 million viewers at 8:30. Fox was a distant second place with back-to-back repeats of Bones at 8 (5.2 million) and 9 (4.5 million). ABC finished third with its holiday special Happy New Year, Charlie Brown at 8 (4.9 million), followed up by low-rated reruns of Greys Anatomy (3 million) and Private Practice (2.7 million). NBC ranked fourth with reruns of its Thursday-night sitcoms.

title: Sarah Palins Nomination Chances: A Reassessment
description: In November 2009, I wrote an article entitled 10 Reasons That Sarah Palin Could Win the Republican Nomination. The article wasnt necessarily arguing that she was the favorite to take the nomination, but it did suggest she had a credible chance at it.

title: Brazils New Leader Begins in Shadow of Predecessor
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  When Dilma Rousseff assumes the presidency of Brazil on Saturday, she will do so at a time when her country is thriving economically and full of swagger, eager to flex more of its newfound wealth and influence at home and abroad.

title: Harrowing Cheshire Case Still Haunts Jurors
description: THEY check and recheck the locks on their doors and windows. Tears can come from nowhere. Images of one of the dead girls pop into their heads. Some have nightmares about children who need their help.
